<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Fulton County Grand Jury said Friday an investigation of Atlanta 's recent primary election produced `` no evidence '' that any irregularities took place .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The jury further said in term end presentments that the City Executive Committee , which had over-all charge of the election , `` deserves the praise and thanks of the City of Atlanta '' for the manner in which the election was conducted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The September October term jury had been charged by Fulton Superior Court Judge Durwood Pye to investigate reports of possible `` irregularities '' in the hard-fought primary which was won by Mayor-nominate Ivan Allen Jr. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` Only a relative handful of such reports was received '' , the jury said , `` considering the widespread interest in the election , the number of voters and the size of this city '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The jury said it did find that many of Georgia 's registration and election laws `` are outmoded or inadequate and often ambiguous '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It recommended that Fulton legislators act `` to have these laws studied and revised to the end of modernizing and improving them '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The grand jury commented on a number of other topics , among them the Atlanta and Fulton County purchasing departments which it said `` are well operated and follow generally accepted practices which inure to the best interest of both governments '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , the jury said it believes `` these two offices should be combined to achieve greater efficiency and reduce the cost of administration '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The City Purchasing Department , the jury said , `` is lacking in experienced clerical personnel as a result of city personnel policies '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It urged that the city `` take steps to remedy '' this problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Implementation of Georgia 's automobile title law was also recommended by the outgoing jury .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It urged that the next Legislature `` provide enabling funds and re-set the effective date so that an orderly implementation of the law may be effected '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The grand jury took a swipe at the State Welfare Department 's handling of federal funds granted for child welfare services in foster homes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` This is one of the major items in the Fulton County general assistance program '' , the jury said , but the State Welfare Department `` has seen fit to distribute these funds through the welfare departments of all the counties in the state with the exception of Fulton County , which receives none of this money .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The jurors said they realize `` a proportionate distribution of these funds might disable this program in our less populous counties '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nevertheless , `` we feel that in the future Fulton County should receive some portion of these available funds '' , the jurors said .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Failure to do this will continue to place a disproportionate burden '' on Fulton taxpayers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The jury also commented on the Fulton ordinary 's court which has been under fire for its practices in the appointment of appraisers , guardians and administrators and the awarding of fees and compensation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The jury said it found the court `` has incorporated into its operating procedures the recommendations '' of two previous grand juries , the Atlanta Bar Association and an interim citizens committee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` These actions should serve to protect in fact and in effect the court 's wards from undue costs and its appointed and elected servants from unmeritorious criticisms '' , the jury said .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Regarding Atlanta 's new million dollar airport , the jury recommended `` that when the new management takes charge Jan. 1 the airport be operated in a manner that will eliminate political influences '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The jury did not elaborate , but it added that `` there should be periodic surveillance of the pricing practices of the concessionaires for the purpose of keeping the prices reasonable '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On other matters , the jury recommended that :
Four additional deputies be employed at the Fulton County Jail and `` a doctor , medical intern or extern be employed for night and weekend duty at the jail '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Fulton legislators `` work with city officials to pass enabling legislation that will permit the establishment of a fair and equitable '' pension plan for city employes .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Daniel personally led the fight for the measure , which he had watered down considerably since its rejection by two previous Legislatures , in a public hearing before the House Committee on Revenue and Taxation .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Daniel termed `` extremely conservative '' his estimate that it would produce 17 million dollars to help erase an anticipated deficit of 63 million dollars at the end of the current fiscal year next Aug. 31 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He told the committee the measure would merely provide means of enforcing the escheat law which has been on the books `` since Texas was a republic '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It permits the state to take over bank accounts , stocks and other personal property of persons missing for seven years or more .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">You will need a stereo music system , with speakers preferably placed at least seven or eight feet apart , and one or more of the new London `` Phase 4 '' records .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are 12 of these to choose from , all of them of popular music except for the star release , Pass in Review ( SP 44001 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This features the marching songs of several nations , recorded as though the various national bands were marching by your reviewing stand .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Complete with crowd effects , interruptions by jet planes , and sundry other touches of realism , this disc displays London 's new technique to the best effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All of the jackets carry a fairly technical and detailed explanation of this new recording program .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No reference is made to the possibility of recording other than popular music in this manner , and it would not seem to lend itself well to serious music .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Directionality is greatly exaggerated most of the time ; but when the sounds of the two speakers are allowed to mix , there is excellent depth and dimension to the music .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You definitely hear some of the instruments close up and others farther back , with the difference in placement apparently more distinct than would result from the nearer instruments merely being louder than the ones farther back .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is a characteristic of good stereo recording and one of its tremendous advantages over monaural sound .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">London explains that the very distinct directional effect in the Phase 4 series is due in large part to their novel methods of microphoning and recording the music on a number of separate tape channels .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These are then mixed by their sound engineers with the active co-operation of the musical staff and combined into the final two channels which are impressed on the record .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In some of the numbers the instrumental parts have even been recorded at different times and then later combined on the master tape to produce special effects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Some clue to the character of London 's approach in these discs may be gained immediately from the fact that ten of the 12 titles include the word `` percussion '' or `` percussive '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Drums , xylophones , castanets , and other percussive instruments are reproduced remarkably well .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As a result , although we still make use of this distinction , there is much confusion as to the meaning of the basic terms employed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just what is meant by `` spirit '' and by `` matter '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The terms are generally taken for granted as though they referred to direct and axiomatic elements in the common experience of all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Yet in the contemporary context this is precisely what one must not do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For in the modern world neither `` spirit '' nor `` matter '' refer to any generally agreed-upon elements of experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We are in a transitional stage in which many of the connotations of former usage have had to be revised or rejected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the words are used , we are never sure which of the traditional meanings the user may have in mind , or to what extent his revisions and rejections of former understandings correspond to ours .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most widespread features of contemporary thought is the almost universal disbelief in the reality of spirit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Just a few centuries ago the world of spirits was as populous and real as the world of material entities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not only in popular thought but in that of the highly educated as well was this true .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Demons , fairies , angels , and a host of other spiritual beings were as much a part of the experiential world of western man as were rocks and trees and stars .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In such a world the words `` matter '' and `` spirit '' both referred to directly known realities in the common experience of all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In it important elements of Christianity and of the Biblical view of reality in general , which now cause us much difficulty , could be responded to quite naturally and spontaneously .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The progress of science over these last few centuries and the gradual replacement of Biblical by scientific categories of reality have to a large extent emptied the spirit world of the entities which previously populated it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In carrying out this program science has undoubtedly performed a very considerable service for which it can claim due credit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The objectification of the world of spirit in popular superstition had certainly gone far beyond what the experience of spirit could justify or support .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Science is fully competent to deal with any element of experience which arises from an object in space and time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When , therefore , it turned its attention to the concrete entities with which popular imagination had peopled the world of spirit , these entities soon lost whatever status they had enjoyed as actual elements of external reality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In doing so science has unquestionably cleared up widespread misconceptions , removed extraneous and illusory sources of fear , and dispelled many undesirable popular superstitions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There have been , indeed , many important and valuable gains from the development of our present scientific view of the world for which we may be rightly grateful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">All this has not , however , been an unmixed blessing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The scientific debunking of the spirit world has been in a way too successful and too thorough .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The house has been swept so clean that contemporary man has been left with no means , or at best with wholly inadequate means , for dealing with his experience of spirit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Although the particular form of conceptualization which popular imagination had made in response to the experience of spirit was undoubtedly defective , the raw experience itself which led to such excesses remains with us as vividly as ever .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We simply find ourselves in the position of having no means for inquiring into the structure and meaning of this range of our experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There is no framework or structure of thought with respect to which we can organize it and no part of reality , as we know and apprehend it , with respect to which we can refer this experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Science has simply left us helpless and powerless in this important sector of our lives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The situation in which we find ourselves is brought out with dramatic force in Arthur Miller 's play The Crucible , which deals with the Salem witch trials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As the play opens the audience is introduced to the community of Salem in Puritan America at the end of the eighteenth century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Aside from a quaint concern with witches and devils which provides the immediate problem in the opening scene , it is a quite normal community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The conversation of the characters creates an atmosphere suggesting the usual mixture of pleasures , foibles , irritations , and concerns which would characterize the common life of a normal village in any age .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is no occasion to feel uneasy or disturbed about these people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Instead , the audience can sit back at ease and , from the perspective of an enlightened time which no longer believes in such things , enjoy the dead seriousness with which the characters in the play take the witches and devils which are under discussion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A teenage girl , Abigail Williams , is being sharply questioned by her minister uncle , the Reverend Samuel Parris , about a wild night affair in the woods in which she and some other girls had seemed to have had contact with these evil beings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For all involved in this discussion the devil is a real entity who can really be confronted in the woods on a dark night , the demon world is populated with real creatures , and witches actually can be seen flying through the air .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As the play unfolds , however , the audience is subtly brought into the grip of an awful evil which grows with ominously gathering power and soon engulfs the community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Everyone in Salem , saint and sinner alike , is swept up by it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is like a mysterious epidemic which , starting first with Abigail and Parris , spreads inexorably with a dreadfully growing virulence through the whole town until all have been infected by it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It grows terribly and unavoidably in power and leaves in its wake a trail of misery , moral disintegration , and destruction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The audience leaves the play under a spell , It is the kind of spell which the exposure to spirit in its living active manifestation always evokes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If one asks about this play , what it is that comes upon this community and works within it with such terrible power , there is no better answer to give than `` spirit '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is not to attempt to say what spirit is , but only to employ a commonly used word to designate or simply identify a common experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the end the good man , John Proctor , expresses what the audience has already come to feel when he says , `` A fire , a fire is burning !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I hear the boot of Lucifer , I see his filthy face '' !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The tragic irony of the play is that the very belief in and concern with a devil who could be met in the woods and combatted with formulae set out in books was the very thing that prevented them from detecting the real devil when he came among them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We marvel at their blindness for not seeing this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Yet are not we of the mid twentieth century , who rightly do not believe there is any such `` thing '' as the devil , just as bad off as they - only in a different way ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In our disbelief we think that we can no longer even use the word and so are unable to even name the elemental power which is so vividly real in this play .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We are left helpless to cope with it because we do not dare speak of it as anything real for fear that to do so would imply a commitment to that which has already been discredited and proved false .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even Mr. Miller himself seems uncertain on this score .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a long commentary which he has inserted in the published text of the first act of the play , he says at one point : `` However , that experience never raised a doubt in his mind as to the reality of the underworld or the existence of Lucifer 's many faced lieutenants .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And his belief is not to his discredit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Better minds than Hale 's were - and still are - convinced that there is a society of spirits beyond our ken '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">( page 33 ) On the other hand , a little later on he says :
`` Since 1692 a great but superficial change has wiped out God 's beard and the Devil 's horns , but the world is still gripped between two diametrically opposed absolutes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The concept of unity , in which positive and negative are attributes of the same force , in which good and evil are relative , ever-changing , and always joined to the same phenomenon - such a concept is still reserved to the physical sciences and to the few who have grasped the history of ideas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we see the steady and methodical inculcation into humanity of the idea of man 's worthlessness - until redeemed - the necessity of the Devil may become evident as a weapon , a weapon designed and used time and time again in every age to whip men into a surrender to a particular church or church-state '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apparently he does not intend that those who read or view this play should think of the devil as being actually real .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet such is the dramatic power of his writing that the audience is nevertheless left in the grip of the terrible power and potency of that which came over Salem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It casts a spell upon them so that they leave with a feeling of having been in the mysterious presence of an evil power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is not enough in accounting for this feeling to analyze it into the wickedness of individual people added together to produce a cumulative effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For this does not account for the integral , elemental power of that which grows with abounding vigor as the play unfolds , nor does it explain the strange numinous sense of presentness which comes over those who watch the play like a spell .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The reality of spirit emerges in this play in spite of the author 's convictions to the contrary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is nothing in the whole range of human experience more widely known and universally felt than spirit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apart from spirit there could be no community , for it is spirit which draws men into community and gives to any community its unity , cohesiveness , and permanence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Think , for example , of the spirit of the Marine Corps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Surely this is a reality we all acknowledge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We cannot , of course , assign it any substance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is not material and is not a `` thing '' occupying space and time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Yet it exists and has an objective reality which can be experienced and known .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So it is too with many other spirits which we all know : the spirit of Nazism or Communism , school spirit , the spirit of a street corner gang or a football team , the spirit of Rotary or the Ku Klux Klan .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Every community , if it is alive has a spirit , and that spirit is the center of its unity and identity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In searching for clues which might lead us to a fresh apprehension of the reality of spirit , the close connection between spirit and community is likely to prove the most fruitful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For it is primarily in community that we know and experience spirit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is spirit which gives life to a community and causes it to cohere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is the spirit which is the source of a community 's drawing power by means of which others are drawn into it from the world outside so that the community grows and prospers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Yet the spirit which lives in community is not identical with the community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The idea of community and the idea of spirit are two distinct and separable ideas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One characteristic of the spirit in community is its givenness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The members of the community do not create the spirit but rather find it present and waiting for them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is for them a given which they and they alone possess .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The spirit of the Marine Corps was present and operative before any of the present members of it came into it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is they , of course , who keep it alive and preserve it so the same spirit will continue to be present in the Corps for future recruits to find as they come into it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the content of faith is to be presented today in a form that can be `` understanded of the people '' - and this , it must not be forgotten , is one of the goals of the perennial theological task - there is no other choice but to abandon completely a mythological manner of representation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This does not mean that mythological language as such can no longer be used in theology and preaching .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The absurd notion that demythologization entails the expurgation of all mythological concepts completely misrepresents Bultmann 's intention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His point is not that mythology may not be used , but that it may no longer be regarded as the only or even the most appropriate conceptuality for expressing the Christian kerygma .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we say that a mythological mode of thought must be completely abandoned , we mean it must be abandoned as the sole or proper means for presenting the Christian understanding of existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Mythological concepts may by all means still be used , but they can be used responsibly only as `` symbols '' or `` ciphers '' , that is , only if they are also constantly interpreted in non mythological ( or existential ) terms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The statement is often made that when Bultmann argues in this way , he `` overestimates the intellectual stumbling-block which myth is supposed to put in the way of accepting the Christian faith '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But this statement is completely unconvincing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If Bultmann 's own definition of myth is strictly adhered to ( and it is interesting that this is almost never done by those who make such pronouncements ) , the evidence is overwhelming that he does not at all exaggerate the extent to which the mythological concepts of traditional theology have become incredible and irrelevant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nor is it necessary to look for such evidence in the great urban centers of our culture that are admittedly almost entirely secularized and so profoundly estranged from the conventional forms in which the gospel has been communicated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the contrary , even in the heart of `` the Bible belt '' itself , as can be attested by any one who is called to work there , the industrial and technological revolutions have long been under way , together with the corresponding changes in man 's picture of himself and his world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , it is in just such a situation that the profundity of Bultmann 's argument is disclosed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although the theological forms of the past continue to exist in a way they do not in a more secularized situation , the striking thing is the rapidity with which they are being reduced to a marginal existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is especially in evidence among the present generation of the suburban middle class .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Time and again in counseling and teaching , one encounters members of this group whose attempts to bring into some kind of unity the insubstantial mythologies of their `` fundamentalist '' heritage and the stubborn reality of the modern world are only too painfully obvious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The same thing is also evidenced by the extreme `` culture Protestantism '' so often observed to characterize the preaching and teaching of the American churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the absence of a truly adequate conceptuality in which the gospel can be expressed , the unavoidable need to demythologize it makes use of whatever resources are at hand - and this usually means one or another of the various forms of `` folk religion '' current in the situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is not to say that the only explanation of the present infatuation with Norman Vincent Peale 's `` cult of reassurance '' or the other types of a purely cultural Christianity is the ever-present need for a demythologized gospel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it is to say that this need is far more important for such infatuation than most of the pundits seem to have suspected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , even if the latent demand for demythologization is not nearly as widespread as we are claiming , at least among the cultured elements of the population there tends to be an almost complete indifference to the church and its traditional message of sin and grace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">To be sure , when this is pointed out , a common response among certain churchmen is to fulminate about `` the little flock '' and `` the great crowd '' and to take solace from Paul 's castigation of the `` wisdom of the wise '' in the opening chapter of First Corinthians .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But can we any longer afford the luxury of such smug indignation ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Can the church risk assuming that the `` folly '' of men is as dear to God as their `` wisdom '' , or , as is also commonly implied , that `` the foolishness of God '' and `` the foolishness of men '' are simply two ways of talking about the same thing ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Can we continue to alienate precisely those whose gifts we so desperately need and apart from whose co-operation our mission in the world must become increasingly precarious ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is an ancient and venerable tradition in the church ( which derives , however , from the heritage of the Greeks rather than from the Bible ) that God is completely independent of his creation and so has no need of men for accomplishing his work in the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">by analogy , the church also has been regarded as entirely independent of the `` world '' in the sense of requiring nothing from it in order to be the church .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But , as Scripture everywhere reminds us , God does have need of his creatures , and the church , a fortiori , can ill afford to do without the talents with which the world , by God 's providence , presents it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And yet this is exactly the risk we run when we assume , as we too often do , that we can continue to preach the gospel in a form that makes it seem incredible and irrelevant to cultured men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Until we translate this gospel into a language that enlightened men today can understand , we are depriving ourselves of the very resources on which the continued success of our witness most certainly depends .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In arguing in this way , we are obviously taking for granted that a demythologized restatement of the kerygma can be achieved ; and that we firmly believe this will presently become evident when we set forth reasons to justify such a conviction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But the main point here is that even if such a restatement were not possible , the demand to demythologize the kerygma would still be unavoidable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is what we mean when we say this demand must be accepted without condition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If to be a Christian means to say yes where I otherwise say no , or where I do not have the right to say anything at all , then my only choice is to refuse to be a Christian .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Expressed differently : if the price for becoming a faithful follower of Jesus Christ is some form of self-destruction , whether of the body or of the mind - sacrificium corporis , sacrificium intellectus - then there is no alternative but that the price remain unpaid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This must be stressed because it is absolutely essential to the argument of this concluding chapter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Modern man , as Dietrich Bonhoeffer has told us , has `` come of age '' ; and though this process by no means represents an unambiguous gain and is , in fact , marked by the estrangement from the depths that seems to be the cost of human maturation , it is still a positive step forward ; and those of us who so richly benefit from it should be the last to despise it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In any event , it is an irreversible step , and if we are at all honest with ourselves , we will know we have no other alternative than to live in the world in which God has seen fit to place us .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To say this , of course , is to take up a position on one side of a controversy going on now for some two hundred years , or , at any rate , since the beginning of the distinctively modern period in theological thought .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We have aligned ourselves with that `` liberal '' tradition in Protestant Christianity that counts among the great names in its history those of Schleiermacher , Ritschl , Herrmann , Harnack , and Troeltsch , and more recently , Schweitzer and the early Barth and , in part at least , Bultmann .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is to this same tradition that most of the creative figures in the last century and a half of American theology also belong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For we must number here not only the names of Bushnell , Clarke , and Rauschenbusch , not to mention those of `` the Chicago School '' and Macintosh , but those of the brothers Niebuhr and ( if America may claim him ! )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Tillich as well .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Finally , we may also mention the several members of the self-consciously `` neoliberal '' movement that developed at the University of Chicago and is heavily indebted philosophically to the creative work of Alfred North Whitehead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What makes this long and diverse tradition essentially one is that those who have belonged to it have been profoundly in earnest about being modern men in a distinctively modern world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although they have also been concerned to stand squarely within the tradition of the apostolic church , they have exhibited no willingness whatever to sacrifice their modernity to their Christianity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They have insisted , rather , on living fully and completely within modern culture and , so far from considering this treason to God , have looked upon it as the only way they could be faithful to him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we say , then , that today , in our situation , the demand for demythologization must be accepted without condition , we are simply saying that at least this much of the liberal tradition is an enduring achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However much we may have to criticize liberal theology 's constructive formulations , the theology we ourselves must strive to formulate can only go beyond liberalism , not behind it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In affirming this we have already taken the decisive step in breaking the deadlock into which Bultmann 's attempt to formulate such a theology has led .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For we have said , in effect , that of the two alternatives to his position variously represented by the other participants in the demythologizing discussion , only one is really an alternative .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the demand for demythologization is unavoidable and so must be accepted by theology unconditionally , the position of the `` right '' is clearly untenable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whereas Bultmann 's `` center '' position is structurally inconsistent and is therefore indefensible on formal grounds alone , the general position of the `` right '' , as represented , say , by Karl Barth , involves the rejection or at least qualification of the demand for demythologization and so is invalidated on the material grounds we have just considered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It follows , then , provided the possibilities have been exhausted , that the only real alternative is the general viewpoint of the `` left '' , which has been represented on the Continent by Fritz Buri and , to some extent at least , is found in much that is significant in American and English theology .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In order to make the implications of our position as clear as possible , we may develop this argument at greater length .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We may show , first , that there cannot possibly be an alternative other than the three typically represented by Bultmann , Barth , and Buri .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To do this , it is sufficient to point out that if the principle in terms of which alternatives are to be conceived is such as to exclude more than two , then the question of a `` third '' possibility is a meaningless question .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , if what is at issue is whether `` All S is P '' , it is indifferent whether `` Some S is not P '' or `` No S is P '' , since in either case the judgment in question is false .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Hence , if what is in question is whether in a given theology myth is or is not completely rejected , it is unimportant whether only a little bit of myth or a considerable quantity is accepted ; for , in either event , the first possibility is excluded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Therefore , the only conceivable alternatives are those represented , on the one hand , by the two at least apparently self-consistent but mutually exclusive positions of Buri and Barth and , on the other hand , by the third but really pseudo position ( analogous to a round square ) of Bultmann .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A second point requires more extended comment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It will be recalled from the discussion in Section 7 that the position of the `` right '' , as represented by Barth , rests on the following thesis : The only tenable alternative to Bultmann 's position is a theology that ( 1 ) rejects or at least qualifies his unconditioned demand for demythologization and existential interpretation ; ( 2 ) accepts instead a special biblical hermeneutics or method of interpretation ; and ( 3 ) in so doing , frees itself to give appropriate emphasis to the event Jesus Christ by means of statements that , from Bultmann 's point of view , are mythological .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One hundred years ago there existed in England the Association for the Promotion of the Unity of Christendom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Representing as it did the efforts of only unauthorized individuals of the Roman and Anglican Churches , and urging a communion of prayer unacceptable to Rome , this association produced little fruit , and , in fact , was condemned by the Holy Office in 1864 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Now again in 1961 , in England , there is perhaps nothing in the religious sphere so popularly discussed as Christian unity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Church Unity Octave , January 18 - 25 , was enthusiastically devoted to prayer and discussion by the various churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Many people seem hopeful , yet it is difficult to predict whether or not there will be any more real attainment of Christian unity in 1961 than there was in 1861 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it must be readily seen that the religious picture in England has so greatly changed during these hundred years as to engender hope , at least on the Catholic side .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For `` the tide is well on the turn '' , as the London Catholic weekly Universe has written .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I came to England last summer to do research on the unpublished letters of Cardinal Newman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As an American Catholic of Irish ancestry , I came with certain preconceptions and expectations ; being intellectually influenced by Newman and the general 19th century literature of England , I knew only a Protestant dominated country .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since arriving here , however , I have formed a far different religious picture of present-day England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In representing part of this new picture , I will be recounting some of my own personal experiences , reactions and judgments ; but my primary aim is to transcribe what Englishmen themselves are saying and writing and implying about the Roman and Anglican Churches and about the present religious state of England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the Protestant clergy for the most part wear gray or some variant from the wholly black suit , my Roman collar and black garb usually identify me in England as a Roman Catholic cleric .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In any case , I have always been treated with the utmost courtesy by Englishmen , even in Devonshire and Cornwall , where anti Catholic feeling has supposedly existed the strongest and longest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nowhere have I seen public expression of anti-Catholicism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On my first Guy Fawkes Day here , I found Catholics as well as non Catholics celebrating with the traditional fireworks and bonfires , and was told that most Englishmen either do not know or are not concerned with the historical significance of the day .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Birmingham newspaper printed in a column for children an article entitled `` The True Story of Guy Fawkes '' , which began :
`` When you pile your '' guy `` on the bonfire tomorrow night , I wonder how much of the true story of Guy Fawkes you will remember ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the 355 years since the first Guy Fawkes Night , much of the story has been forgotten , so here is a reminder '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The article proceeded to give an inaccurate account of a catholic plot to kill King James /1 1 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In spite of the increase in numbers and prestige brought about by the conversions of Newman and other Tractarians of the 1840 's and 1850 's , the Catholic segment of England one hundred years ago was a very small one ( four per cent , or 800000 ) which did not enjoy a gracious hearing from the general public .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The return of the Catholic hierarchy in 1850 was looked upon with indignant disapprobation and , in fact , was charged with being a gesture of disloyalty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1864 Newman professedly had to write his Apologia with his keenest feelings in order to be believed and to command a fair hearing from English readers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Now , in 1961 , the Catholic population of England is still quite small ( ten per cent , or 5 million ) ; yet it represents a very considerable percentage of the churchgoing population .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Protestant woman marveled to me over the large crowds going in and out of the Birmingham Oratory ( Catholic ) Church on Sunday mornings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She found this a marvel because , as she said , only six per cent of English people are churchgoers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">She may not have been exact on this number , but others here feel quite certain that the percentage would be less than ten .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From many sides come remarks that Protestant churches are badly attended and the large medieval cathedrals look all but empty during services .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Catholic priest recently recounted how in the chapel of a large city university , following Anglican evensong , at which there was a congregation of twelve , he celebrated Mass before more than a hundred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Protestants themselves are the first to admit the great falling off in effective membership in their churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">According to a newspaper report of the 1961 statistics of the Church of England , the `` total of confirmed members is 9748000 , but only 2887671 are registered on the parochial church rolls '' , and `` over 27 million people in England are baptized into the Church of England , but roughly only a tenth of them continue '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An amazing article in the Manchester Guardian of last November , entitled `` Fate of Redundant Churches '' , states than an Archbishops ' Commission `` reported last month that in the Church of England alone there are 790 churches which are redundant now , or will be in 20 years ' time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A further 260 Anglican churches have been demolished since 1948 '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And in the last five years , the `` Methodist chapel committee has authorized the demolition or , more often , the sale of 764 chapels '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Most of these former churches are now used as warehouses , but `` neither Anglicans nor Nonconformists object to selling churches to Roman Catholics '' , and have done so .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While it must be said that these same Protestants have built some new churches during this period , and that religious population shifts have emptied churches , a principal reason for this phenomenon of redundancy is that fewer Protestants are going to church .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It should be admitted , too , that there is a good percentage of lapsed or nonchurchgoing Catholics ( one paper writes 50 per cent ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still , it is clear from such reports , and apparently clear from the remarks of many people , that Protestants are decreasing and Catholics increasing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">An Anglican clergyman in Oxford sadly but frankly acknowledged to me that this is true .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A century ago , Newman saw that liberalism ( what we now might call secularism ) would gradually but definitely make its mark on English Protestantism , and that even high Anglicanism would someday no longer be a `` serviceable breakwater against doctrinal errors more fundamental than its own '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That day is perhaps today , 1961 , and it seems no longer very meaningful to call England a `` Protestant country '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One of the ironies of the present crusade for Christian unity is that there are not , relatively speaking , many real Christians to unite .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Many English Catholics are proud of their Catholicism and know that they are in a new ascendancy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The London Universe devoted its centenary issue last December 8 to mapping out various aspects of Catholic progress during the last one hundred years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With traditional nationalistic spirit , some Englishmen claim that English Catholicism is Catholicism at its best .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I have found myself saying with other foreigners here that English Catholics are good Catholics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It has been my experience to find as many men as women in church , and to hear almost everyone in church congregations reciting the Latin prayers and responses at Mass .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">They hope , of course , to reclaim the non-Catholic population to the Catholic faith , and at every Sunday Benediction they recite by heart the `` Prayer for England '' :
`` O Blessed Virgin Mary , Mother of God and our most gentle queen and mother , look down in mercy upon England , thy '' dowry `` , and upon us all who greatly hope and trust in thee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Intercede for our separated brethren , that with us in the one true fold they may be united to the chief Shepherd , the vicar of thy Son '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A hymn often to be heard in Catholic churches is `` Faith of our Fathers '' , which glories in England 's ancient faith that endured persecution , and which proclaims :
`` Faith of our Fathers : Mary 's prayers / Shall win our country back to thee '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The English saints are widely venerated , quite naturally , and now there is great hope that the Forty Martyrs and Cardinal Newman will soon be canonized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Because they have kept the faith of their medieval fathers , English Catholics have always strongly resented the charge of being `` English '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I have not seen this charge made during my stay here , but apparently it is still in the air .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , a writer in a recent number of The Queen hyperbolically states that `` of the myriad imprecations the only one which the English Catholics really resent is the suggestion that they are ' un English '' ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this connection , it has been observed that the increasing number of Irish Catholics , priests and laity , in England , while certainly seen as good for Catholicism , is nevertheless a source of embarrassment for some of the more nationalistic English Catholics , especially when these Irishmen offer to remind their Christian brethren of this good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the more noteworthy changes that have taken place since the mid 19th century is the situation of Catholics at Oxford and Cambridge Universities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At Oxford one hundred years ago there were very few Catholics , partly because religious tests were removed only in 1854 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Moreover , for those few there was almost no ecclesiastical representation in the city to care for their religious needs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Now , not only are there considerably more laity as students and professors at Oxford , but there are also numerous houses of religious orders existing in respectable and friendly relations with the non Catholic members of the University .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some Catholic priests lecture there ; Catholic seminarians attend tutorials and row on the Cherwell with non-Catholic students .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Further evidence that Roman Catholicism enjoys a more favorable position today than in 1861 is the respectful attention given to it in the mass media of England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The general tone of articles appearing in such important newspapers as the Manchester Guardian and the Sunday Observer implies a kindly recognition that the Catholic Church is now at least of equal stature in England with the Protestant churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On successive Sundays during October , 1960 , Paul Ferris ( a non-Catholic ) wrote articles in the Observer depicting clergymen of the Church of England , the Church of Rome and the Nonconformist Church .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Catholic priest , though somewhat superficially drawn , easily came out the best .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There were many letters of strong protest against the portrait of the Anglican clergyman , who was indeed portrayed as a man not particularly concerned with religious matters and without really very much to do as clergyman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Such a series of articles was certainly never printed in the public press of mid Victorian England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There was so much interest shown in this present-day venture that it was continued on B.B.C. , where comments were equally made by an Anglican parson , a Free Church minister and a Catholic priest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Catholic priests have frequently appeared on television programs , sometimes discussing the Christian faith on an equal footing with Protestant clergymen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A notable example of this was the discussion of Christian unity by the Catholic Archbishop of Liverpool , Dr. Heenan , and the Anglican Archbishop of York , Dr. Ramsey , recently appointed Archbishop of Canterbury .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The good feeling which exists between these two important church figures is now well known in England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Holy Sacrifice of the Mass with commentary has been televised several times in recent months .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And it was interesting to observe that B.B.C. .</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">'s television film on Christmas Eve was The Bells of St. Mary's .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Of course , the crowning event that has dramatically upset the traditional pattern of English religious history was the friendly visit paid by Dr. Fisher , then Anglican Archbishop of Canterbury , to the Vatican last December .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was the first time an English Primate has done this since the 14th century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">English Catholics reacted to this event with moderate but real hope .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Almost daily something is reported which feeds this Catholic hope in England : statistics of the increasing numbers of converts and Irish Catholic immigrants ; news of a Protestant minister in Leamington who has offered to allow a Catholic priest to preach from his pulpit ; a report that a Catholic nun had been requested to teach in a non-Catholic secondary school during the sickness of one of its masters ; the startling statement in a respectable periodical that `` Catholics , if the present system is still in operation , will constitute almost one-third of the House of Lords in the next generation '' ; a report that 200 Protestant clergymen and laity attended a votive Mass offered for Christian unity at a Catholic church in Slough during the Church Unity Octave .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The death of a man is unique , and yet it is universal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The straight line would symbolize its uniqueness , the circle its universality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But how can one figure symbolize both ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Christianity declares that in the life and death of Jesus Christ the unique and the universal concur .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Perhaps no church father saw this concurrence of the unique and the universal as clearly , or formulated it as precisely , as Irenaeus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To be the Savior and the Lord , Jesus Christ has to be a historical individual with a biography all his own ; he dare not be a cosmic aeon that swoops to earth for a while but never identifies itself with man 's history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Yet this utterly individual historical person must also contain within himself the common history of mankind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His history is his alone , yet each man must recognize his own history in it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His death is his alone , yet each man can see his own death in the crucifixion of Jesus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each man can identify himself with the history and the death of Jesus Christ because Jesus Christ has identified himself with human history and human death , coming as the head of a new humanity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Not a circle , then , nor a straight line , but a spiral represents the shape of death as Irenaeus sees it ; for a spiral has motion as well as recurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As represented by a spiral , history may , in some sense , be said to repeat itself ; yet each historical event remains unique .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Christ is both unique and universal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first turn of the spiral is the primeval history of humanity in Adam .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As Origen interprets the end of history on the basis of its beginning , so Irenaeus portrays the story of Adam on the basis of the story of Christ .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Whence , then , comes the substance of the first man ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From God 's Will and Wisdom , and from virgin earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For ' God had not rained ' , says the Scripture , before man was made , ' and there was no man to till the earth ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From this earth , then , while it was still virgin God took dust and fashioned the man , the beginning of humanity '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Irenaeus does not regard Adam and Eve merely as private individuals , but as universal human beings , who were and are all of humanity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Adam and Eve were perfect , not in the sense that they possessed perfection , but in the sense that they were capable of development toward perfection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were , in fact , children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Irenaeus does not claim pre-existence for the human soul ; therefore there is no need for him , as there is for Origen , to identify existence itself with the fall .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Existence is created and willed by God and is not the consequence of a pre-existent rebellion or of a cosmic descent from eternity into history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Historical existence is a created good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The biblical symbol for this affirmation is expressed in the words : `` So God created man in his own image ; in the similitude of God he created him '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There are some passages in the writings of Irenaeus where the image of God and the similitude are sharply distinguished , so most notably in the statement : `` If the [ Holy ] Spirit is absent from the soul , such a man is indeed of an animal nature ; and , being left carnal , he will be an imperfect being , possessing the image [ of God ] in his formation , but not receiving the similitude [ of God ] through the Spirit '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus the image of God is that which makes a man a man and not an oyster ; the similitude of God , by contrast , is that which makes a man a child of God and not merely a rational creature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Recent research on Irenaeus , however , makes it evident that he does not consistently maintain this distinction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He does not mean to say that Adam lost the similitude of God and his immortality through the fall ; for he was created not exactly immortal , nor yet exactly mortal , but capable of immortality as well as of mortality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Therefore Irenaeus describes man 's creation as follows :
`` So that the man should not have thoughts of grandeur , and become lifted up , as if he had no lord , because of the dominion that had been given to him , and the freedom , fall into sin against God his Creator , overstepping his bounds , and take up an attitude of self-conceited arrogance towards God , a law was given him by God , that he might know that he had for lord the lord of all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And He laid down for him certain conditions : so that , if he kept the command of God , then he would always remain as he was , that is , immortal ; but if he did not , he would become mortal , melting into earth , whence his frame had been taken '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These conditions man did not keep , and thus he became mortal ; yet he did not stop being human as a result .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is no justification for systematizing the random statements of Irenaeus about the image of God beyond this , nor for reading into his imprecise usage the later theological distinction between the image of God ( humanity ) and the similitude of God ( immortality ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Man was created with the capacity for immortality , but the devil 's promise of immortality in exchange for disobedience cost Adam his immortality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He was , in the words of Irenaeus , `` beguiled by another under the pretext of immortality '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The true way to immortality lay through obedience , but man did not believe this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Eve was disobedient ; for she did not obey when as yet she was a virgin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And even as she , having indeed a husband , Adam , but being nevertheless as yet a virgin , having become disobedient , was made the cause of death , both to herself and to the entire human race ; so also did Mary , having a man betrothed [ to her ] , and being nevertheless a virgin , by yielding obedience , become the cause of salvation , both to herself and the whole human race '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Because he interprets the primitive state of man as one of mere potentiality or capacity and believes that Adam and Eve were created as children , Irenaeus often seems inclined to extenuate their disobedience as being `` due , no doubt , to carelessness , but still wicked '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His interpretation of the beginning on the basis of the end prompts him to draw these parallels between the Virgin Eve and the Virgin Mary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That parallelism affects his picture of man 's disobedience too ; for as it was Christ , the Word of God , who came to rescue man , so it was disobedience to the word of God in the beginning that brought death into the world , and all our woe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With this act of disobedience , and not with the inception of his individual existence , man began the downward circuit on the spiral of history , descending from the created capacity for immortality to an inescapable mortality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At the nadir of that circuit is death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Along with the fruit they did also fall under the power of death , because they did eat in disobedience ; and disobedience to God entails death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wherefore , as they became forfeit to death , from that [ moment ] they were handed over to it '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">This leads Irenaeus to the somewhat startling notion that Adam and Eve died on the same day that they disobeyed , namely , on a Friday , as a parallel to the death of Christ on Good Friday ; he sees a parallel also to the Jewish day of preparation for the Sabbath .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In any case , though they had been promised immortality if they ate of the tree , they obtained mortality instead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The wages of sin is death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Man 's life , originally shaped for immortality and for communion with God , must now be conformed to the shape of death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nevertheless , even at the nadir of the circuit the spiral of history belongs to God , and he still rules .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even death , therefore , has a providential as well as a punitive function .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">`` Wherefore also He [ God ] drove him [ man ] out of Paradise , and removed him far from the tree of life , not because He envied him the tree of life , as some venture to assert , but because He pitied him , [ and did not desire ] that he should continue a sinner for ever , nor that the sin which surrounded him should be immortal , and evil interminable and irremediable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But He set a bound to his [ state of ] sin , by interposing death , and thus causing sin to cease , putting an end to it by the dissolution of the flesh , which should take place in the earth , so that man , ceasing at length to live in sin , and dying to it , might live to God '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This idea , which occurs in both Tatian and Cyprian , fits especially well into the scheme of Irenaeus ' theology ; for it prepares the way for the passage from life through death to life that is achieved in Christ .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As man can live only by dying , so it was only by his dying that Christ could bring many to life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is probably fair to say that the idea of death is more profound in Irenaeus than the idea of sin is .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This applies to his picture of Adam .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is borne out also by the absence of any developed theory about how sin passes from one generation to the next .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It becomes most evident in his description of Christ as the second Adam , who does indeed come to destroy sin , but whose work culminates in the achievement of immortality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This emphasis upon death rather than sin as man 's fundamental problem Irenaeus shares with many early theologians , especially the Greek speaking ones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They speak of the work of Christ as the bestowal of incorruptibility , which can mean ( though it does not have to mean ) deliverance from time and history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Death reminds man of his sin , but it reminds him also of his transience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It represents a punishment that he knows he deserves , but it also symbolizes most dramatically that he lives his life within the process of time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These two aspects of death cannot be successfully separated , but they dare not be confused or identified .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The repeated efforts in Christian history to describe death as altogether the consequence of human sin show that these two aspects of death cannot be separated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such efforts almost always find themselves compelled to ask whether Adam was created capable of growing old and then older and then still older , in short , whether Adam 's life was intended to be part of the process of time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If it was , then it must have been God 's intention to translate him at a certain point from time to eternity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One night , so some of these theories run , Adam would have fallen asleep , much as he fell asleep for the creation of Eve ; and thus he would have been carried over into the life eternal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The embarrassment of these theories over the naturalness of death is an illustration of the thesis that death cannot be only a punishment , for some termination seems necessary in a life that is lived within the natural order of time and change .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other hand , Christian faith knows that death is more than the natural termination of temporal existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is the wages of sin , and its sting is the law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If this aspect of death as punishment is not distinguished from the idea of death as natural termination , the conclusion seems inevitable that temporal existence itself is a form of punishment rather than the state into which man is put by the will of the Creator .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This seems to have been the conclusion to which Origen was forced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If death receives more than its share of attention from the theologian and if sin receives less than its share , the gift of the life eternal through Christ begins to look like the divinely appointed means of rescue from temporal , i.e. , created , existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such an interpretation of death radically alters the Christian view of creation ; for it teaches salvation from , not salvation in , time and history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because Christianity teaches not only salvation in history , but salvation by the history of Christ , such an interpretation of death would require a drastic revision of the Christian understanding of the work of Christ .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Too often a beginning bodybuilder has to do his training secretly either because his parents do n't want sonny-boy to `` lift all those old barbell things '' because `` you 'll stunt your growth '' or because childish taunts from his schoolmates , like `` Hey , lookit Mr. America , whaddya gonna do with all those muscles ( of which he has none at the time ) '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">After all , a guy 's gotta have a little ego !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Therefore it 's a genuine pleasure to tell you about an entirely happy bodybuilder who has never had to train in secret ; has never heard one unkind word from his parents ; and never has been taunted by his schoolmates !</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">So right away Claude introduced Henri to his famous `` moon '' bench and proceeded to teach him his first Push-Pull Super-Set consisting of the wide grip Straight-Arm Pullover ( the `` pull '' part of the Push-Pull Super-Set ) which dramatically widens the rib cage and strongly affects the muscles of the upper back and chest , and the collar-to-collar Bench Press which specifically works on the chest to build those wide , Reeves-type `` gladiator '' pecs , while stimulating the upper lats and frontal deltoids .</MPQASENT>
