<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The exercise I shall discuss in this - the first of a new series of articles on muscle definition specialization of a particular body part - is the One Leg Lunge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">Why it was ever forgotten for even a moment I cannot say because it works perfectly for everyone , no matter whether he has short or long thigh-bone lengths !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is the one exercise that drastically influences the definition of the thighs at the hipline - that mark of the champion that sets him apart from all other bodybuilders - a criterion of muscle `` drama '' that is unforgettable to judges and audiences alike - the facet of muscular development that wins prizes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Definition of the thighs at the uppermost part is quite commonly seen in most championship Olympic lifters which is easily understandable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The One Leg Lunge is a split and all lifters practice this in their regular workouts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But for purely definition purposes - used in conjunction with your regular Squatting , Leg Curling , Leg Extensor programs - a heavy weight is not needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , a lighter weight works much better because a greater , more extensive split can be performed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Used in several sets of high reps once or twice each week it will not be long before your entire upper leg takes on a razor-sharp definition in which the muscles look like wire cables writhing and twisting under the skin !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Really there is no reason why this fine exercise should not find its way into your leg program at all times , for the following suggestions show why it is so effective :
It 's a complete thigh contraction extension exercise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It places terrific tension on the leg muscles from start to finish of each repetition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It improves over-all balance and control for the bodybuilder , and helps to make Squats more easily and more correctly performed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It increases flexibility of the legs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It speeds muscle growth and power development even for the advanced bodybuilder because each hip and leg is exercised separately , thus enabling a massive , concentrated effort to be focused on each .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You 'll need your Weider Power Stands for this fine exercise and here 's the way it 's done :
Place your Power Stands in position and adjust their height so that this will correspond to the height of your shoulders when you are in a deep leg split as for a heavy Clean .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Place a suitably loaded barbell across them ; grasp the bar ( which will rest against the back of your neck ) ; extend your feet forward and backward until you are in a deep leg split .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Now raise the weight by straightening your front leg , without moving your feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the front knee is straight and locked , allow it to bend again until you feel the bar come lightly into contact with the sides of the Power Stands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After you have taken a breather , reverse the position of your legs so that the front thigh of the previous exercise is now to the rear , and the rear thigh now to the front , and perform the same movement in the same manner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">That 's the One-Leg Lunge in a nutshell .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You should have a couple of training partners to stand by when you make your first experiments , just for safety .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You should also begin this exercise with a very light barbell until you become accustomed to it balance wise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Oh , you 'll wobble and weave quite a bit at first .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But do n't worry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Before your first training experiment has ended there will be a big improvement and almost before you know it you 'll be raising and lowering yourself just like a veteran !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although I suggested that you hold the bar at the back of the neck there 's no reason why you should n't make some experiments with the bar held in front of the neck .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Squat style lifters and leg split lifters would both benefit enormously by practicing those variations providing that they remember to make alternate sets with the left and right leg to the front .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This delightful tropical fruit has become well-known in the past thirty years because modern transportation methods have made it possible to ship avocado anywhere in the United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has a great many assets to recommend it and if you have n't made avocado a part of your diet yet , you really should .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is roughly shaped like a large pear , and when properly ripened , its dark green skin covers a meaty , melon like pulp that has about the consistency of a ripe Bartlett pear , but oily .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The avocado should have a `` give '' to it , as you hold it , when it is ripe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The flavor is neither sweet , like a pear , nor tart like an orange ; it is subtle and rather bland , nut like .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is a flavor that might take a little getting used to - not because it is unpleasant , but because the flavor is hard to define in the light of our experience with other fruits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sometimes it takes several `` eatings '' of avocado to catch that delightful quality in taste that has made it such a favorite throughout the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Once you become an avocado fan , you will look forward to the season each year with eager anticipation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Today , refrigerated carriers have made the shipping of avocados possible to any place in the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The fruit is allowed to mature on the tree , but it is still firm at this point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is brought to packing houses , cleaned and graded as to size and quality , and packed in protective excelsior .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The fruit is then cooled to 42 ` F. , a temperature at which it lapses into a sort of dormant state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This cooling does not change the avocado in any way , it just delays the natural softening of the fruit until a grove like temperature ( room temperature ) is restored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This happens on the grocer 's shelf or in your kitchen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most attractive things about avocados is that they do not require processing of any kind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is no dyeing or waxing or gassing needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the temperature is controlled properly , the avocado will delay its ripening until needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And unlike other fruits , one cannot eat the skin of the avocado .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is thick , much like an egg plant 's skin , so that poison sprays , if they are used , present no hazard to the consumer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Good taste and versatility , plus safety from spray poisons would be enough to recommend the frequent use of such a fruit , even if its nutritional values were limited .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Avocados , however , are very rich in nutrients .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Their main asset is an abundance of unsaturated fatty acids , so necessary for maintaining the good health of the circulatory system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Aside from this , the average portion contains some protein , an appreciable amount of vitamins and C - about one-tenth of the minimum daily requirement , and about a third of the official vitamin E requirement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The B vitamins are well represented , especially thiamin and riboflavin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Calcium , phosphorus and iron are present in worthwhile amounts , and eleven other minerals also have been found in varying trace amounts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">None of these values is destroyed , not significantly altered by refrigeration storage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dr. Wilson C. Grant , of the Veterans ' Administration Hospital , Coral Gables , Florida , and the University of Miami School of Medicine , set out to discover if avocados , because of their high content of unsaturated fatty acids , would reduce the cholesterol of the blood in selected patients .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The study comprised 16 male patients , ranging in age from 27 to 72 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were put on control diets to determine as accurately as possible , the normal cholesterol level of their blood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Then they were given 1 2 to 1 - 1 2 avocados per day as a substitute for part of their dietary fat consumption .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The lyric beauties of Schubert 's Trout Quintet - its elemental rhythms and infectious melodies - make it a source of pure pleasure for almost all music listeners .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But for students of musical forms and would-be classifiers , the work presents its problems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Since it requires only five players , it would seem to fall into the category of chamber music - yet it calls for a double bass , an instrument generally regarded as symphonic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Moreover , the piece is written in five movements , rather than the conventional four of most quintets , and this gives the opus a serenade or divertimento flavor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The many and frequent performances of the Trout serve to emphasize the dual nature of its writing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some renditions are of symphonic dimensions , with the contrabass given free rein .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other interpretations present the music as an essentially intimate creation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In these readings , the double bass is either kept discreetly in the background , or it is dressed in clown 's attire - the musical equivalent of a bull in a china shop .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Recently I was struck anew by the divergent approaches , when in the course of one afternoon and evening I listened to no fewer than ten different performances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The occasion for this marathon : Angel 's long awaited reissue in its `` Great Recordings of the Century '' series of the Schnabel-Pro Arte version .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Let me say at the outset that the music sounded as sparkling on the last playing as it did on the first .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whether considered alone or in relation to other editions , COLH 40 is a document of prime importance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Artur Schnabel was one of the greatest Schubert-Beethoven-Mozart players of all time , and any commentary of his on this repertory is valuable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But Schnabel was a great teacher in addition to being a great performer , and the fact that four of the ten versions I listened to are by Schnabel pupils ( Clifford Curzon , Frank Glazer , Adrian Aeschbacher , and Victor Babin ) also sheds light on the master 's pedagogical skills .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Certain pianistic traits are common to all five Schnabelian renditions , most notably the `` Schnabel trill '' ( which differs from the conventional trill in that the two notes are struck simultaneously ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the most impressive testimony to Schnabel 's distinction as a teacher is reflected by the individuality which marks each student 's approach as distinctly his own .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Schnabel 's emphasis on structural clarity , his innate rhythmic vibrancy , and impetuous intensity all tend to stamp his reading as a symphonic one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet no detail was too small to receive attention from this master , and as a result the playing here has humor , delicacy , and radiant humanity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is a serious minded interpretation , but it is never strait-laced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And although Schnabel 's pianism bristles with excitement , it is meticulously faithful to Schubert 's dynamic markings and phrase indications .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The piano performance on this Trout is one that really demands a search for superlatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">About the Pro Arte 's contribution I am less happy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I , for one , rather regret that Schnabel did n't collaborate with the Budapest Quartet , whose rugged , athletic playing was a good deal closer to this pianist 's interpretative outlook than the style of the Belgian group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From a technical standpoint , the string playing is good , but the Pro Arte people fail to enter into the spirit of things here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The violinist , in particular , is very indulgent with swoops and slides , and his tone is pinched and edgy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The twenty-five year old recording offers rather faded string tone , but the balance between the instruments is good and the transfer is very quiet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is a break in continuity just before the fourth variation in the `` Forellen '' movement , and I suspect that this is due to imperfect splicing between sides of the original SPs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Turning to the more modern versions , Curzon 's ( London ) offers the most sophisticated keyboard work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Every detail in his interpretation has been beautifully thought out , and of these I would especially cite the delicious landler touch the pianist brings to the fifth variation ( an obvious indication that he is playing with Viennese musicians ) , and the gossamer shading throughout .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some of Curzon 's playing strikes me as finicky , however .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Why , for example , does he favor two tempos , rather than one , for the third movement ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The assisting musicians from the Vienna Octet are somewhat lacking in expertise , but their contribution is rustic and appealing .</MPQASENT>

his scrawny , tottering sound adds a delightful hilarity to the performance . )</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But having lived with the disc for some time now , I find the performance less exciting than either Schnabel 's or Fleisher 's ( whose superb performance with the Budapest Quartet has still to be recorded ) and a good deal less filled with humor than Curzon 's .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Aeschbacher 's work is very much akin to Schnabel 's , but the sound on his Decca disc is dated , and you will have a hard time locating a copy of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Hephzibah Menuhin-Amadeus Quartet ( Angel ) and Victor Babin-Festival Quartet ( RCA Victor ) editions give us superlative string playing ( both in symphonic style ) crippled by unimaginative piano playing .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Badura-Skoda-Vienna Konzerthaus ( Westminster ) and Demus-Schubert Quartet ( Deutsche Grammophon ) are both warm toned , pleasantly lyrical , but rather slack and tensionless .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Helmut Roloff , playing with a group of musicians from the Bayreuth Ensemble , gives a sturdy reading , in much the same vein as that of the last mentioned pianists .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Telefunken has accorded him beautiful sound , and this bargain-priced disc ( it sells for $ 2.98 ) is worthy of consideration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Returning once again to the Schnabel reissue , I am beguiled anew by the magnificence of this pianist 's musical penetration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Here is truly a `` Great Recording of the Century '' , and its greatness is by no means diminished by the fact that it is not quite perfect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This recording surely belongs in everyone 's collection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Must records always sound like records ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From the beginning of commercial recording , new discs purported to be indistinguishable from The Real Thing have regularly been put in circulation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Seen in perspective , many of these releases have a genuine claim to be milestones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although lacking absolute verisimilitude , they supply the ear and the imagination with all necessary materials for re-creation of the original .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the basis of what they give us we can know how the young Caruso sang , appreciate the distinctive qualities of Parsifal under Karl Muck 's baton , or sense the type of ensemble Toscanini created in his years with the New York Philharmonic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago , the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In many cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational effects :
the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning as the gap between sound and substance became clearer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Other innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing to acquire in time the status of classics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If we return to them today , we have no difficulty spotting their weaknesses but we find them still pleasing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Records sound like records because they provide a different sort of experience than live music .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This difference is made up of many factors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some of them are obvious , such as the fact that we associate recorded and live music with our responses and behavior in different types of environments and social settings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( Music often sounds best to me when I can dress informally and sit in something more comfortable than a theatre seat . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the technical standpoint , records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey the true color , texture , complexity , range , intensity , pulse , and pitch of the original .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Any alteration of one of these factors is distortion , although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Yet it is the accumulation of distortion , the fitting together of fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness , that makes records sound like records .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The sound may be good ; but if you know The Real Thing , you know that what you are hearing is only a clever imitation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Command 's new Brahms Second is a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather than a copy of one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Like the recent Scheherazade from London ( High Fidelity , Sept. 1961 ) , it is successful because emphasis has been placed on good musical and engineering practices rather than on creating sensational effects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because of this , only those with truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the engineers ' triumph .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The easiest way to describe this release is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective Steinberg performance with minimal alteration of its musical values .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The engineering as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The effect of the recording is very open and natural , with the frequency emphasis exactly what you would expect from a live performance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This absence of peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity , but it eliminates listener fatigue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A contributing factor is the perspective , the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The orchestra is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes , valve clicks , and other noises incidental to playing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Yet you feel the orchestra is near at hand , and the individual instruments have the same firm presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically perfect hall .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its full sonority ; yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi performer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All of this would be wasted , of course , if the performance lacked authority and musical distinction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For me it has more of both elements than the majority of its competitors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Steinberg seems to have gone directly back to the score , discounting tradition , and has built his performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly what Brahms set down on paper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those accustomed to broader , more romantic statements of the symphony can be expected to react strongly when they hear this one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Without losing the distinctive undertow of Brahmsian rhythm , the pacing is firm and the over-all performance has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Presto ma non assai of the first trio of the scherzo is taken literally and may shock you , as the real Allegro con spirito of the finale is likely to bring you to your feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the end , however , the thing about this performance that is most striking is the way it sings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Steinberg obviously has concluded that it is the lyric element which must dominate in this score , and he manages at times to create the effect of the whole orchestra bursting into song .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Too many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody and its accompaniment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Command technique invites you to listen to the depth of the orchestration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Your ear takes you into the ensemble , and you may well become aware of instrumental details which previously were apparent only in the score .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is this sort of experience that makes the concept of high fidelity of real musical significance for the home music listener .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The first substantially complete stereo Giselle ( and the only one of its scope since Feyer 's four-sided LP edition of 1958 for Angel ) , this set is , I'm afraid , likely to provide more horrid fascination than enjoyment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The already faded pastel charms of the naive music itself vanish entirely in Fistoulari 's melodramatic contrasts between ultra vehement brute power and chilly , if suave , sentimentality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And in its engineers ' frantic attempts to achieve maximum dynamic impact and earsplitting brilliance , the recording sounds as though it had been `` doctored for super high fidelity '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The home listener is overpowered , all right , but the experience is a far from pleasant one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As with the penultimate Giselle release ( Wolff 's abridgment for RCA Victor ) I find the cleaner , less razor edged monophonic version , for all its lack of big stage spaciousness , the more aurally tolerable - but this may be the result of processing defects in my SD copies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most recreation work calls for a good deal of pre planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This is particularly true in site selection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You must know before you start what the needs and objectives of your organization are ; you must have a list of requirements on where , how many , and what type sites are needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With such a program you can make constructive selections of the best sites available .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Begin the examination of a site with a good map and aerial photos if possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These are becoming more and more available through the work of counties and other government agencies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The new editions of topographic maps being made by the federal government are excellent for orienting yourself to the natural features of the site .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These are inexpensive and available from the U. S. Geological Society , washington 25 , D. C. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In recent years many counties and the U. S. Forest Service have taken aerial photos which show features in detail and are very good for planning use .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most counties also have maps available from the county engineer showing roads and other features and from the assessor 's office showing ownerships of land .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Inspect the site in the field during the time of the year when the area will be most heavily used for recreation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This gives you a better opportunity to get the feel of the climate conditions , the exposure to the sun and wind , the water interests , etcetera , which vary greatly with the seasons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is usually helpful to make a sketch map in the field , showing the size and location of the features of interest and to take photographs at the site .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These are a great aid for planning use back at the office .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For site planning work , it is best to have a qualified and experienced park planner to carry through the study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , there is also much to be gained by making use of the abilities of the local people who are available and interested in recreation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">County judges , commissioners , engineers , assessors , and others who have lived in the area for a long time may have valuable knowledge regarding the site or opinions to offer from their varied professional experiences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A visit to the site by a group of several persons can usually bring out new ideas or verify opinions most helpful to the planning study of any recreation area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">How much study is required ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This , of course , depends on the character of the site itself , the previous experience of the investigator , and the number of factors needed to arrive at a good decision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is too easy for the inexperienced person to make a quick judgment of a few values of the area and base a decision on these alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Usually there are more factors to good site planning than first impressions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A site may be a rundown slum or a desolate piece of desert in appearance today but have excellent potentials for the future with a little development or water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The same is true of areas which at first look good because of a few existing recreation features but may actually be poor areas to develop for general public use .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In looking for the best sites available that meet the requirements , you need information to compare the site with others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You need answers to four important questions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">What are the existing recreation features ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How well can the site be developed ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How useful will it be to the public ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Is this site available ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Check the quantity and quality of all of the recreation interests already existing at the site .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Naturally , a park site with scenic views , a good lake , trees , and sand dunes , will attract more people than a nearby area with only trees and dunes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Quality is vitally important .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Frontage on a body of clear , clean water will be vastly different from the same amount of frontage on polluted water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some recreation features , such as scenic values and water interest , also have greater overall value than other interests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most desirable features for a park are beautiful views or scenery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It may be distant views of a valley or the mountains or natural features such as a small lake , colorful rock formations , or unusual trees .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Modern physics has developed the theory that all matter consists of minute waves of energy .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If the photographically realistic continuity of dreams , however bizarre their combinations , denies that it is purely a composition of the brain , it must be compounded from views of diverse realities , although some of them may never be encountered in what we are pleased to call the real life .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The popularity of folklore in America stands in direct proportion to the popularity of nationalism in America .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And the emphasis on nationalism in America is in proportion to the growth of American influence across the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , if we are to observe American folklore in the twentieth century , we will do well to establish the relationships between folklore , nationalism and imperialism at the outset .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism and international influence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">1 ) Every age rewrites the events of its history in terms of what should have been , creating legends about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary actions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What actually occurred in the past is seldom as important as what a given generation feels must have occurred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">2 ) As a country superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others , it searches its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Its folklore and legend , usually disguised as history , are allowed to account for group actions , to provide a focal point for group loyalty , and to become a cohesive force for national identification .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One can apply these facts to Britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as she spread her dominion over palm and pine , and they can be applied again to the United States in more recent years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The popularity of local color literature before the Spanish-American War , the steady currency of the Lincoln myth , the increased emphasis on the frontier west in our mass media are cases in point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nor is it an accident that baseball , growing into the national game in the last 75 years , has become a microcosm of American life , that learned societies such as the American Folklore Society and the American Historical Association were founded in the 1880's , or that courses in American literature , American civilization , American anything have swept our school and college curricula .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of course , nationalism has really outlived its usefulness in a country as world oriented as ours , and its continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the twentieth century United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet nationalism has lost few of its charms for the historian , writer or man in the street .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is an understandable paradox that most American history and most American literature is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic point of view at the very time America is spreading her dominion over palm and pine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">After all , the average American as he lies and waits for the enemy in Korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or her plight is the result of a complex of personal , economic and governmental actions far beyond the normal citizen 's comprehension and control .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Anyone 's identification with an international struggle , whether warlike or peaceful , requires absurd oversimplification and intense emotional involvement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such identification comes for each group in each crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate national heroes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In America , such self-deception has served a particularly useful purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A heterogeneous people have needed it to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and ever changing land .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But we must never forget , most of the appropriate heroes and their legends were created overnight , to answer immediate needs , almost always with conscious aims and ends .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Parson Weems 's George Washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of the uniting States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Abraham Lincoln emerged as an incarnation of the national Constitution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Robert E. Lee represented the dignity needed by a rebelling confederacy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And their roles are paralleled by those of Patrick Henry , Nathan Hale , Andrew Jackson , Davy Crockett , Theodore Roosevelt and many , many more .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore , the scholar , as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years , will be mindful of two facts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">1 ) Most of the legends that are created to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are not folk legends at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">2 ) The concept that an `` American national folklore '' exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group of people preserve , vary and recreate through oral transmission .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It has come to mean myths , legends , tales , songs , proverbs , riddles , superstitions , rhymes and such literary forms of expression .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Related to written literature , and often remaining temporarily frozen in written form , it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies , it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our folk heritage , the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Enthusiastically , Americans have swept subliterary and bogus materials like Paul Bunyan tales , Abe Lincoln anecdotes and labor union songs up as true products of our American oral tradition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nor have we remembered that in the melting pot of America the hundreds of isolated and semi isolated ethnic , regional and occupational groups did not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education and industrialization had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as a means of carrying culturally significant material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Naturally , such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make money or fan patriotism by means of folklore .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">That much of what he calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As long as his material is Americana , can in some way be ascribed to the masses and appears `` democratic '' to his audience , he remains satisfied .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From all this we can now see that two streams of development run through the history of twentieth century American folklore .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the one side we have the university professors and their students , trained in Teutonic methods of research , who have sought out , collected and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic , regional and occupational groups that make up this nation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other we have the flag wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been willing to use any patriotic , `` frontier western '' or colonial material willy-nilly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Unfortunately , few of the artists ( writers , movie producers , dramatists and musicians ) who have used American folklore since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams even in the most general of ways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After all , the field is large , difficult to define and seldom taught properly to American undergraduates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition , this country has been settled by many peoples of many heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly , in an age of print and easy communication , within an ever expanding and changing society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The problems confuse even the experts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For that matter , the experts themselves are a mixed breed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Anthropologists , housewives , historians and such by profession , they approach their discipline as amateurs , collectors , commercial propagandists , analysts or some combination of the four .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They have widely varying backgrounds and aims .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They have little `` esprit de corps '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The outlook for the amateur , for instance , is usually dependent on his fondness for local history or for the picturesque .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His love of folklore has romanticism in it , and he does n't care much about the dollar sign or the footnote .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Folklore is his hobby , and he , all too rightly , wishes it to remain as such .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The amateur is closely related to the collector , who is actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The collector enjoys the contact with rural life ; he hunts folklore for the very `` field and stream '' reasons that many persons hunt game ; and only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has located .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Fundamentally , both these types , the amateur and the collector , are uncritical and many of them do n't distinguish well between real folklore and bogus material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But there are also the commercial propagandists and the analysts - one dominated by money , the other by nineteenth century German scholarship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both are primarily concerned with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector has found .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond the sewage system and the electric light lines .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The commercial propagandist , who can n't afford to be critical , gets along well with the amateur , from whom he feeds , but he frequently steps on the analyst 's toes by refusing to keep his material genuine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His standards are , of course , completely foreign to those of the analyst .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To both the amateur and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul , lacks appreciation with his endless probings and classifications .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dominated by the vicious circle of the university promotion system , the analyst looks down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups , although he cannot deny his debt to the collector .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The knowledge that most Americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The work done by the analysts , the men who really know what folklore is all about , has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort and reaches a limited , learned audience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Publishers want books that will sell , recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to ears used to hillbilly and jazz music , grade and high schools want quaint , but moral , material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The analyst is apt to be too honest to fit in .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As a result , most people do n't have more than a vague idea what folklore actually is ; they see it as a potpourri of charming , moral legends and patriotic anecdotes , with a superstition or remedy thrown in here and there .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the hundred odd folklore courses given in the United States survive on sentiment and nationalism alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If one wishes to discuss a literary figure who uses folklore in his work , the first thing he must realize is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant American public .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And while every writer must be dealt with as a special case , the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions about each .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Does the writer know the difference between an `` ersatz '' ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial effect or does he leave it pure ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Is the writer propagandistic ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an America that was ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of American attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they may be ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When he gets the answers to his questions he will be discouraged .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the first place , a good many writers who are said to use folklore , do not , unless one counts an occasional superstition or tale .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Robert Frost , for instance , writes about rural life in New England , but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in his poems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This has not , however , prevented publishers from labeling him a `` folk poet '' , simply because he is a rural one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the second place , a large number of writers , making a more direct claim than Frost to being `` folk writers '' of one sort or another , clearly make no distinctions between genuine and bogus material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Stephen Vincent Benet 's John Brown's Body comes immediately to mind in this connection , as does John Steinbeck 's The Grapes of Wrath and Carl Sandburg 's The People, Yes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The last two writers introduce strong political bias into their works , and not unlike the union leaders that we will discuss soon , see folklore as a reservoir of protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Folklore , as used by such writers , really reflects images engraved into it by the very person using it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The folk are simply not homogeneous with respect to nation or political attitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , there is much evidence to indicate they do n't care a bit about anything beyond their particular regional , ethnic and occupational limits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , with a reading public that longs for `` the good old days '' and with an awareness of our expanding international interests , it is easy for the Benets to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of Americana , real or fake , and it is easy for the Steinbecks and Sandburgs to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform into the minds of the folk .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Color was delayed until 1935 , the wide screen until the early fifties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction of the primitive movies of the nineties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each film consisted of fifty feet , which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As long as audiences came to see the movement , there seemed little reason to adventure further .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can still be found in such urban areas as Times Square .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Brief snips of actual events were shown : parades , dances , street scenes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The sensational and frightening enjoyed popularity :
a train rushes straight at the audience , or a great wave threatens to break over the seats .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An early Edison production was The Execution of Mary Queen of Scotts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The unfortunate queen mounted the scaffold ; the headsman swung his axe ; the head dropped off ; end of film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An early film by a competitor of the Wizard of Menlo Park simply showed a long kiss performed by two actors of the contemporary stage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the field of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective as audience boredom , and the first decade of the new device was not over before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded , one minute shows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In response , the industry allowed the discovery of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies the essential form they have had to this day .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Despite the sheer beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries , art films , and travelogues , despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development as Cinerama , the movies are at heart a form of fiction , like the play , the novel , or the short story .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , the most artistically successful of the nonfiction films have invariably borrowed the narrative form from the fiction feature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus such great American documentaries as The River and The Plow That Broke the Plains were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men , a French magician , Georges Melies , and an American employee of Edison , Edwin S. Porter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Of the two , Porter is justly the better known , for he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the first step toward fashioning a language of film , toward making the motion picture the intricate , efficient time machine that it has remained since , even in the most inept hands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Melies , however , out of his professional instincts as a magician , discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain part of the vocabulary of film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of these is the `` dissolve '' , which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As the first scene begins to fade , the succeeding scene begins to appear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For a moment or two , both scenes are present simultaneously , one growing weaker , one growing stronger .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In a series of fairy tales and fantasies , Melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped to tell a straightforward story , with beginning , middle and end , complications , resolutions , climaxes , and conclusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Immediately , the film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Physically , a movie is possible because a series of images is projected one at a time at such a speed that the eye `` remembers '' the one that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Linking the smoothly changing images together , the eye itself endows them with the illusion of movement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The `` projection '' time of painting and sculpture is highly subjective , varying from person to person and even varying for a given person on different occasions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">So is the time of the novel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The drama in the theater and the concert in the hall both have a fixed time , but the time is fixed by the director and the players , the conductor and the instrumentalists , subject , therefore , to much variation , as record collectors well know .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The time of the motion picture is fixed absolutely .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The film consists of a series of still , transparent photographs , or `` frames '' , 35 - mm.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">- wide .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each frame comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected on the screen , at the rate , for silent movies , of 16 frames per second , and , for sound films , 24 frames per second .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This is the rate of projection ; it is also the rate of photographing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Time is built into the motion picture , which cannot exist without time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Now time is also the concern of the fictional narrative , which is , at its simplest , the story of an action with , usually , a beginning , a middle , and an end - elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The `` moving '' picture of the train or the wave coming at the audience is , to be sure , more intense than a still picture of the same subject , but the difference is really one of degree ; the cinematic element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In narrative , time is essential , as it is in film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Almost everything about the movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created and maintained between narrative time and film time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This discovery of Melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling , magician 's tricks produced on film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was Porter , however , who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the half century of film history that has since ensued .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The movie was The Great Train Robbery and its effects on the young industry and art were all but incalculable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Overnight , for one thing , Porter 's film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Great Train Robbery is a one reel film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One reel - from eight to twelve minutes - became the standard length from the year of Robbery , 1903 , until Griffith shattered that limit forever with Birth of a Nation in 1915 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The reel itself became and still is the standard of measure for the movies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The material of the Porter film is simplicity itself ; much of it has continued to be used over the years and the heart of it - good guys and bad guys in the old West - pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950's .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A band of robbers enters a railroad station , overpowers and ties up the telegraph operator , holds up the train and escapes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A posse is formed and pursues the robbers , who , having made their escape , are whooping it up with some wild , wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The robbers run from the hide-out , take cover in a wooded declivity , and are shot dead by the posse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a finale is appended a close-up of one of the band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All this is simple enough , but in telling the story Porter did two important things that had not been done before .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Each scene is shot straight through , as had been the universal custom , from a camera fixed in a single position , but in the outdoor scenes , especially in the capture and destruction of the outlaws , Porter 's camera position breaks , necessarily , with the camera position standard until then , which had been , roughly , that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at a play .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the plane of the film in the camera or on the screen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the change , at first sight , seems minor , we may recall that it took the Italian painters about two hundred years to make an analogous change , and the Italian painters , by universal consent , were the most brilliant group of geniuses any art has seen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In that apparently simple shift Porter opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of art as well as a mechanical recording device .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He did more than that .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He revealed the potential value of the `` cut '' as the basic technique in the art of the film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Cutting , of course , takes place automatically in the creation of a film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The meaning of the word is quite physical , to begin with .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The physical film is cut with a knife at the end of one complete sequence , and the cut edge is joined physically , by cement , to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If , as a home movie maker , you shoot the inevitable footage of your child taking its first steps , you have merely recorded an historical event .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If , in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends , you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child 's grandmother watching this event , you have begun to be an artist in film ; you are employing the basic technique of film ; you are cutting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is what Porter did .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As the robbers leave the looted train , the film suddenly cuts back to the station , where the telegrapher 's little daughter arrives with her father 's dinner pail only to find him bound on the floor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">She dashes around in alarm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The two events are taking place at the same time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Time and space have both become cinematic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We leap from event to event - including the formation of the posse - even though the events , in `` reality '' are taking place not in sequence but simultaneously , and not near each other but at a considerable distance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The `` chase '' as a standard film device probably dates from The Great Train Robbery , and there is a reason for the continued popularity of the device .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The chase in itself is a narrative ; it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands cutting - both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage of the journey of both .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The simple , naked idea of one man chasing another is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other form of fiction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The cowboy films , the cops and robbers films , and the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence ; these films and these sequences are also seeking out - instinctively or by design - the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full potential of the new form and to make it an art .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The man was D.W. Griffith .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When he came to the movies - more or less by accident - they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking for an idle few minutes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In about seven years Griffith either invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource at the disposal of the film maker .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Before he was forty Griffith had created the art of the film .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Not that there had not been attempts , mostly European , to do exactly that .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But in general the European efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly emerging language of the film itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Staggeringly condensed versions of famous novels and famous plays were presented .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Great actors and actresses - the most notable being Sarah Bernhardt - were hired to repeat their stage performances before the camera .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In all of this extensive and expensive effort , the camera was downgraded to the status of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor or by the author .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The phonograph today , for all its high fidelity and stereophonic sound , is precisely what the early art purveyors in the movies wished to make of the camera .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Not surprisingly , this approach did not work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques in the early years of the century and some interesting records of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But no art at all was born of the art effort in the early movies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Northern liberals are the chief supporters of civil rights and of integration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They have also led the nation in the direction of a welfare state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And both in their objectives of non-discrimination and of social progress they have had ranged against them the Southerners who are called Bourbons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The name presumably derives from the French royal house which never learned and never forgot ; since Bourbon whiskey , though of Kentucky origin , is at least as much favored by liberals in the North as by conservatives in the South .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The nature of the opposition between liberals and Bourbons is too little understood in the North .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The race problem has tended to obscure other , less emotional , issues which may fundamentally be even more divisive .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The answer is of course yes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For the family is the simplest example of just such a unit , composed of people , which gives us both some immunity from , and a way of dealing with , other people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Social invention did not have to await social theory any more than use of the warmth of a fire had to await Lavoisier or the buoyant protection of a boat the formulations of Archimedes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it has been during the last two centuries , during the scientific revolution , that our independence from the physical environment has made the most rapid strides .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We have ample light when the sun sets ; the temperature of our homes is independent of the seasons ; we fly through the air , although gravity pulls us down ; the range of our voice ignores distance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At what stage are social sciences then ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Is the future of psychology akin to the rich future of physics at the time of Newton ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is a haunting resemblance between the notion of cause in Copernicus and in Freud .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And it is certainly no slight to either of them to compare both their achievements and their impact .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Political theoretical understanding , although almost at a standstill during this century , did develop during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries , and resulted in a flood of inventions which increased the possibility for man to coexist with man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Constitutional government , popular vote , trial by jury , public education , labor unions , cooperatives , communes , socialized ownership , world courts , and the veto power in world councils are but a few examples .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Most of these , with horrible exceptions , were conceived as is a ship , not as an attempt to quell the ocean of mankind , nor to deny its force , but as a means to survive and enjoy it .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just as present technology had to await the explanations of physics , so one might expect that social invention will follow growing sociological understanding .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We are desperately in the need of such invention , for man is still very much at the mercy of man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In fact the accumulation of the hardware of destruction is day by day increasing our fear of each other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I want , therefore , to discuss a second and quite different fruit of science , the connection between scientific understanding and fear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There are certainly large areas of understanding in the human sciences which in themselves and even without political invention can help to dispel our present fears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Lucretius has remarked : `` The reason why all Mortals are so gripped by fear is that they see all sorts of things happening in the earth and sky with no discernable cause , and these they attribute to the will of God '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Perhaps things were even worse then .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is difficult to reconstruct the primeval fears of man .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The bombs are as harmless as an automobile in a garage .</MPQASENT>
