<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They are in general those fears that once seemed to have been amenable to prayer or ritual .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They include both individual fears and collective ones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They arise in situations in which one believes that what happens depends not only on the external world , but also on the precise pattern of behavior of the individual or group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Often it is recognized that all the details of the pattern may not be essential to the outcome but , because the pattern was empirically determined and not developed through theoretical understanding , one is never quite certain which behavior elements are effective , and the whole pattern becomes ritualized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Yet often fear persists because , even with the most rigid ritual , one is never quite free from the uneasy feeling that one might make some mistake or that in every previous execution one had been unaware of the really decisive act .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To say that science had reduced many such fears merely reiterates the obvious and frequent statement that science eliminated much of magic and superstition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But a somewhat more detailed analysis of this process may be illuminating .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The frequently postulated antique worry that the daylight hours might dwindle to complete darkness apparently gave rise to a ritual and celebration which we still recognize .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is curious that even centuries of repetition of the yearly cycle did not induce a sufficient degree of confidence to allow people to abandon the ceremonies of the winter solstice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This and other fears of the solar system have disappeared gradually , first , with the Ptolemaic system and its built-in concept of periodicity and then , more firmly , with the Newtonian innovation of an universal force that could account quantitatively for both terrestrial and celestial motions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This understanding provides a very simple example of the fact that one can eliminate fear without instituting any controls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , although we have dispelled the fear , we have not necessarily assured ourselves that there are no dangers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is still the remote possibility of planetoid collision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A meteor could fall on San Francisco .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Solar activities could presumably bring long periods of flood or drought .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our understanding of the solar system has taught us to replace our former elaborate rituals with the appropriate action which , in this case , amounts to doing nothing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet we no longer feel uneasy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This almost trivial example is nevertheless suggestive , for there are some elements in common between the antique fear that the days would get shorter and shorter and our present fear of war .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We , in our country , think of war as an external threat which , if it occurs , will not be primarily of our own doing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And yet we obviously also believe that the avoidance of the disaster depends in some obscure or at least uncertain way on the details of how we behave .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What elements of our behavior are decisive ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our weapons production , our world prestige , our ideas of democracy , our actions of trust or stubbornness or secrecy or espionage ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We have staved off a war and , since our behavior has involved all these elements , we can only keep adding to our ritual without daring to abandon any part of it , since we have not the slightest notion which parts are effective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I think that we are here also talking of the kind of fear that a young boy has for a group of boys who are approaching at night along the streets of a large city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If an automobile were approaching him , he would know what was required of him , even though he might not be able to act quickly enough .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He does not know whether to look up or look aside , to put his hands in his pockets or to clench them at his side , to cross the street , or to continue on the same side .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When confronted with a drunk or an insane person I have no notion of what any one of them might do to me or to himself or to others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I believe that what I do has some effect on his actions and I have learned , in a way , to commune with drunks , but certainly my actions seem to resemble more nearly the performance of a rain dance than the carrying out of an experiment in physics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I am usually filled with an uneasiness that through some unwitting slip all hell may break loose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our inability to explain why certain people are fond of us frequently induces the same kind of ritual and malaise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We are forced , in our behavior towards others , to adopt empirically successful patterns in toto because we have such a minimal understanding of their essential elements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our collective policies , group and national , are similarly based on voodoo , but here we often lack even the empirically successful rituals and are still engaged in determining them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We use terms from our personal experience with individuals such as `` trust '' , `` cheat '' , and `` get tough '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We talk about national character in the same way that Copernicus talked of the compulsions of celestial bodies to move in circles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We perform elaborate international exhortations and ceremonies with virtually no understanding of social cause and effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Small wonder , then , that we fear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The achievements which dispelled our fears of the cosmos took place three centuries ago .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What additional roles has the scientific understanding of the 19th and 20th centuries played ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the physical sciences , these achievements concern electricity , chemistry , and atomic physics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the life sciences , there has been an enormous increase in our understanding of disease , in the mechanisms of heredity , and in bio - and physiological chemistry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The major effect of these advances appears to lie in the part they have played in the industrial revolution and in the tools which scientific understanding has given us to build and manipulate a more protective environment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition , our way of dealing directly with natural phenomena has also changed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even in domains where detailed and predictive understanding is still lacking , but where some explanations are possible , as with lightning and weather and earthquakes , the appropriate kind of human action has been more adequately indicated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apparently the population as a whole eventually acquires enough confidence in the explanations of the scientists to modify its procedures and its fears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">How and why this process occurs would provide an interesting separate subject for study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In some areas , the progress is slower than in others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In agriculture , for example , despite the advances in biology , elaborate rituals tend to persist along with a continued sense of the imminence of some natural disaster .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In child care , the opposite extreme prevails ; procedures change rapidly and parental confidence probably exceeds anything warranted by established psychological theory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There are many domains in which understanding has brought about widespread and quite appropriate reduction in ritual and fear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Much of the former extreme uneasiness associated with visions and hallucinations and with death has disappeared .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The persistent horror of having a malformed child has , I believe , been reduced , not because we have gained any control over this misfortune , but precisely because we have learned that we have so little control over it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , the recent warnings about the use of X-rays have introduced fears and ambiguities of action which now require more detailed understanding , and thus in this instance , science has momentarily aggravated our fears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , insofar as science generates any fear , it stems not so much from scientific prowess and gadgets but from the fact that new unanswered questions arise , which , until they are understood , create uncertainty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Perhaps the most illuminating example of the reduction of fear through understanding is derived from our increased knowledge of the nature of disease .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The situation with regard to our attitude and `` control '' of disease contains close analogies to problems confronting us with respect to people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The fear of disease was formerly very much the kind of fear I have tried to describe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is worth dwelling in some detail on the crisis of this story , because it brings together a number of characteristic elements and makes of them a curious , riddling compound obscurely but centrally significant for Mann 's work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The wife , Amra , and her lover are both savagely portrayed , she as incarnate sensuality , `` voluptuous '' and `` indolent '' , possibly `` a mischief maker '' , with `` a kind of luxurious cunning '' to set against her apparent simplicity , her `` bird like brain '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">La^utner , for his part , `` belonged to the present-day race of small artists , who do not demand the utmost of themselves '' , and the bitter description of the type includes such epithets as `` wretched little poseurs '' , the devastating indictment `` they do not know how to be wretched decently and in order '' , and the somewhat extreme prophecy , so far not fulfilled : `` They will be destroyed '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The trick these two play upon Jacoby reveals their want not simply of decency but of imagination as well .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">His appearance as Lizzy evokes not amusement but horror in the audience ; it is a spectacle absolutely painful , an epiphany of the suffering flesh unredeemed by spirit , untouched by any spirit other than abasement and humiliation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">At the same time the multiple transvestitism involved - the fat man as girl and as baby , as coquette pretending to be a baby - touches for a moment horrifyingly upon the secret sources of a life like Jacoby 's , upon the sinister dreams which form the sources of any human life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The music which La^utner has composed for this episode is for the most part `` rather pretty and perfectly banal '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But it is characteristic of him , we are told , `` his little artifice '' , to be able to introduce `` into a fairly vulgar and humorous piece of hackwork a sudden phrase of genuine creative art '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And this occurs now , at the refrain of Jacoby 's song - at the point , in fact , of the name `` Lizzy '' - ; a modulation described as `` almost a stroke of genius '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` A miracle , a revelation , it was like a curtain suddenly torn away to reveal something nude '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is this modulation which reveals to Jacoby his own frightful abjection and , simultaneously , his wife 's infidelity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By the same means he perceives this fact as having communicated itself to the audience ; he collapses , and dies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the work of every artist , I suppose , there may be found one or more moments which strike the student as absolutely decisive , ultimately emblematic of what it is all about ; not less strikingly so for being mysterious , as though some deeply hidden constatation of thoughts were enciphered in a single image , a single moment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The horrifying humor , the specifically sexual embarrassment of the joke gone wrong , the monstrous image of the fat man dressed up as a whore dressing up as a baby ; the epiphany of that quivering flesh ; the bringing together around it of the secret liaison between indolent , mindless sensuality and sharp , shrewd talent , cleverness with an occasional touch of genius ( which , however , does not know `` how to attack the problem of suffering '' ) ; the miraculous way in which music , revelation and death are associated in a single instant - all this seems a triumph of art , a rather desperate art , in itself ; beyond itself , also , it evokes numerous and distant resonances from the entire body of Mann 's work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When I try to work out my reasons for feeling that this passage is of critical significance , I come up with the following ideas , which I shall express very briefly here and revert to in a later essay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Love is the crucial dilemma of experience for Mann 's heroes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The dramatic construction of his stories characteristically turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled and forbidden to love .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The release , the freedom , involved in loving another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible ; and the motion toward it brings disaster .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This prohibition on love has an especially poignant relation to art ; it is particularly the artist ( Tonio Kro^ger , Aschenbach , Leverku^hn ) who suffers from it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem of the `` breakthrough '' in the realm of art .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Again , the sufferings and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another with childhood , with the figure of a child .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Finally , the theatrical ( and perversely erotic ) notions of dressing up , cosmetics , disguise , and especially change of costume ( or singularity of costume , as with Cipolla ) , are characteristically associated with the catastrophes of Mann 's stories .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We shall return to these statements and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of Jacoby , at the moment of his collapse , all these elements come together in prophetic parody .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Professionally a lawyer , that is to say associated with dignity , reserve , discipline , with much that is essentially middle-class , he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself dressed up , disguised - that is , paradoxically , revealed - as a child , and , worse , as a whore masquerading as a child .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That this abandonment takes place on a stage , during an ' artistic ' performance , is enough to associate Jacoby with art , and to bring down upon him the punishment for art ; that is , he is suspect , guilty , punishable , as is anyone in Mann 's stories who produces illusion , and this is true even though the constant elements of the artist nature , technique , magic , guilt and suffering , are divided in this story between Jacoby and La^utner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It appears that the dominant tendency of Mann 's early tales , however pictorial or even picturesque the surface , is already toward the symbolic , the emblematic , the expressionistic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a certain perfectly definite way , the method and the theme of his stories are one and the same .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Something of this can be learned from `` The Way to the Churchyard '' ( 1901 ) , an anecdote about an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die of a stroke or seizure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is no more `` plot '' than that ; only slightly more , perhaps , than a newspaper account of such an incident would give .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The artistic interest , then , lies in what the encounter may be made to represent , in the power of some central significance to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The first sentence , with its platitudinous irony , announces an emblematic intent : `` The way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad , ran beside it all the way to the end ; that is to say , to the churchyard '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The highroad , one might say at first , belongs to life , while the way to the churchyard belongs to death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But that is too simple , and won't hold up .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As the first sentence suggests , both roads belong to death in the end .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But the highroad , according to the description of its traffic , belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death , while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life :
a suffering form , an existence wholly comprised in the awareness of death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , on the highroad , a troop of soldiers `` marched in their own dust and sang '' , while on the footpath one man walks alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This man 's isolation is not merely momentary , it is permanent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is a widower , his three children are dead , he has no one left on earth ; also he is a drunk , and has lost his job on that account .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His name is Praisegod Piepsam , and he is rather fully described as to his clothing and physiognomy in a way which relates him to a sinister type in the author 's repertory - he is a forerunner of those enigmatic strangers in `` Death in Venice '' , for example , who represent some combination of cadaver , exotic , and psychopomp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This strange person quarrels with a cyclist because the latter is using the path rather than the highroad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The cyclist , a sufficiently commonplace young fellow , is not named but identified simply as `` Life '' - that and a license number , which Piepsam uses in addressing him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Life '' points out that `` everybody uses this path '' , and starts to ride on .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Piepsam tries to stop him by force , receives a push in the chest from `` Life '' , and is left standing in impotent and growing rage , while a crowd begins to gather .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His rage assumes a religious form ; that is , on the basis of his own sinfulness and abject wretchedness , Piepsam becomes a prophet who in his ecstasy and in the name of God imprecates doom on Life - not only the cyclist now , but the audience , the world , as well : `` all you light-headed breed '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This passion brings on a fit which proves fatal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Then an ambulance comes along , and they drive Praisegod Piepsam away .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is simple enough , but several more points of interest may be mentioned as relevant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The season , between spring and summer , belongs to life in its carefree aspect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Piepsam 's fatal rage arises not only because he cannot stop the cyclist , but also because God will not stop him ; as Piepsam says to the crowd in his last moments : `` His justice is not of this world '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Life is further characterized , in antithesis to Piepsam , as animal : the image of a dog , which appears at several places , is first given as the criterion of amiable , irrelevant interest aroused by life considered simply as a spectacle : a dog in a wagon is `` admirable '' , `` a pleasure to contemplate '' ; another wagon has no dog , and therefore is `` devoid of interest '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Piepsam calls the cyclist `` cur '' and `` puppy '' among other things , and at the crisis of his fit a little fox-terrier stands before him and howls into his face .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The ambulance is drawn by two `` charming '' little horses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Piepsam is not , certainly , religious in any conventional sense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His religiousness is intimately , or dialectically , connected with his sinfulness ; the two may in fact be identical .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">His unsuccessful strivings to give up drink are represented as religious strivings ; he keeps a bottle in a wardrobe at home , and `` before this wardrobe Praisegod Piepsam had before now gone literally on his knees , and in his wrestlings had bitten his tongue - and still in the end capitulated '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The cyclist , by contrast , blond and blue-eyed , is simply unreflective , unproblematic Life , `` blithe and carefree '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` He made no claims to belong to the great and mighty of this earth '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Piepsam is grotesque , a disturbing parody ; his end is ridiculous and trivial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is `` a man raving mad on the way to the churchyard '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But he is more interesting than the others , the ones who come from the highroad to watch him , more interesting than Life considered as a cyclist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And if I have gone into so much detail about so small a work , that is because it is also so typical a work , representing the germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in Mann 's writing :
the crude sketch of Piepsam contains , in its critical , destructive and self-destructive tendencies , much that is enlarged and illuminated in the figures of , for instance , Naphta and Leverku^hn .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for `` realism '' , anticipates a kind of musical composition , as well as a kind of fictional composition , in which , as Leverku^hn says , `` there shall be nothing unthematic '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It resembles , too , pictures such as Du^rer and Bruegel did , in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial proves on inspection to be also literary , the representation of a proverb , for example , or a deadly sin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Gladius Dei '' ( 1902 ) resembles `` The Way to the Churchyard '' in its representation of a conflict between light and dark , between `` Life '' and a spirit of criticism , negation , melancholy , but it goes considerably further in characterizing the elements of this conflict .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The monk Savonarola , brought over from the Renaissance and placed against the background of Munich at the turn of the century , protests against the luxurious works displayed in the art shop of M. Bluthenzweig ; in particular against a Madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled , according to gossip , upon the painter 's mistress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Hieronymus , like Piepsam , makes his protest quite in vain , and his rejection , though not fatal , is ridiculous and humiliating ; he is simply thrown out of the shop by the porter .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Office of Business Economics ( OBE ) of the U.S. Department of Commerce provides basic measures of the national economy and current analysis of short-run changes in the economic situation and business outlook .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Small Business Administration ( SBA ) provides guidance and advice on sources of technical information relating to small business management and research and development of products .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Practical management problems and their suggested solutions are dealt with in a series of SBA publications .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They are written by specialists in numerous types of business enterprises , cover a wide range of subjects , and are directed to the needs and interests of the small firm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">SBA offers Administrative Management Courses , which are designed to improve the management efficiency and `` know-how '' of small business concerns within a community .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Through the SBA 's Management Counseling Program , practical , personalized advice on sound management principles is available upon request to both prospective and established businessmen in a community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One-day conferences covering some specific phase of business management , also part of the continuing activities of the Small Business Administration , aid community economic development programs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These short , `` streamlined '' meetings usually are sponsored by local banks , Chambers of Commerce , trade associations , or other civic organizations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Production specialists in SBA regional offices are available to help individual small business concerns with technical production problems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Guidance and advice are available on new product research and development ; new product potential ; processing methods ; product and market developments ; new industrial uses for raw , semi-processed and waste materials ; and industrial uses for agricultural products .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">SBA serves also as a clearing house for information on products and processes particularly adaptable for exploitation by small firms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This may be helpful in improving the competitive position of established firms through diversification and expansion or through more economical utilization of plant capacity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Production specialists are available in SBA regional offices to help individual small business concerns with technical production problems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These problems frequently arise where a firm is making items for the Government not directly along the lines of its normal civilian business or where the Government specifications require operations that the firm did not understand when it undertook the contract .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Under this program , property sales specialists in the Small Business Administration regional offices help small business concerns to locate Federal property for sale and insure that small firms have the opportunity to bid competitively for surplus personal and real property and certain natural resources , including timber from the national forests .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Proposed property sales of general interest to small business concerns are publicized through SBA regional news releases , and by `` flyers '' directed to the small business concerns .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Evidence that other sources of financing are unavailable must be provided .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">SBA business loans are of two types : `` participation '' and `` direct '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Participation loans are those made jointly by the SBA and banks or other private lending institutions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Direct loans are those made by SBA alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To qualify for either type of loan , an applicant must be a small business or approved small business `` pool '' and must meet certain credit requirements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A small business is defined as one which is independently owned and operated and which is not dominant in its field .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition , the SBA uses such criteria as number of employees and dollar volume of the business .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The credit requirements stipulate that the applicant must have the ability to operate the business successfully and have enough capital in the business so that , with loan assistance from the SBA , it will be able to operate on a sound financial basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A proposed loan must be for sound purposes or sufficiently secured so as to assure a reasonable chance of repayment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The record of past earnings and prospects for the future must indicate it has the ability to repay the loan out of current and anticipated income .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The amount which may be borrowed from the SBA depends on how much is required to carry out the intended purpose of the loan .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The maximum loan which SBA may make to any one borrower is $ 350000 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Business loans generally are repayable in regular installments - usually monthly , including interest at the rate of 5 - 1/2 percent per annum on the unpaid balance - and have a maximum maturity of 10 years ; the term of loans for working capital is 6 years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For further information , contact SBA Regional Offices in Atlanta , Ga. ; Boston , Mass. ; Chicago , Ill. ; Cleveland , Ohio ; Dallas , Tex. ; Denver , Colo. ; Detroit , Mich. ; Kansas City , Mo. ; Los Angeles , Calif. ; Minneapolis , Minn. ; New York , N.Y. ; Philadelphia , Pa. ; Richmond , Va. ; San Francisco , Calif. ; and Seattle , Wash. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Branch Offices are located in other large cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Small Business Administration , What It Is , What It Does ; SBA Business Loans and Small Business Pooling are available , on request , from Small Business Administration , Washington 25 , D.C. , and its regional offices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Farm Credit Administration , an independent agency located within the Department of Agriculture , supervises and coordinates a cooperative credit system for agriculture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The system is composed of three credit services , Federal Land Banks and National Farm Loan Associations , Federal Intermediate ( short-term ) Credit Banks , and Banks for Cooperatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This system provides long - and short-term credit to farmers and their cooperative marketing , purchasing , and business service organizations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a source of investment capital , the system is beneficial to local communities and encourages the development of industries in rural areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The credit provdied by the first two services in the system outlined above is primarily for general agricultural purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The third credit service , Banks for Cooperatives , exists under authority of the Farm Credit Act of 1933 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Banks for Cooperatives were established to provide a permanent source of credit on a sound basis for farmers ' cooperatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Three distinct classes of loans are made available to farmers ' cooperatives by the Banks for Cooperatives :
Commodity loans , operating capital loans , and facility loans .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To be eligible to borrow from a Bank for Cooperatives , a cooperative must be an association in which farmers act together in processing and marketing farm products , purchasing farm supplies , or furnishing farm business services , and must meet the requirements set forth in the Farm Credit Act of 1933 , as amended .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Interest rates are determined by the board of directors of the bank with the approval of the Farm Credit Administration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For further information , contact the Bank for Cooperatives serving the region , or the Farm Credit Administration , Research and Information Division , Washington 25 , D.C. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Available , on request , from U.S. Department of Agriculture , Washington 25 , D.C. , are : Cooperative Farm Credit Can Assist in Rural Development ( Circular No. 44 ) , and The Cooperative Farm Credit System ( Circular No. 36 - A ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To encourage exploration for domestic sources of minerals , the Office of Minerals Exploration ( OME ) of the U.S. Department of the Interior offers financial assistance to firms and individuals who desire to explore their properties or claims for 1 or more of the 32 mineral commodities listed in the OME regulations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This help is offered to applicants who ordinarily would not undertake the exploration under present conditions or circumstances at their sole expense and who are unable to obtain funds from commercial sources on reasonable terms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each applicant is required to own or have sufficient interest in the property to be explored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Government will contract with an eligible applicant to pay up to one-half of the cost of approved exploration work as it progresses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The applicant pays the rest of the cost , but his own time spent on the work and charges for the use of equipment which he owns may be applied toward his share of the cost .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Funds contributed by the Government are repaid by a royalty on production from the property .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If nothing is produced , there is no obligation to repay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A 5 - percent royalty is paid on any production during the period the contract is in effect ; if the Government certifies that production may be possible from the property , the royalty obligation continues for the 10 - year period usually specified in the contract or until the Government 's contribution is repaid with interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The royalty applies to both principal and interest , but it never exceeds 5 percent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Information , application forms , and assistance in filing may be obtained from the Office of Minerals Exploration , U.S. Department of the Interior , Washington 25 , D.C. , or from the appropriate regional office listed below :
It has recently become practical to use the radio emission of the moon and planets as a new source of information about these bodies and their atmospheres .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The results of present observations of the thermal radio emission of the moon are consistent with the very low thermal conductivity of the surface layer which was derived from the variation in the infrared emission during eclipses ( e.g. , Garstung , 1958 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When sufficiently accurate and complete measurements are available , it will be possible to set limits on the thermal and electrical characteristics of the surface and subsurface materials of the moon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Observations of the radio emission of a planet which has an extensive atmosphere will probe the atmosphere to a greater extent than those using shorter wave lengths and should in some cases give otherwise unobtainable information about the characteristics of the solid surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Radio observations of Venus and Jupiter have already supplied unexpected experimental data on the physical conditions of these planets .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The observed intensity of the radio emission of Venus is much higher than the expected thermal intensity , although the spectrum indicated by measurements at wave lengths near 3 cm and 10 cm is like that of a black body at about 600 ` K .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This result suggests a very high temperature at the solid surface of the planet , although there is the possibility that the observed radiation may be a combination of both thermal and non thermal components and that the observed spectrum is that of a black body merely by coincidence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the case of Jupiter , the radio emission spectrum is definitely not like the spectrum of a black-body radiator , and it seems very likely that the radiation reaching the earth is a combination of thermal radiation from the atmosphere and non thermal components .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of the remaining planets , only Mars and Saturn have been observed as radio sources , and not very much information is available .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mars has been observed twice at about 3 - cm wave length , and the intensity of the observed radiation is in reasonable agreement with the thermal radiation which might be predicted on the basis of the known temperature of Mars .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The low intensity of the radiation from Saturn has limited observations , but again the measured radiation seems to be consistent with a thermal origin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No attempts to measure the radio emission of the remaining planets have been reported , and , because of their distances , small diameters , or low temperatures , the thermal radiation at radio wave lengths reaching the earth from these sources is expected to be of very low intensity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In spite of this , the very large radio reflectors and improved amplifying techniques which are now becoming available should make it possible to observe the radio emission of most of the planets in a few years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The study of the radio emission of the moon and planets began with the detection of the thermal radiation of the moon at 1.25 - cm wave length by Dicke and Beringer ( 1946 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This was followed by a comprehensive series of observations of the 1.25 - cm emission of the moon over three lunar cycles by Piddington and Minnett ( 1949 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They deduced from their measurements that the radio emission from the whole disk of the moon varied during a lunation in a roughly sinusoidal fashion ; that the amplitude of the variation was considerably less than the amplitude of the variation in the infrared emission as measured by Pettit and Nicholson ( 1930 ) and Pettit ( 1935 ) ; and that the maximum of the radio emission came about 3 - 1 2 days after Full Moon , which is again in contrast to the infrared emission , which reaches its maximum at Full Moon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Piddington and Minnett explained their observations by pointing out that rocklike materials which are likely to make up the surface of the moon would be partially transparent to radio waves , although opaque to infrared radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The infrared emission could then be assumed to originate at the surface of the moon , while the radio emission originates at some depth beneath the surface , where the temperature variation due to solar radiation is reduced in amplitude and shifted in phase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the absorption of radio waves in rocklike material varies with wave length , it should be possible to sample the temperature variation at different depths beneath the surface and possibly detect changes in the structure or composition of the lunar surface material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The radio emission of a planet was first detected in 1955 , when Burke and Franklin ( 1955 ) identified the origin of interference like radio noise on their records at about 15 meters wave length as emission from Jupiter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This sporadic type of planetary radiation is discussed by Burke ( chap.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">13 ) and Gallet ( chap.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">14 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Steady radiation which was presumably of thermal origin was observed from Venus at 3.15 and 9.4 cm , and from Mars and Jupiter at 3.15 cm in 1956 ( Mayer , McCullough , and Sloanaker , 1958 a , b , c ) , and from Saturn at 3.75 cm in 1957 ( Drake and Ewen , 1958 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the relatively short time since these early observations , Venus has been observed at additional wave lengths in the range from 0.8 to 10.2 cm , and Jupiter has been observed over the wave-length range from 3.03 to 68 cm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The observable characteristics of planetary radio radiation are the intensity , the polarization , and the direction of arrival of the waves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The maximum angular diameter of any planetary disk as observed from the earth is about 1 minute of arc .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is much smaller than the highest resolution of even the very large reflectors now under construction , and consequently the radio emission of different regions of the disk cannot be resolved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It should be possible , however , to put useful limits on the diameters of the radio sources by observing with large reflectors or with interferometers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Measurements of polarization are presently limited by apparatus sensitivity and will remain difficult because of the low intensity of the planetary radiation at the earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There have been few measurements specifically for the determination of the polarization of planetary radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The measurements made with the NRL 50 - foot reflector , which is altitude azimuth mounted , would have shown a systematic change with local hour angle in the measured intensities of Venus and Jupiter if a substantial part of the radiation had been linearly polarized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Recent interferometer measurements ( Radhakrishnan and Roberts , 1960 ) have shown the 960 - Mc emission of Jupiter to be partially polarized and to originate in a region of larger diameter than the visible disk .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other than this very significant result , most of the information now available about the radio emission of the planets is restricted to the intensity of the radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The concept of apparent black-body temperature is used to describe the radiation received from the moon and the planets .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The received radiation is compared with the radiation from a hypothetical black-body which subtends the same solid angle as the visible disk of the planet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The apparent black-body disk temperature is the temperature which must be assumed for the black body in order that the intensity of its radiation should equal that of the observed radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The use of this concept does not specify the origin of the radiation , and only if the planet really radiates as a black body , will the apparent black-body temperature correspond to the physical temperature of the emitting material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The radio radiation of the sun which is reflected from the moon and planets should be negligible compared with their thermal emission at centimeter wave lengths , except possibly at times of exceptional outbursts of solar radio noise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The quiescent level of centimeter wave-length solar radiation would increase the average disk brightness temperature by less than 1 ` K .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At meter wave lengths and increase of the order of 10 ` K in the average disk temperatures of the nearer planets would be expected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Therefore , neglecting the extreme outbursts , reflected solar radiation is not expected to cause sizable errors in the measurements of planetary radiation in the centimeter - and decimeter wave-length range .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Radio observations of the moon have been made over the range of wave lengths from 4.3 mm to 75 cm , and the results are summarized in Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Observations have also been made at 1.5 mm using optical techniques ( Sinton , 1955 , 1956 , ; see also chap.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">11 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not all the observers have used the same procedures or made the same assumptions about the lunar brightness distribution when reducing the data , and this , together with differences in the methods of calibrating the antennae and receivers , must account for much of the disagreement in the measured radio brightness temperatures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the observations at 4.3 mm ( Coates , 1959 a ) , the diameter of the antenna beam , 6 ' .7 , was small enough to allow resolution of some of the larger features of the lunar surface , and contour diagrams have been made of the lunar brightness distribution at three lunar phases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These observations indicate that the lunar maria heat up more rapidly and also cool off more rapidly than do the mountainous regions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mare Imbrium seems to be an exception and remains cooler than the regions which surround it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These contour diagrams also suggest a rather rapid falloff in the radio brightness with latitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Very recently , observations have been made at 8 - mm wave length with a reflector 22 meters in diameter with a resultant beam width of only about 2 ' ( Amenitskii , Noskova , and Salomonovich , 1960 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The constant temperature contours are much smoother than those observed at 4.3 mm by Coates ( 1959 a ) , and apparently the emission at 8 mm is not nearly so sensitive to differences in surface features .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such high-resolution observations as these are needed at several wave lengths in order that the radio emission of the moon can be properly interpreted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The observations of Mayer , McCullough , and Sloanaker at 3.15 cm and of Sloanaker at 10.3 cm have not previously been published and will be briefly described .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Measurements at 3.15 cm were obtained on 11 days spread over the interval May 3 to June 19 , 1956 , using the 50 - foot reflector at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory in Washington .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The half-intensity diameter of the antenna beam was about 9 ' , and the angle subtended by the moon included the entire main beam and part of the first side lobes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The antenna patterns and the power gain at the peak of the beam were both measured ( Mayer , McCullough , and Sloanaker , 1958 b ) , so that the absolute power sensitivity of the antenna beam over the solid angle of the moon was known .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The ratio of the measured antenna temperature change during a drift scan across the moon to the average brightness temperature of the moon over the antenna beam ( assuming that the brightness temperature of the sky is negligible ) was found , by graphical integration of the antenna directivity diagram , to be 0.85 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The measured brightness temperature is a good approximation to the brightness temperature at the center of the lunar disk because of the narrow antenna beam and because the temperature distribution over the central portion of the moon 's disk is nearly uniform .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The result of the observations is ( in ` K ) **f where the phase angle , |qt , is measured in degrees from new moon and the probable errors include absolute as well as relative errors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This result is plotted along with the 8.6 - mm observations of Gibson ( 1958 ) in figure 1 , a .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The variation in the 3 - cm emission of the moon during a lunation is very much less than the variation in the 8.6 - mm emission , as would be expected from the explanation of Piddington and Minnett ( 1949 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the discussion which follows , the time average of the radio emission will be referred to as the constant component , and the superimposed periodic variation will be called the variable component .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The 10.3 - cm observation of Sloanaker was made on May 20 , 1958 , using the 84 - foot reflector at the Maryland Point Observatory of the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The age of the moon was about 2 days .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The half-intensity diameter of the main lobe of the antenna was about 18 ' .5 , and the brightness temperature was reduced by assuming a Gaussian shape for the antenna beam and a uniformly bright disk for the moon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Experiments were made on an electric arc applying a porous graphite anode cooled by a transpiring gas ( Argon ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , the energy transferred from the arc to the anode was partly fed back into the arc .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was shown that by proper anode design the net energy loss of the arc to the anode could be reduced to approximately 15 % of the total arc energy A detailed energy balance of the anode was established .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The anode ablation could be reduced to a negligible amount .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The dependence of the arc voltage upon the mass flow velocity of the transpirating gas was investigated for various arc lengths and currents between 100 Amp and 200 Amp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Qualitative observations were made and high-speed motion pictures were taken to study flow phenomena in the arc at various mass flow velocities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The high heat fluxes existing at the electrode surfaces of electric arcs necessitate extensive cooling to prevent electrode ablation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The cooling requirements are particularly severe at the anode .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In free burning electric arcs , for instance , approximately 90 % of the total arc power is transferred to the anode giving rise to local heat fluxes in excess of **f as measured by the authors - the exact value depending on the arc atmosphere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In plasma generators as currently commercially available for industrial use or as high temperature research tools often more than 50 % of the total energy input is being transferred to the cooling medium of the anode .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The higher heat transfer rates at the anode compared with those at the cathode can be explained by the physical phenomena occurring in free burning arcs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In plasma generators the superimposed forced convection may modify the picture somewhat .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The heat transfer to the anode is due to the following effects : 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Heat of condensation ( work function ) plus kinetic energy of the electrons impinging on the anode .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This energy transfer depends on the current , the temperature in the arc column , the anode material , and the conditions in the anode sheath .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Heat transfer by molecular conduction as well as by radiation from the arc column .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The heat transfer to the anode in free burning arcs is enhanced by a hot gas jet flowing from the cathode towards the anode with velocities up **f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This phenomenon has been experimentally investigated in detail by Maecker ( Ref.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">1 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pressure gradient producing the jet is due to the nature of the magnetic field in the arc ( rapid decrease of current density from cathode to the anode ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Hence , the flow conditions at the anode of free burning arcs resemble those near a stagnation point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">it is apparent from the above and from experimental evidence that the cooling requirements for the anode of free burning arcs are large compared with those for the cathode .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The gas flow through a plasma generator will modify these conditions ; however , the anode is still the part receiving the largest heat flux .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An attempt to improve the life of the anodes or the efficiency of the plasma generators must , therefore , aim at a reduction of the anode loss .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The following possibilities exist for achieving this : 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The use of high voltages and low currents by proper design to reduce electron heat transfer to the anode for a given power output .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Continuous motion of the arc contact area at the anode by flow or magnetic forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">3 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Feed back of the energy transferred to the anode by applying gas transpiration through the anode .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The third method was , to our knowledge , successfully applied for the first time by C. Sheer and co-workers ( Ref.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">2 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The purpose of the present study is to study the thermal conditions and to establish an energy balance for a transpiration cooled anode as well as the effect of blowing on the arc voltage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Gas injection through a porous anode ( transpiration cooling ) not only feeds back the energy transferred to the anode by the above mentioned processes , but also modifies the conditions in the arc itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A detailed study of this latter phenomenon was not attempted in this paper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Argon was used as a blowing gas to exclude any effects of dissociation or chemical reaction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The anode material was porous graphite .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sintered porous metals should be usable in principle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , technical difficulties arise by melting at local hot spots .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The experimental arrangement as described below is based on the geometry of free burning arcs .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although there is no question but that the process of washing fabrics involves a number of phenomena which are related together in an extremely complicated way and that these phenomena and their interrelations are not well understood at the present , this section attempts to present briefly an up-to-date picture of the physical chemistry of washing either fabrics or hard surfaces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The purpose of washing is , obviously , to remove soils which are arbitrarily classed in the four major categories given below :
Dirt , which is here defined as particulate material which is usually inorganic and is very often extremely finely divided so as to exhibit colloidal properties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Greasy soils , which are typified by hydrocarbons and fats ( esters of glycerol with long chain organic acids ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Stains , which include the wide variety of nonparticulate materials which give color even when present in very low concentration on the soiled object .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Miscellaneous soils , which primarily include sticky substances and colorless liquids which evaporate to leave a residue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The dirt on the soiled objects is mechanically held by surface irregularities to some extent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , a major factor in binding dirt is the attraction between surfaces that goes under the name of van der Waal 's forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is a theoretically complicated dipole interaction which causes any extremely small uncharged particle to agglomerate with other small uncharged particles , or to stick to an uncharged surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Obviously , if colloidal particles bear charges of opposite sign or , if one kind is charged and the other kind is not , the attraction will be intensified and the tendency to agglomerate will be greatly reinforced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Likewise , a charged particle will tend to stick to an uncharged surface and vice versa , and a charged particle will be very strongly attracted to a surface exhibiting an opposite charge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In addition , dirt particles can be held onto a soiled surface by sticky substances or by the surface tension of liquids , including liquid greases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Greases , stains , and miscellaneous soils are usually sorbed onto the soiled surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In most cases , these soils are taken up as liquids through capillary action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In an essentially static system , an oil cannot be replaced by water on a surface unless the interfacial tensions of the water phase are reduced by a surface-active agent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The washing process whereby soils are removed consists basically of applying mechanical action to loosen the dirt particles and dried matter in the presence of water which helps to float off the debris and acts , to some extent , as a dissolving and solvating agent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Greasy soils are hardly removed by washing in plain water ; and natural waters , in addition , often contain impurities such as calcium salts which can react with soils to make them more difficult to remove .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore , detergents are used .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The detergent active is that substance which primarily acts to remove greasy soils .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The other constituents in a built detergent assist in this and in the removal of dirty stains and the hydrophilic sticky or dried soils .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As is well known , detergent actives belong to the chemical class consisting of moderately high molecular weight and highly polar molecules which exhibit the property of forming micelles in solution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Physicochemical investigations of anionic surfactants , including the soaps , have shown that there is little polymerization or agglomeration of the chain anions below a certain region of concentration called the critical micelle concentration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( 1 ) Below the critical micelle concentration , monomers and some dimers are present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( 2 ) In the critical micelle region , there is a rapid agglomeration or polymerization to give the micelles , which have a degree of polymerization averaging around 60 - 80 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( 3 ) For anionics , these micelles appear to be roughly spherical assemblages in which the hydrocarbon tails come together so that the polar groups ( the ionized ends ) face outward towards the aqueous continuous phase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Obviously hydrophobic ( oleophilic ) substances such as greases , oils , or particles having a greasy or oily surface are more at home in the center of a micelle than in the aqueous phase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Micelles can imbibe and hold a considerable amount of oleophilic substances so that the micelle volume may be increased as much as approximately two-fold .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although the matter has not been unequivocally demonstrated , the available data show that micelles in themselves do not contribute significantly to the detergency process .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Related to micelle formation is the technologically important ability of detergent actives to congregate at oil water interfaces in such a manner that the polar ( or ionized ) end of the molecule is directed towards the aqueous phase and the hydrocarbon chain towards the oily phase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the cleaning process , sorbed greasy soils become coated in this manner with an oriented film of surfactant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Then during washing , the greasy soil rolls back at the edges so that emulsified droplets can disengage themselves from the sorbed oil mass , with the aid of mechanical action , and enter the aqueous phase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Obviously , a substance which is permanently or temporarily sorbed on the surface in place of the soil will tend to accelerate this process and effectively push off the greasy soil .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Substances other than detergent actives also tend to be strongly sorbed from aqueous media onto surfaces of other contiguous condensed phases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is particularly true of highly charged ions , especially those ions which fall into the class of polyelectrolytes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Whereas the usual organic surface-active agent is strongly sorbed at oil-water interfaces , the highly charged ions are most strongly sorbed at interfaces between water and insoluble materials exhibiting an ionic structure ( see Table 26 - 2 on p. 1678 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , for aqueous media , we can think of the idealized organic active as an oleophilic or hydrophobic surface-active agent , and of an idealized builder as a oleophobic or hydrophilic surface-active agent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From the equilibrium sorption data which are available , it seems logical to expect that polyphosphate ions would be strongly sorbed on the surface of the dirt ( especially clay soils ) so as to give it a greatly increased negative charge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The charged particles then repel each other and are also repelled from the charged surface , which almost invariably bears a negative charge under washing conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The negatively charged dirt particles then leave the surface and go into the aqueous phase .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The Poynting-Robertson effect ( Robertson , 1937 ; Wyatt and Whipple , 1950 ) , which is a retardation of the orbital motion of particles by the relativistic aberration of the repulsive force of the impinging solar radiation , causes the dust to spiral into the sun in times much shorter than the age of the Earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The radial velocity varies inversely as the particle size - a 1000 - | m diameter particle near the orbit of Mars would reach the sun in about 60 million years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whipple ( 1955 ) extends the effects to include the solar corpuscular radiation pressure , which increases both the minimum particle size and the drag .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Further , the corpuscular radiation , i.e. , the solar wind protons , must sputter away the surface atoms of the dust and cause a slow diminution in size , with a resultant increase in both the Poynting-Robertson effect and the ratio of the repulsive force to the gravitational force .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Poynting-Robertson effect causes the semi major axis of orbits to diminish more rapidly than the semi-minor axis , with a consequent tendency toward circular orbits as the particles move toward the sun .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Also , planetary gravitational attraction increases the dust concentration near the plane of the ecliptic as the sun is approached .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At one astronomical unit from the sun ( the Earth 's distance ) the dust orbits are probably nearly circular .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If such is the case , the particles within a distance of about * * f km of the Earth will have , relative to the Earth , a kinetic energy less than their potential energy and they will be captured into orbits about the Earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">De Jager ( 1955 ) has calculated the times required for these particles to reach the atmosphere under the influence of the Poynting-Robertson effect , which in this case causes the orbits to become more and more eccentric without changing the semi major axis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This effect can give rise to a blanket of micrometeorites around the Earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Since there is a continual loss of micrometeoritic material in space because of the radiation effects , there must be a continual replenishment : otherwise , micrometeorites would have disappeared from interplanetary space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are several possible sources .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">According to Whipple ( 1955 ) , cometary debris is sufficient to replenish the material spiraling into the sun , maintaining a fairly steady state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Asteroidal collisions are also thought to contribute material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is also possible that some of the dust in the vicinity of the Earth originated from meteoritic impacts upon the moon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One cannot make a very satisfactory guess about the micrometeorite flux in space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Even in the neighborhood of the Earth , where information has been obtained both directly and indirectly , the derived flux values vary by at least four orders of magnitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This large discrepancy demonstrates the inadequacies of the experimental methods and the lack of understanding of the various phenomena involved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Beyond a few million kilometers from the Earth , but still in the region of the Earth 's orbit , a prediction of the flux of dust is even more unreliable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At greater distances from the sun , the situation is still less certain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are several sources of evidence on the micrometeorite environment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Direct information has been obtained from rockets and satellites equipped with impact sensors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In addition , the size distribution obtained from visual and radar observations of meteors may be extrapolated to the micrometeorite domain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From the brightness of the F component of the solar corona and the brightness of the zodiacal light , an estimate of the particle sizes , concentrations , and spatial distribution can be derived for regions of space near the ecliptic plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another important source of evidence only recently receiving much attention is the analysis of atmospheric dust for a meteoritic component .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The cores of deep sea sediments and content of collectors in remote regions are valuable in this category .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The data provide a measure of the total mass of cosmic material incident upon the Earth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The direct evidence on the micrometeorite environment near the Earth is obtained from piezoelectric sensors ( essentially microphones ) and from wire gages ; these instruments are installed on rockets , satellites , and space probes .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Many other vehicles with smaller sensitive area exposure time products contribute some information .</MPQASENT>
