<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Biological warfare is the intentional use of living microorganisms or their toxic products for the purpose of destroying or reducing the military effectiveness of man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is the exploitation of the inherent potential of infectious disease agents by scientific research and development , resulting in the production of BW weapons systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Man may also be injured secondarily by damage to his food crops or domestic animals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Biological warfare is considered to be primarily a strategic weapon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The major reason for this is that it has no quick kill effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The incubation period of infectious disease , plus a variable period of illness even before a lethal effect , render this weapon unsuitable for hand-to-hand encounter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A man can be an effective fighting machine throughout the incubation period of most infectious diseases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , an enemy would probably use this weapon for attack on static population centers such as large cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An important operational procedure in BW for an enemy would be to create an aerosol or cloud of agent over the target area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This concept has stimulated much basic research concerning the behavior of particulate biological materials , the pathogenesis of respiratory infections , the medical management of such diseases and defense against their occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The biological and physical properties of infectious particles have been studied intensively during the past fifteen years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Much new equipment and many unique techniques have been developed for the quantitative exposure of experimental animals to aerosols of infectious agents contained in particles of specified dimensional characteristics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Much information has been gathered relative to quantitative sampling and assessment techniques .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Much of the older experimental work on respiratory infections was accomplished by very artificial procedures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The intra nasal instillation of a fluid suspension of infectious agent in an anesthetized animal is far different from exposure , through natural respiration , to aerosolized organisms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The importance of particle size in such aerosols has been thoroughly demonstrated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The natural anatomical and physiological defensive features of the upper respiratory tract , such as the turbinates of the nose and the cilia of the trachea and larger bronchi , are capable of impinging out the larger particles to which we are ordinarily exposed in our daily existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Very small particles , however , in a size range of 1 to 4 microns in diameter are capable of passing these impinging barriers and entering the alveolar bed of the lungs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This area is highly susceptible to infection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The entrance and retention of infectious particles in the alveoli amounts almost to an intra tissue inoculation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The relationship between particle size and infectious dose is illustrated in Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In considering BW defense , it must be recognized that a number of critical meteorological parameters must be met for an aerosol to exhibit optimum effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , bright sunlight is rapidly destructive for living microorganisms suspended in air .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There are optimal humidity requirements for various agents when airborne .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Neutral or inversion meteorological conditions are necessary for a cloud to travel along the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It will rise during lapse conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are , of course , certain times during the 24 - hour daily cycle when most of these conditions will be met .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Certain other properties of small particles , in addition to those already mentioned in connection with penetration of the respiratory tract , are noteworthy in defense considerations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The smaller the particle the further it will travel downwind before settling out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An aerosol of such small particles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">moreover , diffuses through structures in much the same manner as a gas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There may be a number of secondary effects resulting from diffusion through buildings such as widespread contamination of kitchens , restaurants , food stores , hospitals , etc. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Depending on the organism , there may be multiplication in some food or beverage products , i.e. , in milk for example .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The secondary consequences from this could be very serious and must be taken into consideration in planning for defense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Something of the behavior of clouds of small particles can be illustrated by the following field trials :

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A number of unique medical problems might be created when man is exposed to an infectious agent through the respiratory route rather than by the natural portal of entry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some agents have been shown to be much more toxic or infectious to experimental animals when exposed to aerosols of optimum particle size than by the natural portal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Botulinal toxin , for example , is several thousand-fold more toxic by this route than when given per os .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In some instances a different clinical disease picture may result from this route of exposure , making diagnosis difficult .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In tularemia produced by aerosol exposure , one would not expect to find the classical ulcer of `` rabbit fever '' on a finger .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An enemy would obviously choose an agent that is believed to be highly infectious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Agents that are known to cause frequent infections among laboratory workers such as those causing Q fever , tularemia , brucellosis , glanders , coccidioidomycosis , etc. , belong in this category .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An agent would likely be selected which would possess sufficient viability and virulence stability to meet realistic minimal logistic requirements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is , obviously , a proper goal of research to improve on this property .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this connection it should be capable of being disseminated without excessive destruction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , it should not be so fastidious in its growth requirements as to make production on a militarily significant scale improbable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An aggressor would use an agent against which there was a minimal naturally acquired or artificially induced immunity in a target population .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A solid immunity is the one effective circumstance whereby attack by a specific agent can be neutralized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It must be remembered , however , that there are many agents for which there is no solid immunity and a partial or low-grade immunity may be broken by an appropriate dose of agent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is a broad spectrum of organisms from which selection for a specified military purpose might be made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An enemy might choose an acutely debilitating microorganism , a chronic disease producer or one causing a high rate of lethality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is possible that certain mutational forms may be produced such as antibiotic resistant strains .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mutants may also be developed with changes in biochemical properties that are of importance in identification .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All of these considerations are of critical importance in considering defense and medical management .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Biological agents are , of course , highly host specific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They do not destroy physical structures as is true of high explosives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This may be of overriding importance in considering military objectives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The question of epidemic disease merits some discussion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Only a limited effort has been devoted to this problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some of those who question the value of BW have assumed that the only potential would be in the establishment of epidemics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They then point out that with our present lack of knowledge of all the factors concerned in the rise and fall of epidemics , it is unlikely that a planned episode could be initiated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They argue further ( and somewhat contradictorily ) that our knowledge and resources in preventive medicine would make it possible to control such an outbreak of disease .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">this is why this approach to BW defense has not been given major attention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Our major problem is what an enemy might accomplish in an initial attack on a target .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This , of course , does not eliminate from consideration for this purpose agents that are associated naturally with epidemic disease .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A hypothetical example will illustrate this point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Let us assume that it would be possible for an enemy to create an aerosol of the causative agent of epidemic typhus ( Rickettsia prowazwki ) over City A and that a large number of cases of typhus fever resulted therefrom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">No epidemic was initiated nor was one expected because the population in City A was not lousy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Lousiness is a prerequisite for epidemic typhus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In this case , then , the military objective was accomplished with an epidemic agent solely through the results secured in the initial attack .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This was done with full knowledge that there would be no epidemic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other hand , a similar attack might have been made on City B whose population was known to be lousy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One might expect some spread of the disease in this case resulting in increased effectiveness of the attack .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The major defensive problems are concerned with the possibility of overt military delivery of biological agents from appropriate disseminating devices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It should be no more difficult to deliver such devices than other weapons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The same delivery vehicles - whether they be airplanes , submarines or guided missiles - should be usable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If it is possible for an enemy to put an atomic bomb on a city , it should be equally possible to put a cloud of biological agent over that city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Biological agents are , moreover , suitable for delivery through enemy sabotage which imposes many problems in defense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A few obvious target areas of great importance might be mentioned .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The air conditioning and ventilating systems of large buildings are subject to attack .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is an enormous industry that is subject to sabotage .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Huge industries are involved also in the production of biological products , drugs and cosmetics which are liable to this type of attack .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A variety of techniques have been directed toward the isolation and study of blood group antibodies .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Abelson and Rawson , using a stepwise elution scheme , fractionated whole sera containing ABO and Rh antibodies on diethylaminoethyl DEAE cellulose and carboxymethyl cellulose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Speer and coworkers , in a similar study of blood group antibodies of whole sera , used a series of gradients for elution from DEAE-cellulose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Fahey and Morrison used a single , continuous gradient at constant pH for the fractionation of anti - A and anti - B agglutinins from preisolated | g-globulin samples .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the present work whole sera have been fractionated by chromatography on DEAE-cellulose using single gradients similar to those described by Sober and Peterson , and certain chemical and serological properties of the fractions containing antibodies of the ABO and Rh systems have been described .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Serum samples were obtained from normal group A , group B and group O donors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Three of the anti - Rh sera used were taken from recently sensitized individuals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One contained complete antibody and had a titer of 1 : 512 in saline .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The second contained incomplete antibody and showed titers of 1 : 256 in albumin and 1 : 2048 by the indirect Coombs test .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The third , containing the mixed type of complete and incomplete antibodies , had titers of 1 : 256 in saline , 1 : 512 in albumin and 1 : 1024 by the indirect Coombs test .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In addition one serum was obtained from a donor ( R. E. . )</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">who had been sensitized 6 years previously .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These antibody titers were determined by reaction with homozygous * * f red cells .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Anti - A and anti - B activities were determined in fractions from the sera of group A , group B or group O donors by the following tube agglutination methods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One drop of each sample was added to one drop of a 2 % suspension of group * * f or group B red cells in a small * * f test tube .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In several instances group O cells were also used as controls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The red cells were used within 2 days after donation and were washed with large amounts of saline before use .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The mixtures of sample plus cell suspension were allowed to stand at room temperature for 1 hr .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">the tubes were then centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 1 min and examined macroscopically for agglutination .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the albumin method , equal volumes of 30 % bovine albumin , sample and 2 % cells suspended in saline were allowed to stand at room temperature for 1 hr and then were centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 1 min .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All samples were tested by both the saline and albumin methods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The activities of fractions of sera containing Rh antibodies were tested by the saline , albumin and indirect Coombs techniques .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Homozygous and heterozygous * * f cells , * * f and homozygous and heterozygous * * f cells were used to test each sample ; however , in the interest of clarity and conciseness only the results obtained with homozygous * * f and homozygous * * f cells will be presented here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The saline and albumin tests were performed as described for the ABO samples except that the mixture was incubated for 1 hr at 37 ` C before centrifugation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The saline tubes were saved and used for the indirect Coombs test in the following manner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The cells were washed three times with saline , anti human serum was added , the cells were resuspended , and the mixture was centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 1 min and examined for agglutination .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The anti human sera used were prepared by injecting whole human serum into rabbits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Those antisera shown by immunoelectrophoresis to be of the `` broad spectrum '' type were selected for used in the present study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The red cells for the Rh antibody tests were used within 3 days after drawing except for the * * f cells , which had been glycerolized and stored at - 20 ` C for approximately 1 year .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These cells were thawed at 37 ` C for 30 min and were deglycerolized by alternately centrifuging and mixing with descending concentrations of glycerol solutions ( 20 , 18 , 10 , 8 , 4 and 2 % ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The cells were then washed three times with saline and resuspended to 2 % in saline .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Blood samples were allowed to clot at room temperature for 3 hr , centrifuged and the serum was removed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The serum was measured volumetrically and subsequently dialyzed in the cold for at least 24 hr against three to four changes , approximately 750 ml each , of `` starting buffer '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This buffer , pH 8.6 , was 0.005 M in * * f and 0.039 M in tris ( hydroxymethyl ) - aminomethane ( Tris ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After dialysis the sample was centrifuged and the supernatant placed on a * * f cm column of DEAE-cellulose equilibrated with starting buffer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The DEAE-cellulose , containing 0.78 mEq of N / g , was prepared in our laboratory by the method of Peterson and Sober ( 7 ) from powdered cellulose , 100 - 230 mesh .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The small amount of insoluble material which precipitated during dialysis was suspended in approximately 5 ml of starting buffer , centrifuged , resuspended in 2.5 ml of isotonic saline and tested for antibody activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The chromatography was done at 6 ` C using gradient elution , essentially according to Sober and Peterson .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The deep concave gradient employed ( fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">2 ) was obtained with a nine chambered gradient elution device ( `` Varigrad '' , reference ( 8 ) ) and has been described elsewhere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">the other , a shallow concave gradient ( Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">1 ) , was produced with a so-called `` cone sphere '' apparatus , the `` cone '' being a 2 - liter Erlenmeyer flask and the `` sphere , '' a 2 - liter round-bottom flask .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each initially contained 1700 ml of buffer ; in the sphere was starting buffer and in the cone was final buffer , 0.50 M in both * * f and Tris , pH 4.1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A flow rate of 72 * * f was used and 12 ml fractions were collected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Approximately 165 fractions were obtained from each column .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These were read at 280 m | m in a Beckman model DU spectrophotometer and tested for antibody activity as described above .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For protein identification , fractions from the column were concentrated by pervaporation against a stream of air at 5 ` C or by negative pressure dialysis in an apparatus which permitted simultaneous concentration of the protein and dialysis against isotonic saline .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the latter procedure the temperature was maintained at 2 ` C by surrounding the apparatus with ice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because negative pressure dialysis gave better recovery of proteins , permitted detection of proteins concentrated from very dilute solutions and was a gentler procedure , it was used in all but the earliest experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Paper electrophoresis was carried out on the concentrated samples in a Spinco model R cell using barbital buffer , pH 8.6 , ionic strength 0.075 , at room temperature on Whatman 3 MM filter paper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Five milliamperes / cell were applied for 18 hr , after which the strips were stained with bromophenol blue and densitometry was carried out using a Spinco Analytrol .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When paper electrophoresis was to be used for preparation , eight strips of a whole serum sample or a chromatographic fraction concentrated by negative pressure dialysis were run / chamber under the conditions described above .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the end of the run , the strips in the third and sixth positions in each chamber were dried , stained for 1 hr , washed and dried , while the other strips were maintained in a horizontal position at 1 ` C .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The unstained strips were then marked , using the stained ones as a guide , and cut transversely so as to separate the various protein bands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The strip sections containing a given protein were pooled , eluted with 0.5 ml of isotonic saline , and the eluates were tested for antibody activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Fractions from the column which were to be subjected to analytical ultracentrifugation were concentrated by negative pressure dialysis and dialyzed for 16 hr in the cold against at least 500 volumes of phosphate buffered saline , pH 7.2 , ionic strength 0.154 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were then centrifuged at 59780 rpm for 35 to 80 min at 20 ` C in a Spinco model E ultracentrifuge at a protein concentration of 1.00 to 1.25 % .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sedimentation coefficients were computed as * * f values and relative amounts of the various components were calculated from the Schlieren patterns .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For preparative ultracentrifugation , fractions from the column were concentrated by negative pressure dialysis to volumes of 1 ml or less , transferred to cellulose tubes and diluted to 12 ml with isotonic saline .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ultracentrifugation was then carried out in a Spinco model L ultracentrifuge at 40000 rpm for 125 to 150 min , refrigeration being used throughout the run .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Successive 1 - ml fractions were then drawn off with a hypodermic syringe , starting at the top of the tube , and tested for agglutinin activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other methods will be described below .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The insoluble material which precipitated during dialysis against starting buffer always showed intense agglutinin activity , regardless of the blood group of the donor .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The insoluble material resulting from dialysis against starting buffer always showed strong activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In fact agglutination of * * f cells in saline could be produced by the insoluble material from sera containing `` only '' incomplete antibody activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This was later known to be the result of concentrating the minute amount of complete antibody found in these sera ; when the insoluble fraction was suspended in a volume of saline equal to that of the original serum sample , no complete antibody activity could be detected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Apart from the honeybee , practically all bees and bumblebees hibernate in a state of torpor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Occasionally , you may come across one or two bumblebees in the cold season , when you are turning over sods in your garden , but you have to be a really keen observer to see them at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They keep their wings and feet pressed tightly against their bodies , and in spite of their often colorful attire you may very well mistake them for lumps of dirt .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I must add at once that these animals are what we call `` queens '' , young females that have mated in the previous summer or autumn .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is on them alone that the future of their race depends , for all their relatives ( mothers , husbands , brothers , and unmated sisters ) have perished with the arrival of the cold weather .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even some of the queens will die before the winter is over , falling prey to enemies or disease .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The survivors emerge on some nice , sunny day in March or April , when the temperature is close to 50 ` F and there is not too much wind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Now the thing for us to do is to find ourselves a couple of those wonderful flowering currants such as the red Ribes sanguineum of our Pacific Northwest , or otherwise a good sloe tree , or perhaps some nice pussy willow in bloom , preferably one with male or staminate catkins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The blooms of Ribes and of the willow and sloe are the places where large numbers of our early insects will assemble : honeybees , bumblebees , and other wild bees , and also various kinds of flies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is a happy , buzzing crowd .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each male willow catkin is composed of a large number of small flowers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not difficult to see that the stamens of the catkin are always arranged in pairs , and that each individual flower is nothing but one such pair standing on a green , black tipped little scale .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By scrutinizing the flowers , one can also notice that the scale bears one or two tiny warts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Those are the nectaries or honey glands ( Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">26 , page 74 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The staminate willow catkins , then , provide their visitors with both nectar and pollen ; a marvelous arrangement , for it provides exactly what the bee queens need to make their beebread , a combination of honey and pollen with which the young of all species are fed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The only exception to this is certain bees that have become parasites .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I will deal with these later on .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Quite often , honeybees form a majority on the willow catkins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As we have already seen in the first chapter , bumblebees are bigger , hairier , and much more colorful than honeybees , exhibiting various combinations of black , yellow , white and orange .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Let us not try to key them out at this stage of the game , and let us just call them Bombus ; there must be several dozen species in the United States alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If you really insist on knowing their names , an excellent book on the North American species is Bumblebees and Their Ways by O. E. Plath .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If we manage to keep track of a Bombus queen after she has left her feeding place , we may discover the snug little hideout which she has fixed up for herself when she woke up from her winter sleep .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As befits a queen , a bumblebee female is rather choosy and may spend considerable time searching for a suitable nesting place .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Most species seem to prefer a ready-made hollow such as a deserted mouse nest , a bird house , or the hole made by a woodpecker ; some show a definite liking for making their nest in moss .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Once she has made up her mind , the queen starts out by constructing , in her chosen abode , a small `` floor '' of dried grass or some woolly material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On this , she builds an `` egg compartment '' or `` egg cell '' which is filled with that famous pollen and nectar mixture called beebread .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">She also builds one or two waxen cups which she fills with honey .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Then , a group of eggs is deposited in a cavity in the beebread loaf and the egg compartment is closed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The queen afterward keeps incubating and guarding her eggs like a mother hen , taking a sip from time to time from the rather liquid honey in her honey pots .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the larvae hatch , they feed on the beebread , although they also receive extra honey meals from their mother .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She continues to add to the pollen supply as needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The larvae , kept warm by the queen , are full grown in about ten days .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each now makes a tough , papery cocoon and pupates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After another two weeks , the first young emerge , four to eight small daughters that begin to play the role of worker bees , collecting pollen and nectar in the field and caring for the new young generation while the queen retires to a life of egg laying .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first worker bees do not mate or lay eggs ; males and mating females do not emerge until later in the season .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The broods of workers that appear later tend to be bigger than the first ones , probably because they are better fed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By the middle of the summer , many of the larvae apparently receive such a good diet that it is `` optimal '' , and it is then that young queens begin to appear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Simultaneously , males or drones are produced , mostly from the unfertilized eggs of workers , although a few may be produced by the queen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The young queens and drones leave the nest and mate , and after a short period of freedom , the fertilized young queens will begin to dig in for the winter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is an amazing fact that in some species this will happen while the summer is still in full swing , for instance , in August .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The temperature then is still very high .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the old nest , the queen will in the early fall cease to lay the fertilized eggs that will produce females .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As a result , the proportion of males ( which leave the nest ) increases , and eventually the old colony will die out completely .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The nest itself , the structure that in some cases housed about 2000 individuals when the season was at its peak , is now rapidly destroyed by the scavenging larvae of certain beetles and moths .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Not always , though , does the development of a bumblebee colony take place in the smooth fashion we have just described .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some members of the bee family have become idlers , social parasites that live at the expense of their hardworking relatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Bumblebees can thus suffer severely from the onslaughts of Psithyrus , the `` cuckoo bumblebee '' as it is called in some European countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Female individuals of Psithyrus look deceptively like the workers and queens of the bumblebees they victimize .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The one sure way to tell victim and villain apart is to examine the hind legs which in the case of the idler , Psithyrus , lack the pollen baskets - naturally !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The female parasite spends much time in her efforts to find a nest of her host .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When she succeeds , she usually manages to slip in unobtrusively , to deposit an egg on a completed loaf of beebread before the bumblebees seal the egg compartment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The hosts never seem to recognize that something is amiss , so that the compartment afterward is sealed normally .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , the larvae of the intruder can develop at the expense of the rightful inhabitants and the store of beebread .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Later on , they and the mother Psithyrus are fed by the Bombus workers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Worse still , in a number of cases it has been claimed that the Psithyrus female kills off the Bombus queen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But let us return , after this gruesome interlude , to our willow catkins in the spring ; there are other wild bees that command our attention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is almost certain that some of these , usually a trifle smaller than the honeybees , are andrenas or mining bees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There are about 200 different kinds of Andrena in Europe alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One of my favorites is A. armata , a species very common in England , where it is sometimes referred to as the lawn bee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The females like to burrow in the short turf of well-kept lawns , where their little mounds of earth often appear by the hundreds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Almost equal in size to a honeybee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A. armata is much more beautiful in color , at least in the female of the species : a rich , velvety , rusty red .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The males are much duller .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After having mated , an Andrena female digs a hole straight down into the ground , forming a burrow about the size of a lead pencil .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The bottom part of a burrow has a number of side tunnels or `` cells '' , each of which is provided with an egg plus a store of beebread .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The development of the Andrena larvae is very rapid , so that by the end of spring they have already pupated and become adults .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But they are still enclosed in their larval cells and remain there throughout the summer , fall , and winter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Their appearance , next spring , coincides in an almost uncanny way with the flowering of their host plants .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the Sacramento valley in California , for instance , it has been observed that there was not one day 's difference between the emergence of the andrenas and the opening of the willow catkins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This must be due to a completely identical response to the weather , in the plant and the animal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After the male and female andrenas have mated , the cycle is repeated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although Andrena is gregarious , so that we may find hundreds and hundreds of burrows together , we must still call it a solitary bee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its life history is much simpler than that of the truly colonial bumblebees and can serve as an example of the life cycle of many other species .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After all , social life in the group of the bees is by no means general , although it certainly is a striking feature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On the basis of its life history , we like to think that Andrena is more primitive than the bumblebees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The way in which it transports its pollen is not so perfect , either .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It lacks pollen baskets and possesses only a large number of long , branched hairs on its legs , on which the pollen grains will collect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still Andrena will do a reasonably good job , so that an animal with a full pollen load looks like a gay little piece of yellow down floating in the wind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Closely related to the andrenas are the nomias or alkali bees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nomia melanderi can be found in tremendous numbers in certain parts of the United States west of the Great Plains , for example , in Utah and central Washington .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the United States Department of Agriculture 's Yearbook of Agriculture , 1952 , which is devoted entirely to insects , George E. Bohart mentions a site in Utah which was estimated to contain 200000 nesting females .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Often the burrows are only an inch or two apart , and the bee cities cover several acres .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The life history of the alkali bee is similar to that of Andrena , but the first activity of the adults does not take place until summer , and the individuals hibernate in the prepupal stage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In most places , there are two generations a year , a second brood of adults appearing late in the summer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I must plead guilty to a special sympathy for nomias .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This may just be pride in my adopted State of Washington , but certainly I love to visit their mound cities near Yakima and Prosser in July or August , when the bees are in their most active period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The name `` alkali bee '' indicates that one has to look for them in rather inhospitable places .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes , although by no means always , these are indeed alkaline .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The thing is that these bees love a fine-grained soil that is moist ; yet the water in the ground should not be stagnant either .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They dislike dense vegetation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Where does one find such conditions ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The best chance , of course , is offered by gently sloping terrain where the water remains close to the surface and where the air is dry , so that a high evaporation leaves salty deposits which permit only sparse plant growth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Many other ( probably nearly all ) snakes at maturity are already more than half their final length .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Laurence M .</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Klauber put length at maturity at two thirds the ultimate length for some rattlesnakes , and Charles C .</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Carpenter 's data on Michigan garter and ribbon snakes ( Thamnophis ) show that the smallest gravid females are more than half as long as the biggest adults .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Felix Kopstein states that `` when the snake reaches its maturity it has already reached about its maximal length '' , but goes on to cite the reticulate python as an exception , with maximum length approximately three times that at maturity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is hard to understand how he concluded that most snakes do not grow appreciably after attaining maturity ; he was working with species of Java , so perhaps some tropical snakes are unusual in this respect .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Additional records of slow growth have been omitted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is possible to make a few generalizations about the six giants themselves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There seems to be a rough correlation between the initial and ultimate lengths , starting with the smallest ( boa constrictor ) and ending with the largest ( anaconda ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Data on the former are scanty , but there can be little doubt that the latter is sometimes born at a length greater than that of any of the others , thereby lending support to the belief that the anaconda does , indeed , attain the greatest length .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For four of the six ( the anaconda and the amethystine python cannot be included for lack of data ) there is also a correlation between size at maturity and maximum length , the boa constrictor being the smallest and the Indian python the next in size at the former stage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Let us speculate a little on the maximum size of the anaconda .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If , in a certain part of the range , it starts life 1 foot longer than do any of the other ( relatively large ) giants , and reaches maturity at , let us guess , 18 inches longer than the others , a quadrupling of the maturity length would result in a maximum of ( nearly ) 40 feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When it comes to rate of early growth , the Indian python leads with a figure of about 3 feet 6 inches per year for the first two years , more or less .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The African rock python , a close second , is followed in turn by the reticulate python .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are few data on the boa constrictor , those for the anaconda are unconvincing , and there is nothing at all on the amethystine python .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It seems likely that the Indian python comes out ahead because records of its growth have been made more carefully and frequently ; it responds exceptionally well to captivity and does not reach proportions that make it hard to keep .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I cannot make sense out of the figures for post maturity growth ; at best the annual increase appears to be a matter of inches rather than feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Until better records have been kept over longer periods of time and much more is known about the maximum dimensions , it will be wise to refrain from drawing conclusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is often stated that the largest snakes require five years to attain maturity , but this apparently is an overestimation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The best way to determine the correct figure ( in captives ) is by direct observation of pairs isolated from birth , a method that produced surprising results : maturing of a male Indian python in less than two years , his mate in less than three ; data on the boa constrictor about match this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another approach is to estimate from the rate of growth and the smallest size at maturity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Results from this approach amply confirm the direct observations :
about three years are required , there being a possible slight difference between males and females in the time required .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Only the amethystine python and the anaconda must be excluded for lack or paucity of data .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The following information on snakes varying greatly in size ( but all with less than a 10 - foot maximum ) shows , when considered with the foregoing , that there is probably no correlation between the length of a snake and the time required for it to mature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oliver , in his summary of the habits of the snakes of the United States , could supply data on the maturing period for only three species in addition to the rattlers , which I shall consider separately .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These three were much alike : lined snake ( Tropidoclonion ) , one year and nine months ; red-bellied snake ( Storeria ) , two years ; cottonmouth ( Ancistrodon ) , two years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Klauber investigated the rattlesnakes carefully himself and also summarized what others have found .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He concluded that in the southern species , which are rapidly growing types , females mate at the age of two and a half and bear the first young when they are three .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other herpetologists have ascertained that in the northern United States the prairie rattlesnake may not give first birth until it is four or even five years old , and that the young may be born every other year , rather than annually .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Carpenter 's study showed that female common garter and ribbon snakes of Michigan mature at about the age of two .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Oversized monsters are never brought home either alive or preserved , and field measurements are obviously open to doubt because of the universal tendency to exaggerate dimensions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Measurements of skins are of little value ; every snake hide is noticeably longer than its carcass and intentional stretching presents no difficulty to the unscrupulous explorer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In spite of all the pitfalls , there is a certain amount of agreement on some of the giants .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The anaconda proves to be the fly in the ointment , but the reason for this is not clear ; the relatively wild conditions still found in tropical South America might be responsible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are three levels on which to treat the subject .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first is the strictly scientific , which demands concrete proof and therefore may err on the conservative side by waiting for evidence in the flesh .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This approach rejects virtually all field measurements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The next level attempts to weigh varied evidence and come to a balanced , sensible conclusion ; field measurements by experienced explorers are not rejected , and even reports of a less scientific nature are duly evaluated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The third level leans on a belief that a lot of smoke means some fire .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The argument against this last approach is comparable to that which rejects stories about hoop snakes , about snakes that break themselves into many pieces and join up again , or even of ghosts that chase people out of graveyards ; the mere piling up of testimony does not prove , to the scientific mind , the existence of hoop snakes , joint snakes , or ghosts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oliver has recently used the second level approach with the largest snakes , and has come to these conclusions :
the anaconda reaches a length of at least 37 feet , the reticulate python 33 , the African rock python 25 , the amethystine python at least 22 , the Indian python 20 , and the boa constrictor 18 - 1 2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Bernard Heuvelmans also treats of the largest snakes , but on the third level , and is chiefly concerned with the anaconda .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He rejects dimensions of 70 feet and more .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Discussions of the giants one by one will include , as far as possible , data on these aspects of growth :
