<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An unusual increase in the number of bronchial arteries present within the substance of the lung was noted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This was accounted for primarily by the presence of a bronchial artery closely following the pulmonary artery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The diameter of this bronchial artery was much too large for it to be a mere vasa vasorum ( figs.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">16 , 23 , 24 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In distal regions its diameter would be one-fourth to one-fifth that of the pulmonary artery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This vessel could be followed to the parenchyma where it directly provided bronchial arterial blood to the alveolar capillary bed ( figs.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">17 , 18 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Also three other direct pathways of alveolar bronchial arterial supply were noted : via the pleura ; through the interlobular septa ; and along the terminal bronchiole ( figs.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">14 , 17 , 18 , 19 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One bronchial arteriolar pulmonary arteriolar anastomosis was noted at the terminal bronchiolar level ( fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">26 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is evident that many marked and striking differences exist between lungs when an inter-species comparison is made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The significance of these differences has not been studied nor has the existence of corresponding physiologic differences been determined .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , the dynamics of airflow , from morphologic considerations alone , may conceivably be different in the monkey than in the horse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The volume and , perhaps , even the characteristics of bronchial arterial blood flow might be different in the dog than in the horse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Also , interlobular air drifts may be all but nonexistent in the cow ; probably occur in the horse much as in the human being ; and , in contrast are present to a relatively immense degree on a segmental basis in the dog where lobules are absent ( Van Allen and Lindskog , ' 31 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A reason for such wide variation in the pulmonary morphology is entirely lacking at present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Within certain wide limits anatomy dictates function and , if one is permitted to speculate , potential pathology should be included in this statement as well .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , the marked susceptibility of the monkey to respiratory infection might be related to its delicate , long alveolar ducts and short , large bronchioles situated within a parenchyma entirely lacking in protective supportive tissue barriers such as those found in types 1 , and 3 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One might also wonder if monkeys are capable of developing bronchiolitis as we know it in man or the horse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In addition , it would be difficult to imagine chronic generalized emphysema occurring in a cow , considering its marked lobular development but , conversely , not difficult to imagine this occurring in the horse or the dog .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Anatomically , the horse lung appears to be remarkably like that of man , insofar as this can be ascertained from comparison of our findings in the horse with those of others ( Birnbaum , ' 54 ) in the human being .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The only area in which one might find major disagreement in this matter is in regard to the alveolar distribution of the bronchial arteries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As early as 1858 , Le Fort claimed an alveolar distribution of the bronchial arteries in human beings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1951 , this was reaffirmed by Cudkowicz .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The opposition to this point of view has its staunchest support in the work of Miller ( ' 50 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apparently , however , Miller has relied heavily on the anatomy in dogs and cats , and he has been criticized for using pathologic human material in his normal study ( Loosli , ' 38 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although Miller noted in 1907 that a difference in the pleural blood supply existed between animals , nowhere in his published works is it found that he did a comparative study of the intrapulmonary features of various mammalian lungs other than in the dog and cat ( Miller , ' 13 ; ' 25 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The meaning of this variation in distribution of the bronchial artery as found in the horse is not clear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , this artery is known to be a nutrient vessel with a distribution primarily to the proximal airways and supportive tissues of the lung .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The alveoli and respiratory bronchioles are primarily diffusing tissues .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Theoretically , they are capable of extracting their required oxygen either from the surrounding air ( Ghoreyeb and Karsner , ' 13 ) or from pulmonary arterial blood ( Comroe , ' 58 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Therefore , an explanation of this alveolar bronchial artery supply might be the nutritive requirement of an increased amount of supportive tissue , not primarily diffusing in nature , in the region of the alveolus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If this be true , the possibility exists that an occlusive lesion of the bronchial arteries might cause widespread degeneration of supportive tissue similar to that seen in generalized emphysema .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One would not expect such an event to occur in animals possessing lungs of types 1 , or 2 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The presence of normally occurring bronchial artery pulmonary artery anastomoses was first noted in 1721 by Ruysch , and thereafter by many others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Nakamura ( ' 58 ) , Verloop ( ' 48 ) , Marchand , Gilroy and Watson ( ' 50 ) , von Hayek ( ' 53 ) , and Tobin ( ' 52 ) have all claimed their normal but relatively nonfunctional existence in the human being .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Miller ( ' 50 ) is the principal antagonist of this viewpoint .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In criticism of the latter 's views , his conclusions were based upon dog lung injection studies in which all of the vascular channels were first filled with a solution under pressure and then were injected with various sized colored particles designed to stop at the arteriolar level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As early as 1913 Ghoreyeb and Karsner demonstrated with perfusion studies in dogs that bronchial artery flow would remain constant at a certain low level when pressure was maintained in the pulmonary artery and vein , but that increases in bronchial artery flow would occur in response to a relative drop in pulmonary artery pressure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Berry , Brailsford and Daly in 1931 and Nakamura in 1958 reaffirmed this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Our own studies in which bronchial artery pulmonary artery anastomoses were demonstrated , were accomplished by injecting the bronchial artery first with no pressure on the pulmonary artery or vein , and then by injecting the pulmonary artery and vein afterwards .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is distinctly possible , therefore , that simultaneous pressures in all three vessels would have rendered the shunts inoperable and hence , uninjectable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This viewpoint is further supported by Verloop 's ( ' 48 ) demonstration of thickened bronchial artery and arteriolar muscular coats which are capable of acting as valves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In other words , the anastomoses between the bronchial artery and pulmonary artery should be considered as functional or demand shunts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In addition , little work has been done on a comparative basis in regard to the normal existence of bronchial artery pulmonary artery anastomoses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Verloop ( ' 48 ; ' 49 ) found these shunts in the human being but was unable to find them in rats .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Ellis , Grindlay and Edwards ( ' 52 ) also were unable to find them in rats .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nakamura ( ' 58 ) was unable to demonstrate their existence , either by anatomic or physiologic methods , in dogs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The possibility that the absence or presence of these shunts is species dependent is therefore inferred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Certainly , the mere fact of failing to demonstrate them in one or another species does not conclusively deny their existence in that species .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is , however , highly suggestive and agrees well with our own findings in which we also failed to demonstrate normally occurring bronchial artery pulmonary artery shunts in certain species , especially the dog .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In conclusion , these findings suggest the need for a comparative physiology , pathology , and histology of mammalian lungs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In addition , a detailed interspecies survey of the incidence of generalized pulmonary emphysema in mammals would be interesting and pertinent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Also , for the present , great caution should be exercised in the choice of an experimental animal for pulmonary studies if they are to be applied to man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is especially so if the dog , cat or monkey are to be used , in view of their marked anatomical differences from man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , it is suggested that in many respects the horse lung may be anatomically more comparable to that of the human than any other presently known species .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The main subgross anatomical features of the lungs of various mammals are presented .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A tabulation of these features permits the lungs to be grouped into three distinctive subgross types .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Type 1 , is represented by the cow , sheep , and pig ; type 2 , , by the dog , cat , and monkey ; type 3 , , by the horse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Lobularity is extremely well developed in type 1 , ; absent in type 2 , ; imperfectly developed in type 3 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pleura and interlobular septa are thick in types 1 , and 3 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pleura is extremely thin in type 2 , and septa are absent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Arterial supply to the pleura in types 1 , and 3 , is provided by the bronchial artery , and in type 2 , , by the pulmonary artery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In types 1 , , 2 , and 3 , the bronchial artery terminates in a capillary bed shared in common with the pulmonary artery at the level of the distal bronchiole .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In type 3 , the bronchial artery also provides blood directly to the alveolar capillary bed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">True terminal bronchioles comprise the most frequent form taken by the distal airways in types 1 , and 3 , , although small numbers of poorly developed respiratory bronchioles are present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Well developed respiratory bronchioles , on the other hand , appear to be the only form taken by the distal airways in type 2 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In type 1 , the pulmonary vein closely follows the course of the bronchus and the pulmonary artery from the periphery to the hilum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This maybe due to the heavy interlobular connective tissue barriers present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In type 3 , this general relationship is maintained peripherally but not centrally where the pulmonary vein follows a more independent path to the hilum as is the case throughout the lung in type 2 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Some of the features of the top portions of Figure 1 and Figure 2 were mentioned in discussing Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">First , the Onset Profile spreads across approximately 12 years for boys and 10 years for girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In contrast , 20 of the 21 lines in the Completion Profile ( excluding center 5 for boys and 4 for girls ) are bunched and extend over a much shorter period , approximately 30 months for boys and 40 months for girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Maturity Chart for each sex demonstrates clearly that Onset is a phenomenon of infancy and early childhood whereas Completion is a phenomenon of the later portion of adolescence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Second , for both sexes , the 21 transverse lines in the Onset Profile vary more in individual spread than those in the Completion Profile .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although the standard deviation values on which spread of the lines are based are relatively larger for those centers which begin to ossify early ( Table 1 ) , there are considerable differences in this value between centers having the closely timed Onsets .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Third , the process of calcification is seen to begin later and to continue much longer for these boys than for the girls , a fact which confirms data for other groups of children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Onset Profile and Completion Profile are constructed to serve as norms for children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is convenient to classify a child 's onset ages and completion ages as `` advanced '' , `` moderate '' ( modal ) , or `` delayed '' according to whether the child 's age equivalent `` dots '' appeared to the left of , upon , or to the right of the appropriate short transverse line .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When a dot appears close to the end of the transverse line , the `` moderate '' rating may be further classified according to the position of the dot with respect to the vertical marking denoting the mean age .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such classifications may be called `` somewhat advanced '' or `` somewhat delayed '' , as the case may be , reserving `` moderate '' for dots upon or close to the mean .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the lower portion of each Chart , the Skeletal Age ( Hand ) of boy 34 and girl 2 may be similarly classified .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There the middle one of the three curves denotes `` mean Skeletal Age '' for the Maturity Series boys and girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The upper curve denotes the mean plus one standard deviation , and the lower curve represents the mean minus one standard deviation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , a child 's Skeletal Age `` dots '' may be classified as `` advanced '' when they appear above the middle curve , `` moderate '' when they appear immediately above or below the middle curve , and `` delayed '' when they appear below the lower curve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To summarize the purpose of the Skeletal Maturity Chart : each contains two kinds of skeletal maturity norms which show two quite different methods of depicting developmental level of growth centers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">First , the upper portion requires series of films for every child , consisting of those from Hand , Elbow , Shoulder , Knee , and Foot .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The lower portion necessitates only films of Hand .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Second , the upper portion permits comparison of maturity levels of an equal number of growth centers from the long , short , and round bones of the five regions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The lower portion permits comparison of maturity levels of short and round bones predominantly , since only two long bones are included in Hand and Wrist as a region .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Third , the upper portion deals with only two indicators of developmental level , Onset and Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The lower portion utilizes the full complement of intermediate maturity indicators of each Hand center as well as their Onset and Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Fourth , the two indicators are for the most part widely separated chronologically , with the extensive age gap occurring during childhood for all but one growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The lower portion provides a rating at any stage between infancy and adulthood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Onsets , Completions , and Skeletal Ages ( Hand ) of boy 34 and girl 2 may be directly compared and classified , using only those Skeletal Ages which appear immediately below the Onset Profile and the Completion Profile .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It may be assumed that differences in ratings due to selection of growth centers from specific regions of the body will be small , according to existing tables of onset age and completion age for centers throughout the body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Accordingly , maturity level ratings by means of the upper portion and lower portion of the Chart , respectively , should be somewhat similar since Skeletal Age assessments are dependent upon Onsets during infancy and upon Completions during adolescence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is clear that there are some differences in the ratings , but there is substantial agreement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since a Skeletal Age rating can be made at any age during growth , from Elbow , Shoulder , Knee , or Foot as well as Hand , it seems to be the method of choice when one wishes to study most aspects of skeletal developmental progress during childhood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As stated earlier in the paper , Onsets and Completions - particularly the former - provide a different tool or indicator of expectancy in osseous development , each within a limited age period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such an indicator , or indicators , are needed as means of recognizing specific periods of delay in skeletal developmental progress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was stated earlier that one purpose of this study was to extend the analysis of variability of Onset and Completion in each of the 21 growth centers somewhat beyond that provided by the data in Tables 1 and 2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As one approach to doing this , Figures 3 and 4 have been constructed from the mean ages and the individual onset and completion ages for boy 34 and girl 2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The differences between onset age and completion age with respect to the corresponding mean age have been brought into juxtaposition by means of a series of arrows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The data for boy 34 appear in Figure 3 , and for girl 2 in Figure 4 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The numbering system used in Tables 1 and 2 and Figures 1 and 2 was continued for the 21 growth centers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The `` dot '' on one end of each arrow indicates extent of difference in months between the child 's onset age and the corresponding mean age for the growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The `` tip '' of the arrow represents extent of difference between the child 's completion age and the corresponding mean age for the growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , the alignment of the `` dots '' and `` tips '' , respectively , indicate individual variability of the 21 growth centers of each child with respect to the mean values for these boys and girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The direction in which the arrow points shows how the maturity level of the growth center was changed at Completion from the level at Onset .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When the `` dot '' and `` tip '' coincide , the classification used in this paper is `` same schedule '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The length of the arrow indicates amount of slowing or acceleration at Completion over that at Onset , and the difference in months can be read roughly by referring the arrow to the age scale along the base of each figure , or more precisely by referring to the original data in the appropriate tables .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The difference between the sequence of Onset of ossification for the sexes governs the numbering sequence in Figures 3 and 4 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This difference is readily clarified by referring to Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For example , arrow 17 in Figure 3 portrays the proximal radial epiphysis for boy 34 , whereas the same epiphysis for girl 2 is portrayed by arrow 18 in Figure 4 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the boy , this epiphysis was markedly delayed at Onset but near the mean at Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , the Span of its ossification was shortened and the center 's ability to `` catch up '' in ossification is demonstrated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In contrast , for the girl the epiphysis was slightly advanced at Onset and delayed at Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Obviously , the slowing for her may have occurred at any point between Onset and Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Skeletal Age curve in the lower portion of Figure 2 shows that slowing may have occurred for her during the prepubescent period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Length of the shaft of these arrows may be evaluated according to the standard deviation values for each center in Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We have attempted to simplify the extensive task of analyzing onset ages and completion ages of each child - more than 1700 values for the entire group - by constructing figures for each of the 21 centers so that the data for all 34 boys and 34 of the girls will appear together for each growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Figures 5 and 6 are examples of our method of analyzing the results for each growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Forty other figures similar to 5 and 6 and the original data used in the construction of all figures and tables in this monograph have been included in the Appendix .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The principles used in making each arrow for Figures 3 and 4 were applied to the construction of Figures 5 and 6 as well as all figures in the Appendix .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One growth center in a short bone - distal phalanx of the second finger - was chosen as an example for discussion here , primarily because epiphyseal diaphyseal fusion , the maturity indicator for Completion in long and short bones , occurs in this center for girls near the menarche and for boys near their comparable pubescent stage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its Completion thus becomes one of the convenient maturity indicators to include in studies of growth , dietary patterns , and health during adolescence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The following summary , based on Figures 5 and 6 , is an example of one way of interpreting the 42 figures constructed from onset ages and completion ages of individual children with respect to the appropriate mean age for each growth center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the top of Figure 5 , for example , the Onset range and Completion range lines for the chosen growth center have been drawn for girls according to their mean and standard deviation values in Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The 34 arrows , denoting onset age plus completion age deviations , have been arrayed in an Onset sequence which begins with girl 18 who had the earliest Onset of the 34 girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The growth center depicted here , in the distal phalanx of the second finger , is listed as the fifth of those in the seven short bones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The mean onset age was 25.3 months ( Table 1 ) , and the average Span of the osseous stage was 133 months .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The correlation ( Table 2 ) between onset age and completion age was + .50 , and that between onset age and Span was - .10 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With due consideration for the limits of precision in assessing , expected rate of change in ossification of girls age 2 years , and the known variations in rate of ossification of these children as described in our preceding paper in the Supplement , each arrow with a `` shaft length '' of four months or less was selected as indicating `` same schedule '' at Onset and Completion , for this particular epiphysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Accordingly , girls 31 , 29 , 33 , 21 , 26 , 13 , 3 , 4 , 14 , 32 , 24 , 25 , 34 , 23 , 6 , 15 , 22 , and 16 may be said to have the `` same schedule '' at Onset and Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It seems clear , from the counter-balanced shape of the series of arrows in Figure 5 that there was about an equal number of early and late Onsets and Completions for the 34 girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Accordingly , if epiphyseal diaphyseal fusion occurs in this phalanx near menarche , early and late menarches might have been forecast rather precisely at the time of Onset of ossification for the 18 girls with `` same schedule '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As an example of the interpretation of an arrow in the figure which exceeds four months in shaft length in conjunction with its position in the figure : girl 2 had a delayed Onset and further delayed Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is of interest that her menarche was somewhat later than the average for the girls in this group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A similar analysis of Figure 6 for the 34 boys would necessitate quite a different conclusion about the predictive value of onset age in forecasting their attainment of the pubescent stage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Boys 32 , 23 , 31 , 17 , 30 , 19 , and 24 had `` same schedule '' at Onset and Completion ; thus early forecasting of the pubescent stage would appear possible for only seven boys .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Boy 34 , like girl 2 , did not have `` same schedule '' ; his arrow crosses the line denoting the mean .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The `` dot '' on his arrow indicates early Onset and the `` tip '' indicates relatively later Completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After the 42 figures had been drawn like Figures 5 and 6 , classifications of the onset ages and completion ages were summarized from them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Interestingly enough , the effect of the digitalis glycosides is inhibited by a high concentration of potassium in the incubation medium and is enhanced by the absence of potassium ( Wolff , 1960 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The precise mechanism for organification of iodine in the thyroid is not as yet completely understood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">However , the formation of organically bound iodine , mainly mono-iodotyrosine , can be accomplished in cell-free systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the absence of additions to the homogenate , the product formed is an iodinated particulate protein ( Fawcett and Kirkwood , 1953 ; Taurog , Potter and Chaikoff , 1955 ; Taurog , Potter , Tong , and Chaikoff , 1956 ; Serif and Kirkwood , 1958 ; De Groot and Carvalho , 1960 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This iodoprotein does not appear to be the same as what is normally present in the thyroid , and there is no evidence so far that thyroglobulin can be iodinated in vitro by cell-free systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition , the iodoamino acid formed in largest quantity in the intact thyroid is di-iodotyrosine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If tyrosine and a system generating hydrogen peroxide are added to a cell-free homogenate of the thyroid , large quantities of free mono-iodotyrosine can be formed ( Alexander , 1959 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is not clear whether this system bears any resemblance to the in vivo iodinating mechanism , and a system generating peroxide has not been identified in thyroid tissue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On chemical grounds it seems most likely that iodide is first converted to * * f and then to * * f as the active iodinating species .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the thyroid gland it appears that proteins ( chiefly thyroglobulin ) are iodinated and that free tyrosine and thyronine are not iodinated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Iodination of tyrosine , however , is not enough for the synthesis of hormone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The mono - and di-iodotyrosine must be coupled to form tri-iodothyronine and thyroxine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The mechanism of this coupling has been studied in some detail with non-enzymatic systems in vitro and can be simulated by certain di-iodotyrosine analogues ( Pitt-Rivers and James , 1958 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is so far no evidence to indicate conclusively that this coupling is under enzymatic control .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The chemical nature of the iodocompounds is discussed below ( pp.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">76 et seq. ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Little is known of the synthetic mechanisms for formation of thyroglobulin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its synthesis has not been demonstrated in cell-free systems , nor has its synthesis by systems with intact thyroid cells in vitro been unequivocally proven .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is some reason to think that thyroglobulin synthesis may proceed independently of iodination , for in certain transplantable tumours of the rat thyroid containing essentially no iodinated thyroglobulin , a protein that appears to be thyroglobulin has been observed in ultracentrifuge experiments ( Wolff , Robbins and Rall , 1959 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Similar findings have been noted in a patient with congenital absence of the organification enzymes , whose thyroid tissue could only concentrate iodide .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition , depending on availability of dietary iodine , thyroglobulin may contain varying quantities of iodine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Since the circulating thyroid hormones are the amino acids thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine ( cf. Section C ) , it is clear that some mechanism must exist in the thyroid gland for their release from proteins before secretion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The presence of several proteases and peptidases has been demonstrated in the thyroid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One of the proteases has pH optimum of about 3.7 and another of about 5.7 ( McQuillan , Stanley and Trikojus , 1954 ; Alpers , Robbins and Rall , 1955 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The finding that the concentration of one of these proteases is increased in thyroid glands from TSH treated animals suggests that this protease may be active in vivo .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is no conclusive evidence yet that either of the proteases has been prepared in highly purified form nor is their specificity known .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A study of their activity on thyroglobulin has shown that thyroxine is not preferentially released and that the degradation proceeds stepwise with the formation of macromolecular intermediates ( Alpers , Petermann and Rall , 1956 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Besides proteolytic enzymes the thyroid possesses de-iodinating enzymes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A microsomal de-iodinase with a pH optimum of around 8 , and requiring reduced triphosphopyridine nucleotide for activity , has been identified in the thyroid ( Stanbury , 1957 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This de-iodinating enzyme is effective against mono - and di-iodotyrosine , but does not de-iodinate thyroxine or tri-iodothyronine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is assumed that the iodine released from the iodotyrosines remains in the iodide pool of the thyroid , where it is oxidised and re-incorporated into thyroglobulin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine released by proteolysis and so escaping de-iodination presumably diffuse into the blood stream .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has been shown that thyroglobulin binds thyroxine , but the binding does not appear to be particularly strong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has been suggested that the plasma thyroxine binding proteins , which have an extremely high affinity for thyroxine , compete with thyroglobulin for thyroxine ( Ingbar and Freinkel , 1957 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Antithyroid drugs are of two general types .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One type has a small univalent anion of the thiocyanate perchlorate fluoroboride type .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This ion inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by interfering with iodide concentration in the thyroid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It does not appear to affect the iodinating mechanism as such .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The other group of antithyroid agents or drugs is typified by thiouracil .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These drugs have no effect on the iodide concentrating mechanism , but they inhibit organification .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The mechanism of action of these drugs has not been completely worked out , but certain of them appear to act by reducing the oxidised form of iodine before it can iodinate thyroglobulin ( Astwood , 1954 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the other hand , there are a few antithyroid drugs of this same general type , such as resorcinol , possessing no reducing activity and possibly acting through formation of a complex with molecular iodine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Any of the antithyroid drugs , of either type , if given in large enough doses for a long period of time will cause goitre , owing to inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis , with production of hypothyroidism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The anterior lobe of the pituitary then responds by an increased output of TSH , causing the thyroid to enlarge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The effect of drugs that act on the iodide concentrating mechanism can be counteracted by addition of relatively large amounts of iodine to the diet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The antithyroid drugs of the thiouracil type , however , are not antagonised by such means .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Besides those of the thiouracil and resorcinol types , certain antithyroid drugs have been found in naturally occurring foods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The most conclusively identified is L - 5 - vinyl - 2 - thio oxazolidone , which was isolated from rutabaga ( Greer , 1950 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is presumed to occur in other members of the Brassica family .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is some evidence that naturally occurring goitrogens may play a role in the development of goitre , particularly in Tasmania and Australia ( Clements and Wishart , 1956 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There it seems that the goitrogen ingested by dairy animals is itself inactive but is converted in the animal to an active goitrogen , which is then secreted in the milk .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Besides the presence of goitrogens in the diet , the level of iodine itself in the diet plays a major role in governing the activity of the thyroid gland .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the experimental animal and in man gross deficiency in dietary iodine causes thyroid hyperplasia , hypertrophy and increased thyroid activity ( Money , Rall and Rawson , 1952 ; Stanbury , Brownell , Riggs , Perinetti , Itoiz , and Del Castillo , 1954 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In man the normal level of iodine in the diet and the level necessary to prevent development of goitre is about 100 | mg per day .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With lower levels , thyroid hypertrophy and increased thyroid blood flow enable the thyroid to accumulate a larger proportion of the daily intake of iodine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Further , the gland is able to re-use a larger fraction of the thyroid hormone de-iodinated peripherally .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the presence of a low iodine intake , thyroglobulin labelled in vivo with * * f is found to contain more mono-iodotyrosine than normal , the amounts of di-iodotyrosine and iodothyronines being correspondingly reduced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This appears to result from both a reduced amount of the iodine substrate and a more rapid secretion of newly iodinated thyroglobulin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the deficiency persists long enough , it is reasonable to suppose that the * * f label will reflect the * * f distribution in the thyroglobulin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Similar results might be expected from the influence of drugs or pathological conditions that limit iodide trapping , or organification , or accelerate thyroglobulin proteolysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The name thyroid-stimulating hormone ( TSH ) has been given to a substance found in the anterior pituitary gland of all species of animal so far tested for its presence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The hormone has also been called thyrotrophin or thyrotrophic hormone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the present time we do not know by what biochemical mechanism TSH acts on the thyroid , but for bio-assay of the hormone there are a number of properties by which its activity may be estimated , including release of iodine from the thyroid , increase in thyroid weight , increase in mean height of the follicular cells and increase in the thyroidal uptake of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here we shall restrict discussion to those methods that appear sufficiently sensitive and precise for determining the concentration of TSH in blood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Brown ( 1959 ) has reviewed generally the various methods of assaying TSH , and the reader is referred to her paper for further information on the subject .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As long ago as 1851 it was pointed out by Niepce ( 1851 ) that there is a connection between the pituitary and the thyroid .
.</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This connection was clarified by Smith and Smith ( 1922 ) , who showed that saline extracts of fresh bovine pituitary glands could re-activate the atrophied thyroids of hypophysectomised tadpoles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first attempts to isolate TSH came a decade later , when Janssen and Loeser ( 1931 ) used trichloroacetic acid to separate the soluble TSH from insoluble impurities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After their work other investigators applied salt fractionation techniques to the problem , as well as fractionation with organic solvents , such as acetone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Albert ( 1949 ) has concluded that the most active preparations of TSH made during this period , from 1931 to 1945 , were probably about 100 to 300 times as potent as the starting material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Much of this work has been reviewed by White ( 1944 ) and by Albert ( 1949 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Developments up to about 1957 have been discussed by Sonenberg ( 1958 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the last few years , the application of chromatographic and other modern techniques to the problem of isolating TSH has led to further purification ( Bates and Condliffe , 1960 ; Pierce , Carsten and Wynston , 1960 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The most active preparations obtained by these two groups of investigators appear to be similar in potency , composition and physical properties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Two problems present themselves in considering any hormone in blood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">First , is the circulating form of the hormone the same as that found in the gland where it is synthesised and stored ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Second , what is its concentration in normal circumstances and in what circumstances will this concentration depart from the normal level and in which direction ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is therefore necessary to consider the properties of pituitary TSH if the fragmentary chemical information about blood TSH is to be discussed rationally .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The importance of knowing in what chemical forms the hormone may exist is accentuated by the recent observation that there exists an abnormally long-acting TSH in blood drawn from many thyrotoxic patients ( Adams , 1958 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whether this abnormal TSH differs chemically from pituitary TSH , or is , alternatively , normal TSH with its period of effectiveness modified by some other blood constituent , cannot be decided without chemical study of the activity in the blood of these patients and a comparison of the substance responsible for the blood activity with pituitary TSH .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In evaluating data on the concentration of TSH in blood , one must examine critically the bio-assay methods used to obtain them .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Wound tumor virus is a leafhopper transmitted virus not easily transmissible by mechanical inoculation ( Black , 1944 ; Brakke et al. , 1954 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The concentration and apparent localization of the WTV antigen in pseudophloem tissue of the tumor may indicate that the virus preferentially multiplies in the phloem and may need to be directly placed in this tissue in order to infect plants .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since emotional reactions in the higher vertebrates depend on individual experience and are aroused in man , in addition , by complex symbols , one would expect that the hypothalamus could be excited from the cortex .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In experiments with topical application of strychnine on the cerebral cortex , the transmission of impulses from the cortex to the hypothalamus was demonstrated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Moreover , the responsiveness of the hypothalamus to nociceptive stimulation is greatly increased under these conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even more complex and obviously cortically induced forms of emotional arousal could be elicited in monkey A on seeing monkey B ( but not a rabbit ) in emotional stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A previously extinguished conditioned reaction was restored in monkey A and was associated with typical signs of emotional excitement including sympathetic discharges .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It seems to follow that by and large an antagonism exists between the paleo - and the neocortex as far as emotional reactivity is concerned , and that the balance between the two systems determines the emotional responsiveness of the organism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In addition , the neocortical hypothalamic relations play a great role in primates , as Mirsky 's interesting experiment on the `` communication of affect '' demonstrates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But even in relatively primitive laboratory animals such as the rat , sex activity closely identified with the hypothalamus and the visceral brain is enhanced by the neocortex .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">MacLean stressed correctly the importance of the visceral brain for preservation of the individual and the species , as evidenced by the influence of the limbic brain ( including the hypothalamus ) on emotions related to fight and flight and also on sexual functions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It should be added that in man neocortical hypothalamic interrelations probably play a role in the fusion of emotional processes with those underlying perception , memory , imagination , and creativity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Previous experiences are obviously of great importance for the qualitative and quantitative emotional response .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The visceral brain as well as the neocortex is known to contribute to memory , but this topic is beyond the scope of this paper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After this brief discussion of neo - , paleocortical , and cortico-hypothalamic relations , let us return once more to the problem of hypothalamic balance and its physiological and pathological significance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Facilitatory processes take place between neocortex and hypothalamus via ascending and descending pathways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus cortico-fugal discharges induced by topical application of strychnine to a minute area in the neocortex summate with spikes present in the hypothalamus and cause increased convulsive discharges .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the other hand , the temporary reduction in hypothalamic excitability through the injection of a barbiturate into the posterior hypothalamus causes a lessening in frequency and amplitude of cortical strychnine spikes until the hypothalamic excitability is restored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Apparently , a positive feedback exists between the posterior hypothalamus and the cerebral cortex .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Consequently , if for any reason the hypothalamic excitability falls below the physiological level , the lessened hypothalamic cortical discharges lead to a diminished state of activity in the cortex with consequent reduction in the cortico-fugal discharges .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Obviously , a vicious cycle develops .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This tendency can be broken either by restoring hypothalamic excitability directly or via cortico-hypothalamic pathways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is believed that drug therapy and electroshock involve the former and psychotherapy the latter mechanism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Before we comment further on these pathological conditions , we should remember that changes in the state of the hypothalamus within physiological limits distinguish sleep from wakefulness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , a low intensity of hypothalamic cortical discharges prevails in sleep and a high one during wakefulness , resulting in synchronous EEG potentials in the former and asynchrony in the latter condition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , the dominance in parasympathetic action ( with reciprocal inhibition of the sympathetic ) at the hypothalamic level induces , by its peripheral action , the autonomic symptoms of sleep and , by its action on the cortex , a lessening in the reactivity of the sensory and motor apparatus of the somatic nervous system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With the dominance of the sympathetic division of the hypothalamus , the opposite changes occur .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Since electrical stimulation of the posterior hypothalamus produces the effects of wakefulness while stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus induces sleep , it may be said that the reactivity of the whole organism is altered by a change in the autonomic reactivity of the hypothalamus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Similar effects can be induced reflexly via the baroreceptor reflexes in man and animals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of particular importance is the study of the actions of drugs in this respect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although no drugs act exclusively on the hypothalamus or a part of it , there is sufficient specificity to distinguish drugs which shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side from those which produce a parasympathetic dominance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The former comprise analeptic and psychoactive drugs , the latter the tranquilizers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Specific differences exist in the action of different drugs belonging to the same group as , for instance , between reserpine and chlorpromazine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Important as these differences are , they should not obscure the basic fact that by shifting the hypothalamic balance sufficiently to the parasympathetic side , we produce depressions , whereas a shift in the opposite direction causes excitatory effects and , eventually , maniclike changes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The emotional states produced by drugs influence the cortical potentials in a characteristic manner ; synchrony prevails in the EEG of the experimental animal after administration of tranquilizers , but asynchrony after application of analeptic and psychoactive drugs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The shock therapies act likewise on the hypothalamic balance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Physiological experiments and clinical observations have shown that these procedures influence the hypothalamically controlled hypophyseal secretions and increase sympathetic discharges .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This explains the beneficial effect of electroshock therapy in certain depressions and a shift in the reaction from hypo - to normal reactivity of the sympathetic system as shown by the Mecholyl test .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some investigators have found a parallelism between remissions and return of the sympathetic reactivity of the hypothalamus to the normal level as indicated by the Mecholyl test and , conversely , between clinical impairment and increasing deviation of this test from the norm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , the theory that the determining influence of the hypothalamic balance has a profound influence on the clinical behavior of neuropsychiatric patients has not yet been tested on an adequate number of patients .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Mecholyl and noradrenalin tests applied with certain precautions are reliable indicators of this central autonomic balance , but for the sake of correlating autonomic and clinical states , and of studying the effect of certain therapeutic procedures on central autonomic reactions , additional tests seem to be desirable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was assumed that the shift in autonomic hypothalamic balance occurring spontaneously in neuropsychiatric patients from the application of certain therapeutic procedures follows the pattern known from the sleep wakefulness cycle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A change in the balance to the parasympathetic side leads in the normal individual to sleep or , in special circumstances , to cardiovascular collapse or nausea and vomiting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In both conditions the emotional and perceptual sensitivity is diminished , but no depression occurs such as is seen clinically or may be produced in normal persons by drugs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The fundamental differences between physiological and pathological states of parasympathetic ( and also of sympathetic ) dominance remain to be elucidated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Perhaps a clue to these and related problems lies in the fact that changes in the intensity of hypothalamic discharges which are associated with changes in its balance lead also to qualitative alterations in reactivity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A state of parasympathetic `` tuning '' of the hypothalamus induced experimentally causes not only an increase in the parasympathetic reactivity this structure to direct and reflexly induced stimuli , but leads also to an autonomic reversal : a stimulus acting sympathetically under control conditions elicits in this state of tuning a parasympathetic response !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Furthermore , conditioned reactions are fundamentally altered when the hypothalamic sympathetic reactivity is augmented beyond a critical level , and several types of behavioral changes probably related to the degree of central autonomic `` tuning '' are observed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If , for instance , such a change is produced by one or a few insulin comas or electroshocks , previously inhibited conditioned reactions reappear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , if these procedures are applied more often , conditioned emotional responses are temporarily abolished .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In other studies , loss of differentiation in previously established conditioned reflexes resulted from repeated convulsive ( metrazol ) treatments , suggesting a fundamental disturbance in the balance between excitatory and inhibitory cerebral processes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has further been shown that : ( 1 ) an experimental neurosis in its initial stages is associated with a reversible shift in the central autonomic balance ; ( 2 ) drugs altering the hypothalamic balance alter conditioned reactions ; ( 3 ) in a state of depression , the positive conditioned stimulus may fail to elicit a conditioned reaction but cause an increased synchrony instead of the excitatory desynchronizing ( alerting ) effect on the EEG .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These are few and seemingly disjointed data , but they illustrate the important fact that fundamental alterations in conditioned reactions occur in a variety of states in which the hypothalamic balance has been altered by physiological experimentation , pharmacological action , or clinical processes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The foregoing remarks imply that the hypothalamic balance plays a crucial role at the crossroads between physiological and pathological forms of emotion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If this is the case , one would expect that not only the various procedures just mentioned which alter the hypothalamic balance would influence emotional state and behavior but that emotion itself would act likewise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We pointed out that emotional excitement may lead to psychosomatic disorders and neurotic symptoms , particularly in certain types of personality , but it is also known that the reliving of a strong emotion ( `` abreaction '' ) may cure a battle neurosis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This phenomenon raises the question whether the guidance of the emotions for therapeutic ends may not have an even wider application in the area of the neuroses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Being a strictly physiological procedure , one may expect from such a study additional information on the nature of the emotional process itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Wolpe 's experiments and therapeutic work lie in this area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He showed convincingly that anxiety is a learned ( conditioned ) reaction and is the basis of experimental and clinical neuroses and assumed , therefore , that the neuronal changes which underlie the neuroses are functional and reversible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An important observation of Pavlov served as a guide post to achieve such a reversibility by physiological means .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In a conditioning experiment , he demonstrated the antagonism between feeding and pain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A mild electrical shock served as a conditioned stimulus and was followed by feeding .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The pain became thus the symbol for food and elicited salivary secretion ( conditioned reflex ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Even when the intensity of the shocks was increased gradually , it failed to evoke any signs of pain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Since strong nociceptive stimuli produce an experimental neurosis during which the animals fail to eat in the experimental situation , Wolpe thought that he could utilize the feeding pain antagonism to inhibit the neurotic symptoms through feeding .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Appropriate experiments showed that this is , indeed , possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He then applied this principle of reciprocal inhibition to human neuroses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He took advantage of the antagonism between aggressive assertiveness and anxiety and found a relatively rapid disappearance of anxiety when the former attitude was established .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the interpretation of these significant investigations , it should be remembered that reciprocal relations exist in the hypothalamus with respect to autonomic and somatic functions which are closely associated with the emotions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The feeding pain antagonism seems to be based on this reciprocal relation between the tropho - and ergotropic systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Furthermore , a functional antagonism exists between an aggressive attitude and a state of anxiety .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Although in both emotions sympathetic symptoms are present , different autonomic somatic patterns underlie aggression and anxiety , respectively , as indicated by the rate of the excretion of the catecholamines , the state of the muscle tone , and the Mecholyl test .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The psychological incompatibility of these emotional states seems to be reflected in , or based on , this marked difference .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In our attempt to interpret the emotions in their physiological and pathological range , we emphasized the importance of the degree of activity of the parasympathetic and sympathetic divisions of the hypothalamic system and their influence on the inhibitory and excitatory systems , respectively .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We stressed the reciprocal relation of these systems with respect to the autonomic somatic downward discharge as well as regarding the hypothalamic cortical discharge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although we are still far from a complete understanding of these problems , as a first approximation , it is suggested that alterations in the hypothalamic balance with consequent changes in the hypothalamic cortical discharges account for major changes in behavior seen in various moods and states of emotions in man and beast under physiological circumstances , in experimental and clinical neurosis , and as the result of psychopharmacological agents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In view of the important role which emotional disturbances play in the genesis of neurotic and psychotic disorders and the parallelism observed between autonomic states and psychological behavior in several instances , it is further suggested that a hypothalamic imbalance may play an important role in initiating mental changes .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Let V be a finite dimensional vector space over an algebraically closed field F , e.g. , the field of complex numbers .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some experiments are composed of repetitions of independent trials , each with two possible outcomes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The binomial probability distribution may describe the variation that occurs from one set of trials of such a binomial experiment to another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We devote a chapter to the binomial distribution not only because it is a mathematical model for an enormous variety of real life phenomena , but also because it has important properties that recur in many other probability models .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We begin with a few examples of binomial experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A trained marksman shooting five rounds at a target , all under practically the same conditions , may hit the bull's-eye from 0 to 5 times .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In repeated sets of five shots his numbers of bull's-eyes vary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What can we say of the probabilities of the different possible numbers of bull's-eyes ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In litters of eight mice from similar parents , the number of mice with straight instead of wavy hair is an integer from 0 to 8 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What probabilities should be attached to these possible outcomes ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When three dice are tossed repeatedly , what is the probability that the number of aces is 0 ( or 1 , or 2 , or 3 ) ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">More generally , suppose that an experiment consists of a number of independent trials , that each trial results in either a `` success '' or a `` non success '' ( `` failure '' ) , and that the probability of success remains constant from trial to trial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the examples above , the occurrence of a bull's-eye , a straight haired mouse , or an ace could be called a `` success '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In general , any outcome we choose may be labeled `` success '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The major question in this chapter is : What is the probability of exactly x successes in n trials ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In Chapters 3 and 4 we answered questions like those in the examples , usually by counting points in a sample space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Fortunately , a general formula of wide applicability solves all problems of this kind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Before deriving this formula , we explain what we mean by `` problems of this kind '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Experiments are often composed of several identical trials , and sometimes experiments themselves are repeated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the marksmanship example , a trial consists of `` one round shot at a target '' with outcome either one bull's-eye ( success ) or none ( failure ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Further , an experiment might consist of five rounds , and several sets of five rounds might be regarded as a super experiment composed of several repetitions of the five round experiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If three dice are tossed , a trial is one toss of one die and the experiment is composed of three trials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Or , what amounts to the same thing , if one die is tossed three times , each toss is a trial , and the three tosses form the experiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Mathematically , we shall not distinguish the experiment of three dice tossed once from that of one die tossed three times .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These examples are illustrative of the use of the words `` trial '' and `` experiment '' as they are used in this chapter , but they are quite flexible words and it is well not to restrict them too narrowly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ten students act as managers for a high-school football team , and of these managers a proportion p are licensed drivers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each Friday one manager is chosen by lot to stay late and load the equipment on a truck .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On three Fridays the coach has needed a driver .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Considering only these Fridays , what is the probability that the coach had drivers all 3 times ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Exactly 2 times ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">1 time ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">0 time ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Note that there are 3 trials of interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each trial consists of choosing a student manager at random .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The 2 possible outcomes on each trial are `` driver '' or `` nondriver '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since the choice is by lot each week , the outcomes of different trials are independent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The managers stay the same , so that * * f is the same for all weeks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We now generalize these ideas for general binomial experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For an experiment to qualify as a binomial experiment , it must have four properties : ( 1 ) there must be a fixed number of trials , ( 2 ) each trial must result in a `` success '' or a `` failure '' ( a binomial trial ) , ( 3 ) all trials must have identical probabilities of success , ( 4 ) the trials must be independent of each other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Below we use our earlier examples to describe and illustrate these four properties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We also give , for each property , an example where the property is absent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The language and notation introduced are standard throughout the chapter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the marksman , we study sets of five shots ( * * f ) ; for the mice , we restrict attention to litters of eight ( * * f ) ; and for the aces , we toss three dice ( * * f ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Toss a die until an ace appears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Here the number of trials is a random variable , not a fixed number .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each of the n trials is either a success or a failure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Success '' and `` failure '' are just convenient labels for the two categories of outcomes when we talk about binomial trials in general .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These words are more expressive than labels like `` A '' and `` not - A '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is natural from the marksman 's viewpoint to call a bull's-eye a success , but in the mice example it is arbitrary which category corresponds to straight hair in a mouse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The word `` binomial '' means `` of two names '' or `` of two terms '' , and both usages apply in our work : the first to the names of the two outcomes of a binomial trial , and the second to the terms p and * * f that represent the probabilities of `` success '' and `` failure '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes when there are many outcomes for a single trial , we group these outcomes into two classes , as in the example of the die , where we have arbitrarily constructed the classes `` ace '' and `` not ace '' .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Experimentally , we expect independence when the trials have nothing to do with one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A family of five plans to go together either to the beach or to the mountains , and a coin is tossed to decide .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We want to know the number of people going to the mountains .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Indeed , the experiment is better viewed as consisting of one binomial trial for the entire family .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The following is a less extreme example of dependence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Consider couples visiting an art museum .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These societies can expect to face difficult times .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As the historic processes of modernization gradually gain momentum , their cohesion will be threatened by divisive forces , the gaps between rulers and subjects , town and country , will widen ; new aspirants for power will emerge whose ambitions far exceed their competence ; old rulers may lose their nerve and their sense of direction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">National leaders will have to display the highest skills of statesmanship to guide their people through times of uncertainty and confusion which destroy men 's sense of identity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Feelings of a community of interest will have to be recreated - in some of the new nations , indeed , they must be built for the first time - on a new basis which looks toward the future and does not rely only on shared memories of the past .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , with foresight and careful planning , some of the more disruptive and dangerous consequences of social change which have troubled other countries passing through this stage can be escaped .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The United States can help by communicating a genuine concern with the problems these countries face and a readiness to provide technical and other appropriate forms of assistance where possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our central goal should be to provide the greatest positive incentive for these societies to tackle boldly the tasks which they face .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">At the same time , we should recognize that the obstacles to change and the lack of cohesion and stability which characterize these countries may make them particularly prone to diversions and external adventures of all sorts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It may seem to some of them that success can be purchased much less dearly by fishing in the murky waters of international politics than by facing up to the intractable tasks at home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should do what we can to discourage this conclusion , both by offering assistance for their domestic needs and by reacting firmly to irresponsible actions on the world scene .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When necessary , we should make it clear that countries which choose to derive marginal advantages from the cold war or to exploit their potential for disrupting the security of the world will not only lose our sympathy but also risk their own prospects for orderly development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As a nation , we feel an obligation to assist other countries in their development ; but this obligation pertains only to countries which are honestly seeking to become responsible members of a stable and forward-moving world community .</MPQASENT>
