<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we look at countries like Iran , Iraq , Pakistan , and Burma , where substantial progress has been made in creating a minimum supply of modern men and of social overhead capital , and where institutions of centralized government exist , we find a second category of countries with a different set of problems and hence different priorities for policy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The men in power are committed in principle to modernization , but economic and social changes are proceeding only erratically .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Isolated enterprises have been launched , but they are not yet related to each other in a meaningful pattern .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The society is likely to be characterized by having a fairly modernized urban sector and a relatively untouched rural sector , with very poor communications between the two .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Progress is impeded by psychological inhibitions to effective action among those in power and by a failure on their part to understand how local resources , human and material , can be mobilized to achieve the national goals of modernization already symbolically accepted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Most countries in this second category share the difficulty of having many of the structures of a modern political and social system without the modern standards of performance required to make them effective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In these rapidly changing societies there is also too little appreciation of the need for effort to achieve goals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The colonial period has generally left people believing that government can , if it wishes , provide all manner of services for them - and that with independence free men do not have to work to realize the benefits of modern life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , in accordance with the fashion of the times , most transitional societies have announced economic development plans of varying numbers of years ; such is the mystique of planning that people expect that fulfillment of the plan will follow automatically upon its announcement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The civil services in such societies are generally inadequate to deal competently with the problems facing them ; and their members often equate a government career with security and status rather than with sacrifice , self-discipline , and competence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">American policy should press constantly the view that until these governments demand efficiency and effectiveness of their bureaucracies there is not the slightest hope that they will either modernize of democratize their societies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should spread the view that planning and national development are serious matters which call for effort as well as enthusiasm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Above all , we should seek to encourage the leaders of these societies to accept the unpleasant fact that they are responsible for their fates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only within the framework of a mature relationship characterized by honest appraisals of performance can we provide telling assistance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">With respect to those countries whose leaders prefer to live with their illusions , we can afford to wait , for in time their comparative lack of progress will become clear for all to see .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our technical assistance to these countries should place special emphasis on inducing the central governments to assume the role of advisor and guide which at an earlier stage foreign experts assumed in dealing with the central governments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should encourage the governments to develop their own technical assistance to communities , state and provincial governments , rural communities , and other smaller groups , making certain that no important segment of the economy is neglected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Simultaneously we should be underlining the interrelationships of technical progress in various fields , showing how agricultural training can be introduced into education , how health affects labor productivity , how small business can benefit the rural farm community , and , above all , how progress in each field relates to national progress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Efforts such as the Community Development Program in the Philippines have demonstrated that transitional societies can work toward balanced national development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To achieve this goal of balanced development , communications between the central government and the local communities must be such that the needs and aspirations of the people themselves are effectively taken into account .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If modernization programs are imposed from above , without the understanding and cooperation of the people , they will encounter grave difficulties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Land reform is likely to be a pressing issue in many of these countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It should be American policy not only to encourage effective land reform programs but also to underline the relation of such reforms to the economic growth and modernization of the society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As an isolated policy , land reform is likely to be politically disruptive ; as part of a larger development effort , however , it may gain wide acceptance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It should also be recognized that the problem of rural tenancy cannot be solved by administrative decrees alone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Land reform programs need to be supplemented with programs for promoting rural credits and technical assistance in agriculture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Lastly , governmental and private planners will at this stage begin to see large capital requirements looming ahead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By holding out prospects for external capital assistance , the United States can provide strong incentives to prepare for the concerted economic drive necessary to achieve self-sustaining growth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At a third stage in the modernization process are such countries as India , Brazil , the Philippines , and Taiwan , which are ready and committed to move into the stage of self-sustaining growth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They must continue to satisfy basic capital needs ; and there persists the dual problem of maintaining operational unity around a national program of modernization while simultaneously decentralizing participation in the program to wider and wider groups .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But these countries have made big strides toward developing the necessary human and social overhead capital ; they have established reasonably stable and effective governmental institutions at national and local levels ; and they have begun to develop a capacity to deal realistically and simultaneously with all the major sectors of their economies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the economic front , the first priority of these countries is to mobilize a vastly increased volume of resources .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Several related tasks must be carried out if self-sustaining growth is to be achieved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These countries must formulate a comprehensive , long-term program covering the objectives of both the private and the public sectors of the economy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They must in their planning be able to count on at least tentative commitments of foreign capital assistance over periods of several years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Capital imports drawn from a number of sources must be employed and combined skillfully enough to permit domestic investment programming to go forward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Capital flows must be coordinated with national needs and planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , a balance must be effected among project finance , utilization of agricultural surpluses , and general balance of payments support .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , although the agenda of external assistance in the economic sphere are cumulative , and many of the policies suggested for nations in the earlier stages remain relevant , the basic purpose of American economic policy during the later stages of development should be to assure that movement into a stage of self-sustaining growth is not prevented by lack of foreign exchange .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There remain many political and administrative problems to be solved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">For one thing , although considerable numbers of men have been trained , bureaucracies are still deficient in many respects ; even the famed Indian Civil Service is not fully adequate to the tremendous range of tasks it has undertaken .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Technical assistance in training middle - and upper-level management personnel is still needed in many cases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are also more basic problems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is the stage at which democratic developments must take place if the society is to become an open community of creative people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , impulses still exist among the ruling elite to rationalize and thus to perpetuate the need for centralized and authoritarian practices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Another great danger is that the emerging middle class will feel itself increasingly alienated from the political leaders who still justify their dominance by reference to the struggle for independence or the early phase of nationalism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The capacity of intellectuals and members of the new professional classes to contribute creatively to national development is likely to be destroyed by a constraining sense of inferiority toward both their own political class and their colleagues and professional counterparts in the West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Particularly when based upon a single dominant party , governments may respond to such a situation by claiming a monopoly of understanding about the national interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Convinced of the wisdom of their own actions , and reassured by the promises of their economic development programs , governments may fail to push outward to win more and more people to the national effort , becoming instead rigid and inflexible in their policies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">American policy toward such societies should stress our sympathy for the emerging social and professional classes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It should attempt to communicate both an appreciation of professional standards and an understanding of the tremendous powers and potentialities of genuinely open and pluralistic societies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We have every obligation to take seriously their claims to being democratic and free countries ; we also have , in consequence , the duty to appraise realistically and honestly their performance and to communicate our judgments to their leaders in frank but friendly ways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We have emphasized that the modernizing process in each society will take a considerable period of time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With the exception of treaty making , foreign relations were historically concerned for the most part with conditions of short or at least measurable duration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Foreign policy now takes on a different perspective and must become skilled not merely at response but also at projection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">American and free-world policies can marginally affect the pace of transition ; but basically that pace depends on changes in the supply of resources and in the human attitudes , political institutions , and social structure which each society must generate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It follows that any effective policy toward the underdeveloped countries must have a realistically long working horizon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It must be marked by a patience and persistence which have not always been its trademark .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This condition affects not only the conception but also the legislative and financial support of foreign policy , especially in the context of economic aid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The place of religion in the simple , preliterate societies is quite definite ; as a complex it fits into the whole social organization and functions dominantly in every part of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In societies like ours , however , its place is less clear and more complex .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">With the diversity of religious viewpoints , there are differences of opinion as to the essential features of religion ; and there are different opinions as to the essential functions of religion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , for most of the population of heterogeneous advanced societies , though less for the less religious portion , religion does perform certain modal individual and social functions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although the inner functions of religion are not of direct significance in social organization , they have important indirect consequences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the inner functions of religion are performed , the individual is a composed , ordered , motivated , and emotionally secure associate ; he is not greatly frustrated , and he is not anomic ; he is better fitted to perform his social life among his fellows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are several closely related inner functions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the last analysis , religion is the means of inducing , formulating , expressing , enhancing , implementing , and perpetuating man 's deepest experience - the religious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Man is first religious ; the instrumentalities follow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion seeks to satisfy human needs of great pertinence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The significant things in it , at the higher religious levels , are the inner emotional , mental , and spiritual occurrences that fill the pressing human needs of self-preservation , self pacification , and self completion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The chief experience is the sensing of communion , and in the higher religions , of a harmonious relationship with the supernatural power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Related to this is the fact that most of the higher religions define for the individual his place in the universe and give him a feeling that he is relatively secure in an ordered , dependable universe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Man has the experience of being helpfully allied with what he cannot fully understand ; he is a coordinate part of all of the mysterious energy and being and movement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The universe is a safe and permanent home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A number of religions also satisfy for many the need of being linked with the ultimate and eternal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Death is not permanent defeat and disappearance ; man has a second chance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is not lost in the abyss of endless time ; he has endless being .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Religion at its best also offers the experience of spiritual fulfillment by inviting man into the highest realm of the spirit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Religion can summate , epitomize , relate , and conserve all the highest ideals and values - ethical , aesthetic , and religious - of man formed in his culture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is also the possibility , among higher religions , of experiencing consistent meaning in life and enjoying guidance and expansiveness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The kind of religious experience that most moderns seek not only provides , clarifies , and relates human yearnings , values , ideals , and purposes ; it also provides facilities and incitements for the development of personality , sociality , and creativeness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Under the religious impulse , whether theistic or humanistic , men have joy in living ; life leads somewhere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Religion at its best is out in front , ever beckoning and leading on , and , as Lippman put it , `` mobilizing all man 's scattered energies in one triumphant sense of his own infinite importance '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the same time that religion binds the individual helpfully to the supernatural and gives him cosmic peace and a sense of supreme fulfillment , it also has great therapeutic value for him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It gives him aid , comfort , even solace , in meeting mundane life situations where his own unassisted practical knowledge and skill are felt by him to be inadequate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is confronted with the recurrent crises , such as great natural catastrophes and the great transitions of life - marriage , incurable disease , widowhood , old age , the certainty of death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He has to cope with frustration and other emotional disturbance and anomie .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">His religious beliefs provide him with plausible explanations for many conditions which cause him great concern , and his religious faith makes possible fortitude , equanimity , and consolation , enabling him to endure colossal misfortune , fear , frustration , uncertainty , suffering , evil , and danger .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Religion usually also includes a principle of compensation , mainly in a promised perfect future state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The belief in immortality , where held , functions as a redress for the ills and disappointments of the here and now .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The tensions accompanying a repressive consciousness of wrongdoing or sinning or some tormenting secret are relieved for the less self-contained or self-sufficient by confession , repentance , and penance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The feeling of individual inferiority , defeat , or humilation growing out of various social situations or individual deficiencies or failures is compensated for by communion in worship or prayer with a friendly , but all-victorious Father-God , as well as by sympathetic fellowship with others who share this faith , and by opportunities in religious acts for giving vent to emotions and energies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In providing for these inner individual functions , religion undertakes in behalf of individual peace of mind and well-being services for which there is no other institution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In addition to the functions of religion within man , there have always been the outer social functions for the community and society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The two have never been separable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion is vitally necessary in both societal maintenance and regulation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The value-system of a community or society is always correlated with , and to a degree dependent upon , a more or less shared system of religious beliefs and convictions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The religion supports , re-enforces , reaffirms , and maintains the fundamental values .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even in the united states , with its freedom of religious belief and worship and its vast denominational differentiation , there is a general consensus regarding the basic Christian values .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is demonstrated especially when there is awareness of radically different value orientation elsewhere ; for example Americans rally to Christian values vis-a-vis those of atheistic communism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In America also all of our major religious bodies officially sanction a universalistic ethic which is reflective of our common religion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even the non church members - the freewheelers , marginal religionists and so on - have the values of Christian civilization internalized in them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Furthermore , religion tends to integrate the whole range of values from the highest or ultimate values of God to the intermediary and subordinate values ; for example , those regarding material objects and pragmatic ends .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Finally , it gives sanctity , more than human legitimacy , and even , through super empirical reference , transcendent and supernatural importance to some values ; for example , marriage as a sacrament , much law-breaking as sinful , occasionally the state as a divine instrument .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It places certain values at least beyond questioning and tampering .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Closely related to this function is the fact that the religious system provides a body of ultimate ends for the society , which are compatible with the supreme eternal ends .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This something leads to a conception of an over-all Social Plan with a meaning interpretable in terms of ultimate ends ; for example , a plan that fulfills the will of God , which advances the Kingdom of God , which involves social life as part of the Grand Design .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This explains some group ends and provides a justification of their primacy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It gives social guidance and direction and makes for programs of social action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , it gives meaning to much social endeavor , and logic , consistency , and meaning to life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In general , there is no society so secularized as to be completely without religiously inspired transcendental ends .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion integrates and unifies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some of the oldest , most persistent , and most cohesive forms of social groupings have grown out of religion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These groups have varied widely from mere families , primitive , totemic groups , and small modern cults and sects , to the memberships of great denominations , and great , widely dispersed world religions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion fosters group life in various ways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The common ultimate values , ends and goals fostered by religion are a most important factor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Without a system of values there can be no society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Where such a value system prevails , it always unifies all who possess it ; it enables members of the society to operate as a system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The beliefs of a religion also reflecting the values are expressed in creeds , dogmas , and doctrines , and form what Durkheim calls a credo .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As he points out , a religious group cannot exist without a collective credo , and the more extensive the credo , the more unified and strong is the group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The credo unifies and socializes men by attaching them completely to an identical body of doctrine ; the more extensive and firm the body of doctrine , the firmer the group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The religious symbolism , and especially the closely related rites and worship forms , constitute a powerful bond for the members of the particular faith .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The religion , in fact , is an expression of the unity of the group , small or large .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The common codes , for religious action as such and in their ethical aspects for everyday moral behavior , bind the devotees together .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These are ways of jointly participating in significantly symbolized , standardized , and ordered religiously sanctified behavior .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The codes are mechanism for training in , and directing and enforcing , uniform social interaction , and for continually and publicly reasserting the solidarity of the group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Durkheim noted long ago that religion as `` a unified system of beliefs and practices relative to sacred things - unite [ s ] into one single moral community - all those who adhere to them '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His view is that every religion pertains to a community , and , conversely , every community is in one aspect a religious unit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is brought out in the common religious ethos that prevails even in the denominationally diverse audiences at many secular semi-public and public occasions in the United States ; and it is evidenced in the prayers offered , in the frequent religious allusions , and in the confirmation of points on religious grounds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The unifying effect of religion is also brought out in the fact that historically peoples have clung together as more or less cohesive cultural units , with religion as the dominant bond , even though spatially dispersed and not politically organized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Jews for 2500 years have been a prime example , though the adherents of any world or inter people religion are cases in point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">it might be pointed out that the integrating function of religion , for good or ill , has often supported or been identified with other groupings - political , nationality , language , class , racial , sociability , even economic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion usually exercises a stabilizing conserving function .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As such it acts as an anchor for the people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is a marked tendency for religions , once firmly established , to resist change , not only in their own doctrines and policies and practices , but also in secular affairs having religious relevance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has thus been a significant factor in the conservation of social values , though also in some measure , an obstacle to the creation or diffusion of new ones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It tends to support the longstanding precious sentiments , the traditional ways of thinking , and the customary ways of living .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As Yinger has pointed out , the `` reliance on symbols , on tradition , on sacred writings , on the cultivation of emotional feelings of identity and harmony with sacred values , turns one to the past far more than to the future '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Historically , religion has also functioned as a tremendous engine of vindication , enforcement , sanction , and perpetuation of various other institutions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the same time that religion exercises a conserving influence , it also energizes and motivates both individuals and groups .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Much of the important individual and social action has been owing to religious incentives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The great ultimate ends of religion have served as magnificent beacon lights that lured people toward them with an almost irresistible force , mobilizing energies and inducing sacrifices ; for example , the Crusades , mission efforts , just wars .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Much effort has been expended in the sincere effort to apply the teaching and admonitions of religion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The insuperable reward systems that most religions embody have great motivating effects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Religion provides the most attractive rewards , either in this world or the next , for those who not merely abide by its norms , but who engage in good works .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Religion usually acts as a powerful aid in social control , enforcing what men should or should not do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Among primitive peoples the sanctions and dictates of religion were more binding than any of the other controls exercised by the group ; and in modern societies such influence is still great .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Religion has its own supernatural prescriptions that are at the same time codes of behavior for the here and now .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An analysis of the election falls naturally in four parts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">First is the long and still somewhat obscure process of preparation , planning and discussion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Preparation began slightly more than a year after independence with the first steps to organize rural communes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">All political interests supported electoral planning , although there are some signs that the inherent uncertainties of a popular judgment led to some procrastination .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The second major aspect of the election is the actual procedure of registration , nomination and voting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Considerable technical skill was used and the administration of the elections was generally above reproach .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">However , the regionally differentiated results , which appear below in tables , are interesting evidence of the problems of developing self-government under even the most favorable circumstances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A third aspect , and probably the one open to most controversy , is the results of the election .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The electoral procedure prevented the ready identification of party affiliation , but all vitally interested parties , including the government itself , were busily engaged in determining the party identifications of all successful candidates the month following the elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The fourth and concluding point will be to estimate the long-run significance of the elections and how they figure in the current pattern of internal politics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Elections have figured prominently in nearly every government program and official address since independence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were stressed in the speeches of Si Mubarak Bekkai when the first Council of Ministers was formed and again when the Istiqlal took a leading role in the second Council .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">King Muhammad /5 , was known to be most sympathetic to the formation of local self-government and made the first firm promise of elections on May Day , 1957 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There followed a long and sometimes bitter discussion of the feasibility of elections for the fall of 1957 , in which it appears that the Minister of the Interior took the most pessimistic view and that the Istiqlal was something less than enthusiastic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the complicated process of establishing new communes and reviewing the rudimentary plan left by the French did not even begin until the fall of 1957 , this goal appears somewhat ambitious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the very beginning the electoral discussions raised fundamental issues in Moroccan politics , precisely the type of questions that were most difficult to resolve in the new government .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Until the Charter of Liberties was issued in the fall of 1958 , there were no guarantees of the right to assemble or to organize for political purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Istiqlal was still firmly united in 1957 , but the P.D.I. ( Parti Democratique de l'Independance ) , the most important minor party at the time , objected to the Istiqlal 's predominance in the civil service and influence in Radio Maroc .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There were rumors that the Ministry of the Interior favored an arbitrary , `` non-political '' process , which were indirectly affirmed when the King personally intervened in the planned meetings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The day following his intervention the palace issued a statement reassuring the citizens that `` the possibility of introducing appeals concerning the establishment of electoral lists , lists of candidates and finally the holding of the consultation itself '' would be supported by the King himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Ifni crisis in the fall of 1957 postponed further consideration of elections , but French consultants were called in and notices of further investigation appeared from time to time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In January , 1958 , the Minister of the Interior announced that an election law was ready to be submitted to the King , the rumors of election dates appeared once again , first for spring of 1958 and later for the summer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although the government was probably prepared for elections by mid - 1958 , the first decision was no doubt made more difficult as party strife multiplied .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In late 1957 the M.P. ( Mouvement Populaire ) appeared and in the spring of 1958 the internal strains of the Istiqlal was revealed when the third Council of Government under Balafrej was formed without support from progressive elements in the party .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The parties were on the whole unprepared for elections , while the people were still experiencing post independence let-down and suffering the after effects of poor harvests in 1957 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Despite the internal and international crises that harassed Morocco the elections remained a central issue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They figured prominently in the Balafrej government of May , 1958 , which the King was reportedly determined to keep in office until elections could be held .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the eagerly sought `` homogeneity '' of the Balafrej Council of Government was never achieved as the Istiqlal quarreled over foreign policy , labor politics and economic development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By December , 1958 , when ' Abdallah Ibrahim became President of the Council , elections had even greater importance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were increasingly looked upon as a means of establishing the new rural communes as the focus of a new , constructive national effort .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To minimize the chances of repeating the Balafrej debacle the Ibrahim government was formed a titre personnel and a special office was created in the Ministry of the Interior to plan and to conduct the elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">By this time there is little doubt but what election plans were complete .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There remained only the delicate task of maneuvering the laws through the labyrinth of Palace politics and making a small number of policy decisions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From the rather tortuous history of electoral planning in Morocco an important point emerges concerning the first elections in a developing country and evaluating their results .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the new country the electoral process is considered as a means of resolving fundamental , and sometimes bitter , differences among leaders and also as a source of policy guidance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the absence of a reservoir of political consensus each organized political group hopes that the elections will give them new prominence , but in a system where there is as yet no place for the less prominent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Lacking the respected and effective institutions that consensus helps provide , minority parties , such as the P.D.I. in 1957 and the progressive Istiqlal faction in 1958 , clamor for elections when out of power , but are not at all certain they wish to be controlled by popular choice when in power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those in power tend to procrastinate and even to repudiate the electoral process .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The tendency to treat elections as an instrument of self-interest rather than an instrument of national interest had two important effects on electoral planning in Morocco .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">At the central level the scrutin uninominal voting system was selected over some form of the scrutin de liste system , even though the latter had been recommended by Duverger and favored by all political parties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The choice of the single member district was dictated to a certain extent by problems of communication and understanding in the more remote areas of the country , but it also served to minimize the national political value of the elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although the elections were for local officials , it was not necessary to conduct the elections so as to prevent parties from publicly identifying their candidates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With multiple member districts the still fragmentary local party organizations could have operated more effectively and parties might have been encouraged to state their positions more clearly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both parties and the Ministry of the Interior were busily at work after the elections trying to unearth the political affiliations of the successful candidates and , thereby , give the elections a confidential but known degree of national political significance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since a national interpretation cannot be avoided it is unfortunate that the elections were not held in a way to maximize party responsibility and the educational effect of mass political participation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The general setting of the Moroccan election may also encourage the deterioration of local party organization .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The concentration of effective power in Rabat leads not only to party bickering , but to distraction from local activity that might have had many auxiliary benefits in addition to contributing to more meaningful elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Interesting evidence can be found in the results of the Chamber of Commerce elections , which took place three weeks before national elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Istiqlal sponsored U.M.C.I.A. ( L'Union Marocaine des Commercants , Industrialistes et Artisans ) was opposed by candidates of the new U.N.F.P. ( L'Union National des Forces Populaires ) in nearly all urban centers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As the more conservative group with strong backing from wealthy businessmen , the U.M.C.I.A. was generally favored against the more progressive , labor based U.N.F.P.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The newer party campaigned heavily , while the older , more confident party expected the Moroccan merchants and small businessmen to support them as they had done for many years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The local Istiqlal and U.M.C.I.A. offices did not campaign and lost heavily .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The value of the elections was lost , both as an experiment in increased political participation and as a reliable indicator of commercial interest , as shown in Table /1 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The chamber of Commerce elections were , of course , an important event in the preparation for rural commune elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The U.N.F.P. learned that its urban organization , which depends heavily on U.M.T. support , was most effective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The Istiqlal found that the spontaneous solidarity of the independence struggle was not easily transposed to the more concrete , precise problems of internal politics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The overall effect was probably to stimulate more party activity in the communal elections than might have otherwise taken place .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A second major point of this essay is to examine the formal arrangements for the elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although a somewhat technical subject , it has important political implications as the above discussion of the voting system indicated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Furthermore , the problems and solutions devised in the electoral experiences of the rapidly changing countries are often of comparative value and essential to evaluating election results .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The sine qua non of the elections was naturally an impartial and standardized procedure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As the background discussion indicated there were frequently expressed doubts that a government dominated by either party could fairly administer elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The P.D.I. and later the Popular Movement protected the Istiqlal 's `` privileged position '' until the fall of Balafrej , and then the Istiqlal used the same argument , which it had previously ignored , against the pro U.N.F.P. tendencies of the Ibrahim government .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The bulk of the preparation had , of course , proceeded under the supervision of the Ministry of the Interior , whose officials are barred from party activity and probably generally disinterested in party politics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apart from some areas of recurring trouble , like Bani Mellal , where inexperienced officials had been appointed , there is little evidence that local officials intervened in the electoral process .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Centrally , however , the administrative problem was more complex and the sheer prestige of office was very likely an unfair advantage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The King decided to remove Ibrahim a week before elections and to institute a non-party Council of Government under his personal direction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although the monarch had frequently asserted that the elections were to be without party significance , his action was an implicit admission that party identifications were a factor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The new Council was itself inescapably of political meaning , which was most clearly revealed in the absence of any U.N.F.P. members and the presence of several Istiqlal leaders .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the details of the elections were settled the change of government had no direct effect on the technical aspects of the elections , and may have been more important as an indication of royal displeasure with the U.N.F.P.
Voting preparations began in the fall of 1959 , although the actual demarcation and planning for the rural communes was completed in 1958 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There were three major administrative tasks : the fixing of electoral districts , the registration of voters and the registration of candidates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Voter registration began in late November 1959 and continued until early January , 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The government was most anxious that there be a respectable response .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Periodic bulletins of the accomplishment in each province made the registration process into a kind of competition among provincial officials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A goal was fixed , as given in Table 2 , and attention focused on its fulfillment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The qualifications to vote were kept very simple .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both men and women of twenty-one years of age could register and vote upon presenting proof of residence and identification .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There were liberal provisions for dispensation where documents or records were lacking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The police were disqualified along with certain categories of naturalized citizens , criminals and those punished for Protectorate activities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The registration figures given in Table 2 must be interpreted with caution since the estimate for eligible electors were made without the benefit of a reliable census .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But neither was the statement empirical , for goodness was not a quality like red or squeaky that could be seen or heard .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What were they to do , then , with these awkward judgments of value ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To find a place for them in their theory of knowledge would require them to revise the theory radically , and yet that theory was what they regarded as their most important discovery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It appeared that the theory could be saved in one way only .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If it could be shown that judgments of good and bad were not judgments at all , that they asserted nothing true or false , but merely expressed emotions like `` Hurrah '' or `` Fiddlesticks '' , then these wayward judgments would cease from troubling and weary heads could be at rest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is the course the positivists took .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They explained value judgments by explaining them away .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Now I do not think their view will do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But before discussing it , I should like to record one vote of thanks to them for the clarity with which they have stated their case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It has been said of John Stuart Mill that he wrote so clearly that he could be found out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This theory has been put so clearly and precisely that it deserves criticism of the same kind , and this I will do my best to supply .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The theory claims to show by analysis that when we say , `` That is good '' , we do not mean to assert a character of the subject of which we are thinking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I shall argue that we do mean to do just that .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Let us work through an example , and the simpler and commoner the better .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There is perhaps no value statement on which people would more universally agree than the statement that intense pain is bad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Let us take a set of circumstances in which I happen to be interested on the legislative side and in which I think every one of us might naturally make such a statement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We come upon a rabbit that has been caught in one of the brutal traps in common use .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There are signs that it has struggled for days to escape and that in a frenzy of hunger , pain , and fear , it has all but eaten off its own leg .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The attempt failed : the animal is now dead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As we think of the long and excruciating pain it must have suffered , we are very likely to say : `` It was a bad thing that the little animal should suffer so '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The positivist tells us that when we say this we are only expressing our present emotion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I hold , on the contrary , that we mean to assert something of the pain itself , namely , that it was bad - bad when and as it occurred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Consider what follows from the positivist view .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On that view , nothing good or bad happened in the case until I came on the scene and made my remark .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For what I express in my remark is something going on in me at the time , and that of course did not exist until I did come on the scene .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The pain of the rabbit was not itself bad ; nothing evil was happening when that pain was being endured ; badness , in the only sense in which it is involved at all , waited for its appearance till I came and looked and felt .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Now that this is at odds with our meaning may be shown as follows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Let us put to ourselves the hypothesis that we had not come on the scene and that the rabbit never was discovered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Are we prepared to say that in that case nothing bad occurred in the sense in which we said it did ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Clearly not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Indeed we should say , on the contrary , that the accident of our later discovery made no difference whatever to the badness of the animal 's pain , that it would have been every whit as bad whether a chance passer-by happened later to discover the body and feel repugnance or not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If so , then it is clear that in saying the suffering was bad we are not expressing our feelings only .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We are saying that the pain was bad when and as it occurred and before anyone took an attitude toward it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The first argument is thus an ideal experiment in which we use the method of difference .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It removes our present expression and shows that the badness we meant would not be affected by this , whereas on positivist grounds it should be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The second argument applies the method in the reverse way .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It ideally removes the past event , and shows that this would render false what we mean to say , whereas on positivist grounds it should not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Let us suppose that the animal did not in fact fall into the trap and did not suffer at all , but that we mistakenly believe it did , and say as before that its suffering was an evil thing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the positivist theory , everything I sought to express by calling it evil in the first case is still present in the second .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the only sense in which badness is involved at all , whatever was bad in the first case is still present in its entirety , since all that is expressed in either case is a state of feeling , and that feeling is still there .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And our question is , is such an implication consistent with what we meant ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Clearly it is not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If anyone asked us , after we made the remark that the suffering was a bad thing , whether we should think it relevant to what we said to learn that the incident had never occurred and no pain had been suffered at all , we should say that it made all the difference in the world , that what we were asserting to be bad was precisely the suffering we thought had occurred back there , that if this had not occurred , there was nothing left to be bad , and that our assertion was in that case mistaken .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The suggestion that in saying something evil had occurred we were after all making no mistake , because we had never meant anyhow to say anything about the past suffering , seems to me merely frivolous .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If we did not mean to say this , why should we be so relieved on finding that the suffering had not occurred ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On the theory before us , such relief would be groundless , for in that suffering itself there was nothing bad at all , and hence in its nonoccurrence there would be nothing to be relieved about .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The positivist theory would here distort our meaning beyond recognition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So far as I can see , there is only one way out for the positivist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He holds that goodness and badness lie in feelings of approval or disapproval .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And there is a way in which he might hold that badness did in this case precede our own feeling of disapproval without belonging to the pain itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The pain in itself was neutral ; but unfortunately the rabbit , on no grounds at all , took up toward this neutral object an attitude of disapproval and that made it for the first time , and in the only intelligible sense , bad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This way of escape is theoretically possible , but since it has grave difficulties of its own and has not , so far as I know , been urged by positivists , it is perhaps best not to spend time over it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I come now to a third argument , which again is very simple .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we come upon the rabbit and make our remark about its suffering being a bad thing , we presumably make it with some feeling ; the positivists are plainly right in saying that such remarks do usually express feeling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But suppose that a week later we revert to the incident in thought and make our statement again .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And suppose that the circumstances have now so changed that the feeling with which we made the remark in the first place has faded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The pathetic evidence is no longer before us ; and we are now so fatigued in body and mind that feeling is , as we say , quite dead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In these circumstances , since what was expressed by the remark when first made is , on the theory before us , simply absent , the remark now expresses nothing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is as empty as the word `` Hurrah '' would be when there was no enthusiasm behind it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And this seems to me untrue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we repeat the remark that such suffering was a bad thing , the feeling with which we made it last week may be at or near the vanishing point , but if we were asked whether we meant to say what we did before , we should certainly answer Yes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should say that we made our point with feeling the first time and little or no feeling the second time , but that it was the same point we were making .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And if we can see that what we meant to say remains the same , while the feeling varies from intensity to near zero , it is not the feeling that we primarily meant to express .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I come now to a fourth consideration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We all believe that toward acts or effects of a certain kind one attitude is fitting and another not ; but on the theory before us such a belief would not make sense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Broad and Ross have lately contended that this fitness is one of the main facts of ethics , and I suspect they are right .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But that is not exactly my point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">My point is this :
whether there is such fitness or not , we all assume that there is , and if we do , we express in moral judgments more than the subjectivists say we do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Let me illustrate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In his novel The House of the Dead , Dostoevsky tells of his experiences in a Siberian prison camp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Whatever the unhappy inmates of such camps are like today , Dostoevsky 's companions were about as grim a lot as can be imagined .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">`` I have heard stories '' , he writes , `` of the most terrible , the most unnatural actions , of the most monstrous murders , told with the most spontaneous , childishly merry laughter '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Most of us would say that in this delight at the killing of others or the causing of suffering there is something very unfitting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If we were asked why we thought so , we should say that these things involve great evil and are wrong , and that to take delight in what is evil or wrong is plainly unfitting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Now on the subjectivist view , this answer is ruled out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For before someone takes up an attitude toward death , suffering , or their infliction , they have no moral quality at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There is therefore nothing about them to which an attitude of approval or condemnation could be fitting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They are in themselves neutral , and , so far as they get a moral quality , they get it only through being invested with it by the attitude of the onlooker .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But if that is true , why is any attitude more fitting than any other ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Would applause , for example , be fitting if , apart from the applause , there were nothing good to applaud ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Would condemnation be fitting if , independently of the condemnation , there were nothing bad to condemn ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In such a case , any attitude would be as fitting or unfitting as any other , which means that the notion of fitness has lost all point .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed we are forced to go much farther .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If goodness and badness lie in attitudes only and hence are brought into being by them , those men who greeted death and misery with childishly merry laughter are taking the only sensible line .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If there is nothing evil in these things , if they get their moral complexion only from our feeling about them , why should n't they be greeted with a cheer ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To greet them with repulsion would turn what before was neutral into something bad ; it would needlessly bring badness into the world ; and even on subjectivist assumptions that does not seem very bright .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other hand , to greet them with delight would convert what before was neutral into something good ; it would bring goodness into the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The injured German veteran was a former miner , twenty-four years old , who had been wounded by shrapnel in the back of the head .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This resulted in damage to the occipital lobe and very probably to the left side of the cerebellum also .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In any event , the extraordinary result of this injury was that he became `` psychically blind '' , while at the same time , apparently , the sense of touch remained essentially intact .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Psychical blindness is a condition in which there is a total absence of visual memory-images , a condition in which , for example , one is unable to remember something just seen or to conjure up a memory-picture of the visible appearance of a well-known friend in his absence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This circumstance in the patient 's case plus the fact that his tactual capacity remained basically in sound working order constitutes its exceptional value for the problem at hand since the evidence presented by the authors is overwhelming that , when the patient closed his eyes , he had absolutely no spatial ( that is , third-dimensional ) awareness whatsoever .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The necessary inference , as the authors themselves interpret it , would seem to be this : `` ( 1 ) Spatial qualities are not among those grasped by the sense of touch , as such .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We do not arrive at spatial images by means of the sense of touch by itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( 2 ) Spatiality becomes part of the tactual sensation only by way of visual representations ; that is , there is , in the true sense , only a visual space '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The underlying assumption , of course , is that only sight and touch enable us , in any precise and fully dependable way , to locate objects in space beyond us , the other senses being decidedly inferior , if not totally inadequate , in this regard .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is an assumption with which few would be disposed to quarrel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Therefore , if the sense of touch is functioning normally and there is a complete absence of spatial awareness in a psychically blind person when the eyes are closed and an object is handled , the conclusion seems unavoidable that touch by itself cannot focus and take possession of the third-dimensionality of things and that actual sight or visual representations are necessary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The force of the authors ' analysis ( if indeed it has any force ) can be felt by the reader , I believe , only after three questions have been successfully answered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( 1 ) What allows us to think that the patient had no third-dimensional representations when his eyes were closed ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( 2 ) What evidence is there that he was psychically blind ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( 3 ) How can we be sure that his sense of touch was not profoundly disturbed by his head injury ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We shall consider these in the inverse order of their presentation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Obviously , a satisfactory answer to the third question is imperative , if the argument is to get under way at all , for if there is any possibility of doubt whether the patient 's tactual sensitivity had been impaired by the occipital lesion , any findings whatsoever in regard to the first question become completely ambiguous and fail altogether , of course , as evidence to establish the desired conclusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The answer the authors give to it , therefore , is of supreme importance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is as follows : `` The usual sensitivity tests showed that the specific qualities of skin-perceptiveness ( pressure , pain , temperature ) , as well as the kinesthetic sensations ( muscular feelings , feelings in the tendons and joints ) , were , as such , essentially intact , although they seemed , in comparison with normal reactions , to be somewhat diminished over the entire body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The supposed tactual sense of spatial location and orientation in the patient and his ability to specify the location of a member , as well as the direction and scope of a movement , passively executed ( with one of his members ) , proved to have been , on the contrary , very considerably affected '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The authors insist , however , that these abnormalities in the sense of touch were due absolutely to no organic disorders in that sense faculty but rather to the injuries which the patient had sustained to the sense of sight .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">First of all , what is their evidence that the tactual apparatus was fundamentally undamaged ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( 1 ) When an object was placed in the patient 's hand , he had no difficulty determining whether it was warm or cold , sharp or blunt , rough or smooth , flexible , soft , or hard ; and he could tell , simply by the feel of it , whether it was made of wood , iron , cloth , rubber , and so on .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And he could recognize , by touch alone , articles which he had handled immediately before , even though they were altogether unfamiliar to him and could not be identified by him ; that is , he was unaware what kind of objects they were or what their use was .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( 2 ) The patient attained an astonishing efficiency in a new trade .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because of his brain injury and the extreme damage suffered to his sight , the patient had to train himself for a new line of work , that of a portfolio maker , an occupation requiring a great deal of precision in the making of measurements and a fairly well developed sense of form and contour .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It seems clear , when one takes into consideration the exceedingly defective eyesight of the patient ( we shall describe it in detail in connection with our second question , the one concerning the psychical blindness of the patient ) , that he had to rely on his sense of touch much more than the usual portfolio maker and that consequently that faculty was most probably more sensitive to shape and size than that of a person with normal vision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And so the authors conclude : `` The conduct of the patient in his every-day life and in his work , even more than the foregoing facts [ mentioned above under 1 ] , leave positively no room for doubt that the sense of touch , in the ordinary sense of the word , was unaffected ; or , to put the same thing in physiological terms , that the performance capacity of the tactual apparatus , from the periphery up to the tactual centers in the brain , - that is , from one end to the other - was unimpaired '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the argument is accepted as essentially sound up to this point , it remains for us to consider whether the patient 's difficulties in orienting himself spatially and in locating objects in space with the sense of touch can be explained by his defective visual condition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But before we can do this , we must first find answers to our original questions 1 and 2 ; then we shall perhaps be in a position to provide something like a complete answer to the question at hand .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In what ways , then , did the patient 's psychical blindness manifest itself ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He could not see objects as unified , self-contained , and organized figures , as a person does with normal vision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The meaning of this , as we shall see , is that he had no fund of visual memory-images of objects as objects ; and , therefore , he could not recognize even long-familiar things upon seeing them again .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Instead , he constantly became lost in parts and components of them , confused some of their details with those of neighboring objects , and so on , unless he allowed time to `` trace '' the object in question through minute movements of the head and hands and in this way to discover its contours .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">According to his own testimony , he never actually saw things as shaped but only as generally amorphous `` blots '' of color of a more or less indefinite size ; at their edges they slipped pretty much out of focus altogether .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But by the tracing procedure , he could , in a strange obviously kinesthetic manner , find the unseen form ; could piece , as it were , the jumbled mass together into an organized whole and then recognize it as a man or a triangle or whatever it turned out to be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If , however , the figure to be discerned were complicated , composed of several interlocking subfigures , and so on , even the tracing process failed him , and he could not focus even relatively simple shapes among its parts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This meant , concretely , that the patient could not read at all without making writing like movements of the head or body , became easily confused by `` hasher marks '' inserted between hand-written words and thus confused the mark for one of the letters , and could recognize a simple straight line or a curved one only by tracing it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The patient himself denied that he had any visual imagery at all ; and there was ample evidence of the following sort to corroborate him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After a conversation with another man , he was able to recount practically everything that had been said but could not describe at all what the other man looked like .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nor could he call up memory-pictures of close friends or relatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In short , both his own declarations and his figural blindness , when he looked at objects , seem to present undeniable evidence that he had simply no visual memory at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was oblivious of the form of the object actually being viewed , precisely because he could not assign it to a visual shape , already learned and held in visual memory , as persons of normal vision do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He could not recognize it ; he was absolutely unfamiliar with it because he had no visual memory at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Therefore , his only recourse was to learn the shape all over again for each new visual experience of the same individual object or type of object ; and this he could do only by going over its mass with the tracing procedure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Then he might finally recognize it , apparently by combining the visual blot , actually being seen , with tactual feelings in the head or body accompanying the tracing movements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This would mean , it can readily be seen , that , again , for each new visual experience the tracing motions would have to be repeated because of the absence of visual imagery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As one would surmise , the procedure , however , could be repeated with the same object or with the same type of object often enough , so that the corresponding visual blots and the merest beginning of the tracing movement would provide clues as to the actual shape , which the patient then immediately could determine by a kind of inference .</MPQASENT>
