<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Men , trees , automobiles , houses , and so on - objects continually confronted in everyday life - had each its characteristic blot appearance and became easily recognizable , at the very beginning of tracing , by an inference as to what each was .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Dice , for example , he inferred from black dots on a white surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He evidently could not actually see the corners of these objects , but their size and the dots gave them away .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And the authors give numerous instances of calculated guessing on the patient 's part to show how large a role it played in his process of readapting himself and how proficient he became at it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Often he seems even to have been able to guess correctly , without the tracing motions , solely on the basis of qualitative differences among the blot like things which appeared in his visual experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Perhaps the very important question - What is , then , exactly the role of kinesthetic sensations in the patient 's ability to recognize forms and shapes by means of the tracing movements when he is actually looking at things ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">- has now been raised in the reader 's mind and in the following form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the patient can perceive figure kinesthetically when he cannot perceive it visually , then , it would seem , the sense of touch has immediate contact with the spatial aspects of things in independence of visual representations , at least in regard to two dimensions , and , as we shall see , even this much spatial awareness on the part of unaided touch is denied by the authors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">How , then , do the kinesthetic sensations function in all this ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The authors set about answering this fundamental question through a detailed investigation of the patient 's ability , tactually , ( 1 ) to perceive figure and ( 2 ) to locate objects in space , with his eyes closed ( or turned away from the object concerned ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Quite naturally , they make the investigation , first , by prohibiting the patient from making any movements at all and then , later , by repeating it and allowing the patient to move in any way he wanted to .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the patient was not allowed to move his body in any way at all , the following striking results occurred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whenever artists , indeed , turned to actual representations or molded three-dimensional figures , which were rare down to 800 B.C. , they tended to reflect reality ( see Plate 6a , 9b ) ; a schematic , abstract treatment of men and animals , by intent , rose only in the late eighth century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To speak of this underlying view of the world is to embark upon matters of subjective judgment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the least , however , one may conclude that Geometric potters sensed a logical order ; their principles of composition stand very close to those which appear in the Homeric epics and the hexameter line .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Their world , again , was a still simple , traditional age which was only slowly beginning to appreciate the complexity of life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And perhaps an observer of the vases will not go too far in deducing that the outlook of their makers and users was basically stable and secure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The storms of the past had died away , and the great upheaval which was to mark the following century had not yet begun to disturb men 's minds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Throughout the work of the later ninth century a calm , severe serenity displays itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the vases this spirit may perhaps at times bore or repel one in its internal self-satisfaction , but the best of the Geometric pins have rightly been considered among the most beautiful ever made in the Greek world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The ninth century was in its artistic work `` the spiritually freest and most self-sufficient between past and future '' , and the loving skill spent by its artists upon their products is a testimonial to their sense that what they were doing was important and was appreciated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Geometric pottery has not yet received the thorough , detailed study which it deserves , partly because the task is a mammoth one and partly because some of its local manifestations , as at Argos , are only now coming to light .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From even a cursory inspection of its many aspects , however , the historian can deduce several fundamental conclusions about the progress of the Aegean world down to 800 B.C.
The general intellectual outlook which had appeared in the eleventh century was now consolidated to a significant degree .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Much which was in embryo in 1000 had become reasonably well developed by 800 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this process the Minoan Mycenaean inheritance had been transmuted or finally rejected ; the Aegean world which had existed before 1000 differed from that which rises more clearly in our vision after 800 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those modern scholars who urge that we must keep in mind the fundamental continuity of Aegean development from earliest times - granted occasional irruptions of peoples and ideas from outside - are correct ; but all too many observers have been misled by this fact into minimizing the degree of change which took place in the early first millennium .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The focus of novelty in this world now lay in the south-eastern districts of the Greek mainland , and by 800 virtually the entire Aegean , always excepting its northern shores , had accepted the Geometric style of pottery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While Protogeometric vases usually turn up , especially outside Greece proper , together with as many or more examples of local stamp , these `` non Greek '' patterns had mostly vanished by the later ninth century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In their place came local variations within the common style - tentative , as it were , in Protogeometric products but truly distinct and sharply defined as the Geometric spirit developed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Attica , though important , was not the only teacher of this age .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One can take a vase of about 800 B.C. and , without any knowledge of its place of origin , venture to assign it to a specific area ; imitation and borrowing of motifs now become ascertainable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The potters of the Aegean islands thus stood apart from those of the mainland , and in Greece itself Argive , Corinthian , Attic , Boeotian , and other Geometric sequences have each their own hallmarks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These local variations were to become ever sharper in the next century and a half .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The same conclusions can be drawn from the other physical evidence of the Dark ages , from linguistic distribution , and from the survivals of early social , political , and religious patterns into later ages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By 800 B.C. the Aegean was an area of common tongue and of common culture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On these pillars rested that solid basis for life and thought which was soon to be manifested in the remarkably unlimited ken of the Iliad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Everywhere within the common pattern , however , one finds local diversity ; Greek history and culture were enduringly fertilized , and plagued , by the interplay of these conjoined yet opposed factors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Further we cannot go , for the Dark ages deserve their name .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Many aspects of civilization were not yet sufficiently crystallized to find expression , nor could the simple economic and social foundations of this world support a lofty structure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The epic poems , the consolidation of the Greek pantheon , the rise of firm political units , the self-awareness which could permit painted and sculptured representations of men - all these had to await the progress of following decades .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What we have seen in this chapter , we have seen only dimly , and yet the results , however general , are worth the search .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These are the centuries in which the inhabitants of the Aegean world settled firmly into their minds and into their institutions the foundations of the Hellenic outlook , independent of outside forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To interpret , indeed , the era from 1000 to 800 as a period mainly of consolidation may be a necessary but unfortunate defect born of our lack of detailed information ; if we could see more deeply , we probably would find many side issues and wrong turnings which came to an end within the period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The historian can only point out those lines which were major enough to find reflection in our limited evidence , and must hope that future excavations will enrich our understanding .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Throughout the Dark ages , it is clear , the Greek world had been developing slowly but consistently .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The pace could now be accelerated , for the inhabitants of the Aegean stood on firm ground .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The landscape of Greek history broadens widely , and rather abruptly , in the eighth century B.C. , the age of Homer 's `` rosy fingered Dawn '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The first slanting rays of the new day cannot yet dispel all the dark shadows which lie across the Aegean world ; but our evidence grows considerably in variety and shows more unmistakably some of the lines of change .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">For this period , as for earlier centuries , pottery remains the most secure source ; the ceramic material of the age is more abundant , more diversified , and more indicative of the hopes and fears of its makers , who begin to show scenes of human life and death .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Figurines and simple chapels presage the emergence of sculpture and architecture in Greece ; objects in gold , ivory , and bronze grow more numerous .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since writing was practiced in the Aegean before the end of the century , we may hope that the details of tradition will now be occasionally useful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Though it is not easy to apply the evidence of the Iliad to any specific era , this marvelous product of the epic tradition had certainly taken definitive shape by 750 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Dipylon Geometric pottery of Athens and the Iliad are amazing manifestations of the inherent potentialities of Greek civilization ; but both were among the last products of a phase which was ending .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Greek civilization was swirling toward its great revolution , in which the developed qualities of the Hellenic outlook were suddenly to break forth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The revolution was well under way before 700 B.C. , and premonitory signs go back virtually across the century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The era , however , is Janus-faced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">While many tokens point forward , the main achievements stand as a culmination of the simple patterns of the Dark ages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The dominant pottery of the century was Geometric ; political organization revolved about the basileis ; trade was just beginning to expand ; the gods who protected the Greek countryside were only now putting on their sharply anthropomorphic dress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The modern student , who knows what was to come next , is likely to place first the factors of change which are visible in the eighth century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Not all men of the period would have accepted this emphasis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Many potters clung to the past the more determinedly as they were confronted with radically new ideas ; the poet of the Iliad deliberately archaized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although it is not possible to sunder old and new in this era , I shall consider in the present chapter primarily the first decades of the eighth century and shall interpret them as an apogee of the first stage of Greek civilization .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On this principle of division I must postpone the evolution of sculpture , architecture , society , and politics ; for the developments in these areas make sense only if they are connected to the age of revolution itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The growing contacts between Aegean and Orient are also a phase which should be linked primarily to the remarkable broadening of Hellenic culture after 750 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We shall not be able entirely to pass over these connections to the East as we consider Ripe Geometric pottery , the epic and the myth , and the religious evolution of early Greece ; the important point , however , is that these magnificent achievements , unlike those of later decades , were only incidentally influenced by Oriental models .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The antecedents of Dipylon vases and of the Iliad lie in the Aegean past .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pottery of the first half of the eighth century is commonly called Ripe Geometric .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The severe yet harmonious vases of the previous fifty years , the Strong Geometric style of the late ninth century , display as firm a mastery of the principles underlying Geometric pottery ; but artists now were ready to refine and elaborate their inheritance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The vases which resulted had different shapes , far more complex decoration , and a larger sense of style .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Beyond the aesthetic and technical aspects of this expansion we must consider the change in pottery style on broader lines .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In earlier centuries men had had enough to do in rebuilding a fundamental sense of order after chaos .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They had had to work on very simple foundations and had not dared to give rein to impulses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The potters , in particular , had virtually eschewed freehand drawing , elaborate motifs , and the curving lines of nature , while yet expressing a belief that there was order in the universe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In their vases were embodied the basic aesthetic and logical characteristics of Greek civilization , at first hesitantly in Protogeometric work , and then more confidently in the initial stages of the Geometric style .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By 800 social and cultural security had been achieved , at least on a simple plane ; it was time to take bigger steps , to venture on experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Ripe Geometric potters continued to employ the old syntax of ornaments and shapes and made use of the well-defined though limited range of motifs which they had inherited .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In these respects the vases of the early eighth century represent a culmination of earlier lines of progress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To the ancestral lore , however , new materials were added .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Painters left less and less of a vase in a plain dark color ; instead they divided the surface into many bands or covered it by all-over patterns into which freehand drawing began to creep .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wavy lines , feather like patterns , rosettes of indefinitely floral nature , birds either singly or in stylized rows , animals in solemn frieze bands ( see Plates 11 - 12 ) - all these turned up in the more developed fabrics as preliminary signs that the potters were broadening their gaze .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The rows of animals and birds , in particular , suggest awareness of Oriental animal friezes , transmitted perhaps via Syrian silver bowls and textiles , but the specific forms of these rows on local vases and metal products are nonetheless Greek .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Though the spread of this type of decoration in the Aegean has not yet been precisely determined , it seems to appear first in the Cyclades , which were among the leading exporters of pottery throughout the century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As the material at the command of the potters grew and the volume of their production increased , the local variations within a common style became more evident .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Plate 12 illustrates four examples , which are Ripe or Late Geometric work of common spirit but of different schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Cook had discovered a beef in his possession a few days earlier and , when he could not show the hide , arrested him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thinking the evidence insufficient to get a conviction , he later released him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even while suffering the trip to his home , Cook swore to Moore and Lane that he would kill the Indian .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Three weeks later following his recovery , armed with a writ issued by the Catskill justice on affidavits prepared by the district attorney , Cook and Russell rode to arrest Martinez .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Arriving at daybreak , they found Julio in his corral and demanded that he surrender .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Instead , he whirled and ran to his house for a gun forcing them to kill him , Cook reported .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Both Cook 's and Russell 's lives were threatened by the Mexicans following the killing , but the company officers felt that in the end , it would serve to quiet them despite their immediate emotion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">General manager Pels even suggested that it might be wise to keep the Mexicans in suspense rather than accept their offers to sell out and move away , and try to have a few punished .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On February 17 , Russell and Cook were sent to the Pena Flor community on the Vermejo to see about renting out ranches the company had purchased .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">While talking with Julian M. Beall , Francisco Archuleta and Juan Marcus appeared , both heavily armed , and after watching the house for a while , rode away .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was nearly sundown before they finished the business with Beall and began riding down the stream .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They had traveled only a short distance when they spotted five Mexicans riding along a horse-trail across the stream just ahead of them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Suspecting an ambush , the two deputies decided to ride up a side canyon taking a short cut into Catskill .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After spending two nights ( Wednesday and Thursday ) in Catskill , the deputies again headed for the Vermejo to finish their business .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They stayed with a rancher Friday night and by eleven o'clock Saturday morning passed the old Garnett Lee ranch .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Half a mile below at the mouth of Salyer 's Canyon was an old ranch that the company had purchased from A. J. Armstrong , occupied by a Mexican , his wife , and an old trapper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There were three houses in Salyer 's Canyon just at the foot of a low bluff , the road winding along the top , entering above , and then passing down in front of the houses , thence to the Vermejo .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To the west of this road was another low bluff , forty or fifty feet high , covered with scrub oak and other brush .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As they were riding along this winding road on the bench of land between the two bluffs , a volley of rifle fire suddenly crashed around the two officers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Not a bullet touched Cook who was nearer the ambush , but one hit Russell in the leg and another broke his arm , passing on through his body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With the first reports , Russell 's horse wheeled to the right and ran towards the buildings while Cook , followed by a hail of bullets , raced towards the arroyo of Salyer 's Canyon immediately in front of him , just reaching it as his horse fell .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Grabbing his Winchester from its sheath , Cook prepared to fight from behind the arroyo bank .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Bullets were so thick , throwing sand in his face , that he found it difficult to return the fire .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Noticing Russell 's horse in front of the long log building , he assumed his friend had slipped inside and would be able to put up a good fight , so he began working his way down the ditch to join him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At a very shallow place , two Mexicans rushed into the open for a shot .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dropping to one knee , Cook felled one , and the other struggled off with his comrade , sending no further fire in his direction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just before leaving the arroyo where he was partially concealed , he did hear shots down at the house .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Russell had reached the house as Cook surmised , dismounted , but just as the old trapper opened the door to receive him , he fell into the trapper 's arms - dead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A bullet fired by one of the Mexicans hiding in a little chicken house had passed through his head , tearing a hole two inches square on the outgoing side .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Finding him dead , Cook caught Russell 's horse and rode to the cattle foreman 's house to report the incident and request bloodhounds to trail the assassins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Before daylight Sunday morning , a posse of twenty-three men under the leadership of Deputy Sheriff Frank MacPherson of Catskill followed the trail to the house of Francisco Chaves , where 100 to 150 Mexicans had gathered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">MacPherson boldly approached the fortified adobe house and demanded entrance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The men inside informed him that they had some wounded men among them but he would not be allowed to see them even though he offered medical aid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The officer demanded the names of the injured men ; the Mexicans not only refused to give them , but told the possemen if they wanted a fight they could have it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the strength of the Mexicans had been underrated , too small a posse had been collected , and since the deputy had not been provided with search warrants , MacPherson and his men decided it was much wiser to withdraw .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The posse 's retreat encouraged the Mexicans to be overbearing and impudent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the following week , six tons of hay belonging to one rancher were burned ; some buildings , farm tools , two horses , plows , and hay owned by Bonito Lavato , a friendly interpreter for the company , and Pedro Chavez ' hay were stolen or destroyed ; and a store was broken into and robbed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">District Attorney M. W. Mills warned that he would vigorously prosecute persons caught committing these crimes or carrying arms - he just did n't catch anyone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Increasing threats on his life finally convinced Cook that he should leave New Mexico .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His friends advised that it would be only a question of time until either the Mexicans killed him by ambuscade or he would be compelled to kill them in self-defense , perpetuating the troubles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">By early summer , he wrote from Laramie that he was suffering from the wound inflicted in the ambush and was in a bad way financially , so Pels sent him a draft for $ 100 , warning that it was still not wise for him to return .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Pels also sent a check for $ 100 to Russell 's widow and had a white marble monument erected on his grave .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Cattle stealing and killing , again serious during the spring of 1891 , placed the land grant company officers in a perplexing position .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They were reluctant to appoint sheriffs to protect the property , thus running the risk of creating disturbances such as that on the Vermejo , and yet the cowboys protested that they got no salary for arresting cattle thieves and running the risk of being shot .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And the law virtually ignored the situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The judge became ill just as the Colfax District Court convened , no substitute was brought in , no criminal cases heard , only 5 out of 122 cases docketed were tried , and court adjourned sine die after sitting a few days instead of the usual three weeks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Pels complained :
`` Litigants and witnesses were put to the expense and inconvenience of going long distances to transact business ; public money spent ; justice delayed ; nothing accomplished , and the whole distribution of justice in this county seems to be an absolute farce '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Word reached the company that the man behind these depredations was Manuel Gonzales , a man with many followers , including a number who were kept in line through fear of him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Although wanted by the sheriff for killing an old man named Asher Jones , the warrant for his arrest had never been served .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On May 19 , a deputy sheriff 's posse of eight men left Maxwell City and rode thirty-five miles up the Vermejo where they were joined by Juan Jose Martinez .</MPQASENT>
