<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some who have written on Utopia have treated it as `` a learned diversion of a learned world '' , `` a phantasy with which More amused himself '' , `` a holiday work , a spontaneous overflow of intellectual high spirits , a revel of debate , paradox , comedy and invention '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With respect to this view , two points are worth making .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">First , it appears to be based on the fact that on its title page Utopia is described as `` festivus '' , `` gay '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It overlooks the other fact that it is described as `` Nec minus salutaris quam festivus '' , `` no less salutary than gay '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It also overlooks the fact that in a rational lexicon , and quite clearly in More 's lexicon , the opposite of serious is not gay but frivolous , and the opposite of gay is not serious but solemn .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">More believed that a man could be both serious and gay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">That a writer who is gay cannot be serious is a common professional illusion , sedulously fostered by all too many academics who mistakenly believe that their frivolous efforts should be taken seriously because they are expressed with that dreary solemnity which is the only mode of expression their authors are capable of .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Secondly , to find a learned diversion and a pleasing joke in More 's account of the stupid brutalities of early sixteenth century wars , of the anguish of the poor and dispossessed , of the insolence and cruelty of the rich and powerful requires a callousness toward suffering and sin that would be surprising in a moral imbecile and most surprising in More himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , it is even surprising in the Canon of Christ Church and Regius Professor of Ecclesiastical History , who fathered this most peculiar view , and in the brilliant Professor of Medieval and Renaissance English at Cambridge , who inherited it and is now its most eminent proponent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But to return to the main line of our inquiry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is doubtful that Utopia is still widely read because More was medieval or even because he was a martyr - indeed , it is likely that these days many who read Utopia with interest do not even know that its author was a martyr .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Utopia is still widely read because in a sense More stood on the margin of modernity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And if he did stand on the margins of modernity , it was not in dying a martyr for such unity as Papal supremacy might be able to force on Western Christendom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was not even in writing Latin epigrams , sometimes bawdy ones , or in translating Lucian from Greek into Latin or in defending the study of Greek against the attack of conservative academics , or in attacking the conservative theologians who opposed Erasmus 's philological study of the New Testament .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Similar literary exercises were the common doings of a Christian humanist of the first two decades of the sixteenth century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Had More 's writings been wholly limited to such exercises , they would be almost as dimly remembered as those of a dozen or so other authors living in his time , whose works tenuously survive in the minds of the few hundred scholars who each decade in pursuit of their very specialized occasions read those works .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">More stands on the margins of modernity for one reason alone - because he wrote Utopia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And the evidence that he does , indeed , stand there derives quite simply from the vigorous interest with which rather casual readers have responded to that book for the past century or so .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Only one other contemporary of More 's evokes so immediate and direct a response , and only one other contemporary work - Niccolo Machiavelli and The Prince .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Can we discover what it is in Utopia that has evoked this response ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Remember that in seeking the modern in Utopia we do not deny the existence of the medieval and the Renaissance there ; we do not even need to commit ourselves to assessing on the same inconceivable scale the relative importance of the medieval , the Renaissance , and the modern .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The medieval was the most important to Chambers because he sought to place Thomas More , the author of Utopia , in some intelligible relation with St. Thomas More , the martyr .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To others whose concern it is to penetrate the significance of Christian Humanism , the Renaissance elements are of primary concern .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">But here we have a distinctly modern preoccupation ; we want to know why that book has kept on selling the way it has ; we want to know what is perennially new about Utopia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">What is new about it ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To that question the answer is simple ; it can be made in two words , Utopian communism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But it is an answer which opens the door wide to an onrush of objections and denials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Surely there is nothing new about communism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We find it in Plato 's republic , and in Utopia More acknowledges his debt to that book .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We find it in that `` common way of life pleasing to Christ and still in use among the truest societies of Christians '' , that is , the better monasteries which made it easier to convert the Utopians to Christianity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We find it in the later Stoic conception of man 's natural condition which included the community of all possessions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This conception was taken up by the early Church Fathers and by canon lawyers and theologians in the Middle Ages ; and More was far too well read not to have come across it in one or several of the forms thus given it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But although the idea of communism is very old even in More 's day and did not spring full-clad from his imagination in 1515 , it is not communism as such that we are concerned with .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We are concerned not with the genus communism nor with other species of the genus :
Platonic , Stoic , early Christian , monastic , canonist or theological communism ; we are concerned with Utopian communism - that is , simply communism as it appears in the imaginary commonwealth of Utopia , as More conceived it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Perhaps one way to sharpen our sense of the modernity of Utopian communism is to contrast it with the principal earlier types of communistic theory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We will achieve a more vivid sense of what it is by realizing what it is not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In Plato 's Republic communism is - to speak anachronistically - a communism of Janissaries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its function is to separate from the base ruled mass , among whom private ownership prevails , the governing warrior elite .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , it is too readily forgotten that in the Republic what gave the initial impetus to Plato 's excursus into the construction of an imaginary commonwealth with its ruling-class communism of goods , wives , and children , was his quest for a canon for the proper ordering of the individual human psyche ; and it is to this problem that the Republic ultimately returns .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In More 's Utopia communism is not a means of separating out a warrior elite from the lumpish mass .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Utopian communism applies to all Utopians .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And in the economy of the book it is not peripheral but central .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The concern of Utopia is with the optimo reipublicae statu , the best ordering of a civil society ; and it is again and again made clear that Utopian communism provides the institutional array indispensable to that best ordering .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">To derive Utopian communism from the Jerusalem Christian community of the apostolic age or from its medieval successors in spirit , the monastic communities , is with an appropriate shift of adjectives , misleading in the same way as to derive it from Plato 's Republic :
in the Republic we have to do with an elite of physical and intellectual athletes , in the apostolic and monastic communities with an elite of spiritual and religious athletes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The apostolic community was literally an elite : chosen by Christ himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And the monastic communities were supposed to be made up of volunteers selected only after a novitiate which would test their religious aptitude for monastic rigors , their spiritual athleticism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , the conception of the natural community of all possessions which originated with the Stoics was firmly fixed in a tradition by More 's time , although it was not accepted by all the theologian philosophers of the Middle Ages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In that tradition communism lay a safe distance back in the age of innocence before the Fall of Man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It did not serve to contrast the existing order of society with a possible alternative order , because the age of innocence was not a possible alternative once man had sinned .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The actual function of patristic civilian canonist scholastic communism was adequately set forth by St. Gregory almost a millennium before More wrote Utopia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` The soil is common to all men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When we give the necessities of life to the poor , we restore to them what is already theirs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should think of it more as an act of justice than compassion '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because community not severalty of property is the law of nature no man can assert an absolutely unalterable right to what is his .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , of all that is his every man is by nature and reason and therefore by conscience obligated to regard himself as a custodian .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is a trustee for the common good , however feeble the safeguards which the positive or municipal law of property provides against his misuse of that share of the common fund , wisely or unwisely , entrusted to his keeping .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In contrast to this Stoic patristic view , Utopia implies that the nature of man is such that to rely on individual conscience to supply the deficiencies of municipal law is to embark on the bottomless sea of human sinfulness in a sieve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Utopians brace conscience with legal sanctions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a properly ordered society the massive force of public law performs the function which in natural law theory ineptly is left altogether to a small voice so often still .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In all the respects just indicated Utopian communism differs from previous conceptions in which community of possessions and living plays a role .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Neither from one of these conceptions nor from a combination of them can it be deduced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We do not deny originality to the Agamemnon because Aeschylus found the tales of the house of Atreus among the folk lore of the Greeks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In a like sense whatever bits or shreds of previous conceptions one may find in it , Utopian communism remains , as an integral whole , original - a new thing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is not merely a new thing ; it is one of the very few new things in Utopia ; most of the rest is medieval or humanist or part of an old tradition of social criticism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But to say that at a moment in history something is new is not necessarily to say that it is modern ; and for this statement the best evidence comes within the five years following the publication of Utopia , when Martin Luther elaborates a new perception of the nature of the Divine 's encounter with man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">New , indeed , is Luther 's perception , but not modern , as anyone knows who has ever tried to make intelligible to modern students what Luther was getting at .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although Utopian communism is both new in 1516 and also modern , it is not modern communism or even modern socialism , as they exist or have ever existed in theory or in practice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Consider the features of Utopian communism :
generous public provision for the infirm ; democratic and secret elections of all officers including priests , meals taken publicly in common refectories ; a common habit or uniform prescribed for all citizens ; even houses changed once a decade ; six hours of manual labor a day for all but a handful of magistrates and scholars , and careful measures to prevent anyone from shirking ; no private property , no money ; no sort of pricing at all for any goods or services , and therefore no market in the economic sense of the term .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whatever the merits of its intent , Utopian communism is far too naive , far too crude , to suit any modern socialist or communist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not the details of Utopian communism that make Utopia modern , it is the spirit , the attitude of mind that informs those details .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What that spirit and attitude were we can best understand if we see more precisely how it contrasts with the communist tradition with the longest continuous history , the one which reached Christianity by the way of Stoicism through the Church Fathers of Late Antiquity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">During the Dorr trial the Democratic press condemned the proceedings and heralded Dorr as a martyr to the principles of the Declaration of Independence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">During the Brown trial , however , the state 's most powerful Democratic newspaper , the Providence Daily Post , stated that Brown was a murderer , a man of blood , and that he and his associates , with the assistance of Republicans and Abolitionists , had plotted not only the liberation of the slaves but also the overthrow of state and federal governments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Providence Daily Journal answered the Daily Post by stating that the raid of John Brown was characteristic of Democratic acts of violence and that `` He was acting in direct opposition to the Republican Party , who proclaim as one of their cardinal principles that they do not interfere with slavery in the states '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The two major newspapers in Providence continued , throughout the crisis , to accuse each other of misrepresenting the facts and attempting to falsify history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">While the Daily Post continued to accuse Republicans and the Daily Journal continued to accuse Democrats , the Woonsocket Patriot complained that the Virginia authorities showed indecent and cowardly haste to condemn Brown and his men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Editor Foss stated , `` Of their guilt there can be no doubt but they are entitled to sufficient time to prepare for trial , and a fair trial '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Providence Daily Post thought that there were probably good reasons for the haste in which the trial was being conducted and that the only thing gained by a delay would be calmer feelings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Providence Daily Journal stated that although the guilt of Brown was evident , the South must guarantee him a fair trial to preserve domestic peace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On October 31 , 1859 , John Brown was found guilty of treason against the state of Virginia , inciting slave rebellion , and murder .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For these crimes he was sentenced to be hanged in public on Friday , December 2 , 1859 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Upon receiving the news , Northern writers , editors , and clergymen heaped accusations of murder on the Southern states , particularly Virginia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although Rhode Islanders were preparing for the state elections , they watched John Brown 's trial with extreme interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On Wednesday morning , November 2 , 1859 , the Providence Daily Journal stated that although Brown justly deserved the extreme penalty , no man , however criminal , ought to suffer the penalty without a fairer trial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The editor 's main criticism of the trial was the haste with which it was conducted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The readers of the Providence Daily Post , however , learned that it was generally conceded that `` Old Brown '' had a fair trial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Concerning the sentence the editor asked , `` What else can Virginia do than to hang the men who have defied her laws , organized treason , and butchered her citizens '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the eastern section of the state the newspapers ' reaction to Brown 's trial and sentence were basically identical .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">J. Wheaton Smith , editor of the Warren Telegraph stated that `` the ends of justice must be satisfied , a solitary example must be set , in order that all those misnamed philantropists [ sic ] , who , actuated by a blind zeal , dare to instigate riot , treason , and murder , may heed it and shape their future course accordingly '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The editor of the Newport Advertiser could discover no evidence of extenuating circumstances in the Brown trial which would warrant making an exception to the infliction of capital punishment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In direct contrast to the other Rhode Island editors , Samuel S. Foss of the Woonsocket Patriot outwardly condemned the trial as being completely unfair .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Concerning the sentence , Foss wrote , `` If it be possible that mercy shall override vengeance and that John Brown 's sentence shall be commuted to imprisonment , it would be well - well for the country and for Virginia '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Despite the excitement being caused by the trial and sentence of John Brown , Rhode Islanders turned their attention to the state elections .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The state had elected Republican candidates in the past two years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There was no doubt as to the control the Republican party exercised throughout the state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If it failed on occasion to elect its candidates for general state offices by majorities , the failure was due to a lingering remnant of the Know-Nothing party , which called itself the American Republican party .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The American Republicans and the Republicans both nominated lieutenant-governor Turner for governor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Elisha R. Potter was the Democratic candidate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The results of the election of 1859 found Republican candidates not only winning the offices of governor and lieutenant-governor but also obtaining the two Congressional offices from the eastern and western sections of the state .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">During the month of November hardly a day passed when there was not some mention of John Brown in the Rhode Island newspapers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On November 7 , 1859 , the Providence Daily Journal reprinted a letter sent to John Brown from `` E. B. '' , a Quaker lady in Newport .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In reference to Brown 's raid she wrote , `` though we are non-resistants and religiously believe it better to reform by moral and not by carnal weapons we know thee was anemated [ sic ] by the most generous and philanthropic motives '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` E. B. '' compared John Brown to Moses in that they were both acting to deliver millions from oppression .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In contrast to `` E. B. '' , most Rhode Islanders hardly thought of John Brown as being another Moses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Most attempts to develop any sympathy for Brown and his actions found an unresponsive audience in Rhode Island .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On Wednesday evening , November 23 , 1859 , in Warren , Rev. Mark Trafton of New Bedford , gave a `` Mission of Sympathy '' lecture in which he favorably viewed the Harper 's Ferry insurrection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Warren Telegraph stated that many of Rev. Trafton 's remarks were inappropriate and savored strongly of radicalism and fanaticism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In its account of the Trafton lecture , the Providence Daily Post said that the remarks of Rev. Trafton made the people indignant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No sympathy or admiration for Brown could be found in the Providence Daily Post , for the editor claimed that there were a score of men in the state prison who were a thousand times more deserving of sympathy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The Providence Daily Journal , however , stated that Brown 's courage , bravery , and heroism `` in a good cause would make a man a martyr ; it gives something of dignity even to a bad one '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Woonsocket Patriot admitted that John Brown might deserve punishment or imprisonment `` but he should no more be hung than Henry A. Wise or James Buchanan '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Newport Mercury exhibited more concern over the possibility of the abolitionists making a martyr of Brown than it did over the development of sympathy for him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In her letter to John Brown , `` E. B. '' , the Quakeress from Newport , had suggested that the American people owed more honor to John Brown for seeking to free the slaves than they did to George Washington .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the latter days of November to the day of Brown 's execution , it seems that most Rhode Islanders did not concur in `` E. B. 's '' suggestion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On November 22 , 1859 , the Providence Daily Journal stated that although Brown 's `` pluck '' and honest fanaticism must be admired , any honor paid to Brown would only induce other fanatics to imitate his actions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A week later the Daily Journal had discovered the initial plans of some Providence citizens to hold a meeting honoring John Brown on the day of his execution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The editor of the Daily Journal warned , `` that if such a demonstration be made , it will not find support or countenance from any of the men whose names are recognized as having a right to speak for Providence '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Providence Daily Post 's editor wrote that he could not believe that a meeting honoring Brown was to be held in Providence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He further called upon the people of Providence to rebuke the meeting and avoid disgrace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On December 2 , 1859 , John Brown was hanged at Charles Town , Virginia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Extraordinary precautions were taken so that no stranger be allowed in the city and no citizen within the enclosure surrounding the scaffold .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In many Northern towns and cities meetings were held and church bells were tolled .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Such was not the case in Rhode Island .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The only public demonstration in honor of John Brown was held at Pratt 's Hall in Providence , on the day of his execution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Despite the opposition of the city newspapers , the Pratt Hall meeting `` brought together a very respectable audience , composed in part of those who had been distinguished for years for their radical views upon the subject of slavery , of many of our colored citizens , and of those who were attracted to the place by the novelty of such a gathering '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Seated on the platform were Amos C. Barstow , ex-mayor of Providence and a wealthy Republican stove manufacturer ; Thomas Davis , an uncompromising Garrisonian ; the Reverend Augustus Woodbury , a Unitarian minister ; the Reverend George T. Day , a Free-Will Baptist ; Daniel w. Vaughan , and William H. H. Clements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The latter two were appointed secretaries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first speaker was Amos C. Barstow who had been unanimously chosen president of the meeting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He spoke of his desire to promote the abolition of slavery by peaceable means and he compared John Brown of Harper 's Ferry to the John Brown of Rhode Island 's colonial period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Barstow concluded that as Rhode Island 's John Brown became a canonized hero , if not a saint , so would it be with John Brown of Harper 's Ferry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The next speaker was George T. Day .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although admitting Brown 's guilt on legal grounds , Day said that , `` Brown is no common criminal ; his deed was not below , but above the law '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Following Day was Woodbury who spoke of his disapproval of Brown 's attempt at servile insurrection , his admiration of Brown 's character , and his opposition to slavery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Woodbury 's remarks were applauded by a portion of the audience several times and once there was hissing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The fourth and last speaker was Thomas Davis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By this time large numbers of the audience had left the hall .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Davis commenced his remarks by an allusion to the general feeling of opposition which the meeting had encountered from many of the citizens and all the newspapers of the city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He said that the propriety or impropriety of such a gathering was a question that was to be settled by every man in accordance with the convictions of private judgments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the remainder of his speech Davis spoke of his admiration for Brown and warned those who took part in the meeting that they `` are liable to the charge that they are supporting traitors and upholding men whom the laws have condemned '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He recalled that in Rhode Island a party opposed to the state 's condemnation of a man ( Thomas W. Dorr ) proclaimed the state 's action as a violation of the law of the land and the principles of human liberty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">At the close of Davis ' speech the following preamble and resolutions were read by the president , and on the question of their adoption passed unanimously :
Whereas , John Brown has cheerfully risked his life in endeavoring to deliver those who are denied all rights and is this day doomed to suffer death for his efforts in behalf of those who have no helper :
Therefore ,
Resolved that , while we most decidedly disapprove the methods he adopted to accomplish his objects , yet in his willingness to die in aid of the great cause of human freedom , we still recognize the qualities of a noble nature and the exercise of a spirit which true men have always admired and which history never fails to honor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Resolved that his wrongs and bereavements in Kansas , occasioned by the violence and brutality of those who were intent on the propagation of slavery in that territory , call for a charitable judgment upon his recent efforts in Virginia to undermine the despotism from which he had suffered , and commend his family to the special sympathy and aid of all who pity suffering and reverence justice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Resolved that the anti slavery sentiment is becoming ripe for resolute action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Resolved , that we find in this fearful tragedy at Harper 's Ferry a reason for more earnest effort to remove the evil of slavery from the whole land as speedily as possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the morning following the Pratt Hall meeting the editor of the Providence Daily Journal wrote that although the meeting was milder and less extreme than those held in other areas for similar purposes , it could have been avoided completely .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Rather than being deceived , the eye is puzzled ; instead of seeing objects in space , it sees nothing more than - a picture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Through 1911 and 1912 , as the Cubist facet-plane 's tendency to adhere to the literal surface became harder and harder to deny , the task of keeping the surface at arm's length fell all the more to eye-undeceiving contrivances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To reinforce , and sometimes to replace , the simulated typography , Braque and Picasso began to mix sand and other foreign substances with their paint ; the granular texture thus created likewise called attention to the reality of the surface and was effective over much larger areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In certain other pictures , however , Braque began to paint areas in exact simulation of wood graining or marbleizing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These areas by virtue of their abrupt density of pattern , stated the literal surface with such new and superior force that the resulting contrast drove the simulated printing into a depth from which it could be rescued - and set to shuttling again - only by conventional perspective ; that is , by being placed in such relation to the forms depicted within the illusion that these forms left no room for the typography except near the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The accumulation of such devices , however , soon had the effect of telescoping , even while separating , surface and depth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The process of flattening seemed inexorable , and it became necessary to emphasize the surface still further in order to prevent it from fusing with the illusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was for this reason , and no other that I can see , that in September 1912 , Braque took the radical and revolutionary step of pasting actual pieces of imitation woodgrain wallpaper to a drawing on paper , instead of trying to simulate its texture in paint .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Picasso says that he himself had already made his first collage toward the end of 1911 , when he glued a piece of imitation caning oilcloth to a painting on canvas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is true that his first collage looks more Analytical than Braque 's , which would confirm the date he assigns it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it is also true that Braque was the consistent pioneer in the use of simulated textures as well as of typography ; and moreover , he had already begun to broaden and simplify the facet-planes of Analytical Cubism as far back as the end of 1910 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we examine what each master says was his first collage we see that much the same thing happens in each .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( It makes no real difference that Braque 's collage is on paper and eked out in charcoal , while Picasso 's is on canvas and eked out in oil . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By its greater corporeal presence and its greater extraneousness , the affixed paper or cloth serves for a seeming moment to push everything else into a more vivid idea of depth than the simulated printing or simulated textures had ever done .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But here again , the surface declaring device both overshoots and falls short of its aim .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For the illusion of depth created by the contrast between the affixed material and everything else gives way immediately to an illusion of forms in bas-relief , which gives way in turn , and with equal immediacy , to an illusion that seems to contain both - or neither .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Because of the size of the areas it covers , the pasted paper establishes undepicted flatness bodily , as more than an indication or sign .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Literal flatness now tends to assert itself as the main event of the picture , and the device boomerangs : the illusion of depth is rendered even more precarious than before .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Instead of isolating the literal flatness by specifying and circumscribing it , the pasted paper or cloth releases and spreads it , and the artist seems to have nothing left but this undepicted flatness with which to finish as well as start his picture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The actual surface becomes both ground and background , and it turns out - suddenly and paradoxically - that the only place left for a three-dimensional illusion is in front of , upon , the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In their very first collages , Braque and Picasso draw or paint over and on the affixed paper or cloth , so that certain of the principal features of their subjects as depicted seem to thrust out into real , bas-relief space - or to be about to do so - while the rest of the subject remains imbedded in , or flat upon , the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And the surface is driven back , in its very surfaceness , only by this contrast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the upper center of Braque 's first collage , Fruit Dish ( in Douglas Cooper 's collection ) , a bunch of grapes is rendered with such conventionally vivid sculptural effect as to lift it practically off the picture plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The trompe-l'oeil illusion here is no longer enclosed between parallel flatnesses , but seems to thrust through the surface of the drawing paper and establish depth on top of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet the violent immediacy of the wallpaper strips pasted to the paper , and the only lesser immediacy of block capitals that simulate window lettering , manage somehow to push the grape cluster back into place on the picture plane so that it does not `` jump '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the same time , the wallpaper strips themselves seem to be pushed into depth by the lines and patches of shading charcoaled upon them , and by their placing in relation to the block capitals ; and these capitals seem in turn to be pushed back by their placing , and by contrast with the corporeality of the woodgraining .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Thus every part and plane of the picture keeps changing place in relative depth with every other part and plane ; and it is as if the only stable relation left among the different parts of the picture is the ambivalent and ambiguous one that each has with the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And the same thing , more or less , can be said of the contents of Picasso 's first collage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In later collages of both masters , a variety of extraneous materials are used , sometimes in the same work , and almost always in conjunction with every other eye-deceiving and eye-undeceiving device they can think of .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The area adjacent to one edge of a piece of affixed material - or simply of a painted in form - will be shaded to pry that edge away from the surface , while something will be drawn , painted or even pasted over another part of the same shape to drive it back into depth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Planes defined as parallel to the surface also cut through it into real space , and a depth is suggested optically which is greater than that established pictorially .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All this expands the oscillation between surface and depth so as to encompass fictive space in front of the surface as well as behind it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Flatness may now monopolize everything , but it is a flatness become so ambiguous and expanded as to turn into illusion itself - at least an optical if not , properly speaking , a pictorial illusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Depicted , Cubist flatness is now almost completely assimilated to the literal , undepicted kind , but at the same time it reacts upon and largely transforms the undepicted kind - and it does so , moreover , without depriving the latter of its literalness ; rather , it underpins and reinforces that literalness , re-creates it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Out of this re-created literalness , the Cubist subject reemerged .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For it had turned out , by a further paradox of Cubism , that the means to an illusion of depth and plasticity had now become widely divergent from the means of representation or imaging .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In the Analytical phase of their Cubism , Braque and Picasso had not only had to minimize three-dimensionality simply in order to preserve it ; they had also had to generalize it - to the point , finally , where the illusion of depth and relief became abstracted from specific three-dimensional entities and was rendered largely as the illusion of depth and relief as such : as a disembodied attribute and expropriated property detached from everything not itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In order to be saved , plasticity had had to be isolated ; and as the aspect of the subject was transposed into those clusters of more or less interchangeable and contour obliterating facet-planes by which plasticity was isolated under the Cubist method , the subject itself became largely unrecognizable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Cubism , in its 1911 - 1912 phase ( which the French , with justice , call `` hermetic '' ) was on the verge of abstract art .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was then that Picasso and Braque were confronted with a unique dilemma : they had to choose between illusion and representation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If they opted for illusion , it could only be illusion per se - an illusion of depth , and of relief , so general and abstracted as to exclude the representation of individual objects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If , on the other hand , they opted for representation , it had to be representation per se - representation as image pure and simple , without connotations ( at least , without more than schematic ones ) of the three-dimensional space in which the objects represented originally existed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was the collage that made the terms of this dilemma clear : the representational could be restored and preserved only on the flat and literal surface now that illusion and representation had become , for the first time , mutually exclusive alternatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the end , Picasso and Braque plumped for the representational , and it would seem they did so deliberately .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( This provides whatever real justification there is for the talk about `` reality '' . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But the inner , formal logic of Cubism , as it worked itself out through the collage , had just as much to do with shaping their decision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the smaller facet-planes of Analytical Cubism were placed upon or juxtaposed with the large , dense shapes formed by the affixed materials of the collage , they had to coalesce - become `` synthesized '' - into larger planar shapes themselves simply in order to maintain the integrity of the picture plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Left in their previous atom-like smallness , they would have cut away too abruptly into depth ; and the broad , opaque shapes of pasted paper would have been isolated in such a way as to make them jump out of plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Large planes juxtaposed with other large planes tend to assert themselves as independent shapes , and to the extent that they are flat , they also assert themselves as silhouettes ; and independent silhouettes are apt to coincide with the recognizable contours of the subject from which a picture starts ( if it does start from a subject ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was because of this chain-reaction as much as for any other reason - that is , because of the growing independence of the planar unit in collage as a shape - that the identity of depicted objects , or at least parts of them , re-emerged in Braque 's and Picasso 's papiers colles and continued to remain more conspicuous there - but only as flattened silhouettes - than in any of their paintings done wholly in oil before the end of 1913 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Analytical Cubism came to an end in the collage , but not conclusively ; nor did Synthetic Cubism fully begin there .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only when the collage had been exhaustively translated into oil , and transformed by this translation , did Cubism become an affair of positive color and flat , interlocking silhouettes whose legibility and placement created allusions to , if not the illusion of , unmistakable three-dimensional identities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Synthetic Cubism began with Picasso alone , late in 1913 or early in 1914 ; this was the point at which he finally took the lead in Cubist innovation away from Braque , never again to relinquish it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But even before that , Picasso had glimpsed and entered , for a moment , a certain revolutionary path in which no one had preceded him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was as though , in that instant , he had felt the flatness of collage as too constricting and had suddenly tried to escape all the way back - or forward - to literal three-dimensionality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This he did by using utterly literal means to carry the forward push of the collage ( and of Cubism in general ) literally into the literal space in front of the picture plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some time in 1912 , Picasso cut out and folded a piece of paper in the shape of a guitar ; to this he glued and fitted other pieces of paper and four taut strings , thus creating a sequence of flat surfaces in real and sculptural space to which there clung only the vestige of a picture plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The affixed elements of collage were extruded , as it were , and cut off from the literal pictorial surface to form a bas-relief .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( Los Angeles in 1957 finally bowed to the skyscraper . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And without high density in the core , rapid-transit systems cannot be maintained economically , let alone built from scratch at today 's prices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">However , the building of freeways and garages cannot continue forever .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The new interchange among the four Los Angeles freeways , including the grade-constructed accesses , occupies by itself no less than eighty acres of downtown land , one-eighth of a square mile , an area about the size of Rockefeller Center in New York .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is hard to believe that this mass of intertwined concrete constitutes what the law calls `` the highest and best use '' of centrally located urban land .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As it affects the city 's fiscal situation , such an interchange is ruinous ; it removes forever from the tax rolls property which should be taxed to pay for the city services .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Subways improved land values without taking away land ; freeways boost valuation less ( because the garages they require are not prime buildings by a long shot ) , and reduce the acreage that can be taxed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Downtown Los Angeles is already two-thirds freeway , interchange , street , parking lot and garage - one of those preposterous `` if '' statistics has already come to pass .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The freeway with narrowly spaced interchanges concentrates and mitigates the access problem , but it also acts inevitably as an artificial , isolating boundary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">City planners do not always use this boundary as effectively as they might .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Less ambitious freeway plans may be more successful - especially when the roadways and interchanges are raised , allowing for cross access at many points and providing parking areas below the ramp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Meanwhile , the automobile and its friend the truck have cost the central city some of its industrial dominance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In ever greater numbers , factories are locating in the suburbs or in `` industrial parks '' removed from the city 's political jurisdiction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The appeal of the suburb is particularly strong for heavy industry , which must move bulky objects along a lengthy assembly line and wants enough land area to do the entire job on one floor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To light industry , the economies of being on one floor are much slighter , but efficiency engineers usually believe in them , and manufacturers looking for ways to cut costs cannot be prevented from turning to efficiency engineers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This movement of industry away from the central cities is not so catastrophically new as some prophets seem to believe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is merely the latest example of the leapfrog growth which formed the pattern of virtually all American cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The big factories which are relatively near the centers of our cities - the rubber factories in Akron , Chrysler 's Detroit plants , U. S. Steel 's Pittsburgh works - often began on these sites at a time when that was the edge of the city , yet close to transport ( river ) , storage ( piers ) and power ( river ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The `` leapfrog '' was a phenomenon of the railroad and the steam turbine , and the time when the belts of residence surrounding the old factory area were not yet blighted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The truck and the car gave the manufacturer a new degree of freedom in selecting his plant site .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Until internal combustion became cheap , he had to be near a railroad siding and a trolley line or an existing large community of lower-class homes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The railroad siding is still important - it is usually , though not always , true that long-haul shipment by rail is cheaper than trucking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But anybody who promises a substantial volume of business can get a railroad to run a short spur to his plant these days , and many businesses can live without the railroad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And there are now many millions of workers for whom the factory with the big parking lot , which can be reached by driving across or against the usual pattern of rush hour traffic and grille route bus lines , is actually more convenient than the walk-to factory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Willow Run , General Electric 's enormous installations at Louisville and Syracuse , the Pentagon , Boeing in Seattle , Douglas and Lockheed in Los Angeles , the new automobile assembly plants everywhere - none of these is substantially served by any sort of conventional mass rapid transit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They are all suburban plants , relying on the roads to keep them supplied with workers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And wherever the new thruways go up their banks are lined by neat glass and metal and colored brick light industry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The drive along Massachusetts ' Route 128 , the by-pass which makes an arc about twenty miles from downtown Boston , may be a vision of the future .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The future could be worse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The plants along Route 128 are mostly well designed and nicely set against the New England rocks and trees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They can even be rather grand , like Edward Land 's monument to the astonishing success of Polaroid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But they deny the values of the city - the crowded , competitive , tolerant city , the `` melting pot '' which gave off so many of the most admirable American qualities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They are segregated businesses , combining again on one site the factory and the office , drawing their work force from segregated communities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is interesting to note how many of the plants on Massachusetts ' Route 128 draw most of their income either from the government in non-competitive cost-plus arrangements , or from the exploitation of patents which grant at least a partial monopoly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While the factories were always the center of the labor market , they were often on the city 's periphery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In spreading the factories even farther , the automobile may not have changed to any great extent the growth pattern of the cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Even the loss of hotel business to the outskirt 's motel has been relatively painless ; the hotel-motel demarcation is becoming harder to find every year .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What hurts most is the damage the automobile has done to central-city retailing , especially in those cities where public transit is feeble .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some retailing , of course , always spreads with the population - grocery stores , drugstores , local haberdasheries and dress shops , candy stores and the like .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But whenever a major purchase was contemplated forty years ago - a new bedroom set or a winter coat , an Easter bonnet , a bicycle for Junior - the family set off for the downtown department store , where the selection would be greatest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Department stores congregated in the `` one hundred per cent location '' , where all the transit lines converged .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These stores are still there , but the volume of the `` downtown store '' has been on a relative decline , while in many cities the suburban `` branch '' sells more and more dry goods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the retailer and hotelman 's downtown unit sales have been decreasing , however , his dollar volume continues to rise , and it is dollars which you put in the bank .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In most discussions of this phenomenon , the figures are substantially inflated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">No suburban shopping-center branch - not even Hudson 's vast Northland outside Detroit - does anything like the unit volume of business or carries anything like the variety of merchandise to be found in the home store .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Telephone orders distort the picture :
the suburbanite naturally calls a local rather than a central city number if both are listed in an advertisement , especially if the local call eliminates city sales tax .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The suburban branch is thereby credited with a sale which would have been made even if its glass doors had never opened .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Accounting procedures which continue to charge a disproportionate overhead and warehouse expense to the main store make the branches seem more profitable than they are .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In many cases that statement `` We break even on our downtown operation and make money on our branches '' would be turned around if the cost analysis were recalculated on terms less prejudicial to the old store .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Fear of the competition - always a great motivating force in the American economy - makes retailers who do not have suburban operations exaggerate both the volume and the profitability of their rival 's shiny new branches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The fact seems to be that very many large branch stores are uneconomical , that the choice of location in the suburbs is as important as it was downtown , and that even highly suburbanized cities will support only so many big branches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , the cost of operations is always high in any new store , as the conservative bankers who act as controllers for retail giants are beginning to discover .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When all has been said , however , the big branch store remains a major break with history in the development of American retailing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just as the suburban factory may be more convenient than the downtown plant to the worker with a car , the trip to the shopping center may seem far easier than to the downtown department store , though both are the same distance from home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Indeed , there are some cities where the suburban shopping pulls customers who are geographically much nearer to downtown .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Raymond Vernon reports that residents of East St. Louis have been driving across the Mississippi , through the heart of downtown St. Louis and out to the western suburbs for major shopping , simply because parking is easier at the big branches than it is in the heart of town .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To the extent that the problem is merely parking , an aggressive downtown management , like that of Lazarus Brothers in Columbus , Ohio , can fight back successfully by building a garage on the lot next door .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the distant patron of the suburban branch has been frightened away from downtown by traffic problems , however , the city store can only pressure the politicians to do something about the highways or await the completion of the federal highway program .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And if the affection for the suburban branch reflects a desire to shop with `` nice people '' , rather than with the indiscriminate urban mass which supports the downtown department store , the central location may be in serious trouble .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Today , according to land economist Homer Hoyt , shopping centers and their associated parking lots cover some 46000 acres of land , which is almost exactly the total land area in all the nation 's Central Business Districts put together .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The downtown store continues to offer the great inducement of variety , both within its gates and across the street , where other department stores are immediately convenient for the shopper who wants to see what is available before making up her mind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If anything may be predicted in the quicksilver world of retailing , it seems likely that the suburban branch will come to dominate children 's clothing ( taking the kid downtown is too much of a production ) , household gadgetry and the discount business in big-ticket items .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Department stores were built on dry goods , especially ladies ' fashions , and in this area , in the long run , the suburban branches will be hard put to compete against downtown .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If this analysis is correct , the suburban branches will turn out to be what management 's cost accountants refuse to acknowledge , marginal operations rather than major factors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Historically in America the appeal of cities has been their color and life , the variety of experience they offered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` How ya gonna keep ' em down on the farm '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">was a question that had to be asked long before they saw Paree .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Though Americans usually lived in groups segregated by national origin or religious belief , they liked to work and shop in the noise and vitality of downtown .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only a radical change in the nature of the population in the central city would be likely to destroy this preference - and we must now turn our attention to the question of whether such a change , gloomily foreseen by so many urban diagnosticians , is actually upon us .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In their book American Skyline , Christopher Tunnard and Henry Hope Reed argue that Franklin Roosevelt 's New Deal was what made the modern suburb a possibility - a fine ironical argument , when you consider how suburbanites tend to vote .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first superhighways - New York 's Henry Hudson and Chicago 's Lake Shore , San Francisco 's Bay Bridge and its approaches , a good slice of the Pennsylvania Turnpike - were built as part of the federal works program which was going to cure the depression .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the same time , Roosevelt 's Federal Housing Administration , coupled with Henry Morgenthau 's cheap-money policy , permitted ordinary lower-middle-class families to build their own homes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Bankers who had been reluctant to lend without better security than the house itself got that security from the U. S. government ; householders who had been unable to pick up the burden of short-term high interest mortgages found they could borrow for twenty-five years at 4 per cent , under government aegis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the midwest , oxidation ponds are used extensively for the treatment of domestic sewage from suburban areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The high cost of land and a few operational problems resulting from excessive loadings have created the need for a wastewater treatment system with the operational characteristics of the oxidation pond but with the ability to treat more organic matter per unit volume .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Research at Fayette , Missouri on oxidation ponds has shown that the BOD in the treated effluent varied from 30 to 53 mg / l with loadings from 8 to 120 lb BOD / day / acre .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since experience indicates that effluents from oxidation ponds do not create major problems at these BOD concentrations , the goal for the effluent quality of the accelerated treatment system was the same as from conventional oxidation ponds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Recent studies by Weston and Stack had indicated that a turbine aerator could be added to an oxidation pond to increase the rate of oxygen transfer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Their study showed that it was possible to transfer 3 to 4 lb of oxygen / hr / hp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">O'Connor and Eckenfelder discussed the use of aerated lagoons for treating organic wastes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They indicated that a 4 - day retention , aerated lagoon would give 60 to 76 per cent BOD reduction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Later , Eckenfelder increased the efficiency of treatment to between 75 and 85 per cent in the summer months .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It appeared from the limited information available that the aerated lagoon might offer a satisfactory means of increasing the capacity of existing oxidation ponds as well as providing the same degree of treatment in a smaller volume .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With the development of the Red Bridge Subdivision south of Kansas City , Missouri , the developer was faced with the problem of providing adequate sewage disposal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The sewage system from Kansas City was not expected to serve the Red Bridge area for several years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This necessitated the construction of temporary sewage treatment facilities with an expected life from 5 to 15 yrs. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the initial development an oxidation pond was constructed as shown in Figure 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The oxidation pond has a surface area of 4.77 acres and a depth of 4 ft .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The pond is currently serving 1230 persons or 260 persons per acre .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the summer of 1960 the oxidation pond became completely septic and emitted obnoxious odors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was possible to maintain aerobic conditions in the pond by regular additions of sodium nitrate until the temperature decreased and the algae population changed from blue-green to green algae .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The anaerobic conditions in the existing oxidation pond necessitated examination of other methods for supplying additional oxygen than by sodium nitrate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At the same time further expansion in the Red Bridge Subdivision required the construction of additional sewage treatment facilities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The large land areas required for oxidation ponds made this type of treatment financially unattractive to the developer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was proposed that aerated lagoons be used to eliminate the problem at the existing oxidation ponds and to provide the necessary treatment for the additional development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The lack of adequate data on the aerated lagoon system prompted the developer to construct an aerated lagoon pilot plant to determine its feasibility for treating domestic sewage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The pilot plant was a circular lagoon 81 ft in diam at the surface and 65 ft in diam at the bottom , 4 ft below the surface , with a volume of 121000 gal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The side slopes were coated with fiberglas matting coated with asphalt to prevent erosion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pilot lagoon was located as shown in Figure 1 to serve the area just south of the existing housing area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The major contributor was a shopping center with houses being added to the system as the subdivision developed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The pilot lagoon was designed to handle the wastes from 314 persons with a 4 - day aeration period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Initially , the wastewater would be entirely from the shopping center with the domestic sewage from the houses increasing over an 18 - month period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This operation would permit evaluation of the pilot plant , with a slowly increasing load , over a reasonable period of time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The pilot plant was equipped with a 3 - hp turbine aerator ( Figure 2 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The aerator had a variable speed drive to permit operation through a range of speeds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The sewage flow into the treatment plant was metered and continuously recorded on 24 - hr charts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The raw sewage was introduced directly under the turbine aerator to insure maximum mixing of the raw sewage with the aeration tank contents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The effluent was collected through two pipes and discharged to the Blue River through a surface drainage ditch .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Composite samples were collected at weekly intervals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The long retention period and the complete mixing concept prevented rapid changes in either the mixed liquor or in the effluent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Weekly samples would make any changes more readily discernible than daily samples .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The composite samples were normally collected over a 6 - hr period , but an occasional 24 - hr composite was made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Examination of the operations of the shopping center permitted correlation of the 6 - hr composite samples with 24 - hr operations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The data indicated that the organic load during the 6 - hr composites was essentially 50 per cent of the 24 - hr organic load .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Grab samples were collected from the existing oxidation pond to determine its operating conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Efforts were made to take the grab samples at random periods so that the mass of data could be treated as a 6 - hr composite sample .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A single 24 - hr composite sample indicated that the sewage flow pattern and characteristics were typical .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The BOD of the influent to the pilot plant varied between 110 and 710 mg / l with an average of 350 mg / l .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This was equivalent to 240 mg / l BOD on a 24 - hr basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The BOD of the raw sewage was typical of domestic sewage from a subdivision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The BOD in the effluent averaged 58 mg / l , a 76 - per cent reduction over the 24 - hr period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Examination of the data in Table 1 , shows that a few samples contributed to raising the effluent BOD .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The periods of high effluent BOD occurred during cold periods when operational problems with the aerator resulted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ice caused the aerator to overload , straining the drive belts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The slippage of the drive belts caused the aerator to slow down and reduce oxygen transfer as well as the mixing of the raw sewage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The organic loading on the unit averaged 32 lb of BOD / day or about 2 lb BOD / day 1000 cu ft aeration capacity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Needless to say , the organic load was very low on a volumetric basis , but was 270 lb BOD / day / acre on a surface loading basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It seems that the aerated lagoon was a very heavily loaded oxidation pond or a lightly loaded activated sludge system .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The large amount of vegetable grindings from the grocery store in the shopping center created a suspended solids problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The vegetables were not readily metabolized by the bacteria in the aeration unit and tended to float on the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A skimming device at the effluent weir prevented loss of most of these light solids .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The oxygen uptake rate in the mixed liquor averaged 0.8 mg / l / hr during the first four months of this study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Variations in aerator speeds during the latter two months of this study caused increased mixing and increased oxygen demand .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The increase in oxygen uptake rates from 1.2 to 2.6 mg / l / hr which followed an increase in rotor speed was believed to be related to resuspension of solids which had settled at the lower rotor speeds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It appeared that most of the mixed liquor suspended solids were active microbial solids with the heavier , less active solids settling out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The suspended solids discharged in the effluent were found to be the major source of the BOD .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Routine microscopic examinations were made of the mixed liquor as indicated by McKinney and Gram for the various types of protozoa .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was found that the aerated lagoon was an activated sludge system rather than an oxidation pond .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At no time were algae found in the mixed liquor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The bacteria formed typical activated sludge floc .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The characteristic thing about this church was its Amen corner and the weekly religious orgy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A knot of old worshippers , chiefly women , listened weekly to a sermon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It began invariably in low tones , almost conversational , and then gradually worked up to high , shrill appeals to God and man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And then the Amen corner took hold , re-enacting a form of group participation in worship that stemmed from years before the Greek chorus , spreading down through the African forest , overseas to the West Indies , and then here in Alabama .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With shout and slow dance , with tears and song , with scream and contortion , the corner group was beset by hysteria and shivering , wailing , shouting , possession of something that seemed like an alien and outside force .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Serge Prokofieff whom we knew in the United States of America was gay , witty , mercurial , full of pranks and bonheur - and very capable as a professional musician .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Certainly its composer was an ascending star on a new world horizon .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All musical Paris was there .</MPQASENT>
