<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We attended the premieres of his concertos , symphonies , and suites ; we studied , taught , and performed his piano sonatas , chamber music , gavottes , and marches ; we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We unanimously agreed that Prokofieff had won his rights as a world citizen to the first ranks of Twentieth Century Composers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nevertheless , Prokofieff was much influenced by Paris during the Twenties : the Paris which was the artistic center of the Western World - the social Paris to which Russian aristocracy migrated - the chic Paris which attracted the tourist dollars of rich America - the avant-garde Paris of Diaghileff , Stravinsky , Koussevitzky , Cocteau , Picasso - the laissez-faire Paris of Dadaism and ultramodern art - the Paris sympathique which took young composers to her bosom with such quick and easy enthusiasms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">So young Prokofieff was the darling of success :
in his motherland ; in the spacious hunting grounds of `` Uncle Sam '' ; in the exciting salons of his lovely , brilliant Paris - mistress of gaiety - excess and abandon - world theatre of new found freedoms in tone , color , dance , design , and thought .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Meanwhile , three great terrible forces were coagulating and crystallizing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this world-wide conscription of men , minds , and machines , Prokofieff was recalled to his native land .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The world exploded when Fascism challenged all concepts of peace and liberty , and the outraged , freedom loving peoples of the Capitalist and Socialist worlds combined forces to stamp Fascist tyranny into cringing submission .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After this holocaust , a changing world occupied the minds of men ; a world beset with new boundaries , new treaties and governments , new goals and methods , and the age-old fears of aggression and subjugation - hunger and exposure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this changed world , Prokofieff settled to find himself , and to create for large national purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Here , this happy , roving son of good fortune proved that he could accept the disciplines of a new social economic order fighting for its very existence and ideals in a truculent world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Here , Prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of Socialism - producing music for the masses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is at this point in his life that the mature Prokofieff emerges .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By 1937 he had clarified his intentions to serve his people : `` I have striven for clarity and melodious idiom , but at the same time I have by no means attempted to restrict myself to the accepted methods of harmony and melody .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The early works were conceived for a sophisticated , international audience ; the later works were conceived to affirm a way of life for fellow citizens .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , in all of Prokofieff 's music , young or mature , we find his profile - his `` signature '' - his craftsman 's attitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Prokofieff never forsakes his medium for the cause of experimentation per se .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In orchestration , he stretches the limits of instrumentation with good judgment and a fine imagination for color .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His sense for rhythmic variety and timing is impeccable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">His creative development of melodic designs of Slavic dance tunes and love songs is captivating : witty , clever , adroit , and subtle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His counterpoint is pertinent , skillful , and rarely thick .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Also , it should be noted that the polytonal freedom of his melodies and harmonic modulations , the brilliant orchestrations , the adroitness for evading the heaviness of figured bass , the skill in florid counterpoint were not lost in his mature output , even in the spectacular historical dramas of the stage and cinema , where a large , dramatic canvas of sound was required .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That Prokofieff 's harmonies and forms sometimes seem professionally routine to our ears , may or may not indicate that he was less of an `` original '' than we prefer to believe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Need for novelty may be a symptom of cultural fatigue and instability .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero , who , by the force of his creative life , helped preserve the main stream of tradition , to which the surviving idioms of current experimentalism may be eventually added and integrated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At this date , it seems probable that the name of Serge Prokofieff will appear in the archives of History , as an effective Traditionalist , who was fully aware of the lure and danger of experimentation , and used it as it served his purpose ; yet was never caught up in it - never a slave to its academic dialectics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Certainly , it is the traditional clarity of his music which has endeared him to the Western World - not his experimentations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So Prokofieff was able to cultivate his musical talents and harvest a rich reward from them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Nor can anyone be certain that Prokofieff would have done better , or even as well , under different circumstances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His fellow countryman , Igor Stravinsky , certainly did not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Why did Prokofieff expand in stature and fecundity , while Stravinsky ( who leaped into fame like a young giant ) dwindled in stature and fruitfulness ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I think the answer is to be found in Prokofieff 's own words :
`` the clarity must be new , not old '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When Prokofieff forged his new clarity of `` lucid , straightforward music , so difficult to compose '' , he shaped his talents to his purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When Stravinsky shaped his purpose to the shifting scenes of many cultures , many salons , many dialectics , many personalities , he tried to refashion himself into a stylist of many styles , determined by many disparate cultures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Prokofieff was guided in a consistent direction by the life of his own people - by the compass of their national ideas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But Stravinsky was swayed by the attitudes of whatever culture he was reflecting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In all his miscalculations , Stravinsky made the fatal historical blunder of presuming that he could transform other composers ' inspirations - representing many peoples , time periods and styles - into his own music by warping the harmony , melody , or form , to verify his own experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Because of the authentic homogeneity of his early Nationalistic materials , and his flair for orchestrations - his brilliant Petruchka , his savage Sacre du Printemps , his incisive Les Noces - the world kept hoping that he could recapture the historical direction for which his native talents were predisposed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But time is running out , and many of Stravinsky 's admirers begin to fear that he will never find terra firma .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His various aesthetic postulates remain as landmarks of a house divided against itself : Supra Expressionism , Neo Paganism , Neo Classicism , Neo Romanticism , Neo Jazz , Neo Ecclesiasticism , Neo Popularism , and most recently , Post Serialism - all competing with each other within one composer !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What a patchwork of proclamations and renunciations !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Meager and shabby by-products linger to haunt our memories of a once mighty protagonist ; a maladroit reharmonization of our National Anthem ( The Star-Spangled Banner ) ; a poor attempt to write an idiomatic jazz concerto ; a circus polka for elephants ; his hopes that the tunes from his old music might be used for popular American commercial songs !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Stravinsky , nearing the age of eighty , is like a lost and frantic bird , flitting from one abandoned nest to another , searching for a home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">How differently Prokofieff 's life unfolded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Prokofieff was able to adjust his creative personality to a swiftly changing world without losing his particular force and direction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the process , his native endowments were stretched , strengthened and disciplined to serve their human purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">With a large and circumspect 20 th Century technique , he wove the materials of national heroes and events , national folklore and children 's fairy tales - Slavic dances and love songs - into a solid musical literature which served his people well , and is providing much enjoyment to the World at large .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of course , it must not be forgotten that in achieving this historical feat , Prokofieff had the vast resources of his people behind him ; time and economic security ; symphony orchestras , opera and ballet companies ; choruses , chamber music ensembles ; soloists ; recordings ; broadcastings ; television ; large and eager audiences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It must be conceded that his native land provided Prokofieff with many of the necessary conditions for great creative incentive :
economic security and cultural opportunities , incisive idioms , social fermentations for a new national ideology - a sympathetic public and a large body of performers especially trained to fulfill his purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus in Prokofieff the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics produced one of the great composers of the Twentieth Century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That his moods , even in his early years , are those of his people , does him honor , as his music honors those who inspired it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">That he mastered every aspect of his medium according to his own great talents and contemporary judgments , is a good and solid symbol of his people under the tremendous pressures of proclaiming and practising the rigors of a new culture ; and perhaps of even greater significance - his music is strong 20 th Century evidence of the effectiveness of Evolution , based on a broad Traditionalism for the creative art of music .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">April 10 marked a memorable date in New York 's musical history - indeed in the musical history of the entire eastern United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On that date the Musicians Emergency Fund , organized to furnish employment for musicians unable to obtain engagements during the depression and to provide relief for older musicians who lost their fortunes in the stock market crash , observed its 30 th anniversary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Roy Mason is essentially a landscape painter whose style and direction has a kinship with the English watercolorists of the early nineteenth century , especially the beautifully patterned art of John Sell Cotman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And like this English master , Mason realizes his subjects in large , simplified masses which , though they seem effortless , are in reality the result of skilled design born of hard work and a thorough distillation of the natural form that inspired them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a boy Roy Mason began the long process of extracting the goodness of the out-of-doors , its tang of weather , its change of seasons , its variable moods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His father , a professional engraver and an amateur landscape painter , took his sons on numerous hunting expeditions , and imparted to them his knowledge and love of nature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Out of this background of hunting and fishing , it was only natural that Roy first painted subjects he knew best : hunters in the field , fishermen in the stream , ducks and geese on the wing - almost always against a vast backdrop of weather landscape .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is this subject matter that has brought Mason a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen , but it is his exceptional performance with this motif that commends him to artists and discerning collectors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Mason had to earn the privilege of devoting himself exclusively to painting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Like many others , he had to work hard , long hours in a struggling family business which , though it was allied to art of a kind - the design and production of engraved seals - bore no relation to the painting of pictures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But it did teach Roy the basic techniques of commercial art , and later , for twelve years , he and his sister Nina conducted an advertising art studio in Philadelphia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the death of their father , they returned to their home in Batavia , New York .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After more years of concentrated effort , Roy and his brother Max finally established a thriving family business at the old stand .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">During all this time Roy continued to paint , first only on weekends , and then , as the family business permitted , for longer periods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether , and for the past thirty years , he has worked independently as a painter , except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But even on these , the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off !</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the best tradition , he first taught himself to see , then to draw with accuracy and assurance , and then to paint .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It has been my privilege to paint with Roy Mason on numerous occasions , mostly in the vicinity of Batavia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">More often than not I have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at a respectable distance where I could watch this man transform raw nature into a composed , not imitative , painting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What I have observed time and time again is a process of integration , integration that begins as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form ; color patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition ; and that over all , amazing control of large washes which is the Mason stylemark .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the job is done .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Inspiring - yes ; instructive - maybe ; duplicable - no !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But for the technical fact , we have the artist 's own testimony :
`` Of late years , I find that I like best to work out-of-doors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">First I make preliminary watercolor sketches in quarter scale ( approximately * * f inches ) in which I pay particular attention to the design principles of three simple values - the lightest light , the middle tone , and the darkest dark - by reducing the forms of my subject to these large patterns .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If a human figure or wild life are to be part of the projected final picture , I try to place them in the initial sketch .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For me , these will belong more completely to their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage , though I freely admit that I do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on the full sheet when it serves my final purpose .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` I am thoroughly convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects nature will do his composing for him ; as a result , such pictures are only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting , unless the position serves the design of the whole composition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain units in his design , often only slightly , finer pictures would result .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Out of long experience I have found that incidental figures and other objects like trees , logs , and bushes can be traced from the original sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they occupy the right position , which I call ' clicking ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Speed in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity and crispness , but unless the artist has lots of experience so that he can control rapid execution , he would do well to take these first sketches and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` If I have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition , I mean to project equal concern for color .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Often , in working out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere , a particular passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be too bright , too dull , or too light , or too dark when viewed indoors in a mat .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When this occurs , I make the change on the sketch or on the final watercolor - if I have been working on a full sheet in the field .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` When working from one of my sketches I square it up and project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When this linear draft is completed , I dust it down to a faint image .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From this point , I paint in as direct a manner as possible , by flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as I can manage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , first I thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and design along the lines I have described .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Then I plan my attack : the parts I will finish first , the range of values , the accenting of minor details - all in all , mechanics of producing the finished job with a maximum of crispness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The longer I work , the more I am sure that for me , at least , a workmanlike method is important .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Trial and error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles in the final painting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` As for materials , I use the best available .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I work on a watercolor easel in the field , and frequently resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue strain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In my studio I work at a tilt-top table , but leave the paper unfixed so that I can move it freely to control the washes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I have used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers , but prefer an English make , rough surface , in 400 - pound weight .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After selecting a sheet and inspecting it for flaws ( even the best sometimes has foreign ' nubbins ' on its surface ) , I sponge it thoroughly on both sides with clean , cold water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Then I dry the sheet under mild pressure so that it will lie flat as a board .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` In addition to the usual tools , I make constant use of cleansing tissue , not only to wipe my brushes , but to mop up certain areas , to soften edges , and to open up lights in dark washes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the watercolorist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I also use a small electric hand blower to dry large washes in the studio .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` My brushes are different from those used by most watercolorists , for I combine the sable and the bristle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The red sables are 8 ; two riggers , 6 and 10 ; and a very large , flat wash brush .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The bristles are a Fitch 2 and a one-half inch brush shaved to a sharp chisel edge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` My usual palette consists of top-quality colors :
alizarin crimson , orange , raw sienna , raw umber , burnt sienna , sepia , cerulean blue , cobalt blue , French ultramarine blue , Winsor green , Hooker's green 2 , cadmium yellow pale , yellow ochre , Payne's gray , charcoal gray , Davy's gray , and ivory black '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In analyzing the watercolors of Roy Mason , the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness , yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">True , a Mason watercolor is unmistakably a synthesis of nature rather than a detailed inventory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Unlike many decorative patterns that present a static flat convention , this artist 's pictures are full of atmosphere and climate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Long observation has taught Mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes : a foreground in sharp focus - either a light area with dark accents or a dark one with lights ; a middle distance often containing the major motif ; and a background , usually a silhouetted form foiled against the sky .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In following this general principle , Mason provides the observer with a natural eye progression from foreground to background , and the illusion of depth is instantly created .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When painting , Mason 's physical eyes are half closed , while his mind's eye is wide open , and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression he wishes to convey .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He does not insist on telling all he knows about any given subject ; rather his pictures invite the observer to draw on his memory , his imagination , his nostalgia .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His pictures generalize , though they are inspired by a particular locale ; they universalize in terms of weather , skies , earth , and people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By dealing with common landscape in an uncommon way , Roy Mason has found a particular niche in American landscape art .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor , a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor the Creator of it all .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual defense budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion of these expenditures go for military electronics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We have noted how some electronic techniques , developed for the defense effort , have evenutally been used in commerce and industry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The host of novel applications of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment , the prospect is staggering .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The author has recently studied the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that , in this area alone , the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be greater by far than any previous medical discovery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We use the term `` bio-medicine '' because of the close interrelation between biology and medical research .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Electronics has been applied to medicine for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine , the electrocardiograph , and the diathermy machine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Recently many doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage of bruises , contusions , and simple bursitis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Commonly used electronic devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit TV and audio systems for internal paging and instruction , along with radiation counters , timers , and similar devices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this is where tomorrow 's commonplace equipment originates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the wealth of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely new tools in medical research .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Many cells , bacteria , and other microorganisms are transparent to visible light and must be stained for microscopic investigation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This stain often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A completely new insight into living cells and their structure will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color - TV system to view the results .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">1 is a simplified block diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the Medical Electronics Center of Rockefeller Institute .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">By combining the talents of a medical man , Dr. Aterman , a biophysicist , Mr. Berkely , and an electronics expert , Dr. Zworykin , this novel technique has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding life processes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Three different wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the rotating mirror ; the specimen is magnified by the microscope .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Instead of the observer 's eye the image orthicon in the TV camera does the `` looking '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The microscope and orthicon are both selected to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum , which means that all lenses must be quartz .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The video signal is amplified and then switched , in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of a second only one wavelength , corresponding to red , green , or blue , is seen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( Note :
Because of light leakage from one ultraviolet source to another , the lights are switched by a commutator like assembly rotated by a synchronous motor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This assembly also supplies a 20 - cps switching gate for the electronics circuitry . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This is the same system as was used in the field sequential color TV system which preceded the present simultaneous system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Three separate amplifiers then drive a 21 - inch tricolor tube .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The result is a color picture of the specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet wavelengths .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Many of the cells and microorganisms which are transparent to visible light , absorb or reflect the much shorter wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Different parts of these cells sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows or nothing at all , ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation into a color TV picture reveal a wealth of detail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The medical title of `` Lobar Ventilation in Man '' by Drs. C. J. Martin and A. C. Young , covers a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics to the study of the respiratory process .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At the University of Washington Medical School , the electronics group has developed the `` Respiratory Gas Analyzer '' shown in Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">3 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This unit , affectionately dubbed `` The Monster '' , can be wheeled to any convenient location and provides a wealth of information about the patient 's breathing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the lower center rack an 8 - channel recorder indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper and lower lobes of one lung , the total volume of inhalation per breath , the flow of air from both lobes , and the pressure of the two lobes with respect to each other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece while walking a treadmill , standing still , or in some other medically significant position .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the resulting data the doctor can determine lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The original electrocardiograph primarily indicates irregularities in the heartbeat , but today 's techniques allow exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta , dimensioning of the heart and its chambers , and a much more detailed study of each heartbeat .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For many of these measurements the chest must be opened , but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A group of researchers at the University of Washington have given a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One simple method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber tube , filled with mercury , around the heart and record the change in resistance as the tube is stretched .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A balanced resistance bridge and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The travel time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second thus it takes about 16 | msec.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">to traverse 25 mm.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">of tissue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A sonar or radar type of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for body tissue evaluation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In addition to the heart and aorta , successful measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Doppler effect , using ultrasonic signals , can be employed to measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining the effective power of the heart itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It uses both an ultrasonic dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor inserted into the bloodstream .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The latter measures the heat carried away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood flow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer , mounted at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart 's left ventricle , to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This pressure measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning measurement is made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A simplified version of the instrumentation for this procedure is shown in Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Outputs of the two systems are measured by a pulse timing circuit and a resistance bridge , followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From this doctors can read heart rate , change in diameter , pressure , and effective heart power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Several years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal pressure data to external receivers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This original capsule contained a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">in diameter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Battery life limited the use of this `` pill '' to about 8 to 30 hours maximum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A refinement of this technique has been described by Drs. Zworykin and Farrar and Mr. Berkely of the Medical Electronics Center of the Rockefeller Institute .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this novel arrangement the `` pill '' is much smaller and contains only a resonant circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure sensing transducer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As shown in Fig.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">4 , an external antenna is placed over or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400 - kc.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">bursts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The energy received by the `` pill '' causes the resonant circuit to `` ring '' on after the burst and this `` ringing '' takes place at the resonant frequency of the `` pill '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These frequencies are amplified and detected by the FM receiver after each burst of transmitted energy and , after the `` pill '' has been calibrated , precise internal pressure indications can be obtained .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the advantages of this method is that the `` pill '' can remain in the patient for several days , permitting observation under natural conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are planned for future experiments .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine detection is in the exploration of the human body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Our readers are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Various methods of pulsing , scanning , and displaying these sound waves are used to detect submarines , map ocean floors , and even communicate under water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In medicine the frequencies are much higher , transducers and the sonar beams themselves are much smaller , and different scanning techniques may be used , but the principles involved are the same as in sonar .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Because the body contains so much liquid , transmission of ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic signals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Based on this phenomenon , a number of investigators have used this method to `` look through '' human organs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A good example of the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers presented by Dr. G. Baum who has explored the human eye .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate blindness due to glaucoma .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oersted 's boyhood represented a minimal chance of either attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a span of life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He was born in the small Danish town of Rudkoebing on the island of Langeland in the south central part of Denmark on August 14 , 1777 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His father Soeren was the village apothecary whose slender income made it difficult to feed his family , let alone educate them in a town without even a school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The two older boys , Hans and Anders , his junior by a year , therefore went daily to the home of a warm and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in German ; his wife taught the two boys to read and write Danish .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other brothers later joined them for instruction with Oldenburg , the wigmaker , and also arithmetic was added to Bible reading , German , and Danish in the informal curriculum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oldenburg 's contributions were soon exhausted and the boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town 's learned , such as the pastor , to supplement the simple teaching .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the town surveyor , Hans learned drawing and mathematics and , from a university student , some academic subjects .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The mayor of the town taught them English and French .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whatever Hans or Anders learned separately they passed on to each other ; they read every book that they could borrow in the village .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At 12 , Hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in the apothecary shop , which helped stimulate his interest in medicine and science .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His earlier love for literature and history remained with him for his entire life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1793 the brothers decided to enter the University of Copenhagen ( founded in 1479 ) and the following spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the autumn session .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">While Hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine , physics , and astronomy , his brother studied law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The brothers continued to help each other during their studies , sharing a joint purse , lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of their aunt .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They supplemented their income by small government assistance , by tutoring and economizing wherever they could .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">So impressive were those serious years of study at the university that Hans later wrote , `` to be perfectly free , the young man must revel in the great kingdom of thought and imagination ; there is a struggle there , in which , if he falls , it is easy for him to rise again , there is freedom of utterance there , which draws after it no irreparable consequences on society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I lived in this onward driving contest where each day overcame a new difficulty , gained a new truth , or banished a previous error '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing about science .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this third year at the university , Hans , in 1797 , was awarded the first important token of recognition , a gold medal for his essay on `` Limits of Poetry and Prose '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He completed his training in pharmacy also , taking his degree with high honors in 1797 , and in 1799 was awarded the degree of Doctor of Philosophy along with a prize for an essay in medicine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He proposed a fresh theory of alkalis which later was accepted in chemical practices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Han 's student days were at a time when Europe was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in America and in France , Germany and Italy were rising from divisive nationalisms and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the Continent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The new century opened with Oersted beginning his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in Copenhagen and as lecturer at the university .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was stirred by the announcement of Volta 's discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The following year he devoted to the customary `` Wanderjahr '' , traveling in Germany , France , and the Netherlands , meeting the philosophers Schelling , Fichte , and Tieck .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He also met Count Rumford ( born Benjamin Thompson in Woburn, Mass . )</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">who was then serving the Elector of Bavaria , and the physicist Ritter ; these were Oersted 's main contacts in science .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From Go ^ ttingen ( 1801 ) where he stayed for 10 days , he wrote , `` The first question asked everywhere is about galvanism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As everybody is curious to see the battery of glass tubes I have invented , I have had quite a small one made here of four glass tubes ( in Copenhagen I used 30 ) and intend to carry it with me '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Oersted joined Ritter at Jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks , continuing their correspondence after he left .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With Ritter he was exposed to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host 's fertile but disorganized mind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oersted remodeled Ritter 's notes into an essay in French which was submitted to the Institut de France for its annual prize of 3000 francs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The sound discoveries of this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize was never awarded to him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In May , 1803 , Ritter , in another flight of fancy , wrote to Oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided with the years of important electrical discoveries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , 1745 corresponded to the invention of the `` Leiden '' jar by Kleist , 1764 that of the electrophorus by Wilcke , 1782 produced the condenser of Volta , and 1801 the voltaic pile .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ritter proceeded , `` You now emerge into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 , you will have to reckon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This we might well witness '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ritter died in 1810 and Oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1803 Oersted returned to Copenhagen and applied for the university 's chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably considered more a philosopher than a physicist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">However , he continued experimenting and lecturing , publishing the results of his experiments in German and Danish periodicals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1806 his ambition was realized and he became professor of physics at the Copenhagen University , though not realizing full professorship ( ordinarius ) until 1817 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">During Oersted 's attendance at the university , it was poorly equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was , however , fortunate in his contact with Prof. J. G. L. Manthey ( 1769 - 1842 ) , teacher of chemistry , who , in addition to his academic chair , was also proprietor of the `` Lion Pharmacy '' in Copenhagen where Oersted assisted him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Manthey maintained a valuable collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at Oersted 's disposal during and after his graduation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1800 , Manthey went abroad and Oersted was appointed manager of the Lion Pharmacy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In February 1801 , Oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates of zinc and lead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the following year , 1803 , Oersted , simultaneously with Davy , discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic battery more than did salts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Eager as he was to pursue this promising line , he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university that he could devote only Sunday afternoons to `` galvanizing '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He assumed his academic career with the same intensity and thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The university was the only one in Denmark and the status of professor represented the upper social level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His broad interest in literary , political , and philosophical movements opened many doors to him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His friends were numerous and their ties to him were strong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The years 1812 and 1813 saw him in Germany and France again , but on this visit to Berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his first journey .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In Berlin he published his views of the chemical laws of nature in German and this was issued in French translation ( Paris , 1813 ) under the title Recherches sur l ' identite des forces chimiques et electriques , a work held in very high esteem by the new generation of research chemists .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His interest in finding a relationship between voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Chapter 8 , is entitled `` On Magnetism '' and in it are included such remarks as , `` One has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces with the electrical forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The great resemblance between electrical and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their laws necessarily would bring about this comparison .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is true , that nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication ; but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest difference .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The form of galvanic activity is halfway between the magnetic form and the electrical form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There , forces are more latent than in electricity , and less than in magnetism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But in such an important question , we would be satisfied if the judgment were that the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity and magnetism were only a difficulty , and not a thing which is contrary to it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One could also add to these analogies that steel loses its magnetism by heat , which proves that steel becomes a better conductor through a rise in temperature , just as electrical bodies do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature , as proven by Bruckmann and Coulomb .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By that , one feels that magnetic forces are as general as electrical forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An attempt should be made to see if electricity , in its most latent stage , has any action on the magnet as such '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His plan and intent were clearly charted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and political discussions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In one debate he supported the freedom of judgment as opposed to dogma , in another he held that the practice of science was in fact an act of religious worship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He continued as a popular lecturer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was caused to glow by an electric current .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1819 under royal command he undertook a very successful geological expedition to Bornholm , one of the Danish islands , being one of three scientists in the expedition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition , Lauritz Esmarch , that Oersted succeeded in producing light by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric current was made to flow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Together they also developed a new form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of copper , thereby producing stronger currents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Esmarch was among those who witnessed Oersted 's first demonstration of his discovery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The association between electric ( both electrostatic and voltaic ) forces and magnetic forces had been recognized by investigators for many decades .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Electrical literature contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and had altered the polarity of compass needles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the late 1700 's Beccaria and van Marum , among others , had magnetized iron by sending an electrostatic charge through it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Beccaria had almost stumbled on a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge from a Leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece of watch spring steel making its ends magnetic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The resulting magnetic effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The experiments of Romagnosi and others have already been noted but no one had determined the cause and effect relationship between these two primary forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Oersted 's own earlier experiments were unimpressive , possibly because he had , like other experimenters , laid the conducting wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the university related that the first direct event that led to the publication of Oersted 's discovery occurred during a private lecture made before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At this lecture Oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel to a magnetic needle .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Farming is confining .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The farmer 's life must be arranged to meet the demands of crops and livestock .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Livestock must be tended every day , routinely .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A slight change in the work schedule may cut the production of cows or chickens .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Even if there are no livestock , the farmer cannot leave the farm for long periods , particularly during the growing season .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The worker who lives on a farm cannot change jobs readily .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He cannot leave the farm to take work in another locality on short notice ; such a move may mean a loss of capital .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hard physical labor and undesirable hours are a part of farm life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The farmer must get up early , and , at times , work late at night .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Frequently he must work long hours in the hot sun or cold rain .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It may not be profitable for a part-time farmer to own the labor-saving machinery that a full-time farmer can invest in profitably .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Production may fall far below expectations .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Returns for money and labor invested may be small even in a good year .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The high cost of land , supplies , and labor make it difficult to farm profitably on a part-time basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Land within commuting distance of a growing city is usually high in price , higher if it has subdivision possibilities .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It will frequently be uneconomical for him to own the most up-to-date equipment .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A farm provides a wholesome and healthful environment for children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It gives them room to play and plenty of fresh air .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The children can do chores adapted to their age and ability .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Generally , the same level of living costs less in the country than in the city .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Where schools , fire and police protection , and similar municipal services are of equal quality in city and country , real estate taxes are usually about the same .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Three quarters to 1 acre of good land is enough for raising fruits and vegetables for home use , and for a small flock of chickens , a cow , and two pigs .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Its worth as a place to live .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To figure the value of the farm in terms of investment income , divide the estimated annual net farm income by the percentage that you could expect to get in interest if the money were invested in some other way .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Everyone with a personal or group tragedy to relate had to be given his day in court as in some vast collective dirge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">For almost two months , the defendant and the world heard from individuals escaped from the grave about fathers and mothers , graybeards , adolescents , babies , starved , beaten to death , strangled , machine-gunned , gassed , burned .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One who had been a boy in Auschwitz had to tell how children had been selected by height for the gas chambers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The gruesome humor of the Nazis was not forgotten - the gas chamber with a sign on it with the name of a Jewish foundation and bearing a copper Star of David - nor the gratuitous sadism of SS officers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Public relations strategists everywhere , watching the reaction of the German press , the liberal press , the lunatic fringe press , listening to their neighbors , studying interviews with men and women on the street , cried out : Too much , too much - the mind of the audience is becoming dulled , the horrors are losing their effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And still another witness , one who had crawled out from under a heap of corpses , had to tell how the victims had been forced to lay themselves head to foot one on top of the other before being shot .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most of this testimony may have been legally admissible as bearing on the corpus delicti of the total Nazi crime but seemed subject to question when not tied to the part in it of the defendant 's Department of Jewish Affairs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Counsel for the defense , however , shrewdly allowing himself to be swept by the current of dreadful recollections , rarely raised an objection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Would not the emotional catharsis eventually brought on by this awfulness have a calming , if not exhausting , effect likely to improve his client 's chances ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those who feared `` emotionalism '' at the Trial showed less understanding than Dr. Servatius of the route by which man achieves the distance necessary for fairness toward enemies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Interruptions came largely from the bench , which numerous times rebuked the Attorney General for letting his witnesses run on , though it , too , made no serious effort to choke off the flow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But there was a contrast even more decisive than a hunger for fact between the Trial in Jerusalem and those in Moscow and New York .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In each of the last , the trial marked the beginning of a new course : in Moscow the liquidation of the Old Bolsheviks and the tightening of Stalin 's dictatorship ; in the United States the initiation of militant anti Communism , with the repentant ex Communist in the vanguard .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These trials were properly termed `` political cases '' in that the trial itself was a political act producing political consequences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But what could the Eichmann Trial initiate ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of what new course could it mark the beginning ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Eichmann case looked to the past , not to the future .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was the conclusion of the first phase of a process of tragic recollection , and of refining the recollection , that will last as long as there are Jews .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As such , it was beyond politics and had no need of justification by a `` message '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` It is not an individual that is in the dock at this historical trial '' - said Ben Gurion , `` and not the Nazi regime alone - but anti-Semitism throughout history '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">How could supplying Eichmann with a platform on which to maintain that one could collaborate in the murder of millions of Jews without being an anti-Semite contribute to a verdict against anti-Semitism ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And if it was not an individual who was in the dock , why was the Trial , as we shall observe later , all but scuttled in the attempt to prove Eichmann a `` fiend '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These questions touch the root of confusion in the prosecution 's case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It might be contended , of course , that Eichmann in stubbornly denying anti-Semitic feelings was lying or insisting on a private definition of anti-Semitism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But in either event he was the wrong man for the kind of case outlined by Ben Gurion and set forth in the indictment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In such a case the defendant should serve as a clear example and not have to be tied to the issue by argument .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One who could be linked to anti-Semitism only by overcoming his objections is scarcely a good specimen of the Jew-baiter throughout the ages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Shout at Eichmann though he might , the Prosecutor could not establish that the defendant was falsifying the way he felt about Jews or that what he did feel fell into the generally recognized category of anti-Semitism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Yes , he believed that the Jews were `` enemies of the Reich '' , and such a belief is , of course , typical of `` patriotic '' anti-Semites ; but he believed in the Jew as enemy in a kind of abstract , theological way , like a member of a cult speculating on the nature of things .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The real question was how one passed from anti-Semitism of this sort to murder , and the answer to this question is not to be found in anti-Semitism itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In regard to Eichmann , it was to be found in the Nazi outlook , which contained a principle separate from and far worse than anti-Semitism , a principle by which the poison of anti-Semitism itself was made more virulent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Perhaps under the guidance of this Nazi principle one could , as Eichmann declared , feel personally friendly toward the Jews and still be their murderer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Not through fear of disobeying orders , as Eichmann kept trying to explain , but through a peculiar giddiness that began in a half acceptance of the vicious absurdities contained in the Nazi interpretation of history and grew with each of Hitler 's victories into a permanent light mindedness and sense of magical rightness that was able to respond to any proposal , and the more outrageous the better , `` Well , let 's try it '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At any rate , the substance of Eichmann 's testimony was that all his actions flowed from his membership in the party and the SS , and though the Prosecutor did his utmost to prove actual personal hatred of Jews , his success on this score was doubtful and the anti-Semitic lesson weakened to that extent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But if the Trial did not expose the special Nazi mania so deadly to Jews as well as to anyone upon whom it happened to light , neither did it warn very effectively against the ordinary anti-Semitism of which the Nazis made such effective use in Germany and wherever else they could find it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If anti-Semitism was on trial in Jerusalem , why was it not identified , and with enough emphasis to capture the notice of the world press , in its connection with the activities of Eichmann 's Department of Jewish Affairs , as exemplified by the betrayal and murder of Jews by non police and non-party anti-Semites in Germany , as well as in Poland , Czechoslovakia , Hungary ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The infamous Wansee Conference called by Heydrich in January 1942 , to organize the material and technical means to put to death the eleven million Jews spread throughout the nations of Europe , was attended by representatives of major organs of the German state , including the Reich Minister of the Interior , the State Secretary in charge of the Four Year Plan , the Reich Minister of Justice , the Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The measures for annihilation proposed and accepted at the Conference affected industry , transportation , civilian agencies of government .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Heydrich , in opening the Conference , followed the reasoning and even the phraseology of the order issued earlier by Goering which authorized the Final Solution as `` a complement to '' previous `` solutions '' for eliminating the Jews from German living space through violence , economic strangulation , forced emigration , and evacuation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In other words , the promulgators of the murder plan made clear that physically exterminating the Jews was but an extension of the anti-Semitic measures already operating in every phase of German life , and that the new conspiracy counted on the general anti-Semitism that had made those measures effective , as a readiness for murder .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This , in fact , it turned out to be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the magnitude of the plan made secrecy impossible , once the wheels had began to turn , persons controlling German industries , social institutions , and armed forces became , through their anti-Semitism or their tolerance of it , conscious accomplices of Hitler 's crimes ; whether in the last degree or a lesser one was a matter to be determined individually .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What more could be asked for a Trial intended to warn the world against anti-Semitism than this opportunity to expose the exact link between the respectable anti-Semite and the concentration-camp brute ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not in Eichmann 's anti-Semitism but in the anti-Semitism of the sober German man of affairs lay the potential warning of the Trial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No doubt many of the citizens of the Third Reich had conceived their anti-Semitism as an `` innocent '' dislike of Jews , as do others like them today .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Final Solution proved that the Jew-baiter of any variety exposes himself as being implicated in the criminality and madness of others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Ought not an edifying Trial have made every effort to demonstrate this once and for all by showing how representative types of `` mere '' anti-Semites were drawn step by step into the program of skull bashings and gassings ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Prosecutor in his opening remarks did refer to `` the germ of anti-Semitism '' among the Germans which Hitler `` stimulated and transformed '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But if there was evidence at the Trial that aimed over Eichmann 's head at his collaborators in the societies where he functioned , the press seems to have missed it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nor did the Trial devote much attention to exposing the usefulness of anti-Semitism to the Nazis , both in building their own power and in destroying that of rival organizations and states .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Certainly , one of the best ways of warning the world against anti-Semitism is to demonstrate its workings as a dangerous weapon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Eichmann himself is a model of how the myth of the enemy Jew can be used to transform the ordinary man of present-day society into a menace to all his neighbors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Do patriots everywhere know enough about how the persecution of the Jews in Germany and later in the occupied countries contributed to terrorizing the populations , splitting apart individuals and groups , arousing the meanest and most dishonest impulses , pulverizing trust and personal dignity , and finally forcing people to follow their masters into the abyss by making them partners in unspeakable crimes ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The career of Eichmann made the Trial a potential showcase for anti-Semitic demoralization :
fearful of being mistaken for a Jew , he seeks protection in his Nazi uniform ; clinging to the enemy Jew idea , he is forced to overcome habits of politeness and neighborliness ; once in power he begins to give vent to a criminal opportunism that causes him to alternate between megalomania and envy of those above him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` Is this the type of citizen you desire '' ?</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">the Trial should have asked the nations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But though this characterization in no way diminished Eichmann 's guilt , the Prosecutor , more deeply involved in the tactics of a criminal case than a political one , would have none of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Finally , if the mission of the Trial was to convict anti-Semitism , how could it have failed to post before the world the contrasting fates of the countries in which the Final Solution was aided by native Jew haters - i.e. , Germany , Poland , Hungary , Czechoslovakia - and those in which it met the obstacle of human solidarity - Denmark , Holland , Italy , Bulgaria , France ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Should not everyone have been awakened to it as an outstanding fact of our time that the nations poisoned by anti-Semitism proved less fortunate in regard to their own freedom than those whose citizens saved their Jewish compatriots from the transports ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Was n't this meaning of Eichmann 's experience in various countries worth highlighting ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As the first collective confrontation of the Nazi outrage , the Trial of Eichmann represents a recovery of the Jews from the shock of the death camps , a recovery that took fifteen years and which is still by no means complete ( though let no one believe that it could be hastened by silence ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Only across a distance of time could the epic accounting begin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is already difficult to recall how little we knew before the Trial of what had been done to the Jews of Europe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not that the facts of the persecution were unavailable ; most of the information elicited in Jerusalem had been brought to the surface by the numerous War Crimes tribunals and investigating commissions , and by reports , memoirs , and survivors ' accounts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In Poughkeepsie , N. Y. , in 1952 , a Roman Catholic hospital presented seven Protestant physicians with an ultimatum to quit the Planned Parenthood Federation or to resign from the hospital staff .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Three agreed , but four declined and were suspended .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After a flood of protests , they were reinstated at the beginning of 1953 .</MPQASENT>
