<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The peace of the community was badly disturbed , and people across the nation , reading of the incident , felt uneasy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In New York City in 1958 , the city 's Commissioner of Hospitals refused to permit a physician to provide a Protestant mother with a contraceptive device .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He thereby precipitated a bitter controversy involving Protestants , Jews and Roman Catholics that continued for two months , until the city 's Board of Hospitals lifted the ban on birth-control therapy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A year later in Albany , N. Y. , a Roman Catholic hospital barred an orthopedic surgeon because of his connection with the Planned Parenthood Association .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Immediately , the religious groups of the city were embroiled in an angry dispute over the alleged invasion of a man 's right to freedom of religious belief and conscience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These incidents , typical of many others , dramatize the distressing fact that no controversy during the last several decades has caused more tension , rancor and strife among religious groups in this country than the birth-control issue .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It has flared up periodically on the front pages of newspapers in communities divided over birth prevention regulations in municipal hospitals and health and family welfare agencies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It has erupted on the national level in the matter of including birth-control information and material in foreign aid to underdeveloped countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Where it is not actually erupting , it rumbles and smolders in sullen resentment like a volcano , ready to explode at any moment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The time has come for citizens of all faiths to unite in an effort to remove this divisive and nettlesome issue from the political and social life of our nation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The first step toward the goal is the establishment of a new atmosphere of mutual good will and friendly communication on other than the polemical level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Instead of emotional recrimination , loaded phrases and sloganeering , we need a dispassionate study of the facts , a better understanding of the opposite viewpoint and a more serious effort to extend the areas of agreement until a solution is reached .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` All too frequently '' , points out James O' Gara , managing editor of Commonweal , `` Catholics run roughshod over Protestant sensibilities in this matter , by failure to consider the reasoning behind the Protestant position and , particularly , by their jibes at the fact that Protestant opinion on birth control has changed in recent decades '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">All too often our language is unduly harsh .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The second step is to recognize the substantial agreement - frequently blurred by emotionalism and inaccurate newspaper reporting - already existing between Catholics and non-Catholics concerning the over-all objectives of family planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Instead of Catholics ' being obliged or even encouraged to beget the greatest possible number of offspring , as many non-Catholics imagine , the ideal of responsible parenthood is stressed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Family planning is encouraged , so that parents will be able to provide properly for their offspring .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Pope Pius 12 , declared in 1951 that it is possible to be exempt from the normal obligation of parenthood for a long time and even for the whole duration of married life , if there are serious reasons , such as those often mentioned in the so-called medical , eugenic , economic and social `` indications '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This means that such factors as the health of the parents , particularly the mother , their ability to provide their children with the necessities of life , the degree of population density of a country and the shortage of housing facilities may legitimately be taken into consideration in determining the number of offspring .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These are substantially the same factors considered by non-Catholics in family planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The laws of many states permit birth control only for medical reasons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Roman Catholic Church , however , sanctions a much more liberal policy on family planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Catholics , Protestants and Jews are in agreement over the objectives of family planning , but disagree over the methods to be used .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Roman Catholic Church sanctions only abstention or the rhythm method , also known as the use of the infertile or safe period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Church considers this to be the method provided by nature and its divine Author : It involves no frustration of nature 's laws , but simply an intelligent and disciplined use of them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With the exception of the Roman Catholic and the Orthodox Catholic Churches , most churches make no moral distinction between rhythm and mechanical or chemical contraceptives , allowing the couple free choice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Here is a difference in theological belief where there seems little chance of agreement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The grounds for the Church 's position are Scriptural ( Old Testament ) , the teachings of the fathers and doctors of the early Church , the unbroken tradition of nineteen centuries , the decisions of the highest ecclesiastical authority and the natural law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The latter plays a prominent role in Roman Catholic theology and is considered decisive , entirely apart from Scripture , in determining the ethical character of birth-prevention methods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Roman Catholic natural-law tradition regards as self-evident that the primary objective purpose of the conjugal act is procreation and that the fostering of the mutual love of the spouses is the secondary and subjective end .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This conclusion is based on two propositions : that man by the use of his reason can ascertain God 's purpose in the universe and that God makes known His purpose by certain `` given '' physical arrangements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , man can readily deduce that the primary objective end of the conjugal act is procreation , the propagation of the race .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Moreover , man may not supplant or frustrate the physical arrangements established by God , who through the law of rhythm has provided a natural method for the control of conception .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Believing that God is the Author of this law and of all laws of nature , Roman Catholics believe that they are obliged to obey those laws , not frustrate or mock them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Let it be granted then that the theological differences in this area between Protestants and Roman Catholics appear to be irreconcilable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But people differ in their religious beliefs on scores of doctrines , without taking up arms against those who disagree with them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Why is it so different in regard to birth control ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is because each side has sought to implement its distinctive theological belief through legislation and thus indirectly force its belief , or at least the practical consequences thereof , upon others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is always a temptation for a religious organization , especially a powerful or dominant one , to impose through the clenched fist of the law its creedal viewpoint upon others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Both Roman Catholics and Protestants have succumbed to this temptation in the past .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Consider what happened during World War 1 , , when the Protestant churches united to push the Prohibition law through Congress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Many of them sincerely believe that the use of liquor in any form or in any degree is intrinsically evil and sinful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With over four million American men away at war , Protestants forced their distinctive theological belief upon the general public .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With the return of our soldiers , it soon became apparent that the belief was not shared by the great majority of citizens .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The attempt to enforce that belief ushered in a reign of bootleggers , racketeers , hijackers and gangsters that led to a breakdown of law unparalleled in our history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The so-called `` noble experiment '' came to an inglorious end .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That tumultuous , painful and costly experience shows clearly that a law expressing a moral judgment cannot be enforced when it has little correspondence with the general view of society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">That experience holds a lesson for us all in regard to birth control today .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Up to the turn of the century , contraception was condemned by all Christian churches as immoral , unnatural and contrary to divine law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This was generally reflected in the civil laws of Christian countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Today , the Roman Catholic and Orthodox Churches stand virtually alone in holding that conviction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The various Lambeth Conferences , expressing the Anglican viewpoint , mirror the gradual change that has taken place among Protestants generally .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In 1920 , the Lambeth Conference repeated its 1908 condemnation of contraception and issued `` an emphatic warning against the use of unnatural means for the avoidance of conception , together with the grave dangers - physical , moral , and religious - thereby incurred , and against the evils which the extension of such use threaten the race '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Denouncing the view that the sexual union is an end in itself , the Conference declared : `` We steadfastly uphold what must always be regarded as the governing considerations of Christian marriage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One is the primary purpose for which marriage exists , namely , the continuance of the race through the gift and heritage of children ; the other is the paramount importance in married life of deliberate and thoughtful self-control '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Conference called for a vigorous campaign against the open or secret sale of contraceptives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In 1930 , the Lambeth Conference again affirmed the primary purpose of marriage to be the procreation of children , but conceded that , in certain limited circumstances , contraception might be morally legitimate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1958 , the Conference endorsed birth control as the responsibility laid by God on parents everywhere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Many other Protestant denominations preceded the Anglicans in such action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In March , 1931 , 22 out of 28 members of a committee of the Federal Council of Churches ratified artificial methods of birth control .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` As to the necessity '' , the committee declared , `` for some form of effective control of the size of the family and the spacing of children , and consequently of control of conception , there can be no question .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is general agreement also that sex union between husbands and wives as an expression of mutual affection without relation to procreation is right '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since then , many Protestant denominations have made separate pronouncements , in which they not only approved birth control , but declared it at times to be a religious duty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What determines the morality , they state , is not the means used , but the motive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In general , the means ( excluding abortion ) that prove most effective are considered the most ethical .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This development is reflected in the action taken in February , 1961 , by the general board of the National Council of Churches , the largest Protestant organization in the US .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The board approved and commended the use of birth-control devices as a part of Christian responsibility in family planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It called for opposition to laws and institutional practices restricting the information or availability of contraceptives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The general board declared : `` Most of the Protestant churches hold contraception and periodic continence to be morally right when the motives are right .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The general Protestant conviction is that motives , rather than methods , form the primary moral issue , provided the methods are limited to the prevention of conception '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An action once universally condemned by all Christian churches and forbidden by the civil law is now not only approved by the overwhelming majority of Protestant denominations , but also deemed , at certain times , to be a positive religious duty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This viewpoint has now been translated into action by the majority of people in this country .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Repeated polls have disclosed that most married couples are now using contraceptives in the practice of birth control .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">For all concerned with social-welfare legislation , the significance of this radical and revolutionary change in the thought and habits of the vast majority of the American people is clear , profound and far reaching .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To try to oppose the general religious and moral conviction of such a majority by a legislative fiat would be to invite the same breakdown of law and order that was occasioned by the ill-starred Prohibition experiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This brings us to the fact that the realities we are dealing with lie not in the field of civil legislation , but in the realm of conscience and religion : They are moral judgments and matters of theological belief .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Conscience and religion are concerned with private sin : The civil law is concerned with public crimes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only confusion , failure and anarchy result when the effort is made to impose upon the civil authority the impossible task of policing private homes to preclude the possibility of sin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Among the chief victims of such an ill conceived imposition would be religion itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On April 17 , 1610 , the sturdy little three masted bark , Discovery , weighed anchor in St. Katherine's Pool , London , and floated down the Thames toward the sea .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">She carried , besides her captain , a crew of twenty-one and provisions for a voyage of exploration of the Arctic waters of North America .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Seventeen months later , on September 6 , 1611 , an Irish fishing boat sighted the Discovery limping eastward outside Galway Bay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When she reached port , she was found to have on board only eight men , all near starvation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The captain was gone , and the mate was gone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The man who now commanded her had started the voyage as an ordinary seaman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">What disaster struck the Discovery during those seventeen months ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">What happened to the fourteen missing men ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These questions have remained one of the great sea mysteries of all time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For hundreds of years , the evidence available consisted of ( 1 ) the captain 's fragmentary journal , ( 2 ) a highly prejudiced account by one of the survivors , ( 3 ) a note found in a dead man 's desk on board , and ( 4 ) several second-hand reports .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All told , they offered a highly confused picture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But since 1927 , researchers digging into ancient court records and legal files have been able to find illuminating pieces of information .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not enough to do away with all doubts , but sufficient to give a fairly accurate picture of the events of the voyage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Historians have had two reasons for persisting so long in their investigations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">First , they wanted to clarify a tantalizing , bizarre enigma .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Second , they believed it important to determine the fate of the captain - a man whose name is permanently stamped on our maps , on American towns and counties , on a great American river , and on half a million square miles of Arctic seas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The name : Henry Hudson .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is the story of his last tragic voyage , as nearly as we are able - or ever , probably , will be able - to determine :
The sailing in the spring of 1610 was Hudson 's fourth in four years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each time his objective had been the same - a direct water passage from Western Europe to the Far East .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1607 and 1608 , the English Muscovy Company had sent him northward to look for a route over the North Pole or across the top of Russia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Twice he had failed , and the Muscovy Company indicated it would not back him again .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1609 , the Dutch East India Company hired Hudson , gave him two learned geographers , fitted him out with a ship called the Half Moon , and supplied him with Dutch sailors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This time he turned westward , to the middle Atlantic coast of North America .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His chief discovery was important - the Great North ( later , the Hudson ) River - but it produced no northwest passage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the Half Moon put in at Dartmouth , England , in the fall of 1609 , word of Hudson 's findings leaked out , and English interest in him revived .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The government forbade Hudson to return to Amsterdam with his ship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He thereupon went to London and spent the winter talking to men of wealth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">By springtime , he was supported by a rich merchant syndicate under the patronage of Henry , Prince of Wales .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He had obtained and provisioned a veteran ship called the Discovery and had recruited a crew of twenty-one , the largest he had ever commanded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The purpose of this fourth voyage was clear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A century of exploration had established that a great land mass , North and South America , lay between Europe and the Indies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One by one , the openings in the coast that promised a passage through had been explored and discarded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In fact , Hudson 's sail up the Great North River had disposed of one of the last hopes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But there remained one mysterious , unexplored gap , far to the north .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Nearly twenty-five years before , Captain John Davis had noted , as he sailed near the Arctic Circle , `` a very great gulf , the water whirling and roaring , as it were the meeting of tides '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He named this opening , between Baffin Island and Labrador , the `` Furious Overfall '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( Later , it was to be called Hudson Strait . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1602 , George Waymouth , in the same little Discovery that Hudson now commanded , had sailed 300 miles up the strait before his frightened men turned the ship back .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hudson now proposed to sail all the way through and test the seas beyond for the long sought waterway .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even Hudson , experienced in Arctic sailing and determined as he was , must have had qualms as he slid down the Thames .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Ahead were perilous , ice filled waters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On previous voyages , it had been in precisely such dangerous situations that he had failed as a leader and captain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the second voyage , he had turned back at the frozen island of Novaya Zemlya and meekly given the crew a certificate stating that he did so of his own free will - which was obviously not the case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the third voyage , a near mutiny rising from a quarrel between Dutch and English crew members on the Half Moon had almost forced him to head the ship back to Amsterdam in mid Atlantic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Worse , his present crew included five men who had sailed with him before .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of only one could he be sure - young John Hudson , his second son .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The mate , Robert Juet , who had kept the journal on the half Moon , was experienced - but he was a bitter old man , ready to complain or desert at any opportunity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Philip Staffe , the ship 's carpenter , was a good worker , but perversely independent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Arnold Lodley and Michael Perse were like the rest - lukewarm , ready to swing against Hudson in a crisis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But men willing to sail at all into waters where wooden ships could be crushed like eggs were hard to find .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hudson knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And he refused to be anything else .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is believed that Hudson was related to other seafaring men of the Muscovy Company and was trained on company ships .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was a Londoner , married , with three sons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( The common misconception that he was Dutch and that his first name was Hendrik stem from Dutch documents of his third voyage . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In 1610 , Hudson was probably in his early forties , a good navigator , a stubborn voyager , but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hudson 's first error of the fourth voyage occurred only a few miles down the Thames .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There at the river 's edge waited one Henry Greene , whom Hudson listed as a `` clerk '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Greene was in actuality a young ruffian from Kent , who had broken with his parents in order to keep the company he preferred - pimps , panders and whores .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was not the sort of sailor Hudson wanted his backers to see on board and he had Greene wait at Gravesend , where the Discovery picked him up .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the first three weeks , the ship skirted up the east coast of Great Britain , then turned westward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On May 11 , she reached Iceland .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Poor winds and fog locked her up in a harbor the crew called `` Lousie Bay '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The subsequent two-weeks wait made the crew quarrelsome .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With Hudson looking on , his protege Greene picked a fight with the ship 's surgeon , Edward Wilson .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The issue was settled on shore , Greene winning and Wilson remaining ashore , determined to catch the next fishing boat back to England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With difficulty , Hudson persuaded him to rejoin the ship , and they sailed from Iceland .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Early in June , the Discovery passed `` Desolation '' ( southern Greenland ) and in mid-June entered the `` Furious Overfall '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Floating ice bore down from the north and west .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Fog hung over the route constantly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The ship 's compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic North Pole .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As the bergs grew larger , Hudson was forced to turn south into what is now Ungava Bay , an inlet of the great strait .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After finding that its coasts led nowhere , however , he turned north again , toward the main , ice filled passageway - and the crew , at first uneasy , then frightened , rebelled .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The trouble was at least partly Juet 's doing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For weeks he had been saying that Hudson 's idea of sailing through to Java was absurd .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The great , crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice of pure reason .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A group of sailors announced to Hudson that they would sail no farther .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Instead of quelling the dissension , as many captains of the era would have done ( Sir Francis Drake lopped a man 's head off under similar circumstances ) , Hudson decided to be reasonable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart , which he set up in view of the crew .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Patiently , he explained what he knew about their course and their objectives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When Hudson had finished , the `` town meeting '' broke down into a general , wordy argument .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds , he would give ninety of them to be back in England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Up spoke carpenter Staffe , who said he would n't give ten pounds to be home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The statement was effective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The meeting broke up .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hudson was free to sail on .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All through July the Discovery picked her way along the 450 - mile long strait , avoiding ice and rocky islands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On August 3 , two massive headlands reared out of the mists - great gateways never before , so far as Hudson knew , seen by Europeans .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To starboard was a cape a thousand feet high , patched with ice and snow , populated by thousands of screaming sea birds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To port was a point 200 feet high rising behind to a precipice of 2000 feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hudson named the capes Digges and Wolstenholme , for two of his backers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hudson pointed the Discovery down the east coast of the newly discovered sea ( now called Hudson Bay ) , confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the Pacific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After three weeks ' swift sailing , however , the ship entered an area of shallow marshes and river deltas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The ship halted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The great `` sea to the westwards '' was a dead end .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This must have been Hudson 's blackest discovery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For he seemed to sense at once that before him was no South Sea , but the solid bulk of the North American continent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This was the bitter end , and Hudson seemed to know he was destined to failure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Feverishly , he tried to brush away this intuition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">North and south , east and west , back and forth he sailed in the land-locked bay , plowing furiously forward until land appeared , then turning to repeat the process , day after day , week after week .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hundreds of miles to the north , the route back to England through the `` Furious Overfall '' was again filling with ice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The men were at first puzzled , then angered by the aimless tacking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Once more , Juet 's complaints were the loudest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hudson 's reply was to accuse the mate of disloyalty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Juet demanded that Hudson prove his charges in an open trial .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The trial was held September 10 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hudson , presiding , heard Juet 's defense , then called for testimony from crew members .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Juet had made plentiful enemies , several men stepped forward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hands on Bible , seaman Lodley and carpenter Staffe swore that Juet had tried to persuade them to keep muskets and swords in their cabins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Cook Bennett Mathues said Juet had predicted bloodshed on the ship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Others added that Juet had wanted to turn the ship homeward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hudson deposed Juet and cut his pay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The new mate was Robert Bylot , talented but inexperienced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There were other shifts and pay cuts according to the way individuals had conducted themselves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The important result , however , was that Juet and Francis Clemens , the deposed boatswain , became Hudson 's sworn enemies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As Hudson resumed his desperate criss-crossing of the little bay , every incident lessened the crew 's respect for him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Once , after the Discovery lay for a week in rough weather , Hudson ordered the anchor raised before the sea had calmed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Just as it was being hauled inboard , a sea hit the ship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Michael Butt and Adame Moore were thrown off the capstan and badly injured .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The anchor cable would have been lost overboard , but Philip Staffe was on hand to sever it with his axe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thomas Douglas , fifth Earl of Selkirk , a noble humanitarian Scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native Highlands , conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the Red River of the North .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the land he desired lay within the great northern empire of the Hudson's Bay Company , he purchased great blocks of the Company's stock with the view to controlling its policies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Having achieved this end , he was able to buy 116000 square miles in the valleys of the Red and Assiniboine rivers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The grant , which stretched southward to Lake Traverse - the headwaters of the Red - was made in May , 1811 , and by October of that year a small group of Scots was settling for the winter at York Factory on Hudson Bay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus at the same time that William Henry Harrison was preparing to pacify the aborigines of Indiana Territory and winning fame at the battle of Tippecanoe , Anglo-Saxon settlement made a great leap into the center of the North American continent to the west of the American agricultural frontier .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Seven hundred miles south of York Factory , at `` the Forks '' of the Red and the Assiniboine , twenty-three men located a settlement in August 1812 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By October the little colony about Fort Douglas ( present-day Winnipeg ) numbered 100 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Within a few years the Scots , engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring the rich soil of the valley , were joined by a group called Meurons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The latter , members of two regiments of Swiss mercenaries transported by Great Britain to Canada to fight the Americans in the War of 1812 , had settled in Montreal and Kingston at the close of the war in 1815 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go to Red River where they were to serve as a military force to protect his settlers from the hostile Northwest Company which resented the intrusion of farmers into the fur traders ' empire .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The mercenaries were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as 1818 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was the low yield of the Selkirk plots and the ravages of grasshoppers in 1818 that led to the dispersal of the settlement southward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When late in the summer the full extent of the damage was assessed , all but fifty of the Scots , Swiss and metis moved up the Red to the mouth of the Pembina river .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Here they built huts and a stockade named Fort Daer after Selkirk's barony in Scotland .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The new site was somewhat warmer than Fort Douglas and much closer to the great herds of buffalo on which the settlement must depend for food .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move southward by British fur traders .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For many years the Northwest Company had its southern headquarters at Prairie du Chien on the Mississippi River , some 300 miles southeast of present-day St. Paul , Minnesota .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When in 1816 an act of Congress forced the foreign firm out of the United States , its British born employees , now become American citizens - Joseph Rolette , Joseph Renville and Alexis Bailly - continued in the fur business .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On Big Stone Lake near the headwaters of the Red River , Robert Dickson , Superintendent of the Western Indian Department of Canada , had a trading post and planned in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small artillery pieces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His trading goods came from Canada to the Forks of Red River and from Selkirk's settlement he brought them south in carts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These carts were of a type devised in Pembina in the days of Alexander Henry the Younger about a decade before the Selkirk colony was begun .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1802 Henry referred to `` our new carts '' as being about four feet off the ground and carrying five times as much as a horse could pack .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were held together by pegs and withes and in later times drawn by a single ox in thills .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was Dickson who suggested to Lord Selkirk that he return to the Atlantic coast by way of the United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In September 1817 at Fort Daer ( Pembina ) Dickson met the noble lord whom , with the help of a band of Sioux , he escorted to Prairie du Chien .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the trip Selkirk decided that the route through Illinois territory to Indiana and the eastern United States was the best route for goods from England to reach Red River and that the United States was a better source of supply for many goods than either Canada or England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Upon arriving at Baltimore , Selkirk on December 22 wrote to John Quincy Adams , Secretary of State at Washington , inquiring about laws covering trade with `` Missouri and Illinois Territories '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This traffic , he declared prophetically , `` tho ' it might be of small account at first , would increase with the progress of our Settlements '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The route which he had traveled and which he believed might develop into a trade route was followed by his settlers earlier than he might have expected .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1819 grasshoppers again destroyed the crop at `` the Forks '' ( Fort Douglas ) and in December 1819 , twenty men left Fort Daer for the most northerly American outpost at Prairie du Chien .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was a three month journey in the dead of winter followed by three months of labor on Mackinac boats .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With these completed and ice gone from the St. Peter's River ( present-day Minnesota river ) their 250 bushels of wheat , 100 bushels of oats and barley and 30 bushels of peas and some chickens were loaded onto the flat-bottomed boats and rowed up the river to Big Stone Lake , across into Lake Traverse , and down the Red .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They reached Fort Douglas in June 1820 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost Selkirk 1040 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were forced to retreat to Fort Daer for food .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thereafter seed and food became more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Activity by British traders and the presence of a colony on the Red prompted the United State War Department in 1819 to send Lieutenant-Colonel Henry Leavenworth from Detroit to put a post 300 miles northwest of Prairie du Chien , until then the most advanced United States post .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In September 1822 two companies of infantry arrived at the mouth of the St. Peter's River , the head of navigation on the Mississippi , and began construction of Fort St. Anthony which , upon completion , was renamed in honor of its commander , Colonel Josiah Snelling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was from the American outposts that Red River shortages of livestock were to be made good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hercules L. Dousman , fur trader and merchant at Prairie du Chien , contracted to supply Selkirk 's people with some 300 head of cattle , and Alexis Bailly and Francois Labothe were hired as drovers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Bailly , after leaving Fort Snelling in August 1821 , was forced to leave some of the cattle at the Hudson's Bay Company's post on Lake Traverse `` in the Sieux Country '' and reached Fort Garry , as the Selkirk Hudson's Bay Company center was now called , late in the fall .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He set out on his 700 - mile return journey with five families of discontented and disappointed Swiss who turned their eyes toward the United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Observing their distressing condition , Colonel Snelling allowed these half starved immigrants to settle on the military reservation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As these Swiss were moving from the Selkirk settlement to become the first civilian residents of Minnesota , Dousman of Michilimackinac , Michigan , and Prairie du Chien was traveling to Red River to open a trade in merchandise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Early in 1822 he was at Fort Garry offering to bring in pork , flour , liquor and tobacco .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Alexander McDonnell , governor of Red River , and James Bird , a chief factor of the Hudson's Bay Company , ordered such `` sundry articles '' to a value of 4500 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For its part the Hudson's Bay Company was troubled by the approach of American settlement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As the time drew near for the drawing of the British American frontier by terms of the agreement of 1818 , the company suspected that the Pembina colony - its own post and Fort Daer - was on American territory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Accordingly Selkirk 's agents ordered the settlers to move north , and by October , John Halkett had torn down both posts , floating the timber to `` the Forks '' in rafts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` I have done everything '' , he wrote , `` to break up the whole of that unfortunate establishment '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Despite Company threats , duly carried through , to cut off supplies of powder , ball , and thread for fishing nets , about 350 persons stayed in the village .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They would attempt to bring supplies from St. Louis or Prairie du Chien at `` great expense as well as danger '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At Fort Garry some of the Swiss also decided to cast their lot with the United States , and in 1823 several families paid guides to take them to Fort Snelling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The disasters of 1825 - 1826 caused more to leave .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After heavy rains and an onslaught of mice , snow fell on October 15 , 1825 , and remained on the ground through a winter so cold that the ice on the Red was five feet thick .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In April came a rapid thaw that produced high waters which did not recede until mid-June .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On June 24 more than 400 families started the three month trip across the plains to the Mississippi .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">By fall , 443 survivors of this arduous journey were clustered about Fort Snelling , but most of them were sent on to Galena and St. Louis , with a few going as far as Vevay , Indiana , a notable Swiss center in the United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1837 , 157 Red River people with more than 200 cattle were living on the reservation at Fort Snelling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Below the fort , high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the Mississippi River .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the point where they ended , another settlement grew up around a chapel built at the boat landing by Father Lucian Galtier in 1840 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its people , including Pierre Bottineau and other American Fur Company employees and the refugees from Fort Garry , were joined by the remaining Scots and Swiss from Fort Snelling when Major Joseph Plympton expelled them from the reservation in May 1840 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The resultant town , platted in 1847 and named for the patron of Father Galtier 's mission , St. Paul , was to become an important center of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those Selkirkers who remained at Red River .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While population at Fort Garry increased rapidly , from 2417 in 1831 to 4369 in 1840 , economic opportunities did not increase at a similar rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Accordingly , though the practice violated the no trading provision of the Selkirk charter which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the Hudson's Bay Company , some settlers went into trade .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Company maintained a store at which products of England could be purchased and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they refrain from trading in furs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Despite this prohibiton , by 1844 some of the Fort Garry merchants were trading with the Indians for furs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In June 1845 , the Governor and Council of Assiniboia imposed a 20 per cent duty on imports via Hudson's Bay which were viewed as aimed at the `` very vitals of the Company 's trade and power '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To reduce further the flow of goods from England , the Company 's local officials asked that its London authorities refrain from forwarding any more trade goods to these men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With their customary source of supply cut off , the Fort Garry free traders engaged three men to cart goods to them from the Mississippi country .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Others carried pemmican from `` the Forks '' to St. Paul and goods from St. Paul to Red River , as in the summer of 1847 when one trader , Wells , transported twenty barrels of whisky to the British settlement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This trade was subject to a tariff of 7.5 per cent after February 1835 , but much was smuggled into Assiniboia with the result that the duty was reduced by 1841 to 4 per cent on the initiative of the London committee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The trade in a few commodities noted above was to grow in volume as a result of changes both north and south of the 49 th parallel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Indeed , no richer humor is to be found in the whole of American literature than in the letters of the semi-literate men who wore the blue and the gray .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Some of their figures of speech were colorful and expressive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Confederate observed that the Yankees were : `` thicker than lise on a hen and a dam site ornraier '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Another reported that his comrades were `` in fine spirits pitching around like a blind dog in a meat house '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A third wrote that it was `` raining like poring peas on a rawhide '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Yanks were equally adept at figurative expression .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One wrote : `` [ I am so hungry ] I could eat a rider off his horse + snap at the stirups '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A second reported that the dilapidated houses in Virginia `` look like the latter end of original sin and hard times '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A third remarked of slowness of Southerners : `` They moved about from corner to corner , as uneasy as a litter of hungry leaches on the neck of a wooden god '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Still another , annoyed by the brevity of a recently received missive , wrote : `` Yore letter was short and sweet , jist like a roasted maget '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A Yankee sergeant gave the following description of his sweetheart : `` My girl is none of your one-horse girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">She is a regular stub and twister , double geered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She is well-educated and refined , all wildcat and fur , and Union from the muzzle to the crupper '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Humor found many modes of expression .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Texan wrote to a male companion at home : `` What has become of Halda and Laura ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When you see them again give them my love - not best respects now , but love by God '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">William R. Stillwell , an admirable Georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved in the Georgia Department of Archives and History , liked to tease his wife in his letters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After he had been away from home about a year he wrote : `` [ Dear Wife ] If I did not write and receive letters from you I believe that I would forgit that I was married I do n't feel much like a maryed man but I never forgit it sofar as to court enny other lady but if I should you must forgive me as I am so forgitful '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A Yank , disturbed by his increasing corpulence , wrote : `` I am growing so fat I am a burden 2 myself '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Another Yank parodied the familiar bedtime prayer :
`` Now I lay me down to sleep , The gray-backs o ' er my body creep ; If they should bite before I wake , I pray the Lord their jaws to break '' `` .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Charles Thiot , a splendid Georgia soldier , differed from most of his comrades in the ranks in that he was the owner of a large plantation , well-educated , and nearly fifty years of age .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But he was very much like his associates in his hatred of camp routine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Near the end of his service he wrote that when the war was over he was going to buy two pups , name one of them `` fall-in '' and the other `` close-up '' , and then shoot them both , `` and that will be the end of ' fall-in ' and ' close-up '' ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The soldiers who comprised the rank and file of the Civil War armies were an earthy people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They talked and wrote much about the elemental functions of the body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most common of camp maladies was diarrhoea .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Men of more delicate sensibilities referred to this condition as `` looseness of the bowels '' ; but a much more common designation was `` the sh-ts '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Michigan soldier stationed in Georgia wrote in 1864 : `` I expect to be tough as a knott as soon as I get over the Georgia Shitts '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Johnny Rebs from the deep South who were plagued with diarrhoea after transfer to the Virginia front often informed their families that they were suffering from the `` the Virginia quickstep '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A Georgia soldier gave his wife the following description of the cause and consequence of diarrhoea : `` I have bin a little sick with diorah two or three days .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I eat too much eggs and poark it sowered [ on ] my stomack and turn loose on me '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Michigan soldier wrote his brother : `` I am well at present with the exception I have got the Dyerear and I hope thease few lines find you the same '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The letters which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Save for brief periods in garrison or winter quarters , soldiers rarely enjoyed the luxury of a writing desk or table .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most of the letters were written in the hubbub of camp , on stumps , pieces of bark , drum heads , or the knee .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the South , after the first year of the war , paper and ink were very poor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Scarcity of paper caused many Southerners to adopt the practice of cross writing , i. e. , after writing from left to right of the page in the usual manner , they gave the sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously written .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes soldiers wrote letters while bullets were whizzing about their heads .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A Yank writing from Vicksburg , May 28 , 1863 , stated `` Not less than 50 balls have passed over me since I commenced writing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I could tell you of plenty narrow escapes , but we take no notice of them now '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A Reb stationed near Petersburg informed his mother : `` I need not tell you that I dodge pretty often , for you can see that very plainly by the blots in this letter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Just count each blot a dodge and add in a few for I do n't dodge every time '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Another Reb writing under similar circumstances before Atlanta reported : `` The Yankees keep Shooting so I am afraid they will knock over my ink , so I will close '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The most common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But fathers often addressed communications to their small children ; and these , full of homely advice , are among the most human and revealing of Civil War letters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the Negro community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Occasionally they would write to the slaves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Early in the war it was not uncommon for planters ' sons to retain in camp Negro `` body servants '' to perform the menial chores such as cooking , foraging , cleaning the quarters , shining shoes , and laundering clothes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters of their soldier masters messages to their relatives and to members of their owners ' families .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Unmarried soldiers carried on correspondence with sweethearts at home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Owing to the restrained usages characteristic of 19 th century America , these letters usually were stereotyped and revealed little depth of feeling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Occasionally gay young blades would write vividly to boon companions at home about their amorous exploits in Richmond , Petersburg , Washington , or Nashville .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But these comments are hardly printable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An Alabama soldier whose feminine associations were of the more admirable type wrote boastfully of his achievements among the Virginia belles : `` They thout I was a saint .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I told them some sweet lies and they believed it all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I would tell them I got a letter from home stating that five of my Negroes had run away and ten of Pappies But I wold say I recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some of the letters were pungently expressive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">An Ohio soldier who , from a comrade just returned from leave , received an unfavorable comment on the conduct of his sister , took pen in hand and delivered himself thus : `` [ Dear Sis ] Alf sed he heard that you and hardy was a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I think you made a dam good chouise to turn off as nise a feler as Alf dyer and let that orney thefin , drunkard , damed card playing Sun of a bich com to Sea you , the god damed theaf and lop yeard pigen tode helion , he is too orney for hel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">i will Shute him as shore as i Sea him '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Initiation into combat sometimes elicited from soldier correspondents choice comments about their experiences and reactions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A Federal infantryman wrote to his father shortly after his first skirmish in Virginia : `` Dear Pa .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Went out a Skouting yesterday .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We got to one house where there were five secessionist they brok + run and Arch holored out to shoot the ornery suns of biches and we all let go at them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thay may say what they please but godamit Pa it is fun '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some of the choicest remarks made by soldiers in their letters were in disparagement of unpopular officers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A Mississippi soldier wrote : `` Our General Reub Davis is a vain , stuck-up , illiterate ass '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">An Alabamian wrote : `` Col. Henry is [ an ignoramus ] fit for nothing higher than the cultivation of corn '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A Floridian stated that his officers were `` not fit to tote guts to a bear '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On December 9 , 1862 , Sergeant Edwin H. Fay , an unusual Louisianan who held A. B. and M. A. degrees from Harvard University and who before the war was headmaster of a private school for boys in Louisiana , wrote his wife :
`` I saw Pemberton and he is the most insignificant puke I ever saw .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His head cannot contain enough sense to command a regiment , much less a corps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Jackson runs first and his Cavalry are well drilled to follow their leader .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He is not worth shucks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But he is a West Point graduate and therefore must be born to command '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Similar comments about officers are to be found in the letters of Northern soldiers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A Massachusetts soldier , who seems to have been a Civil War version of Bill Mauldin , wrote : `` The officers consider themselves as made of a different material from the low fellows in the ranks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They get all the glory and most of the pay and do n't earn ten cents apiece on the average , the drunken rascals '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Private George Gray Hunter of Pennsylvania wrote : `` I am well convinced in My own Mind that had it not been for officers this war would have ended long ago '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another Yankee became so disgusted as to state : `` I wish to God one half of our officers were knocked in the head by slinging them against [ the other half ] '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">No group of officers came in for more spirited denunciation than the doctors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One Federal soldier wrote : `` The docters is no a conte .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">hell will be filde with do [ c ] ters and offersey when this war is over '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Shortly after the beginning of Sherman 's Georgia campaign , an ailing Yank wrote his homefolk : `` The surgeon insisted on Sending me to the hospital for treatment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I insisted on takeing the field and prevailed - thinking that I had better die by rebel bullets than [ by ] Union quackery '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The attitudes which the Rebs and Yanks took toward each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut of feeling , from friendliness to extreme hatred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Rebs were , to a Massachusetts corporal , `` fighting madmen or not men at all but whiskey + gunpowder put into a human frame '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A Pennsylvania soldier wrote that `` they were the hardest looking set of men that Ever i saw they Looked as if they had been fed on vinegar and shavings '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Private Jenkins Lloyd Jones of the Wisconsin Light Artillery wrote in his diary : `` I strolled among the Alabamans on the right , found some of the greenest specimens of humanity I think in the universe their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise with as imperfect a dialect ' They Recooned as how you ' uns all would be a heap wus to we ' uns all '' ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a similar vein , but writing from the opposite side , Thomas Taylor , a private in the 6 th Alabama Volunteers , in a letter to his wife , stated : `` You know that my heart is with you but I never could have been satisfied to have staid at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe By a set of cowardly Skunks whose Motto is Booty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As part of the same arrangement , Torrio had , in the spirit of peace and good will , and in exchange for armed support in the April election campaign , bestowed upon O ' Banion a third share in the Hawthorne Smoke Shop proceeds and a cut in the Cicero beer trade .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The coalition was to prove inadvisable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">O ' Banion was a complex and frightening man , whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour into others ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He had a round , frank Irish face , creased in a jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets into someone 's body .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He carried three guns - one in the right trouser pocket , one under his left armpit , one in the left outside coat pocket - and was equally lethal with both hands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He killed accurately , freely , and dispassionately .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The police credited him with twenty-five murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He was an expert florist , tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He had no apparent comprehension of morality ; he divided humanity into `` right guys '' and `` wrong guys '' , and the wrong ones he was always willing to kill and trample under .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He had what was described by a psychologist as a `` sunny brutality '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He walked with a heavy list to the right , as that leg was four inches shorter than the other , but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Landesco thought him `` just a superior sort of plugugly '' but he was , in fact , with his aggression and hostility , and nerveless indifference to risking or administering pain , a casebook psychopath .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was also at this time , although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets as Torrio and Capone , the most powerful and most dangerous mob leader in the Chicago underworld , the roughneck king .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">O ' Banion was born in poverty , the son of an immigrant Irish plasterer , in the North Side 's Little Hell , close by the Sicilian quarter and Death Corner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He had been a choir boy at the Holy Name Cathedral and also served as an acolyte to Father O ' Brien .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The influence of Mass was less pervasive than that of the congested , slum tenements among the bawdy houses , honkytonks , and sawdust saloons of his birthplace ; he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood , and went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving , police dodging , and housebreaking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At the age of ten , when he was working as a newsboy in the Loop , he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted in his permanently shortened leg .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Because of this he was known as Gimpy ( but , as with Capone and his nickname of Scarface , never in his presence ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In his teens O ' Banion was enrolled in the vicious Market Street gang and he became a singing waiter in McGovern's Cafe , a notoriously low and rowdy dive in North Clark Street , where befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing waiters before being thrown out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He then got a job with the Chicago Herald-Examiner as a circulation slugger , a rough fighter employed to see that his paper 's news pitches were not trespassed upon by rival vendors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was also at the same time gaining practical experience as a safe breaker and highwayman , and learning how to shoot to kill from a Neanderthal convicted murderer named Gene Geary , later committed to Chester Asylum as a homicidal maniac , but whose eyes misted with tears when the young Dion sang a ballad about an Irish mother in his clear and syrupy tenor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">O ' Banion 's first conflict with the police came in 1909 , at seventeen , when he was committed to Bridewell Prison for three months for burglary ; two years later he served another three months for assault .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Those were his only interludes behind bars , although he collected four more charges on his police record in 1921 and 1922 , three for burglary and one for robbery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But by now O ' Banion 's political pull was beginning to be effective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $ 10000 bond was furnished by an alderman , and the charge was nolle prossed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On one of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a Detective Sergeant John J. Ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour office safe in the Postal Telegraph Building ; the jury wanted better evidence than that and he was acquitted , at a cost of $ 30000 in bribes , it was estimated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As promptly as Torrio , O ' Banion jumped into bootlegging .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous violence than the Sicilians , but he had his huge North Side portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Unlike the Sicilians , he additionally conducted holdups , robberies , and safe cracking expeditions , and refused to touch prostitution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was also personally active in ward politics , and by 1924 O ' Banion had acquired sufficient political might to be able to state : `` I always deliver my borough as per requirements '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But whose requirements ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Until 1924 O ' Banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had kept his North Side domain solidly Democratic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There was a question and answer gag that went around at that time : Q. `` Who 'll carry the Forty-second and Forty-third wards '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A. `` O ' Banion , in his pistol pocket '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But as November 1924 drew close the Democratic hierarchy was sorely troubled by grapevine reports that O ' Banion was being wooed by the opposition , and was meeting and conferring with important Republicans .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To forestall any change of allegiance , the Democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for O ' Banion , as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where his loyalties lay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The reception was held in a private dining room of the Webster Hotel on Lincoln Park West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was an interesting fraternisation of ex convicts , union racketeers , ward heelers , sold-out officials , and gunmen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The guest list is in itself a little parable of the state of American civic life at this time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It included the top O ' Banion men and Chief of Detectives Michael Hughes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When Mayor Dever heard of the banquet he summoned Hughes for an explanation of why he had been dishonouring the police department by consorting with these felons and fixers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hughes said that he had understood the party was to be in honour of Jerry O ' Connor , the proprieter of a Loop gambling house .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` But when I arrived and recognised a number of notorious characters I had thrown into the detective bureau basement half a dozen times , I knew I had been framed , and withdrew almost at once '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In fact , O ' Connor was honoured during the ceremony with the presentation of a $ 2500 diamond stickpin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There was a brief interruption while one of O ' Banion 's men jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering him for a tip .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Then O ' Banion was presented with a platinum watch set with rubies and diamonds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This dinner was the start of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians , which , prior to 1924 , says Pasley , `` had been maintained with more or less stealth '' , but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious gatherings , denounced by a clergyman as `` Belshazzar feasts '' , at which `` politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters , openly , in the big downtown hotels '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Pasley continued : `` They became an institution of the Chicago scene and marked the way to the moral and financial collapse of the municipal and county governments in 1928 - 29 '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , this inaugural feast did its sponsors no good whatever .</MPQASENT>
