<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">O ' Banion accepted his platinum watch and the tributes to his loyalty , and proceeded with the bigger and better Republican deal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On Election Day - November 4 - he energetically marshalled his force of bludgeon men , bribers , and experts in forging repeat votes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The result was a landslide for the Republican candidates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This further demonstration of O ' Banion 's ballooning power did not please Torrio and Capone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the past year there had been too many examples of his euphoric self-confidence and self aggrandisement for their liking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He behaved publicly with a cocky , swaggering truculence that offended their vulpine Latin minds , and behaved towards them personally with an unimpressed insolence that enraged them beneath their blandness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They were disturbed by his idiotic bravado - as , when his bodyguard , Yankee Schwartz , complained that he had been snubbed by Dave Miller , a prize-fight referee , chieftain of a Jewish gang and one of four brothers of tough reputation , who were Hirschey , a gambler politician in loose beer running league with Torrio and O ' Banion , Frank , a policeman , and Max , the youngest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To settle this slight , O ' Banion went down to the La Salle Theatre in the Loop , where , he had learned , Dave Miller was attending the opening of a musical comedy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At the end of the performance , Dave and Max came out into the brilliantly lit foyer among a surge of gowned and tuxedoed first nighters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">O ' Banion drew his guns and fired at Dave , severely wounding him in the stomach .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A second bullet ricocheted off Max 's belt buckle , leaving him unhurt but in some distress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">O ' Banion tucked away his gun and walked out of the theatre ; he was neither prosecuted nor even arrested .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">That sort of braggadocio , for that sort of reason , in the view of Torrio and Capone , was a nonsense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A further example of the incompatible difference in personalities was when two policemen held up a Torrio beer convoy on a West Side street and demanded $ 300 to let it through .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the beer runners telephoned O ' Banion - on a line tapped by the detective bureau - and reported the situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">O ' Banion 's reaction was :
`` Three hundred dollars !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To them bums ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Why , I can get them knocked off for half that much '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Upon which the detective bureau despatched rifle squads to prevent trouble if O ' Banion should send his gunmen out to deal with the hijacking policemen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But in the meantime the beer runner , unhappy with this solution , telephoned Torrio and returned to O ' Banion with the message : `` Say , Dionie , I just been talking to Johnny , and he said to let them cops have the three hundred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He says he do n't want no trouble '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But Torrio and Capone had graver cause to hate and distrust the Irishman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For three years , since the liquor territorial conference , Torrio had , with his elastic patience , and because he knew that retaliation could cause only violent warfare and disaster to business , tolerated O ' Banion 's impudent double-crossing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They had suffered , in sulky silence , the sight of his sharp practice in Cicero .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When , as a diplomatic gesture of amity and in payment for the loan of gunmen in the April election , Torrio had given O ' Banion a slice of Cicero , the profits from that district had been $ 20000 a month .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In six months O ' Banion had boosted the profits to $ 100000 a month - mainly by bringing pressure to bear on fifty Chicago speak-easy proprietors to shift out to the suburb .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These booze customers had until then been buying their supplies from the Sheldon , Saltis-McErlane , and Druggan-Lake gangs , and now they were competing for trade with the Torrio-Capone saloons ; once again O ' Banion 's brash recklessness had caused a proliferation of ill will .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The revenue from O ' Banion 's Cicero territory went up still higher , until the yield was more than the Torrio-Capone takings from the far bigger trade area of Chicago 's South and West Sides .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But he still showed no intention of sharing with the syndicate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At last , even the controlled Torrio was unable to hold still , and he tentatively suggested that O ' Banion should take a percentage in the Stickney brothels in return for one from his Cicero beer concession .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">O ' Banion 's reply was a raucous laugh and a flat refusal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still more jealous bitterness was engendered by the O ' Banion gang 's seizure from a West Side marshalling yard of a freight-car load of Canadian whisky worth $ 100000 and by one of the biggest coups of the Prohibition era - the Sibley warehouse robbery , which became famous for the cool brazenness of the operation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Here was stored $ 1000000 worth of bonded whisky .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These 1750 cases were carted off in a one night operation by the O ' Banion men , who left in their stead the same number of barrels filled with water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide , an earthquake or a volcanic eruption .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The most infamous of all was launched by the explosion of the island of Krakatoa in 1883 ; it raced across the Pacific at 300 miles an hour , devastated the coasts of Java and Sumatra with waves 100 to 130 feet high , and pounded the shore as far away as San Francisco .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The ancient Greeks recorded several catastrophic inundations by huge waves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Whether or not Plato 's tale of the lost continent of Atlantis is true , skeptics concede that the myth may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the Arabian Sea in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists in the Biblical story of the Flood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the most damaging tsunami on record followed the famous Lisbon earthquake of November 1 , 1755 ; its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away as the English coast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tsunami are rare , however , in the Atlantic Ocean ; they are far more common in the Pacific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Japan has had 15 destructive ones ( eight of them disastrous ) since 1596 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Hawaiian Islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In 1707 an earthquake in Japan generated waves so huge that they piled into the Inland Sea ; one wave swamped more than 1000 ships and boats in Osaka Bay .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A tsunami in the Hawaiian Islands in 1869 washed away an entire town ( Ponoluu ) , leaving only two forlorn trees standing where the community had been .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1896 a Japanese tsunami killed 27000 people and swept away 10000 homes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The dimensions of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">An ordinary sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to crest - no longer than 320 feet in the Atlantic or 1000 feet in the Pacific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes as much as 600 miles from crest to crest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">While a wind wave never travels at more than 60 miles per hour , the velocity of a tsunami in the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The greater the depth of the water , the greater is the speed of the wave ; Lagrange 's law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the deep waters of the Pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles per hour .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Their amplitude sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Usually it is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build up to their terrifying heights .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On the fateful day in 1896 when the great waves approached Japan , fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Not until they sailed home at the end of the day , through a sea strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses , were they aware of what had happened .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers , drowning thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height , but when they pour into a V shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell , not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore as the first great trough arrives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Reefs are left high and dry , and the beaches are covered with stranded fish .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At Hilo large numbers of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives , for some minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After an earthquake in Japan in 1793 people on the coast at Tugaru were so terrified by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher ground .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When a second quake came , they dashed back to the beach , fearing that they might be buried under landslides .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just as they reached the shore , the first huge wave crashed upon them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A tsunami is not a single wave but a series .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The waves are separated by intervals of 15 minutes to an hour or more ( because of their great length ) , and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great wave has crashed that it is all over .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The waves may keep coming for many hours .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the biggest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at Hilo was Francis P. Shepard of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography , one of the world 's foremost marine geologists .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was able to make a detailed inspection of the waves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Their onrush and retreat , he reported , was accompanied by a great hissing , roaring and rattling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On some of the islands ' beaches the waves came in gently ; they were steepest on the shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In Hilo Bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The highest waves , 55 feet , occurred at Pololu Valley .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Scientists and fishermen have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During a 1933 tsunami in Japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism Noctiluca miliaris by the turbulence of the sea .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Japanese fishermen have sometimes observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have enormously swollen stomachs ; the fish have swallowed vast numbers of bottom living diatoms , raised to the surface by the disturbance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The waves of a 1923 tsunami in Sagami Bay brought to the surface and battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth of 3000 feet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The tsunami warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in Hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised by Commander C. K. Green of the Coast and Geodetic Survey staff .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It consists of a series of pipes and a pressure measuring chamber which record the rise and fall of the water surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ordinary water tides are disregarded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But when waves with a period of between 10 and 40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean , they set in motion a corresponding oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This in turn sets off an alarm , notifying the observers at the station that a tsunami is in progress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Such equipment has been installed at Hilo , Midway , Attu and Dutch Harbor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The moment the alarm goes off , information is immediately forwarded to Honolulu , which is the center of the warning system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This center also receives prompt reports on earthquakes from four Coast Survey stations in the Pacific which are equipped with seismographs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Its staff makes a preliminary determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide stations near the epicenter for a tsunami .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By means of charts showing wave travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations , it is possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival at Hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the Pacific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger , and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All of these activities are geared to a top priority communication system , and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work smoothly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami in the Pacific , but only one was of any consequence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On November 4 , 1952 , an earthquake occurred under the sea off the Kamchatka Peninsula .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">At 17 : 07 that afternoon ( Greenwich time ) the shock was recorded by the seismograph alarm in Honolulu .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The warning system immediately went into action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Within about an hour with the help of reports from seismic stations in Alaska , Arizona and California , the quake 's epicenter was placed at 51 degrees North latitude and 158 degrees East longitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While accounts of the progress of the tsunami came in from various points in the Pacific ( Midway reported it was covered with nine feet of water ) , the Hawaiian station made its calculations and notified the military services and the police that the first big wave would arrive at Honolulu at 23 : 30 Greenwich time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">They hurled a cement barge against a freighter in Honolulu Harbor , knocked down telephone lines , marooned automobiles , flooded lawns , killed six cows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But not a single human life was lost , and property damage in the Hawaiian Islands did not exceed $ 800000 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There is little doubt that the warning system saved lives and reduced the damage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it is plain that a warning system , however efficient , is not enough .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the vulnerable areas of the Pacific there should be restrictions against building homes on exposed coasts , or at least a requirement that they be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The key to the world of geology is change ; nothing remains the same .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the sea to complex combinations in man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The land , too , is changing , and earthquakes are daily reminders of this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Earthquakes result when movements in the earth twist rocks until they break .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sometimes this is accompanied by visible shifts of the ground surface ; often the shifts cannot be seen , but they are there ; and everywhere can be found scars of earlier breaks once deeply buried .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Today 's earthquakes are most numerous in belts where the earth 's restlessness is presently concentrated , but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth that has not had them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The effects of earthquakes on civilization have been widely publicized , even overemphasized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The role of an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously frightening , but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular disaster .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Superstition has often blended with fact to color reports .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">We have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know about the earth 's interior , for they send waves through the earth which emerge with information about the materials through which they have traveled .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These waves have shown that 1800 miles below the surface a liquid core begins , and that it , in turn , has a solid inner core .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface , but they do not occur at greater depths .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Two unsolved mysteries are based on these facts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( 1 ) As far down as 400 miles below the surface the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking , as rigid surface rocks do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( 2 ) If earthquakes do occur at such depths , why not deeper ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been applied in various fields .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the search for oil and gas , we make similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation of these resources .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We have also developed techniques for recognizing and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the ground which they generate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The following discussion of this subject has been adapted from the book Causes of Catastrophe by L. Don Leet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At twelve minutes after five on the morning of Wednesday , April 18 , 1906 , San Francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A sharp tremor was followed by a jerky roll .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In Ireland 's County Limerick , near the River Shannon , there is a quiet little suburb by the name of Garryowen , which means `` Garden of Owen '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Undoubtedly none of the residents realize the influence their town has had on American military history , or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The cry `` Garryowen '' !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of Cheyennes , Sioux and Apaches , Mexican banditos under Pancho Villa , Japanese in the South Pacific , and Chinese and North Korean Communists in Korea .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Garryowen is the battle cry of the 7 th U. S. Cavalry Regiment , `` The Fighting Seventh '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Today a battle cry may seem an anachronism , for in the modern Army , esprit de corps has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But do n't tell that to a veteran of the Fighting Seventh , especially in a saloon on Saturday night .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Of all the thousands of men who have served in the 7 th Cav , perhaps no one knows its spirit better than Lieutenant Colonel Melbourne C. Chandler .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wiry and burr headed , with steel blue eyes and a chest splattered with medals , Chandler is the epitome of the old-time trooper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The truth is , however , that when Mel Chandler first reported to the regiment the only steed he had ever ridden was a swivel chair and the only weapon he had ever wielded was a pencil .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Chandler had been commissioned in the Medical Service Corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the Kansas City Medical Depot when he decided that if he was going to make the Army his career , he wanted to be in the fighting part of it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Though he knew no more about military science and tactics than any other desk officer , he managed to get transferred to the combat forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The next thing he knew he was reporting for duty as commanding officer of Troop H , 7 th Cavalry , in the middle of corps maneuvers in Japan .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Outside of combat , he could n't have landed in a tougher spot .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">First of all , no unit likes to have a new CO brought in from the outside , especially when he 's an armchair trooper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Second , if there is ever a perfect time to pull the rug out from under him , it 's on maneuvers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In combat , helping your CO make a fool of himself might mean getting yourself killed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But in maneuvers , with the top brass watching him all the time , it 's easy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Chandler understood this and expected the worst .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But his first few days with Troop H were full of surprises , beginning with First Sergeant Robert Early .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Chandler had expected a tough old trooper with a gravel voice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Instead Sergeant Early was quiet , sharp and confident .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He had enlisted in the Army straight out of high school and had immediately set about learning his new trade .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There was no weapon Early could not take apart and reassemble blind-folded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He could lead a patrol and he knew his paper work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Further , he had taken full advantage of the Army 's correspondence courses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He not only knew soldiering , but mathematics , history and literature as well .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But for all his erudite confidence , Sergeant Early was right out of the Garryowen mold .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He was filled with the spirit of the Fighting Seventh .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">That saved Mel Chandler .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sergeant Early let the new CO know just how lucky he was to be in the best troop in the best regiment in the United States Army .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He fed the captain bits of history about the troops and the regiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , it was a battalion of the 7 th Cavalry under Colonel George Armstrong Custer that had been wiped out at the Battle of The Little Big Horn .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It did n't take Captain Chandler long to realize that he had to carry a heavy load of tradition on his shoulders as commander of Troop H .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But what made the load lighter was the realization that every officer , non-com and trooper was ready and willing to help him carry it , for the good of the troop and the regiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Maneuvers over , the 7 th returned to garrison duty in Tokyo , Captain Chandler still with them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was the 7 th Cavalry whose troopers were charged with guarding the Imperial Palace of the Emperor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But still Mel Chandler was not completely convinced that men would really die for a four syllable word , `` Garryowen '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The final proof was a small incident .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It happened at the St. Patrick 's Day party , a big affair for a regiment which had gone into battle for over three quarters of a century to the strains of an Irish march .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the middle of the party Chandler looked up to see four smiling faces bearing down upon him , each beaming above the biggest , greenest shamrock he had ever seen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The faces belonged to Lieutenant Marvin Goulding , his wife and their two children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And when the singing began , it was the Gouldings who sang the old Irish songs the best .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Though there was an occasional good-natured chuckle about Marvin Goulding , the Jewish officer from Chicago , singing tearfully about the ould sod , no one really thought it was strange .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For Marvin Goulding , like Giovanni Martini , the bugler boy who carried Custer 's last message , or Margarito Lopez , the one-man Army on Leyte , was a Garryowen , through and through .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was no coincidence that Goulding was one of the most beloved platoon leaders in the regiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And so Mel Chandler got the spirit of Garryowen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He set out to keep Troop H the best troop in the best regiment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One of his innovations was to see to it that every man - cook and clerk as well as rifleman - qualified with every weapon in the troop .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even the mess sergeant , Bill Brown , a dapper , cocky transfer from an airborne division , went out on the range .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The troop received a new leader , Lieutenant Robert M. Carroll , fresh out of ROTC and bucking for Regular Army status .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Carroll was sharp and military , but he was up against tough competition for that RA berth , and he wanted to play it cool .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So Mel Chandler set out to sell him on the spirit of Garryowen , just as he himself had been sold a short time before .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the Korean war began , on June 25 , 1950 , the anniversary of the day Custer had gone down fighting at the Little Big Horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead of Leyte during World War 2 , , the 7 th Cavalry was not in the best fighting condition .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From then on the Fighting Seventh was in the thick of the bitterest fighting in Korea .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He was a member of The Fighting Seventh .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Although it was at the Battle of The Little Horn , about which more words have been written than any other battle in American history , that the 7 th Cavalry first made its mark in history , the regiment was ten years old by then .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Brevet Major General George Armstrong Custer was the regiment 's first permanent commander and , like such generals as George S. <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the Civil War , Custer , who achieved a brilliant record , was made brigadier general at the age of 23 .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I do not mean to suggest that these assumptions are self-evident , in the sense that everyone agrees with them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If they were , Walter Lippmann would be writing the same columns as George Sokolsky , and Herblock would have nothing to draw cartoons about .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I do mean , however , that I take them for granted , and that everything I shall be saying would appear quite idiotic against any contrary assumptions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The ultimate objective of American policy is to help establish a world in which there is the largest possible measure of freedom and justice and peace and material prosperity ; and in particular - since this is our special responsibility - that these conditions be enjoyed by the people of the United States .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I speak of `` the largest possible measure '' because any person who supposes that these conditions can be universally and perfectly achieved - ever - reckons without the inherent imperfectability of himself and his fellow human beings , and is therefore a dangerous man to have around .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These conditions are unobtainable - are not even approachable in the qualified sense I have indicated - without the prior defeat of world Communism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This is true for two reasons : because Communism is both doctrinally , and in practice , antithetical to these conditions ; and because Communists have the will and , as long as Soviet power remains intact , the capacity to prevent their realization .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover , as Communist power increases , the enjoyment of these conditions throughout the world diminishes pro rata and the possibility of their restoration becomes increasingly remote .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It follows that victory over Communism is the dominant , proximate goal of American policy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Proximate in the sense that there are more distant , more `` positive '' ends we seek , to which victory over Communism is but a means .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But dominant in the sense that every other objective , no matter how worthy intrinsically , must defer to it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Peace is a worthy objective ; but if we must choose between peace and keeping the Communists out of Berlin , then we must fight .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Freedom , in the sense of self-determination , is a worthy objective ; but if granting self-determination to the Algerian rebels entails sweeping that area into the Sino-Soviet orbit , then Algerian freedom must be postponed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Justice is a worthy objective ; but if justice for Bantus entails driving the government of the Union of South Africa away from the West , then the Bantus must be prepared to carry their identification cards yet a while longer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Prosperity is a worthy objective ; but if providing higher standards of living gets in the way of producing sufficient guns to resist Communist aggression , then material sacrifices and denials will have to be made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It may be , of course , that such objectives can be pursued consisently with a policy designed to overthrow Communism ; my point is that where conflicts arise they must always be resolved in favor of achieving the indispensable condition for a tolerant world - the absence of Soviet Communist power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This much having been said , the question remains whether we have the resources for the job we have to do - defeat Communism - and , if so , how those resources ought to be used .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This brings us squarely to the problem of power , and the uses a nation makes of power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I submit that this is the key problem of international relations , that it always has been , that it always will be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And I suggest further that the main cause of the trouble we are in has been the failure of American policy-makers , ever since we assumed free world leadership in 1945 , to deal with this problem realistically and seriously .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the recent political campaign two charges were leveled affecting the question of power , and I think we might begin by trying to put them into proper focus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One was demonstrably false ; the other , for the most part , true .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first was that America had become - or was in danger of becoming - a second-rate military power .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I know I do not have to dwell here on the absurdity of that contention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">You may have misgivings about certain aspects of our military establishment - I certainly do - but you know any comparison of over-all American strength with over-all Soviet strength finds the United States not only superior , but so superior both in present weapons and in the development of new ones that our advantage promises to be a permanent feature of U. S. - Soviet relations for the foreseeable future .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I have often searched for a graphic way of impressing our superiority on those Americans who have doubts , and I think Mr. Jameson Campaigne has done it well in his new book American Might and Soviet Myth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Suppose , he says , that the tables were turned , and we were in the Soviets ' position : `` There would be more than 2000 modern Soviet fighters , all better than ours , stationed at 250 bases in Mexico and the Caribbean .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Overwhelming Russian naval power would always be within a few hundred miles of our coast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Half of the population of the U. S. would be needed to work on arms just to feed the people '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Add this to the unrest in the countries around us where oppressed peoples would be ready to turn on us at the first opportunity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Add also a comparatively primitive industrial plant which would severely limit our capacity to keep abreast of the Soviets even in the missile field which is reputed to be our main strength .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If we look at the situation this way , we can get an idea of Khrushchev 's nightmarish worries - or , at least , of the worries he might have if his enemies were disposed to exploit their advantage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The other charge was that America 's political position in the world has progressively deteriorated in recent years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The contention needs to be formulated with much greater precision than it ever was during the campaign , but once that has been done , I fail to see how any serious student of world affairs can quarrel with it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The argument was typically advanced in terms of U. S. `` prestige '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Prestige , however , is only a minor part of the problem ; and even then , it is a concept that can be highly misleading .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Prestige is a measure of how other people think of you , well or ill .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But contrary to what was implied during the campaign , prestige is surely not important for its own sake .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only the vain and incurably sentimental among us will lose sleep simply because foreign peoples are not as impressed by our strength as they ought to be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The thing to lose sleep over is what people , having concluded that we are weaker than we are , are likely to do about it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The evidence suggests that foreign peoples believe the United States is weaker than the Soviet Union , and is bound to fall still further behind in the years ahead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This ignorant estimate , I repeat , is not of any interest in itself ; but it becomes very important if foreign peoples react the way human beings typically do - namely , by taking steps to end up on what appears to be the winning side .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">To the extent , then , that declining U. S. prestige means that other nations will be tempted to place their bets on an ultimate American defeat , and will thus be more vulnerable to Soviet intimidation , there is reason for concern .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still , these guesses about the outcome of the struggle cannot be as important as the actual power relationship between the Soviet Union and ourselves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here I do not speak of military power where our advantage is obvious and overwhelming but of political power - of influence , if you will - about which the relevant questions are :
Is Soviet influence throughout the world greater or less than it was ten years ago ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And is Western influence greater or less than it used to be ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In answering these questions , we need to ask not merely whether Communist troops have crossed over into territories they did not occupy before , and not merely whether disciplined agents of the Cominform are in control of governments from which they were formerly excluded :
the success of Communism 's war against the West does not depend on such spectacular and definitive conquests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Success may mean merely the displacement of Western influence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Communist political warfare , we must remember , is waged insidiously and in deliberate stages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Fearful of inviting a military showdown with the West which they could not win , the Communists seek to undermine Western power where the nuclear might of the West is irrelevant - in backwoods guerrilla skirmishes , in mob uprisings in the streets , in parliaments , in clandestine meetings of undercover conspirators , at the United Nations , on the propaganda front , at diplomatic conferences - preferably at the highest level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Soviets understand , moreover , that the first step in turning a country toward Communism is to turn it against the West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , typically , the first stage of a Communist takeover is to `` neutralize '' a country .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The second stage is to retain the nominal classification of `` neutralist '' , while in fact turning the country into an active advocate and adherent of Soviet policy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And this may be as far as the process will go .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Kremlin 's goal is the isolation and capture , not of Ghana , but of the United States - and this purpose may be served very well by countries that masquerade under a `` neutralist '' mask , yet in fact are dependable auxiliaries of the Soviet Foreign Office .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To recite the particulars of recent Soviet successes is hardly reassuring .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Six years ago French Indochina , though in troubie , was in the Western camp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Today Northern Vietnam is overtly Communist ; Laos is teetering between Communism and pro Communist neutralism ; Cambodia is , for all practical purposes , neutralist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Indonesia , in the early days of the Republic , leaned toward the West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Today Sukarno 's government is heavily besieged by avowed Communists , and for all of its `` neutralist '' pretensions , it is a firm ally of Soviet policy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Ceylon has moved from a pro Western orientation to a neutralism openly hostile to the West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the Middle East , Iraq , Syria and Egypt were , a short while ago , in the Western camp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Today the Nasser and Kassem governments are adamantly hostile to the West , are dependent for their military power on Soviet equipment and personnel ; in almost every particular follow the Kremlin 's foreign policy line .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A short time ago all Africa was a Western preserve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Never mind whether the Kikiyus and the Bantus enjoyed Wilsonian self-determination : the point is that in the struggle for the world that vast land mass was under the domination and influence of the West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Today , Africa is swerving violently away from the West and plunging , it would seem , into the Soviet orbit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Latin America was once an area as `` safe '' for the West as Nebraska was for Nixon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Today it is up for grabs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One Latin American country , Cuba , has become a Soviet bridgehead ninety miles off our coast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In some countries the trend has gone further than others :
Mexico , Panama , and Venezuela are displaying open sympathy for Castroism , and there is no country - save the Dominican Republic whose funeral services we recently arranged - where Castroism and anti Americanism does not prevent the government from unqualifiedly espousing the American cause .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Only in Europe have our lines remained firm - and there only on the surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The strains of neutralism are running strong , notably in England , and even in Germany .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What have we to show by way of counter successes ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We have had opportunities - clear invitations to plant our influence on the other side of the Iron Curtain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There was the Hungarian Revolution which we praised and mourned , but did nothing about .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There was the Polish Revolution which we misunderstood and then helped guide along a course favorable to Soviet interests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There was the revolution in Tibet which we pretended did not exist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Only in one instance have we moved purposively and effectively to dislodge existing Communist power :
in Guatemala .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And contrary to what has been said recently , we did not wait for `` outside pressures '' and `` world opinion '' to bring down that Communist government ; we moved decisively to effect an anti Communist coup d ' etat .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We served our national interests , and by so doing we saved the Guatemalan people the ultimate in human misery .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first rattle of the machine guns , at 7 : 10 in the evening , roused around me the varied voices and faces of fear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Sounds exactly like last time '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The young man spoke steadily enough , but all at once he looked grotesquely unshaven .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The middle-aged man said over and over , `` Why did I come here , why did I come here '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Then he was sick .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Then the lights went out .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It takes place in the household , a rite of well wishing for myriad occasions - for the traveler , a wedding , a newborn child , the sick , the New Year , for any good purpose .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">My interviews with teen-agers confirmed this portrait of the weakening of religious and ethnic bonds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Jewish identity was often confused with social and economic strivings .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When I pressed for a purely religious definition , I encountered the familiar blend of liberal piety , interfaith good will , and a small residue of ethnic loyalty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` I like the tradition '' , a girl said .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The most important aims of the Jewish students were as follows : to make the world a better place to live in - 30 per cent ; to get happiness for yourself - 28 per cent ; and financial independence - 21 per cent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Nevertheless , most of the teen-agers I interviewed believed in maintaining their Jewish identity and even envisioned joining a synagogue or temple .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , they were hostile to Jewish Orthodoxy , professing to believe in Judaism `` but in a moderate way '' .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still another suggested that he would join a temple `` for social reasons , since I 'll be living in a suburb '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Intermarriage , which is generally regarded as a threat to Jewish survival , was regarded not with horror or apprehension but with a kind of mild , clinical disapproval .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most of the teen-agers I interviewed rejected it on pragmatic grounds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` When you marry , you want to have things in common '' , a girl said , `` and it 's hard when you do n't marry someone with your own background '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A fourteen year old girl from the Middle West observed wryly that , in her community , religion inconveniently interfered with religious activities - at least with the peripheral activities that many middle class Jews now regard as religious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It appears that an Orthodox girl in the community disrupted plans for an outing sponsored by one of the Jewish service groups because she would not travel on Saturday and , in addition , required kosher food .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This is , no doubt , inaccurate , but it does convey how isolated she feels among the vast army of the nonobservant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the significant things about Jewish culture in the older teen years is that it is largely college oriented .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Sixty five per cent of the Jewish teen-agers of college age attend institutions of higher learning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This is substantially higher than the figures for the American population at large - 45.6 per cent for males and 29.2 per cent for females .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This may help explain a phenomenon described by a small town Jewish boy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In their first two years in high school , Jewish boys in this town make strenuous exertions to win positions on the school teams .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , in their junior and senior years , they generally forego their athletic pursuits , presumably in the interest of better academic achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is significant , too , that the older teen-agers I interviewed believed , unlike the younger ones , that Jewish students tend to do better academically than their gentile counterparts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The percentage of Jewish girls who attend college is almost as high as that of boys .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The vocational motive is the dominant one for boys , while Jewish girls attend college for social reasons and to become culturally developed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One of the significant developments in American Jewish life is that the cultural consumers are largely the women .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It is they who read - and make - Jewish best-sellers and then persuade their husbands to read them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In upper teen Jewish life , the non college group tends to have a sense of marginality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` People automatically assume that I 'm in college '' , a nineteen year old machinist observed irritably .</MPQASENT>
