<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Jewish working girl almost invariably works in an office - in contradistinction to gentile factory workers - and , buttressed by a respectable income , she is likely to dress better and live more expansively than the college student .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She is even prone to regard the college girl as immature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the reasons for the high percentage of Jewish teen-agers in college is that a great many urban Jews are enabled to attend local colleges at modest cost .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is particularly true in large centers of Jewish population like New York , Chicago , and Philadelphia .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">What is noteworthy about this large group of teen-agers is that , although their attitudes hardly differentiate them from their gentile counterparts , they actually lead their lives in a vast self enclosed Jewish cosmos with relatively little contact with the non Jewish world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Perhaps the Jewish students at Brooklyn College - constituting 85 per cent of those who attend the day session - can serve as a paradigm of the urban , lower middle class Jewish student .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There is , to begin , an important sex difference .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Typically , in a lower-middle class Jewish family , a son will be sent to an out-of-town school , if financial resources warrant it , while the daughter will attend the local college .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There are two reasons for this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">First , the girl 's education has a lower priority than the son 's .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Second , the attitude in Jewish families is far more protective toward the daughter than toward the son .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Most Jewish mothers are determined to exercise vigilance over the social and sexual lives of their daughters by keeping them home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The consequence of this is that the girls at Brooklyn College outnumber the boys and do somewhat better academically .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One can assume that some of the brightest boys are out of town .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Brooklyn College students have an ambivalent attitude toward their school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the one hand , there is a sense of not having moved beyond the ambiance of their high school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This is particularly acute for those who attended Midwood High School directly across the street from Brooklyn College .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They have a sense of marginality at being denied that special badge of status , the out-of-town school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">At the same time , there is a good deal of self congratulation at attending a good college - they are even inclined to exaggerate its not inconsiderable virtues - and they express pleasure at the cozy in-group feeling that the college generates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` It 's people of your own kind '' , a girl remarked .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` You do n't have to watch what you say .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of course , I would like to go to an out-of-town school where there are all kinds of people , but I would want lots of Jewish kids there '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For most Brooklyn College students , college is at once a perpetuation of their ethnic attachments and a breaking away from the cage of neighborhood and family .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Brooklyn College is unequivocally Jewish in tone , and efforts to detribalize the college by bringing in unimpeachably midwestern types on the faculty have been unavailing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , a growing intellectual sophistication and the new certitudes imparted by courses in psychology and anthropology make the students increasingly critical of their somewhat provincial and overprotective parents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And the rebellion of these third generation Jews is not the traditional conflict of culture but , rather , a protest against a culture that they view as softly and insidiously enveloping .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` As long as I 'm home , I 'll never grow up '' , a nineteen year old boy observed sadly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` They do n't like it if I do anything away from home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It 's so much trouble , I do n't usually bother '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For girls , the overprotection is far more pervasive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Parents will drive on Friday night to pick up their daughters after a sorority or House Plan meeting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A freshman girl 's father not too long ago called a dean at Brooklyn College and demanded the `` low-down '' on a boy who was going out with his daughter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The domestic tentacles even extend to the choice of a major field .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Under pressure from parents , the majority of Brooklyn College girls major in education since that co-ordinates best with marriage plans - limited graduate study requirement and convenient working hours .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This means that a great many academically talented girls are discouraged from pursuing graduate work of a more demanding nature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A kind of double standard exists here for Jewish boys and girls as it does in the realm of sex .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The breaking away from the prison house of Brooklyn is gradual .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">First , the student trains on his hapless parents the heavy artillery of his newly acquired psychological and sociological insights .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Then , with the new affluence , there is actually a sallying forth into the wide , wide world beyond the precincts of New York .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is significant that the Catskills , which used to be the summer playground for older teen-agers , a kind of summer suburb of New York , no longer attracts them in great numbers - except for those who work there as waiters , bus boys , or counselors in the day camps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The great world beyond beckons .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But it should be pointed out that some of the new watering places - Fire Island , Nantucket , Westhampton , Long Island , for example - tend to be homogeneously Jewish .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although Brooklyn College does not yet have a junior year abroad program , a good number of students spend summers in Europe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In general , however , the timetable of travel lags considerably behind that of the student at Harvard or Smith .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And acculturation into the world at large is likely to occur for the Brooklyn College student after college rather than during the four school years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Brooklyn College is Marjorie Morningstar territory , as much as the Bronx or Central Park West .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There are hordes of nubile young women there who , prodded by their impatient mothers , are determined to marry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is interesting that , although the percentage of married students is not appreciably higher at Brooklyn than elsewhere - about 30 per cent of the women and 25 per cent of the men in the graduating class - the anxiety of the unmarried has puffed up the estimate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` Almost everybody in the senior class is married '' , students say dogmatically .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And the school newspaper sells space to jubilant fraternities , sororities , and houses ( in the House Plan Association ) that have good news to impart .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These announcements are , in effect , advertisements for themselves as thriving marriage marts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There are boxed proclamations in the newspaper of watchings , pinnings , ringings , engagements , and marriages in a scrupulously graded hierarchy of felicity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Witt House happily announces the engagement of Fran Horowitz to Erwin Schwartz of Fife House '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Brooklyn College student shows some striking departures from prevailing collegiate models .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Ivy League enjoys no easy dominion here , and the boys are as likely to dress in rather foppish Continental fashion , or even in nondescript working class manner , as they are in the restrained , button-down Ivy way .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The girls are prone to dress far more flamboyantly than their counterparts out of town , and eye shadow , mascara , and elaborate bouffant hairdos - despite the admonitions of cautious guidance personnel - are not unknown even in early morning classes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Among the boys , there is very little bravado about drinking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Brooklyn College is distinctive for not having an official drinking place .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Fort Lauderdale encampment for drinking is foreign to most Brooklyn College boys .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In a few school districts one finds a link between school and job .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In those vocational programs organized with Smith-Hughes money , there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In these cases a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program , saving a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The apprentice program will involve further education on a part-time basis , usually at night , perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such crafts as auto mechanics , carpentry , drafting , electrical work , tool-and-die work , and sheet-metal work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Formally organized vocational programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time job on graduation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The `` diversified occupations '' program is a part-time trade preparatory program conducted over two school years on a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business employers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The `` distributive education '' program operates in a similar way , with arrangements between the school and employers in merchandising fields .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In both cases the student attends school half-time and works in a regular job the other half .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He receives remuneration for his work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a few places cooperative programs between schools and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing the student , while still in school , to develop skills which are immediately marketable upon graduation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Adult education courses , work-study programs of various sorts - these are all evidence of a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities for out-of-school youth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In general , however , it may be said that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school , the school authorities play little or no part in the decision of what happens next .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the student drops out of high school , the break with the school is even more complete .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When there is employment opportunity for youth , this arrangement - or lack of arrangement - works out quite well .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and went to work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Statistically this has represented a loss to the nation , although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in retrospect may have been a wise one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I make no attempt to measure the enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business which he entered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He may or may not be `` better off '' than his classmate who went on to a college and professional school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But in the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all the potential professional talent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In a later chapter dealing with the suburban school , I shall discuss the importance of arranging a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any high school where he is found .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the Negro neighborhoods and also to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of identification and motivation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">High motivation towards higher education must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are essential for academic work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Undoubtedly far more can be done in the lower grades in this regard in the Negro schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , the teacher can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family is anti-intellectual .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And the fact remains that there are today few shining examples of Negroes in positions of intellectual leadership .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the Northern universities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Quite the contrary , as I can testify from personal experience as a former university president .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Rather we see here another vicious circle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The absence of successful Negroes in the world of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among Negro youth for academic careers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I believe the situation is improving , but the success stories need to be heavily publicized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here again we run into the roadblock that Negroes do not like to be designated as Negroes in the press .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">How can the vicious circle be broken ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is a problem to which leaders of opinion , both Negro and white , should devote far more attention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is at least as important as the more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the South .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I should like to underline four points I made in my first report with respect to vocational education .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">First and foremost , vocational courses should not replace courses which are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Second , vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and not require more than half the student 's time in those years ; however , for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to begin earlier .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Third , the significance of the vocational courses is that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work ; they realize the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers , and this sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they are studying at the same time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Fourth , the type of vocational training programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the general locality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This last point is important because if high school pupils are aware that few , if any , graduates who have chosen a certain vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training , the whole idea of relevance disappears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Vocational training which holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable skill becomes just another school `` chore '' for those whose interest in their studies has begun to falter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those who , because of population mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees , would limit vocational education to general rather than specific skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind of school experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I have been using the word `` vocational '' as a layman would at first sight think it should be used .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I intend to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys and girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These courses develop skills other than those we think of when we use the adjective `` academic '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Practically all of these practical skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at once on the basis of the skill .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They are in this sense skills marketable immediately on graduation from high school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To be sure , in tool-and-die work and in the building trades , the first job must be often on an apprentice basis , but two years of halftime vocational training enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Similarly , a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two of further study in a community college or secretarial school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of course , it can be argued that an ability to write English correctly and with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">So , too , is the mathematical competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a sense almost all high school and college courses could be considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student in his vocation ( which may be a profession ) will be called upon to use some of the skills developed and the competence obtained .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In spite of the shading of one type of course into another , I believe it is useful to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which proves the rule .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Today many college bound students try to take a course in personal typing , as they feel a certain degree of mastery of this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work in college and a professional school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Most of our largest cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this respect , public education in the large cities differs from education in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The neighborhood high schools are not , strictly speaking , comprehensive schools , because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational or technical high school instead of the local school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , one school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term comprehensive high school for the senior high schools in his city , because these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He prefers to designate such schools as `` general '' high schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The suburban high school , it is worth noting , also is not a widely comprehensive high school because of the absence of vocational programs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The reason is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic of the comprehensive high school described in my first report .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities must be reckoned as permanent institutions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By and large their programs are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and to the realities of the apprentice system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not often realized to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of employment , except for a lucky few .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One has to talk confidentially with some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a boy cannot just say , `` I want to be a plumber '' , and then , by doing good work , find a job .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is far more difficult in many communities to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Two stories will illustrate what I have in mind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One vocational instructor in a city vocational school , speaking of his course in a certain field , said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside of the city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the city , he said , the waiting list for those who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside track he can n't get in .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In a far distant part of the United States , I was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade was doing special work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` What does he have in mind to do when he graduates '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` Oh , he 'll be a plumber '' , came the answer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` But is n't it almost impossible to get into the union '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I asked .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">`` He 'll have no difficulty '' , I was told .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` He has very good connections '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In my view , there should be a school which offers significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every family in a city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Ideally these schools should be so located that one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is at the highest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An excellent example of a successful location of a new vocational high school is the Dunbar Vocational High School in Chicago .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment , this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational aims of its students .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hardly a window has been broken since Dunbar first was opened ( and vandalism in schools is a major problem in many slum areas ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I discovered in the course of a visit there that almost all the pupils were Negroes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They were learning trades as diverse as shoe repairing , bricklaying , carpentry , cabinet making , auto mechanics , and airplane mechanics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The physical facilities at Dunbar are impressive , but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In general , religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis ; congregational membership , however , is another thing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A congregation survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership ; that is , when it can preserve economic integration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Religious faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in a congregation , since the decision to join a worshiping group requires some motive force , but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining ; the presence of other members of similar social and economic level is the sufficient condition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The breakdown of social homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account for the decline of central city churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Central cities reveal two adverse features for the major denominations :
( 1 ) central cities tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes ; ( 2 ) central cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The central city areas , in other words , exhibit the two characteristics which violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations : they have too few middle-class people ; they mix middle-class people with lower-class residents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Central city areas have become progressively poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus of middle-class people from most central cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With few exceptions , the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The key to Protestant development , therefore , is economic integration of the nucleus of the congregation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Members of higher and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus , so that Protestant figures on social class give the impression of spread over all social classes ; but this is deceptive , for the core of membership is concentrated in a single social and economic stratum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The congregation perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the neighborhood ; moreover , residential mobility is so high in metropolitan areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum in order to survive ; they can lose higher - and lower status members from the church without collapsing , but they need adequate recruits for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group ; it is secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If it were primarily a believing fellowship , it would recruit believers from all social and economic ranks , something which most congregations of the New Protestantism ( with a few notable exceptions ) have not been able to do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The vulnerability of Protestant congregations to social differences has often been attributed to the `` folksy spirit '' of Protestant religious life ; in fact , a contrast is often drawn in this regard with the `` impersonal '' Roman Catholic parish .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We have seen that the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers ; consequently , the vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress on personal community in Protestant congregations ; actually , there is little evidence of such personal community in Protestant congregations , as we shall see in another connection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The vulnerability of Protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of the new religious style in middle-class life , where the congregation is a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform , therefore , to the principle of economic integration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This fact is evident in the recruitment of new members .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the missionary outreach of the major denominations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is much talk in theological circles about the `` Church as Mission '' and the `` Church 's Mission '' ; theologians have been stressing the fact that the Church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in the world for the healing of the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A crucial question , therefore , is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan Protestantism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If economic integration really shapes congregational life , then evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The task of a congregation would be defined , according to economic integration , as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( Co-optation means to choose by joint action in order to fill a vacancy ; it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power from an environment in order to strengthen an organization . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a mobile society , congregational health depends on a constant process of recruitment ; this recruitment , however , must follow the pattern of economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation ; therefore , the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation rather than proclamation - like elements will have to be assimilated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Evangelism and congregational outreach have not been carefully studied in the churches ; one study in Pittsburgh , however , has illuminated the situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a sample of new members of Pittsburgh churches , almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial `` contacts with friendly members '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If we add to these contacts with friendly members the `` contacts with an organization of the church '' ( 11.2 per cent of the cases ) , then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment is through friendly contact .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">On the surface , this seems a sound approach to Christian mission : members of the congregation show by their friendly attitudes that they care for new people ; the new people respond in kind by joining the church .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Missionary outreach by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods ; the majority of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic position ; association by level of achievement is the dominant principle of informal relations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This means that the antennae of the congregation are extended into the community , picking up the wave lengths of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation ; the mission of the church is actually a process of informal co-optation ; the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people who can fit the pattern of economic integration ; once the pool of recruits diminishes , the congregation is helpless - friendly contacts no longer keep it going .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The transmutation of mission to co-optation is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities , worship , preaching , and publicity in reaching new members .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts by the clergy ( 17.3 per cent of new members ) and friendly contacts by members ( over two thirds if organizational activities are included ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Publicity accounted for 1.1 per cent of the initial contacts with new members .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In general , friendly contact with a member followed by contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment by the churches , making it quite evident that the extension of economic integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission in the contemporary church ; economic integration and co-optation are the two methods by which Protestants associate with and recruit from the neighborhood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The inner life of congregations will prosper so long as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize together ; the outer life of congregations - the suitability of the environment to their survival - will be propitious so long as the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the membership .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Economic integration ceases when the social and economic statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of the congregation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a rapidly changing society congregations will run into difficulties repeatedly , since such nice balances of economic integration are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single generation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle to maintain economic balance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The expense of this type of organization in religious life , when one recalls the number of city churches which deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned , raises fundamental questions about the principle of Protestant survival in a mobile society ; nonetheless , the prevalence of economic integration in congregations illumines the nature of the Protestant development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had split into two trends - expanding interdependence on an impersonal basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These trends seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Residential associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential communities have polarized ; the schism between central city and suburb , Negro and White , blue collar and white collar can be viewed as symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved with the economy of middle-class culture , for it serves to crystallize the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable environment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">More than creatures of metropolitan forces , the churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan life , crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of peoples , giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world of heterogeneous peoples .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since American life is committed above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life , the countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have fought a desperate , rearguard action against the expanding interdependence of the metropolis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Consumer communities have suffered at the hands of the productive interests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Negroes , Puerto Ricans , and rural newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Soon they will fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs , and the churches will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized their history for a century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The identification of the basic unit of religious organization - the parish or congregation - with a residential area is self defeating in a modern metropolis , for it simply means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the Christian fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mission to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential community , because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan interdependence with residential exclusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This interpretation of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could lead to various projections for the churches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It could be argued that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the middle classes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain religious activity , since worship presupposes some local stabilities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whatever projection one makes , the striking fact about congregational and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the social identity of middle-class people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Attention will be given in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational churches ; this style is characteristically an expression of the communal style of the middle classes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The keynotes of this style are activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman , dictating the methods of child rearing , determining the pattern of community participation , setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of middle-class illness , and informing the congregational life of the major denominations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` Fellowship by likeness '' and `` mission by friendly contact '' form the iron cage of denominational religion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Its contents are another matter , for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued by the congregation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What goes on in the cage will occupy our attention under the rubric of the organization church .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An understanding of the new role of residential association in an industrial society serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs and charities should fill the same need .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These polar concerns ( imitation vs. formalism ) reflect a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing over a long period of time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The breakdown of classical structures of meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal and spiritual qualities , and complete objectification in sub-human and quasi mechanistic powers .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">All such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism : if man can neither know nor love reality as it is , he can at least invent an artistic `` reality '' which is its own world and which can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable of being known and worthy of being loved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The person of the artist becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical systems .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art , their peculiar authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously and gives promise that from their very substance , new and valid chapters in the philosophy of art may be written .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For better or worse we cannot regard `` imitation '' in the arts in the simple mode of classical rationalism or detached realism .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the other hand , we cannot regard artistic invention as pure , uncaused , and unrelated to the times in which it occurs .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">Accordingly , it is the aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation ( which I shall call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of imitation ) and a new theory of invention ( which I shall call symbol for reasons to be stated hereafter ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The word `` mimesis '' ( `` imitation '' ) is usually associated with Plato and Aristotle .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For Plato , `` imitation '' is twice removed from reality , being a poor copy of physical appearance , which in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All artistic and mythological representations , therefore , are `` imitations of imitations '' and are completely superseded by the truth value of `` dialectic '' , the proper use of the inquiring intellect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In Plato 's judgment , the arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young , prior to the full development of their intellectual powers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Presupposed in Plato 's system is a doctrine of levels of insight , in which a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating to the most sublime wisdom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Aristotle also tended to stratify all aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and , like Plato , he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Poetics , in affirming that all human arts are `` modes of imitation '' , gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than did Plato .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But Aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented it by describing in the Poetics what kinds of character and action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and important human truths .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For both Plato and Aristotle artistic mimesis , in contrast to the power of dialectic , is relatively incapable of expressing the character of fundamental reality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The central concern of Erich Auerbach 's impressive volume called Mimesis is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation ( based upon a recognition of levels of truth ) to a Christian theory of imitation in which the levels are dissolved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Following the theme of Incarnation in the Gospels , the Christian artist and critic sees in the most commonplace and ordinary events `` figures '' of divine power and reality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Artistic mimesis under Christian influence records the involvement of all persons , however humble , in a divine drama .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The artist , unlike the philosopher , is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified high levels of abstraction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is the conveyor of a sacred reality by which he has been grasped .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I have chosen to use the word `` mimesis '' in its Christian rather than its classic implications and to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological expression which , as in the Christian mind , are the direct consequence of involvement in historical experience , which are not reserved , as in the Greek mind , only to moments of theoretical reflection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the first instance , `` mimesis '' is here used to mean the recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms of abstract ideas or conventional designations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By `` image '' is meant not only a visual presentation , but also remembered sensations of any of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined therewith .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is the primary function of the imagination operating in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images were first appropriated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mimesis is the nearest possible thing to the actual re-living of experience , in which the imagining person recovers through images something of the force and depth characteristic of experience itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The images themselves , like their counterparts in experience , are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately ; they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities and a unique relatedness to one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They bring an inextricable component of value within themselves , with attractions and repulsions native to their own quality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As in experience one is seized by given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in value feelings to them , so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation of images .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism or realism in the conventional sense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A word taken in its dictionary meaning , a photographic image of a recognizable object , the mere picturing of a `` scene '' tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without the incitement of value feelings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Similarly experience itself can be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential field .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection to a sense of immediacy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The mimetic character of the imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation of artistic forms and materials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When words can be used in a more fresh and primitive way so that they strike with the force of sights and sounds , when tones of sound and colors of paint and the carven shape all strike the sensibilities with an undeniable force of data in and of themselves , compelling the observer into an attitude of attention , all this imitates the way experience itself in its deepest character strikes upon the door of consciousness and clamors for entrance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self and thrusts the self into decision and choice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The presence of genuine mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely understood .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which require some exposition before the main argument can proceed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Experience is not seen , as it is in classical rationalism , as presenting us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space and registering their character , movements , and changes on the tabula rasa of an uninvolved intellect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Neither is primary experience understood according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing their responses in the appropriate sense organs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Primary feelings of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects ( houses , trees , implements , etc . )</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">nor a collection of isolated and neutral sensory qualities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In contrast to all this , primary data are data of a self involved in environing processes and powers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings , both positive and negative : a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment into oneself ; a desire to avoid and repel this or that other part .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers in which one is involved , some working for one 's good , others threatening ill .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Gone is the tabula rasa of the mind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In its place is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive or negative values even as the actions of one 's life are determined by constellations of process in which one is caught .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The principal defender of this view of primary experience as `` causal efficacy '' is Alfred North Whitehead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our most elemental and unavoidable impressions , he says , are those of being involved in a large arena of powers which have a longer past than our own , which are interrelated in a vast movement through the present toward the future .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We feel the quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors of judgment in these apprehensions of value , but the apprehensions themselves are the primary stuff of experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It takes a great deal of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger unities of power and influence and to view one 's world simply as a collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern , devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far as they present themselves for inspection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whitehead is here questioning David Hume 's understanding of the nature of experience ; he is questioning , also , every epistemology which stems from Hume 's presupposition that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from causal efficacy , and that causal efficacy is something intellectually imputed to the world , not directly perceived .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">What Hume calls `` sensation '' is what Whitehead calls `` perception in the mode of presentational immediacy '' which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception in the mode of causal efficacy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As long as perception is seen as composed only of isolated sense data , most of the quality and interconnectedness of existence loses its objectivity , becomes an invention of consciousness , and the result is a philosophical scepticism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whitehead contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because the basic form of such an understanding , for all its vagueness and tendency to mistake the detail , is initially given in the way man feels the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this respect experience is broader and full of a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A chief characteristic of experience in the mode of causal efficacy is one of derivation from the past .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both I and my feelings come up out of a chain of events that fan out into the past into sources that are ultimately very unlike the entity which I now am .</MPQASENT>
