<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Being somewhat delicate in health , at the age of sixteen he was sent to Southern Europe , for which he at once developed a passion , so that he spent nearly all of the following ten years abroad , at first in Italy , then in Greece , Egypt , Asia Minor , and Palestine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In one of his summers at home he married , to the great disapproval of his father , who objected because of his extreme youth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Deciding to become a painter , he entered the studio of Gerome in Paris , where he enjoyed the life of the artists , but soon found that whatever talent he might have did not lie in that direction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He gives us an account of this in his lively and humorous poem , `` The Happy Artists '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` I scanned the world through printed symbol swart , And through the beggar 's rags I strove to see The inner man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">I looked unceasingly With my cold mind and with my burning heart '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this final line , we have the key to his nature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Few writers have better understood their deepest selves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Heidenstam could never be satisfied by surface .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It may , however , be noted that his gift for color and imagery must have been greatly stimulated by his stay in Paris .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first result of Heidenstam 's long sojourn abroad was a volume of poems , Pilgrimage and Wander Years ( Vallfart och vandringsar ) , published in 1888 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was a brilliant debut , so much so indeed that it aroused a new vitality in the younger poets , as did Byron 's Childe Harold .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Professor Fredrik Bo ^ o ^ k , Sweden 's foremost critic of the period , acclaims it as follows : `` In this we have the verse of a painter ; strongly colorful , plastic , racy , vivid .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In a bold , sometimes careless , form there is nothing academic ; all is seen and felt and experienced , the observation is sharp and the imagination lively .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The young poet painter reproduces the French life of the streets ; he tells stories of the Thousand and One Nights , and conjures up before us the bazaars of Damascus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In the care-free indolence of the East he sees the last reflection of the old happy existence , and for that reason he loves it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And yet amid all the gay hedonism in Pilgrimage and Wander-Years is a cycle of short poems , '' Thoughts in Loneliness `` , filled with brooding , melancholy , and sombre longing '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of the longer pieces of the volume none is so memorable as `` Nameless and Immortal '' , which at once took rank among the finest poems ever written in the Swedish language .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It celebrates the unknown architect who designed the temple of Neptune at Paestum , next to the Parthenon the noblest example of Grecian classic style now in existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the eve of his return to their native Naxos he speaks with his wife of the masterpiece which rises before them in its completed perfection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The supreme object of their lives is now fulfilled , says the wife , her husband has achieved immortality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Not so , he answers , it is not the architect but the temple that is immortal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` The man 's true reputation is his work '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The short poems grouped at the end of the volume as `` Thoughts in Loneliness '' is , as Professor Bo ^ o ^ k indicated , in sharp contrast with the others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It consists of fragmentary personal revelations , such as `` The Spark '' :
`` There is a spark dwells deep within my soul .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To get it out into the daylight 's glow Is my life 's aim both first and last , the whole .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It slips away , it burns and tortures me .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">That little spark is all the wealth I know , That little spark is my life 's misery '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A dominant motive is the poet 's longing for his homeland and its boyhood associations : `` Not men folk , but the fields where I would stray , The stones where as a child I used to play '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is utterly disappointed in himself and in the desultory life he has been leading .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">What he really wants is to find `` a sacred cause '' to which he can honestly devote himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This restless individualism found its answer when he returned to live nearly all the rest of his life in Sweden .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His cause was to commemorate the glory of her past and to incite her people to perpetuate it in the present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He did not , however , find himself at once .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">His next major work , completed in 1892 , was a long fantastic epic in prose , entitled Hans Alienus , which Professor Bo ^ o ^ k describes as a monument on the grave of his carefree and indolent youth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The hero , who is himself , is represented as a pilgrim in the storied lands of the East , a sort of Faustus type , who , to quote from Professor Bo ^ o ^ k again , `` even in the pleasure gardens of Sardanapalus can not cease from his painful search after the meaning of life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is driven back by his yearning to the wintry homeland of his fathers in the forest of Tiveden '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From this time on Heidenstam proceeded to find his deeper self .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">By the death of his father in 1888 he had come into possession of the family estate and had re-assumed its traditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He did not , however , settle back into acquiescence with things as they were .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Like his friend and contemporary August Strindberg he had little patience with collective mediocrity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He saw Sweden as a country of smug and narrow provincialism , indifferent to the heroic spirit of its former glory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Strindberg 's remedy for this condition was to tear down the old structures and build anew from the ground up .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Heidenstam 's conception , on the contrary , was to revive the present by the memories of the past .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Whether in prose or poetry , all of Heidenstam 's later work was concerned with Sweden .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With the first of a group of historical novels , The Charles Men ( Karolinerna ) , published in 1897 - 8 , he achieved the masterpiece of his career .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In scope and power it can only be compared to Tolstoy 's War and Peace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">About one-third as long , it is less intimate and detailed , but better coordinated , more concise and more dramatic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Though it centers around the brilliant and enigmatic figure of Charles 12 , , the true hero is not finally the king himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Hence the title of the book , referring to the soldiers and subjects of the king ; on the fatal battlefield of Poltava , to quote from the novel , `` the wreath he twined for himself slipped down upon his people '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Charles Men consists not of a connected narrative but of a group of short stories , each depicting a special phase of the general subject .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Somewhat uneven in interest for an average reader , eight or ten of these are among the finest of their kind in literature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">They comprise a great variety of scene and interest : grim episodes of war , idyllic interludes , superb canvases of world-shaking events , and delightfully humorous sketches of odd characters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The general effect is tragic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Almost nothing is said of Charles ' spectacular victories , the central theme being the heroic loyalty of the Swedish people to their idolized king in misfortune and defeat .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">To carry out this exalted conception the author has combined the vivid realism and imaginative power we have noticed in his early poetry and carried them out on a grand scale .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His peculiar gift , as had been suggested before , is his intensity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">George Meredith has said that fervor is the core of style .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Of few authors is this more true than of Heidenstam .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Charles Men has a tremendous range of characters , of common folk even more than of major figures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The career of Charles 12 , is obviously very similar to that of Napoleon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His ideal was Alexander of Macedon , as Napoleon 's was Julius Caesar .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His purpose , however , was not to establish an empire , but to assert the principle of divine justice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Each aspired to be a god in human form , but with each it was a different kind of god .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each failed catastrophically in an invasion of Russia and each brought ruin on the country that worshipped him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Each is still glorified as a national hero .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The first half of The Charles Men , ending on the climax of the battle of Poltava in 1709 , is more dramatically coherent than the second .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">After the collapse of that desperate and ill-fated campaign the character of the king degenerated for a time into a futility that was not merely pitiable but often ridiculous .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Like Napoleon , he was the worst of losers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There are , however , some wonderful chapters at the beginning of the second part , concerning the reactions of the Swedes in adversity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Then more than ever before did they show their fortitude and patient cheerfulness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This comes out in `` When the Bells Ring '' , which describes the rallying of the peasants in southern Sweden to repel an invasion by the Danes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In `` The King 's Ride '' , Charles breaks out of a long period of petulance and inertia , regains his old self , escapes from Turkey , and finally reaches his own land after an absence of eighteen years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He finds it in utter misery and desolation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All his people ask for is no more war .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">But he plunges into yet another , this time with Norway , and is killed in an assault on the fortress of Fredrikshall , being only thirty-six years of age when he died .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He had become king at fifteen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Then suddenly there was a tremendous revulsion of popular feeling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From being a hated tyrant and madman he was now the symbol of all that was noblest and best in the history of Sweden .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This is brought out in the next to last chapter of the book , `` A Hero 's Funeral '' , written in the form of an impassioned prose poem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Slowly the procession of warriors and statesmen passes through the snow beside the black water and into the brilliantly lighted cathedral , the shrine of so many precious memories .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The guns are fired , the hymns are sung , and the body of Charles is carried down to the vault and laid beside the tombs of his ancestors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As he had longed to be , he became the echo of a saga .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Heidenstam wrote four other works of fiction about earlier figures revered in Swedish memory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Excellent in their way , they lack the wide appeal of The Charles Men , and need not detain us here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is different with his volume The Swedes and Their Chieftains ( Svenskarna och deras ho ^ vdingar ) , a history intended for the general reader and particularly suited for high school students .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Admirably written , it is a perfect introduction to Swedish history for readers of other countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some of the earlier episodes have touches of the supernatural , as suited to the legendary background .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These are suggestive of Selma Lagerlo ^ f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Especially touching is the chapter , `` The Little Sister '' , about a king 's daughter who became a nun in the convent of St. Birgitta .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The record teems with romance and adventure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Gustaf Vasa is a superb example , and Charles 10 , , the conqueror of Denmark , hardly less so .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of Gustavus Adolphus and Charles 12 , it is unnecessary to speak .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or handle divorce cases , but his primary function remains what it has always been , to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with those who have not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is from this unpromising background that the fictional private detective was recruited .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The mythological private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential ways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the one hand , he does not work for a large agency , but is almost always self-employed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a free-lance investigator , the fictional detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For this reason , he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure , whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a 9 to 5 routine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other hand , the fictional detective does not break strikes or handle divorce cases ; no client would ever think of asking him to do such things .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Whatever his original assignment , the fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime , usually a murder .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Operating as a one man police force in fact if not in name , he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police themselves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He catches criminals not merely because he is paid to do so ( frequently he does not receive a fee at all ) , but because he enjoys his work , because he firmly believes that murder must be punished .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He is , first and foremost , a defender of public morals , a servant of society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is this curious blend of rugged individualism and public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological detective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By virtue of his self-reliance , his individualism and his freedom from external restraint , the private eye is a perfect embodiment of the middle class conception of liberty , which amounts to doing what you please and let the devil take the hindmost .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the same time , because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal dictates of his society , because he likes to catch criminals , he is in middle class eyes a virtuous man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In this way , the private detective gets the best of two possible worlds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is an individualist but not an anarchist ; he is a public servant but not a cop .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In short , the fictional private eye is a specialized version of Adam Smith 's ideal entrepreneur , the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere promote the public welfare .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the mystery story , as in The Wealth of Nations , individualism and the social good are two sides of the same benevolent coin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is only one catch to this idyllic arrangement :
Adam Smith was wrong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not only did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest number , he ended by destroying himself , by giving birth to monopoly capitalism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The rise of the giant corporations in Western Europe and the United States dates from the period 1880 - 1900 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Now , although the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far as Balzac , Dickens , and Poe , it was not until the closing decades of the 19 th century that the private detective became an established figure in popular fiction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sherlock Holmes , the ancestor of all private eyes , was born during the 1890 s .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus the transformation of Adam Smith 's ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Driven from the marketplace by the course of history , our hero disguises himself as a private detective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The birth of the myth compensates for the death of the ideal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even on the fictional level , however , the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully resolved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The individualism and public service of the private detective both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct : he enforces the law without being told to do so .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The private eye is therefore a moral man ; but his morality rests upon that of his society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Unfortunately , this assumption does not always hold good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">As capitalism in the 20 th century has become increasingly dependent upon force and violence for its survival , the private detective is placed in a serious dilemma .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If he is good , he may not be legal ; if he is legal , he may not be good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is the gradual unfolding and deepening of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution of the mystery story .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With the advent of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle 's Sherlock Holmes , the development of the modern private detective begins .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sherlock Holmes is not merely an individualist ; he is very close to being a mental case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A brief list of the great detective 's little idiosyncrasies would provide Dr. Freud with ample food for thought .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and other refreshing stimulants ; he is prone to semi catatonic trances induced by the playing of the vioiln ; he is a recluse , an incredible egotist , a confirmed misogynist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Holmes rebels against the social conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was in order to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that Holmes became a detective in the first place .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As he informs Watson , `` My life is spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These little problems help me to do so '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Holmes is a public servant , to be sure ; but the society which he serves bores him to tears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The curious relationship between Holmes and Scotland Yard provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric behavior .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with Scotland Yard , Holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality of the police .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They for their part are convinced that Holmes is too `` unorthodox '' and `` theoretical '' to make a good detective .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Why do the police find Holmes `` unorthodox '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the face of it , it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official police routine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Another , more interesting explanation , is hinted at by Watson when he observes on several occasions that Holmes would have made a magnificent criminal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The great detective modestly agrees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Watson 's insight is verified by the mysterious link between Holmes and his arch opponent , Dr. Moriarty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The two men resemble each other closely in their cunning , their egotism , their relentlessness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first series of Sherlock Holmes adventures ends with Holmes and Moriarty grappling together on the edge of a cliff .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They are presumed to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Linked to Holmes even in death , Moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great detective , the image of what our hero might have become were he not a public servant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Just as Holmes the eccentric stands behind Holmes the detective , so Holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the modern English `` whodunnit '' , this insinuation of latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hercule Poirot and Lord Peter Whimsey ( the respective creations of Agatha Christie and Dorothy Sayers ) have retained Holmes ' egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Poirot and his counterparts are perfectly respectable people ; it is true that they are also extremely dull .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Their dedication to the status quo has been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism of a Sherlock Holmes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The latter 's real descendents were unable to take root in England ; they fled from the Victorian parlor and made their way across the stormy Atlantic .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the American `` hardboiled '' detective story of the ' 20 s and ' 30 s , the spirit of the mad genius from Baker Street lives on .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Like Holmes , the American private eye rejects the social conventions of his time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But unlike Holmes , he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Surrounded by crime and violence everywhere , the `` hardboiled '' private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed isolation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">His alienation is far more acute than Holmes ' ; he is not an eccentric but rather an outcast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">With Rex Stout 's Nero Wolfe , alienation is represented on a purely physical plane .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wolfe refuses to ever leave his own house , and spends most of his time drinking beer and playing with orchids .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">More profound and more disturbing , however , is the moral isolation of Raymond Chandler 's Philip Marlowe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In a society where everything is for sale , Marlowe is the only man who cannot be bought .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His tough honesty condemns him to a solitary and difficult existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Beaten , bruised and exhausted , he pursues the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low morals , always alone , always despised .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the end , he gets his man , but no one seems to care ; virtue is its own and only reward .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A similar tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers of Eric Ambler and dominates the most famous of all American mystery stories , Dashiell Hammett 's The Maltese Falcon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sam Spade joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled statue of a falcon ; but when the bird is found at last , it turns out to be a fake .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Now the detective must save his own skin by informing on the girl he loves , who is also the real murderer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For Sam Spade , neither crime nor virtue pays ; moreover , it is increasingly difficult to distinguish between the two .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Because the private eye intends to save society in spite of himself , he invariably finds himself in trouble with the police .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The latter are either too stupid to catch the killer or too corrupt to care .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In either case , they do not appreciate the private detective 's zeal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Perry Mason and Hamilton Burger , Nero Wolfe and Inspector Cramer spend more time fighting each other than they do in looking for the criminal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Frequently enough , the police are themselves in league with the killer ; Dashiell Hammett 's Red Harvest provides a classic example of this theme .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But even when the police are honest , they do not trust the private eye .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is , like Phillip Marlowe , too alienated to be reliable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Finally , in The Maltese Falcon among others , the clash between detective and police is carried to its logical conclusion : Sam Spade becomes the chief murder suspect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In order to exonerate himself , he is compelled to find the real criminal , who happens to be his girl friend .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What was only a vague suspicion in the case of Sherlock Holmes now appears as a direct accusation : the private eye is in danger of turning into his opposite .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is the growing contradiction between individualism and public service in the mystery story which creates this fatal dilemma .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By upholding his own personal code of behavior , the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">That society responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo , a potential criminal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If the detective insists upon retaining his personal standards , he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He must , in short , cease to be a detective and become a rebel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the other hand , if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession , he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Dashiell Hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write mystery stories and turning to other pursuits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His successors have adopted the opposite alternative .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In order to save the mystery story , they have converted the private detective into an organization man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by Mickey Spillane 's Mike Hammer .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in an organization determine the type of network required , because the type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages enumerated in Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Great stress is placed on the role that the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness of the network .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">By monitoring , we mean some system of control over the types of information sent from the various centers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As a word of caution , we should be aware that in actual practice no message is purely one of the four types , question , command , statement , or exclamation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For example , suppose a man wearing a $ 200 watch , driving a 1959 Rolls Royce , stops to ask a man on the sidewalk , `` What time is it '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This sentence would have most of the characteristics of a question , but it has some of the characteristics of a statement because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in his own timepiece or the one attached to his car .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If the man on the sidewalk is surprised at this question , it has served as an exclamation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Also , since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer ( and thereby avoid the consequences of being thought queer ) the question has assumed some measurable properties of a command .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , for convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified according to Table 1 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On this basis , certain extreme kinds of networks will be discussed for illustrative purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host 's desire to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy for future cooperative endeavors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The party is usually in a room small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The information is furnished by each of the guests , is sent by oral broadcasting over the air waves , and is received by the ears .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since the air is a continuum , the network of communication remains intact regardless of the positions or motions of the points ( the people ) in the net .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As shown in Figure 1 , there is a connection for communication between every pair of points .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This , and other qualifications , make the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication system ever dreamed up .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">All four types of message listed in Table 1 are permitted , although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding the commands to a minimum , while exclamations having complimentary intonations are more than customarily encouraged .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The completeness of the connections provide that , for N people , there are * * f lines of communication between the pairs , which can become a large number ( 1225 ) for a party of fifty guests .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Looking at the diagram , we see that * * f connection lines come in to each member .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Thus the cocktail party would appear to be the ideal system , but there is one weakness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group , the * * f incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond comprehension if N exceeds about six .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The crowd consequently breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six , with a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers , then the `` open house '' system is advantageous because the honored guests are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections at the door .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We consider a rural community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary for family subsistence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We assume for this illustration that the size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication is between nearest neighbors only , as shown in Figure 2 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Information beyond nearest neighbor is carried second - , third - , and fourth hand as a distortable rumor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In Figure 2 , the points in the network are designated by a letter accompanied by a number .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The numbers indicate the number of nearest neighbors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It will be noted that point f has seven nearest neighbors , h and e have six , and p has only one , while the remaining points have intermediate numbers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In any social system in which communications have an importance comparable with that of production and other human factors , a point like f in Figure 2 would ( other things being equal ) be the dwelling place for the community leader , while e and h would house the next most important citizens .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A point like p gets information directly from n , but all information beyond n is indirectly relayed through n .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The dweller at p is last to hear about a new cure , the slowest to announce to his neighbors his urgent distresses , the one who goes the farthest to trade , and the one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or getting people to join him in a cooperative effort .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the hazards of poor communication are so great , p can be justified as a habitable site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made available by a waterfall for milling purposes , a mine , or a sugar maple camp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Location theorists have given these matters much consideration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The networks for military communications are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the addition of new machines of war .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They also furnish proof that , in modern war , message sending must be monitored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Without monitoring , a military hookup becomes a noisy party .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The need for monitoring became greater when radio was adopted for military signaling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Alexander the Great , who used runners as message carriers , did not have to worry about having every officer in his command hear what he said and having hundreds of them comment at once .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">As time has passed and science has progressed , the speed of military vehicles has increased , the range of missiles has been extended , the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles has been adopted , and the range and breadth of message sending has increased .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Next to the old problem of the slowness of decision making , network structure seems to be paramount , and without monitoring no network has value .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On the parade ground the net may be similar to that shown in Figure 3 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The monitoring is the highest and most restrictive of any organization in existence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">No questions , statements , or explanations are permitted - only commands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Commands go only from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The same command is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to corporal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All orders originate with the officer of highest rank and terminate with action of the men in the ranks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Even the officer in charge , be it a captain ( for small display ) or a general , is restrained by monitoring .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The commands are specified by the military regulations ; are few in number , briefly worded , all different in sound ; and are combinable into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be desired on a parade ground .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This monitoring is necessary because , on a parade ground , everyone can hear too much , and without monitoring a confused social event would develop .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With troops dispersed on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground , it may seem that a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines of communication .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Years ago this was true , but with the replacement of wires or runners by radio and radar ( and perhaps television ) , these restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In contrast to cocktail parties , military organizations , even in the field , are more formal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the extreme and oversimplified example suggested in Figure 3 , the organization is more easily understood and more predictable in behavior .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A military organization has an objective chosen by the higher command .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This objective is adhered to throughout the duration of the action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The connective system , or network , is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective , and it is therefore not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated unit has a different communication network than a factory , a college , or a rural village .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The assumptions upon which the example shown in Figure 3 is based are : ( a ) One man can direct about six subordinates if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not need too much personal coaching , indoctrinating , etc. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">( b ) A message runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more than about six consecutive times .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( c ) Decisions of a general kind are made by the central command .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And ( d ) all action of a physical kind pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower rank .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the top , six directly under him , six under each of these , and so on until there are six levels of personnel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The number of people acting as one body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of * * f 55987 men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This organizational network would be of no avail if there were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of types of message listed in Table 1 , commands and statements are the only ones sent through the vertical network shown in Figure 3 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A further regulation is that commands always go down , unaccompanied by statements , and statements always go up , unaccompanied by commands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Questions and , particularly , exclamations are usually channeled along informal , horizontal lines not indicated in Figure 3 and seldom are carried beyond the nearest neighbor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It will readily be seen that in this suggested network ( not materially different from some of the networks in vogue today ) greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than is usually put into practice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Furthermore , the network in Figure 3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics and the like are interlaced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Not discussed here are some military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare , where the surveillance , sending , transmitting , and receiving are all so inadequate that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Such problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they could teach .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is an unsolved problem which probably has never been seriously investigated , although one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists of the kind who can compete with the Germans or Swiss , for example , in precision machinery and mathematics , or the Finns in geochemistry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This problem of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Since the difficulty of drawing the net is great , we will merely discuss it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">First , we realize that a pure specialist does not exist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But , for practical purposes , we have people who can be considered as such .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For example , there are persons who are in physical science , in the field of mineralogy , trained in crystallography , who use only X-rays , applying only the powder technique of X-ray diffraction , to clay minerals only , and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating on the montmorillonites ; or persons in the social sciences in the field of anthropology , studying the lung capacity of seven Andean Indians .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">So we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more about less and less as he develops , as contrasted to the generalist , who knows less and less about more and more .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">American democratic thought , pointed up the relation between the Protestant movement in this country and the development of a social religion , which he called the American Democratic Faith .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Those familiar with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the democratic faith at around 1850 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And he describes it as a balanced polarity between the notions of the free individual and what he called the fundamental law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I want to say more about Gabriel 's so-called fundamental law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But first I want to quote him on the relationship that he found between religion and politics in this country and what happened to it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He points out that from the time of Jackson on through World War 1 , , evangelical Protestantism was a dominant influence in the social and political life of America .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He terms this early enthusiasm `` Romantic Christianity '' and concludes that its similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that `` the doctrine of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical Protestantism '' .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He specifies , `` In the middle period of the Nineteenth Century it was colored by Christian supernaturalism , in the Twentieth Century it was affected by naturalism .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And let me add , utopianism , also .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">During the decade that followed , the common man , as that piece put it , grew uncomfortable as the Voice of God and fled from behind Saint Woodrow ( Wilson ) only to learn from Science , to his shocked relief that after all there was no God he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow - that there was a chemical formula for him , and that too much could n't be expected of him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The socialism implicit in the slogan of the Roosevelt Revolution , freedom from want and fear , seems a far cry from the individualism of the First Amendment to the Constitution , or of the Jacksonian frontier .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What had happened to the common man ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">French Egalitarianism had had only nominal influence in this country before the days of Popularism .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The riotous onrush of industrialism after the War for Southern Independence and the general secular drift to the Religion of Humanity , however , prepared the way for a reception of the French Revolution 's socialistic offspring of one sort of another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first of which to find important place in our federal government was the graduated income tax under Wilson .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920 s , the dislocations of the Depression , the common ethos of Materialism everywhere , all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced Mike Fink and the Great Gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy of the Little People .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , it is important to trace the philosophy of the French Revolution to its sources to understand the common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence of the latter on the former .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">That John Locke 's philosophy of the social contract fathered the American Revolution with its Declaration of Independence , I believe , we generally accept .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Yet , after Rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion of the General Will , the same philosophy , it may be said , became the idea source of the French Revolution also .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The importance of Rousseau 's twist has not always been clear to us , however .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This notion of the General Will gave rise to the Commune of Paris in the Revolution and later brought Napoleon to dictatorship .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They have an ancestry extending back , however , at least to 1728 , when William Byrd described the Lubberlanders he encountered in the back country of Virginia and North Carolina .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The chief literary antecedents of the Snopes clan appeared in the realistic , humorous writing which originated in the South and the Southwest in the three decades before the Civil War .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These narratives of coarse action and crude language appeared first in local newspapers , as a rule , and later found their way between book covers , though rarely into the planters ' libraries beside the morocco bound volumes of Horace , Mr. Addison , Mr. Pope , and Sir Walter Scott .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There is evidence to suggest , in fact , that many authors of the humorous sketches were prompted to write them - or to make them as indelicate as they are - by way of protesting against the artificial refinements which had come to dominate the polite letters of the South .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">William Gilmore Simms , sturdy realist that he was , pleaded for a natural robustness such as he found in his favorites the great Elizabethans , to vivify the pale writings being produced around him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Simms admired the raucous tales emanating from the backwoods , but he had himself social affiliations which would not allow him to approve them fully .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Augustus Baldwin Longstreet , a preacher and a college and university president in four Southern states , published the earliest of these backwoods sketches and in the character Ransy Sniffle , in the accounts of sharp horse-trading and eye gouging physical combat , and in the shockingly unliterary speech of his characters , he set an example followed by many after him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Others who wrote of low characters and low life included Thomas Bangs Thorpe , creator of the Big Bear of Arkansas and Tom Owen , the Bee-Hunter ; Johnson Jones Hooper , whose character Simon Suggs bears a close kinship to Flem Snopes in both his willingness to take cruel advantage of all and sundry and the sharpness with which he habitually carried out his will ; and George Washington Harris , whose Tennessee hillbilly character Sut Lovingood perpetrated more unmalicious mischief and more unintended pain than any other character in literature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It would be profitable , I believe , to read these realistic humorists alongside Faulkner 's works , the thought being not that he necessarily read them and owed anything to them directly , but rather that they dealt a hundred years ago with a class of people and a type of life which have continued down to our time , to Faulkner 's time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such a comparison reminds us that in employing low characters in his works Faulkner is recording actuality in the South and moreover is following a long established literary precedent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Such characters , with their low existence and often low morality , produce humorous effects in his novels and tales , as they did in the writing of Longstreet and Hooper and Harris , but it need not be added that he gives them far subtler and more intricate functions than they had in the earlier writers ; nor is there need to add that among them are some of the most highly individualized and most successful of his characters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One of the early humorists already mentioned , Thomas Bangs Thorpe , can be used to illustrate another point where Faulkner touches authentic Southern materials and also earlier literary treatment of those materials .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thorpe came to Louisiana from the East as a young man prepared to find in the new country the setting of romantic adventure and idealized beauty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But Thorpe saw also the hardships of pioneer existence , the cultural poverty of the frontier settlements , and the slack morality which abounded in the new regions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As a consequence of the tensions thus produced in his thoughts and feelings , he wrote on the one hand sketches of idealized hunting trips and on the other an anecdote of the village of Hardscrabble , Arkansas , where no one had ever seen a piano ; and he wrote also the masterpiece of frontier humor , `` The Big Bear of Arkansas '' , in which earthy realism is placed alongside the exaggeration of the backwoods tall-tale and the awe with which man contemplates the grandeur and the mysteries of nature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Henrietta 's feeling of identity with Sara Sullam was crowned by her discovery of the coincidence that Sara 's epitaph in the Jewish cemetery in Venice referred to her as `` the Sulamite '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Into the texture of this tapestry of history and human drama Henrietta , as every artist delights to do , wove strands of her own intuitive insights into human nature and - especially in the remarkable story of the attraction and conflict between two so disparate and fervent characters as this pair - into the relations of men and women : `` In their relations , she was the giver and he the receiver , nay the demander .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His feeling always exacted sacrifices from her .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One is so accustomed to think of men as the privileged who need but ask and receive , and women as submissive and yielding , that our sympathies are usually enlisted on the side of the man whose love is not returned , and we condemn the woman as a coquette .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The very firmness of her convictions and logical clearness of her arguments captivated and stimulated him to make greater efforts ; usually , this is most exasperating to men , who expect every woman to verify their preconceived notions concerning her sex , and when she does not , immediately condemn her as eccentric and unwomanly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">She had the opportunity that few clever women can resist , of showing her superiority in argument over a man .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Women themselves have come to look upon matters in the same light as the outside world , and scarcely find any wrong in submitting to the importunities of a stronger will , even when their affections are withheld .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">She was exposing herself to temptation which it is best to avoid where it can consistently be done .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One who invites such trials of character is either foolhardy , overconfident or too simple and childlike in faith in mankind to see the danger .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In any case but the last , such a course is sure to avenge itself upon the individual ; the moral powers no more than the physical and mental , can bear overstraining .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And , in the last case , a bitter disappointment but too often meets the confiding nature '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Henrietta was discovering in the process of writing , as the born writer does , not merely a channel for the discharge of accumulated information but a stimulus to the development of the creative powers of observation , insight and intuition .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dr. Isaacs was so pleased with the quality of her biographical study of Sara Sullam that he considered submitting it to the Century Magazine or Harper 's but he decided that its Jewish subject probably would not interest them and published it in The Messenger , `` so our readers will be benefited instead '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Under her father 's influence it did not occur to Henrietta that she might write on subjects outside the Jewish field , but she did begin writing for other Anglo Jewish papers and thus increased her output and her audience .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By her eighteenth birthday her bent for writing was so evident that Papa and Mamma gave her a Life of Dickens as a spur to her aspiration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another source of intellectual stimulus was opened to her at that time by the founding of Johns Hopkins University within walking distance of home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It was established in a couple of buildings in the shopping district , with only a few professors , but all eminent men , and a few hundred eager students housed in nearby dwellings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In September ' 76 Thomas Huxley , Darwin 's famous disciple , came from England to speak in a crowded auditorium at the formal opening of the University ; and although it was a school for men only , it afforded Henrietta an opportunity to attend its public lectures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the following year her father undertook to give a course in Hebrew theology to Johns Hopkins students , and this brought to the Szold house a group of bright young Jews who had come to Baltimore to study , and who enjoyed being fed and mothered by Mamma and entertained by Henrietta and Rachel , who played and sang for them in the upstairs sitting room on Sunday evenings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">From Philadelphia came Cyrus Adler and Joseph Jastrow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Adler , Judge Sulzberger 's nephew , came to study Assyriology .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A smart , shrewd and ambitious young man , well connected , and with a knack for getting in the good graces of important people , he was bound to go far .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Joseph Jastrow , the younger son of the distinguished rabbi , Marcus Jastrow , was a friendly , round-faced fellow with a little mustache , whose field was psychology , and who was also a punster and a jolly tease .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His father was a good friend of Rabbi Szold , and Joe lived with the Szolds for a while .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Both these youths , who greatly admired Henrietta , were somewhat younger than she , as were also the neighboring Friedenwald boys , who were then studying medicine ; and bright though they all were , they could not possibly compete for her interest with Papa , whose mind - although he never tried to dazzle or patronize lesser lights with it - naturally eclipsed theirs and made them seem to her even younger than they were .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Besides , Miss Henrietta - as she was generally known since she had put up her hair with a chignon in the back - had little time to spare them from her teaching and writing ; so Cyrus Adler became interested in her friend Racie Friedenwald , and Joe Jastrow - the only young man who when he wrote had the temerity to address her as Henrietta , and signed himself Joe - fell in love with pretty sister Rachel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Henrietta , however , was at that time engaged in a lengthy correspondence with Joe 's older and more serious brother , Morris , who was just about her own age and whom she had got to know well during trips to Philadelphia with Papa , when he substituted for Rabbi Jastrow at Rodeph Shalom Temple there during its Rabbi 's absence in Europe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Young Morris , who , while attending the University of Pennsylvania , also taught and edited a paper , found time to write Henrietta twenty page letters on everything that engaged his interest , from the acting of Sarah Bernhardt in Philadelphia to his reactions to the comments of `` Sulamith '' on the Jewish reform movement being promulgated by the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Unlike his younger brother , Joe , he never presumed to address her more familiarly than as `` My dear friend '' , although he praised and envied the elegance and purity of her style .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">And when he complained of the lack of time for all he wanted to do , Henrietta advised him to rise at five in the morning as she and Papa did .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One thing Papa had not taught Henrietta was how to handle a young man as high-spirited and opinionated as herself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">She could not resist the opportunity `` of showing her superiority in argument over a man '' which she had remarked as one of the `` feminine follies '' of Sara Sullam ; and in her forthright way , Henrietta , who in her story of Sara had indicated her own unwillingness `` to think of men as the privileged '' and `` women as submissive and yielding '' , felt obliged to defend vigorously any statement of hers to which Morris Jastrow took the slightest exception - he objected to her stand on the Corbin affair , as well as on the radical reforms of Dr. Wise of Hebrew Union College - until once , in sheer desperation , he wrote that he had given up hope they would ever agree on anything .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But that did not prevent him from writing more long letters , or from coming to spend his Christmas vacations with the hospitable , lively Szolds in their pleasant house on Lombard Street .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">`` We 've got Father and Mother and each other , '' said Beth on the first page of Louisa Alcott 's Little Women ; and , `` I do think that families are the most beautiful things in all the world '' , burst out Jo some five hundred pages later in that popular story of the March family , which had first appeared when Henrietta was eight ; and the Szold family , as it developed , bore a striking resemblance to the Marches .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mr. March , like Benjamin Szold , was a clergyman , although of an indeterminate denomination ; and `` Marmee '' March , like Sophie Szold , was the competent manager of her brood of girls , of whom the Marches had only four to the Szolds ' five .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the March girls had their counterparts in the Szold girls .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Each was her mother 's assistant and confidante ; and each stood out conspicuously in the family picture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Bertha Szold was more like Meg , the eldest March girl , who `` learned that a woman 's happiest kingdom is home , her highest honor the art of ruling it , not as a queen , but a wise wife and mother '' .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When her right hand was incapacitated by the rheumatism , Sadie learned to write with her left hand .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The Szolds , like the Marches , enjoyed and loved living together , even in troubled times ; and , as in the March home , any young man who called on the Szolds found himself confronted with a phalanx of femininity which made it rather difficult to direct his particular attention to any one of them .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And just as `` Laurie '' Lawrence was first attracted to bright Jo March , who found him immature by her high standards , and then had to content himself with her younger sister Amy , so Joe Jastrow , who had also been writing Henrietta before he came to Johns Hopkins , had to content himself with her younger sister , pretty Rachel .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When Harold Arlen returned to California in the winter of 1944 , it was to take up again a collaboration with Johnny Mercer , begun some years before .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Mercer is supposed to have refused it with , `` Anyone who wears a square monocle must be affected '' !</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For him Mercer produced the lyric to `` Out of Breath Scared to Death of You '' , introduced in that most successful of all the Gaieties , by Sterling Holloway .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Entrance into such stellar song writing company encouraged the burgeoning song writer to take a wife , Elizabeth Meehan , a dancer in the Gaieties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Mercers took up residence in Brooklyn , and Mercer found a regular job in Wall Street `` misplacing stocks and bonds '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">When he heard that Paul Whiteman was looking for singers to replace the Rhythm Boys , Mercer applied and got the job , `` not for my voice , I 'm sure , but because I could write songs and material generally '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While with the Whiteman band Mercer met Jerry Arlen .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He had yet to meet Harold Arlen , for although they had `` collaborated '' on `` Satan 's Li ' l Lamb '' , Mercer and Harburg had worked from a lead sheet the composer had furnished them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The lyric , Mercer remembers , was tailored to fit the unusual melody .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Mercer 's Whiteman association brought him into contact with Hoagy Carmichael , whose `` Snowball '' Mercer relyriced as `` Lazybones '' , in which form it became a hit and marked the real beginning of Mercer 's song writing career .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After leaving Whiteman , Mercer joined the Benny Goodman band as a vocalist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With the help of Ziggy Elman , also in the band , he transformed a traditional Jewish melody into a popular song , `` And the Angels Sing '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The countrywide success of `` Lazybones '' and `` And the Angels Sing '' could only lead to Hollywood , where , besides Harold Arlen , Mercer collaborated with Harry Warren , Jimmy Van Heusen , Richard Whiting , Walter Donaldson , Jerome Kern , and Arthur Schwartz .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Mercer has also written both music and lyrics for several songs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He may be the only song writer ever to have collaborated with a secretary of the U. S. Treasury ; he collaborated on a song with William Hartman Woodin , who was Secretary of the Treasury , 1932 - 33 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When Johnny Mercer and Harold Arlen began their collaboration in 1940 , Mercer , like Arlen , had several substantial film songs to his credit , among them `` Hooray for Hollywood '' , `` Ride , Tenderfoot , Ride '' , `` Have You Got Any Castles , Baby ? ''</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">, and `` Too Marvelous for Words '' ( all with Richard Whiting ) ; with Harry Warren he did `` The Girl Friend of the Whirling Dervish '' , `` Jeepers Creepers '' , and `` You Must Have Been a Beautiful Baby '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Mercer 's lyrics are characterized by an unerring ear for rhythmic nuances , a puckish sense of humor expressed in language with a colloquial flair .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Though versatile and capable of turning out a ballad lyric with the best of them , Mercer 's forte is a highly polished quasi folk wit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His casual , dreamlike working methods , often as not in absentia , were an abrupt change from Harburg 's , so that Arlen had to adjust again to another approach to collaboration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There were times that he worked with both lyricists simultaneously .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Speaking of his work with Johnny Mercer , Arlen says , `` Our working habits were strange .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I would n't hear from him for a couple of weeks , then he 'd come around with the completed lyric '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Arlen is one of the few ( possibly the only ) composer Mercer has been able to work with so closely , for they held their meetings in Arlen 's study .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While Arlen and Mercer collaborated on Hot Nocturne , Mercer worked also with Arthur Schwartz on another film , Navy Blues .</MPQASENT>
