<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Important considerations common to each type of shelter are :
Arrangement of the entrance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Ventilation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Radio reception .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Lighting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The entrance must have at least one right-angle turn .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Radiation scatters somewhat like light .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Some will go around a corner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The rest continues in a straight line .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore , sharp turns in a shelter entrance will reduce radiation intensity inside the shelter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Ventilation is provided in a concrete block basement shelter by vents in the wall and by the open entrance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A blower may be installed to increase comfort .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A blower is essential for the double wall shelter and for the underground shelters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It should provide not less than 5 cubic feet per minute of air per person .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Vent pipes also are necessary ( as shown in figs.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">9 , 10 , and 11 ) , but filters are not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Radio reception is cut down by the shielding necessary to keep out radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As soon as the shelter is completed a radio reception check must be made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It probably will be necessary to install an outside antenna , particularly to receive CONELRAD broadcasts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Lighting is an important consideration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Continuous low-level lighting may be provided in the shelter by means of a 4 - cell hot-shot battery to which is wired a 150 - milliampere flashlight type bulb .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tests have shown that such a device , with a fresh battery , will furnish light continuously for at least 10 days .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With a spare battery , a source of light for 2 weeks or more would be assured .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A flashlight or electric lantern also should be available for those periods when a brighter light is needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There should be a regular electrical outlet in the shelter as power may continue in many areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other considerations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">- If there are outside windows in the basement corner where you build a shelter , they should be shielded as shown in the Appendix , page 29 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other basement windows should be blocked when an emergency threatens .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Basement walls that project above the ground should be shielded as shown in the Appendix , page 29 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In these shelters the entrance should be not more than 2 feet wide .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Bunks , or materials to build them , may have to be put inside the enclosure before the shelter walls are completed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The basement or belowground shelters also will serve for tornado or hurricane protection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The radioactivity of fallout decays rapidly at first .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Forty-nine hours after an atomic burst the radiation intensity is only about 1 percent of what it was an hour after the explosion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But the radiation may be so intense at the start that one percent may be extremely dangerous .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore , civil defense instructions received over CONELRAD or by other means should be followed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A battery powered radio is essential .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Radiation instruments suitable for home use are available , and would be of value in locating that portion of the home which offers the best protection against fallout radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is a possibility that battery powered radios with built-in radiation meters may become available .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One instrument thus would serve both purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Your local civil defense will gather its own information and will receive broad information from State and Federal sources .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It will tell you as soon as possible :
How long to stay in your shelter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How soon you may go outdoors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How long you may stay outside .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">You should be prepared to stay in your shelter full time for at least several days and to make it your home for 14 days or longer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A checklist in the Appendix , ( page 30 ) tells what is needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Families with children will have particular problems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They should provide for simple recreation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There should be a task for everyone and these tasks should be rotated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Part of the family should be sleeping while the rest is awake .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">To break the monotony it may be necessary to invent tasks that will keep the family busy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Records such as diaries can be kept .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The survival of the family will depend largely on information received by radio .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A record should be kept of the information and instructions , including the time and date of broadcast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Family rationing probably will be necessary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Blowers should be operated periodically on a regular schedule .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There will come a time in a basement shelter when the radiation has decayed enough to allow use of the whole basement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , as much time as possible should be spent within the shelter to hold radiation exposure to a minimum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The housekeeping problems of living in a shelter will begin as soon as the shelter is occupied .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Food , medical supplies , utensils , and equipment , if not already stored in the shelter , must be quickly gathered up and carried into it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After the family has settled in the shelter , the housekeeping rules should be spelled out by the adult in charge .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sanitation in the confines of the family shelter will require much thought and planning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Provision for emergency toilet facilities and disposal of human wastes will be an unfamiliar problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A covered container such as a kitchen garbage pail might do as a toilet .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A 10 - gallon garbage can , with a tightly fitting cover , could be used to keep the wastes until it is safe to leave the shelter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Water rationing will be difficult and should be planned carefully .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A portable electric heater is advisable for shelters in cold climates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It would take the chill from the shelter in the beginning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even if the electric power fails after an attack , any time that the heater has been used will make the shelter that much more comfortable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Body heat in the close quarters will help keep up the temperature .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Warm clothing and bedding , of course , are essential .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Open flame heating or cooking should be avoided .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A flame would use up air .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Some families already have held weekend rehearsals in their home shelters to learn the problems and to determine for themselves what supplies they would need .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Few areas , if any , are as good as prepared shelters but they are worth knowing about .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A family dwelling without a basement provides some natural shielding from fallout radiation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the ground floor the radiation would be about half what it is outside .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The best protection would be on the ground floor in the central part of the house .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A belowground basement can cut the fallout radiation to one tenth of the outside level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The safest place is the basement corner least exposed to windows and deepest below ground .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If there is time after the warning , the basement shielding could be improved substantially by blocking windows with bricks , dirt , books , magazines , or other heavy material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Large apartment buildings of masonry or concrete provide better natural shelter than the usual family dwellings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In general , such apartments afford more protection than smaller buildings because their walls are thick and there is more space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The central area of the ground floor of a heavily constructed apartment building , with concrete floors , should provide more fallout protection than the ordinary basement of a family dwelling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The basement of such an apartment building may provide as much natural protection as the specially constructed concrete block shelter recommended for the basement of a family dwelling .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Federal Government is aiding local governments in several places to survey residential , commercial and industrial buildings to determine what fallout protection they would provide , and for how many people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The problem for the city apartment dweller is primarily to plan the use of existing space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Such planning will require the cooperation of other occupants and of the apartment management .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A former du Pont official became a General Motors vice president and set about maximizing du Pont 's share of the General Motors market .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Lines of communications were established between the two companies and several du Pont products were actively promoted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Within a few years various du Pont manufactured items were filling the entire requirements of from four to seven of General Motors ' eight operating divisions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Fisher Body division , long controlled by the Fisher brothers under a voting trust even though General Motors owned a majority of its stock , followed an independent course for many years , but by 1947 and 1948 `` resistance had collapsed '' and its purchases from du Pont `` compared favorably '' with purchases by other General Motors divisions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Competitors came to receive higher percentage of General Motors business in later years , but it is `` likely '' that this trend stemmed `` at least in part '' from the needs of General Motors outstripping du Pont 's capacity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">`` The fact that sticks out in this voluminous record is that the bulk of du Pont 's production has always supplied the largest part of the requirements of the one customer in the automobile industry connected to du Pont by a stock interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The inference is overwhelming that du Pont 's commanding position was promoted by its stock interest and was not gained solely on competitive merit '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">353 U. S. , at 605 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This Court agreed with the trial court `` that considerations of price , quality and service were not overlooked by either du Pont or General Motors '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">353 U. S. , at 606 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">However , it determined that neither this factor , nor `` the fact that all concerned in high executive posts in both companies acted honorably and fairly , each in the honest conviction that his actions were in the best interests of his own company and without any design to overreach anyone , including du Pont 's competitors '' , 353 U. S. , at 607 , outweighed the Government 's claim for relief .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This claim , as submitted to the District Court and dismissed by it , 126 F. Supp .235 , alleged violation not only of 7 of the Clayton Act , but also of 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The latter provisions proscribe any contract , combination , or conspiracy in restraint of interstate or foreign trade , and monopolization of , or attempts , combinations , or conspiracies to monopolize , such trade .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , this Court put to one side without consideration the Government 's appeal from the dismissal of its Sherman Act allegations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It rested its decision solely on 7 , which reads in pertinent part : `` [ N ] o corporation engaged in commerce shall acquire , directly or indirectly , the whole or any part of the stock or other share capital of another corporation engaged also in commerce , where the effect of such acquisition may be to substantially lessen competition between the corporation whose stock is so acquired and the corporation making the acquisition , or to restrain such commerce in any section or community , or tend to create a monopoly of any line of commerce .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This section shall not apply to corporations purchasing such stock solely for investment and not using the same by voting or otherwise to bring about , or in attempting to bring about , the substantial lessening of competition `` .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The purpose of this provision was thus explained in the Court 's opinion : `` Section 7 is designed to arrest in its incipiency not only the substantial lessening of competition from the acquisition by one corporation of the whole or any part of the stock of a competing corporation , but also to arrest in their incipiency restraints or monopolies in a relevant market which , as a reasonable probability , appear at the time of suit likely to result from the acquisition by one corporation of all or any part of the stock of any other corporation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The section is violated whether or not actual restraints or monopolies , or the substantial lessening of competition , have occurred or are intended '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">353 U. S. , at 589 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , a finding of conspiracy to restrain trade or attempt to monopolize was excluded from the Court 's decision .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , as already noted , the Court proceeded on the assumption that the executives involved in the dealings between du Pont and General Motors acted `` honorably and fairly '' and exercised their business judgment only to serve what they deemed the best interests of their own companies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This , however , did not bar finding that du Pont had become pre-eminent as a supplier of automotive fabrics and finishes to General Motors ; that these products constituted a `` line of commerce '' within the meaning of the Clayton Act ; that General Motors ' share of the market for these products was substantial ; and that competition for this share of the market was endangered by the financial relationship between the two concerns :
`` The statutory policy of fostering free competition is obviously furthered when no supplier has an advantage over his competitors from an acquisition of his customer 's stock likely to have the effects condemned by the statute .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We repeat , that the test of a violation of 7 is whether , at the time of suit , there is a reasonable probability that the acquisition is likely to result in the condemned restraints .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The conclusion upon this record is inescapable that such likelihood was proved as to this acquisition '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">353 U. S. , at 607 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the basis of the findings which led to this conclusion , the Court remanded the case to the District Court to determine the appropriate relief .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The sole guidance given the Court for discharging the task committed to it was this : `` The judgment must therefore be reversed and the cause remanded to the District Court for a determination , after further hearing , of the equitable relief necessary and appropriate in the public interest to eliminate the effects of the acquisition offensive to the statute .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The District Courts , in the framing of equitable decrees , are clothed ' with large discretion to model their judgments to fit the exigencies of the particular case ' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">International Salt Co. v. United States , 332 U. S. 392 , 400 - 401 '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">353 U. S. , at 607 - 608 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This brings us to the course of the proceedings in the District Court .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This Court 's judgment was filed in the District Court on July 18 , 1957 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first pretrial conference - held to appoint amici curiae to represent the interest of the stockholders of du Pont and General Motors and to consider the procedure to be followed in the subsequent hearings - took place on September 25 , 1957 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the outset , the Government 's spokesman explained that counsel for the Government and for du Pont had already held preliminary discussions with a view to arriving at a relief plan that both sides could recommend to the court .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Du Pont , he said , had proposed disenfranchisement of its General Motors stock along with other restrictions on the du Pont-General Motors relationship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Government , deeming these suggestions inadequate , had urged that any judgment include divestiture of du Pont 's shares of General Motors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Counsel for the Government invited du Pont 's views on this proposal before recommending a specific program , but stated that if the court desired , or if counsel for du Pont thought further discussion would not be profitable , the Government was prepared to submit a plan within thirty days .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Counsel for du Pont indicated a preference for the submission of detailed plans by both sides at an early date .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No previous antitrust case , he said , had involved interests of such magnitude or presented such complex problems of relief .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The submission of detailed plans would place the issues before the court more readily than would discussion of divestiture or disenfranchisement in the abstract .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Court adopted this procedure with an appropriate time schedule for carrying it out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Government submitted its proposed decree on October 25 , 1957 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The plan called for divestiture by du Pont of its 63000000 shares of General Motors stock by equal annual distributions to its stockholders , as a dividend , over a period of ten years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Christiana Securities Company and Delaware Realty + Investment Company , major stockholders in du Pont , and the stockholders of Delaware were dealt with specially by provisions requiring the annual sale by a trustee , again over a ten year period , of du Pont 's General Motors stock allocable to them , as well as any General Motors stock which Christiana and Delaware owned outright .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If , in the trustee 's judgment , `` reasonable market conditions '' did not prevail during any given year , he was to be allowed to petition the court for an extension of time within the ten year period .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In addition , the right to vote the General Motors stock held by du Pont was to be vested in du Pont 's stockholders , other than Christiana and Delaware and the stockholders of Delaware ; du Pont , Christiana , and Delaware were to be enjoined from acquiring stock in or exercising control over General Motors ; du Pont , Christiana , and Delaware were to be prohibited to have any director or officer in common with General Motors , and vice versa ; and General Motors and du Pont were to be ordered to terminate any agreement that provided for the purchase by General Motors of any specified percentage of its requirements of any du Pont manufactured product , or for the grant of exclusive patent rights , or for a grant by General Motors to du Pont of a preferential right to make or sell any chemical discovery of General Motors , or for the maintenance of any joint commercial enterprise by the two companies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On motion of the amici curiae , the court directed that a ruling be obtained from the Commissioner of Internal Revenue as to the federal income tax consequences of the Government 's plan .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On May 9 , 1958 , the Commissioner announced his rulings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The annual dividends paid to du Pont stockholders in shares of General Motors stock would be taxable as ordinary income to the extent of du Pont 's earnings and profits .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The measure , for federal income tax purposes , of the dividend to individual stockholders would be the fair market value of the shares at the time of each annual distribution .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the case of taxpaying corporate stockholders , the measure would be the lesser of the fair market value of the shares or du Pont 's tax basis for them , which is approximately $ 2.09 per share .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The forced sale of the General Motors stock owned by or allocable to Christiana , Delaware , and the stockholders of Delaware , and deposited with the trustee , would result in a tax to those parties at the capital gains rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Du Pont 's counterproposal was filed on May 14 , 1958 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Under its plan du Pont would retain its General Motors shares but be required to pass on to its stockholders the right to vote those shares .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Christiana and Delaware would , in turn , be required to pass on the voting rights to the General Motors shares allocable to them to their own stockholders .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Du Pont would be enjoined from having as a director , officer , or employee anyone who was simultaneously an officer or employee of General Motors , and no director , officer , or employee of du Pont could serve as a director of General Motors without court approval .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Du Pont would be denied the right to acquire any additional General Motors stock except through General Motors ' distributions of stock or subscription rights to its stockholders .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">On June 6 , 1958 , General Motors submitted its objections to the Government 's proposal .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It argued , inter alia , that a divestiture order would severely depress the market value of the stock of both General Motors and du Pont , with consequent serious loss and hardship to hundreds of thousands of innocent investors , among them thousands of small trusts and charitable institutions ; that there would be a similar decline in the market values of other automotive and chemical stocks , with similar losses to the stockholders of those companies ; that the tremendous volume of General Motors stock hanging over the market for ten years would hamper the efforts of General Motors and other automobile manufacturers to raise equity capital ; and that all this would have a serious adverse effect on the entire stock market and on general business activity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">General Motors comprehensively contended that the Government plan would not be `` in the public interest '' as required by the mandate of this Court .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The decrees proposed by the amici curiae were filed in August of 1958 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These plans , like du Pont 's contained provisions for passing the vote on du Pont 's General Motors shares on to the ultimate stockholders of du Pont , Christiana , and Delaware , except that officers and directors of the three companies , their spouses , and other people living in their households , as well as other specified persons , were to be totally disenfranchised .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Both plans also prohibited common directors , officers , or employees between du Pont , Christiana , and Delaware , on the one hand , and General Motors on the other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not a medieval mental quirk or an attitude `` unnourished by sense '' to believe that husbands and wives should not be subjected to such a risk , or that such a possibility should not be permitted to endanger the confidentiality of the marriage relationship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">While it is easy enough to ridicule Hawkins ' pronouncement in Pleas of the Crown from a metaphysical point of view , the concept of the `` oneness '' of a married couple may reflect an abiding belief that the communion between husband and wife is such that their actions are not always to be regarded by the criminal law as if there were no marriage .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">With this enlarged role in mind , I should like to make a few suggestions : What we in the United States do or do not do will make a very large difference in what happens in the rest of the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We in this Department must think about foreign policy in its total context .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We cannot regard foreign policy as something left over after defense policy or trade policy or fiscal policy has been extracted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Foreign policy is the total involvement of the American people with peoples and governments abroad .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">That means that , if we are to achieve a new standard of leadership , we must think in terms of the total context of our situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is the concern of the Department of State that the American people are safe and secure - defense is not a monopoly concern of the Department of Defense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is also the concern of the Department of State that our trading relationships with the rest of the world are vigorous , profitable , and active - this is not just a passing interest or a matter of concern only to the Department of Commerce .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We can no longer rely on interdepartmental machinery `` somewhere upstairs '' to resolve differences between this and other departments .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Means must be found to enable us to keep in touch as regularly and as efficiently as possible with our colleagues in other departments concerned with foreign policy .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Unless we keep our eyes on the horizon ahead , we shall fail to bring ourselves on target with the present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The movement of events is so fast , the pace so severe , that an attempt to peer into the future is essential if we are to think accurately about the present .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If there is anything which we can do in the executive branch of the Government to speed up the processes by which we come to decisions on matters on which we must act promptly , that in itself would be a major contribution to the conduct of our affairs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Action taken today is often far more valuable than action taken several months later in response to a situation then out of control .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We want to stimulate ideas from the bottom to the top of the Department .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We want to make sure that our junior colleagues realize that ideas are welcome , that initiative goes right down to the bottom and goes all the way to the top .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I hope no one expects that only Presidential appointees are looked upon as sources of ideas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The responsibility for taking the initiative in generating ideas is that of every officer in the Department who has a policy function , regardless of rank .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Further , I would hope that we could pay attention to little things .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">While observing the operations of our Government in various parts of the world , I have felt that in many situations where our policies were good we have tended to ignore minor problems which spoiled our main effort .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">To cite only a few examples :
The wrong man in the wrong position , perhaps even in a junior position abroad , can be a source of great harm to our policy ; the attitudes of a U.N. delegate who experiences difficulty in finding adequate housing in New York City , or of a foreign diplomat in similar circumstances in our Capital , can be easily be directed against the United States and all that it stands for .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dozens of seemingly small matters go wrong all over the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sometimes those who know about them are too far down the line to be able to do anything about them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I would hope that we could create the recognition in the Department and overseas that those who come across little things going wrong have the responsibility for bringing these to the attention of those who can do something about them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the Department of State is to take primary responsibility for foreign policy in Washington , it follows that the ambassador is expected to take charge overseas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This does not mean in a purely bureaucratic sense but in an active , operational , interested , responsible fashion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is expected to know about what is going on among the representatives of other agencies who are stationed in his country .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is expected to supervise , to encourage , to direct , to assist in any way he can .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If any official operation abroad begins to go wrong , we shall look to the ambassador to find out why and to get suggestions for remedial action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It occurred to me that you might be interested in some thoughts which I expressed privately in recent years , in the hope of clearing up a certain confusion in the public mind about what foreign policy is all about and what it means , and of developing a certain compassion for those who are carrying such responsibilities inside Government .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I tried to do so by calling to their attention some of the problems that a senior departmental policy officer faces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This means practically everybody in this room .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whether it will strike home for you or not will be for you to determine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The senior policy officer may be moved to think hard about a problem by any of an infinite variety of stimuli : an idea in his own head , the suggestions of a colleague , a question from the Secretary or the President , a proposal by another department , a communication from a foreign government or an American ambassador abroad , the filing of an item for the agenda of the United Nations or of any other of dozens of international bodies , a news item read at the breakfast table , a question to the President or the Secretary at a news conference , a speech by a Senator or Congressman , an article in a periodical , a resolution from a national organization , a request for assistance from some private American interests abroad , et cetera , ad infinitum .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The policy officer lives with his antennae alerted for the questions which fall within his range of responsibility .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His first thought is about the question itself :
Is there a question here for American foreign policy , and , if so , what is it ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For he knows that the first and sometimes most difficult job is to know what the question is - that when it is accurately identified it sometimes answers itself , and that the way in which it is posed frequently shapes the answer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Chewing it over with his colleagues and in his own mind , he reaches a tentative identification of the question - tentative because it may change as he explores it further and because , if no tolerable answer can be found , it may have to be changed into one which can be answered .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Meanwhile he has been thinking about the facts surrounding the problem , facts which he knows can never be complete , and the general background , much of which has already been lost to history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He is appreciative of the expert help available to him and draws these resources into play , taking care to examine at least some of the raw material which underlies their frequently policy oriented conclusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">He knows that he must give the expert his place , but he knows that he must also keep him in it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He is already beginning to box the compass of alternative lines of action , including doing nothing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He knows that he is thinking about action in relation to a future which can be perceived but dimly through a merciful fog .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But he takes his bearings from the great guidelines of policy , well established precedents , the commitments of the United States under international charters and treaties , basic statutes , and well understood notions of the American people about how we are to conduct ourselves , in policy literature such as country papers and National Security Council papers accumulated in the Department .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He will not be surprised to find that general principles produce conflicting results in the factual situation with which he is confronted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He must think about which of these principles must take precedence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He will know that general policy papers written months before may not fit his problem because of crucial changes in circumstance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He is aware that every moderately important problem merges imperceptibly into every other problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He must deal with the question of how to manage a part when it cannot be handled without relation to the whole - when the whole is too large to grasp .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He must think of others who have a stake in the question and in its answer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Who should be consulted among his colleagues in the Department or other departments and agencies of the Government ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Which American ambassadors could provide helpful advice ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Are private interests sufficiently involved to be consulted ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">What is the probable attitude of other governments , including those less directly involved ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How and at what stage and in what sequence are other governments to be consulted ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If action is indicated , what kind of action is relevant to the problem ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The selection of the wrong tools can mean waste , at best , and at worst an unwanted inflammation of the problem itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Can the President or the Secretary act under existing authority , or will new legislation and new money be required ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Should the action be unilateral or multilateral ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Is the matter one for the United Nations or some other international body ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For , if so , the path leads through a complex process of parliamentary diplomacy which adds still another dimension to the problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What type of action can hope to win public support , first in this country and then abroad ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the policy officer will know that action can almost never be secret and that in general the effectiveness of policy will be conditioned by the readiness of the country to sustain it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He is interested in public opinion for two reasons :
first , because it is important in itself , and , second , because he knows that the American public cares about a decent respect for the opinions of mankind .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And , given probable public attitudes - about which reasonably good estimates can be made - what action is called for to insure necessary support ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">May I add a caution on this particular point ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We do not want policy officers below the level of Presidential appointees to concern themselves too much with problems of domestic politics in recommending foreign policy action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the first place our business is foreign policy , and it is the business of the Presidential leadership and his appointees in the Department to consider the domestic political aspects of a problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Mr. Truman emphasized this point by saying , `` You fellows in the Department of State do n't know much about domestic politics '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This is an important consideration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">If we sit here reading editorials and looking at public opinion polls and other reports that cross our desks , we should realize that this is raw , undigested opinion expressed in the absence of leadership .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What the American people will do turns in large degree on their leadership .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We cannot test public opinion until the President and the leaders of the country have gone to the public to explain what is required and have asked them for support for the necessary action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I doubt , for example , that , 3 months before the leadership began to talk about what came to be the Marshall plan , any public-opinion expert would have said that the country would have accepted such proposals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The problem in the policy officer 's mind thus begins to take shape as a galaxy of utterly complicated factors - political , military , economic , financial , legal , legislative , procedural , administrative - to be sorted out and handled within a political system which moves by consent in relation to an external environment which cannot be under control .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">And the policy officer has the hounds of time snapping at his heels .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Strategy and tactics of the U. S. military forces are now undergoing one of the greatest transitions in history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The change of emphasis from conventional type to missile type warfare must be made with care , mindful that the one type of warfare cannot be safely neglected in favor of the other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our military forces must be capable of contending successfully with any contingency which may be forced upon us , from limited emergencies to all-out nuclear general war .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">- This budget will provide in the fiscal year 1961 for the continued support of our forces at approximately the present level - a year-end strength of 2489000 men and women in the active forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The forces to be supported include an Army of 14 divisions and 870000 men ; a Navy of 817 active ships and 619000 men ; a Marine Corps of 3 divisions and 3 air wings with 175000 men ; and an Air Force of 91 combat wings and 825000 men .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the reserve components are to serve effectively in time of war , their basic organization and objectives must conform to the changing character and missions of the active forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Quality and combat readiness must take precedence over mere numbers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Under modern conditions , this is especially true of the ready reserve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I have requested the Secretary of Defense to reexamine the roles and missions of the reserve components in relation to those of the active forces and in the light of the changing requirements of modern warfare .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Last year the Congress discontinued its previously imposed minimum personnel strength limitations on the Army Reserve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Similar restrictions on the strength of the Army National Guard contained in the 1960 Department of Defense Appropriation Act should likewise be dropped .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I strongly recommend to the Congress the avoidance of mandatory floors on the size of the reserve components so that we may have the flexibility to make adjustments in keeping with military necessity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I again proposed a reduction in the Army National Guard and Army Reserve - from their present strengths of 400000 and 300000 , respectively , to 360000 and 270000 by the end of the fiscal year 1961 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These strengths are considered adequate to meet the essential roles and missions of the reserves in support of our national security objectives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">- About 30 % of the expenditures for the Department of Defense in 1961 are for military personnel costs , including pay for active , reserve , and retired military personnel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These expenditures are estimated to be $ 12.1 billion , an increase of $ 187 million over 1960 , reflecting additional longevity pay of career personnel , more dependents , an increased number of men drawing proficiency pay , and social security tax increases ( effective for the full year in 1961 compared with only 6 months in 1960 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Retired pay costs are increased by $ 94 million in 1961 over 1960 , partly because of a substantial increase in the number of retired personnel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These increased costs are partially offset by a decrease of $ 56 million in expenditures for the reserve forces , largely because of the planned reduction in strength of the Army Reserve components during 1961 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Traditionally , rates of pay for retired military personnel have been proportionate to current rates of pay for active personnel .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The 1958 military pay act departed from this established formula by providing for a 6 % increase rather than a proportionate increase for everyone retired prior to its effective date of June 1 , 1958 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I endorse pending legislation that will restore the traditional relationship between retired and active duty pay rates .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">- Expenditures for operating and maintaining the stations and equipment of the Armed Forces are estimated to be $ 10.3 billion in 1961 , which is $ 184 million more than in 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The increase stems largely from the growing complexity of and higher degree of maintenance required for newer weapons and equipment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A substantial increase is estimated in the cost of operating additional communications systems in the air defense program , as well as in all programs where speed and security of communications are essential .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Also , the program for fleet modernization will be stepped up in 1961 causing an increase in expenditures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Further increases arise from the civilian employee health program enacted by the Congress last year .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other factors increasing operating costs include the higher unit cost of each flying hour , up 11 % in two years , and of each steaming hour , up 15 % .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In total , these increases in operating costs outweigh the savings that result from declining programs and from economy measures , such as reduced numbers of units and installations , smaller inventories of major equipment , and improvements in the supply and distribution systems of the Armed Forces .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the budget message for 1959 , and again for 1960 , I recommended immediate repeal of section 601 of the Act of September 28 , 1951 ( 65 Stat.</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">365 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This section prevents the military departments and the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization from carrying out certain transactions involving real property unless they come into agreement with the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Representatives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As I have stated previously , the Attorney General has advised me that this section violates fundamental constitutional principles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Accordingly , if it is not repealed by the Congress at its present session , I shall have no alternative thereafter but to direct the Secretary of Defense to disregard the section unless a court of competent jurisdiction determines otherwise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Basic long line communications in Alaska are now provided through Federal facilities operated by the Army , Air Force , and Federal Aviation Agency .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The growing communications needs of this new State can best be met , as they have in other States , through the operation and development of such facilities by private enterprise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Legislation has already been proposed to authorize the sale of these Government owned systems in Alaska , and its early enactment is desirable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">- Approximately 45 % of the expenditures for the Department of Defense are for procurement , research , development , and construction programs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In 1961 , these expenditures are estimated at $ 18.9 billion , compared to $ 19.3 billion in 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The decreases , which are largely in construction and in aircraft procurement , are offset in part by increases for research and development and for procurement of other military equipment such as tanks , vehicles , guns , and electronic devices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Expenditures for shipbuilding are estimated at about the same level as in 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">New obligational authority for 1961 recommended in this budget for aircraft procurement ( excluding amounts for related research and construction ) totals $ 4753 million , which is $ 1390 million below that enacted for 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">On the other hand , the new authority of $ 3825 million proposed for missile procurement ( excluding research and construction ) in 1961 is $ 581 million higher than for 1960 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These contrasting trends in procurement reflect the anticipated changes in the composition and missions of our Armed Forces in the years ahead .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Department of Defense appropriation acts for the past several years have contained a rider which limits competitive bidding by firms in other countries on certain military supply items .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As I have repeatedly stated , this provision is much more restrictive than the general law , popularly known as the Buy American Act .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I urge once again that the Congress not reenact this rider .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The task of providing a reasonable level of military strength , without endangering other vital aspects of our security , is greatly complicated by the swift pace of scientific progress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The last few years have witnessed what have been perhaps the most rapid advances in military technology in history .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some weapons systems have become obsolescent while still in production , and some while still under development .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Furthermore , unexpectedly rapid progress or a technological break-through on any one weapon system , in itself , often diminishes the relative importance of other competitive systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This has necessitated a continuous review and reevaluation of the defense program in order to redirect resources to the newer and more important weapons systems and to eliminate or reduce effort on weapons systems which have been overtaken by events .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , in the last few years , a number of programs which looked very promising at the time their development was commenced have since been completely eliminated .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , the importance of the Regulus 2 , , a very promising aerodynamic ship to surface missile designed to be launched by surfaced submarines , was greatly diminished by the successful acceleration of the much more advanced Polaris ballistic missile launched by submerged submarines .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another example is the recent cancellation of the F-108 , a long range interceptor with a speed three times as great as the speed of sound , which was designed for use against manned bombers in the period of the mid 1960 's .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The substantial progress being made in ballistic missile technology is rapidly shifting the main threat from manned bombers to missiles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Considering the high cost of the F-108 system - over $ 4 billion for the force that had been planned - and the time period in which it would become operational , it was decided to stop further work on the project .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Meanwhile , other air defense forces are being made effective , as described later in this message .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The size and scope of other important programs have been reduced from earlier plans .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Notable in this category are the Jupiter and Thor intermediate range ballistic missiles , which have been successfully developed , produced , and deployed , but the relative importance of which has diminished with the increasing availability of the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The impact of technological factors is also illustrated by the history of the high energy fuel program .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This project was started at a time when there was a critical need for a high energy fuel to provide an extra margin of range for high performance aircraft , particularly our heavy bombers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Continuing technical problems involved in the use of this fuel , coupled with significant improvements in aircraft range through other means , have now raised serious questions about the value of the high energy fuel program .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a result , the scope of this project has been sharply curtailed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">These examples underscore the importance of even more searching evaluations of new major development programs and even more penetrating and far ranging analyses of the potentialities of future technology .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The cost of developing a major weapon system is now so enormous that the greatest care must be exercised in selecting new systems for development , in determining the most satisfactory rate of development , and in deciding the proper time at which either to place a system into production or to abandon it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">- The deterrent power of our Armed Forces comes from both their nuclear retaliatory capability and their capability to conduct other essential operations in any form of war .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first capability is represented by a combination of manned bombers , carrier based aircraft , and intercontinental and intermediate range missiles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The second capability is represented by our deployed ground , naval , and air forces in essential forward areas , together with ready reserves capable of effecting early emergency reinforcement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Strategic Air Command is the principal element of our long range nuclear capability .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One of the important and difficult decisions which had to be made in this budget concerned the role of the B-70 , a long range supersonic bomber .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This aircraft , which was planned for initial operational use about 1965 , would be complementary to but likewise competitive with the four strategic ballistic missile systems , all of which are scheduled to become available earlier .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first Atlas ICBM 's are now operational , the first two Polaris submarines are expected to be operational this calendar year , and the first Titan ICBM 's next year .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Minuteman solid fueled ICBM is planned to be operational about mid 1963 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">By 1965 , several or all of these systems will have been fully tested and their reliability established .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , the need for the B-70 as a strategic weapon system is doubtful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">However , I am recommending that development work on the B-70 air-frame and engines be continued .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is expected that in 1963 two prototype aircraft will be available for flight testing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By that time we should be in a much better position to determine the value of that aircraft as a weapon system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">I am recommending additional acquisitions of the improved version of the B-52 ( the B-52 H with the new turbofan engine ) and procurement of the B-58 supersonic medium bomber , together with the supporting refueling tankers in each case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These additional modern bombers will replace some of the older B-47 medium bombers ; one B-52 can do the work of several B-47 's which it will replace .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Funds are also included in this budget to continue the equipping of the B-52 wings with the Hound Dog air-to-surface missile .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the coming fiscal year additional quantities of Atlas , Titan , and Polaris missiles also will be procured .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If you elect to use the Standard Deduction or the Tax Table , and later find you should have itemized your deductions , you may do so by filing an amended return within the time prescribed for filing a claim for refund .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">See You May Claim a Refund , Page 135 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The same is true if you have itemized your deductions and later decide you should have used the Standard Deduction or Tax Table .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It would have been desirable for the two communities to have differed only in respect to the variable being investigated : the degree of structure in teaching method .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The structured schools were in an industrial city , with three family tenement houses typical of the residential areas , but with one rather sizable section of middle-class homes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The unstructured schools were in a large suburban community , predominantly middle - to upper-middle class , but fringed by an industrial area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In order to equate the samples on socioeconomic status , we chose schools in both cities on the basis of socioeconomic status of the neighborhoods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">School principals and guidance workers made ratings of the various neighborhoods and the research team made independent observations of houses and dwelling areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An objective scale was developed for rating school neighborhoods from these data .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Equal proportions of children in each city were drawn from upper-lower and lower-middle class neighborhoods .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Individual differences in maturation and the development of readiness for learning to read indicate that not until the third grade have most children had ample opportunity to demonstrate their capacity for school achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Therefore , third grade children were chosen as subjects for this study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For purposes of sample selection only ( individual tests were given later ) we obtained group test scores of reading achievement and intelligence from school records of the entire third grade population in each school system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The subjects for this study were randomly selected from stratified areas of the distribution , one-third as underachievers , one-third medium , and one-third over-achievers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Children whose reading scores were at least one standard deviation below the regression line of each total third grade school population were considered under-achievers for the purposes of sample selection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Over-achievers were at least one standard deviation above the regression line in their school system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The final sample was not significantly different from a normal distribution in regard to reading achievement or intelligence test scores .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Twenty-four classrooms in twelve unstructured schools furnished 156 cases , 87 boys and 69 girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Eight classrooms in three structured schools furnished 72 cases , 36 boys and 36 girls .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Administrative restrictions necessitated the smaller sample size in the structured schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It was assumed that the sampling procedure was purely random with respect to the personality variables under investigation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An interview schedule of open-ended questions and a multiple-choice questionnaire were prepared , and one parent of each of the sample children was seen in the home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The parent was asked to describe the child 's typical behavior in certain standard situations in which there was an opportunity to observe tendencies toward perfectionism in demands upon self and others , irrational conformity to rules , orderliness , punctuality , and need for certainty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The interviewers were instructed not to suggest answers and , as much as possible , to record the parents ' actual words as they described the child 's behavior in home situations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The rating scale of compulsivity was constructed by first perusing the interview records , categorizing all evidence related to compulsivity , then arranging a distribution of such information apart from the case records .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Final ratings were made on the basis of a point system which was developed after studying the distributions of actual behaviors recorded and assigning weight values to each type of behavior that was deviant from the discovered norms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Children scoring high in compulsivity were those who gave evidence of tension or emotionality in situations where there was lack of organization or conformity to standards and expectations , or who made exaggerated efforts to achieve these goals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The low compulsive child was one who appeared relatively unconcerned about such matters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For instance , the following statement was rated low in compulsivity , `` She 's naturally quite neat about things , but it does n't bother her at all if her room gets messy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But she cleans it up very well when I remind her '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Castaneda , et al. revised the Taylor Anxiety Scale for use with children .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Taylor Scale was adapted from the Minnesota Multiphastic Personality Inventory , with item selection based upon clinical definitions of anxiety .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There is much research evidence to validate the use of the instrument in differentiating individuals who are likely to manifest anxiety in varying degrees .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Reliability and validation work with the Children 's Anxiety Scale by Castaneda , et al. demonstrated results closely similar to the findings with the adult scale .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Although the Taylor Scale was designed as a group testing device , in this study it was individually administered by psychologically trained workers who established rapport and assisted the children in reading the items .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The question may be raised whether or not we are dealing with a common factor in anxiety and compulsivity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The two ratings yield a correlation of + .04 , which is not significantly different from zero ; therefore , we have measured two different characteristics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In theory , compulsive behavior is a way of diminishing anxiety , and one might expect a negative association except for the possibility that for many children the obsessive-compulsive defenses are not sufficient to quell the amount of anxiety they suffer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The issue of interaction between anxiety and compulsivity will be taken up later .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the primary grades , reading permeates almost every aspect of school progress , and the children 's early experiences of success or failure in learning to read often set a pattern of total achievement that is relatively enduring throughout the following years .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In establishing criterion measurements , it was therefore thought best to broaden the scope beyond the reading act itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The predicted interaction effect should , if potent , extend its influence over all academic achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Stanford Achievement Test , Form J , was administered by classroom teachers , consisting of a battery of six sub tests : Paragraph Meaning , Word Meaning , Spelling , Language , Arithmetic Computation , and Arithmetic Reasoning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">All of these sub-tests involve reading except Arithmetic Computation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Scores are stated in grade equivalents on a national norm .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The battery median grade equivalent was used in data analysis in this study .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children was administered to each sample third grade child by a clinical worker .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The relationship of intelligence test scores to school achievement is a well established fact ( in this case , * * f ) ; therefore , in the investigation of the present hypothesis , it was necessary to control this factor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The criterion score used in the statistical analysis is an index of over - or under-achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is the discrepancy between the actual attained achievement test score and the score that would be predicted by the I. Q. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For example , on the basis of the regression equation , a child with an I. Q. of 120 in this sample would be expected to earn an achievement test score of 4.8 ( grade equivalent ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If a child with an I. Q. of 120 scored 5.5 in achievement , his discrepancy score would be + .7 , representing .7 of one year of over-achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A child with an I. Q. of 98 would be expected to earn an achievement test score of 3.5 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If such a child scored 3.0 , his discrepancy score would be - .5 , representing .5 of one year of under-achievement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this manner , the factors measured by the intelligence test were controlled , allowing discovered differences in achievement to be interpreted as resulting from other variables .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tables 1 and 2 present the results of the statistical analysis of the data when compulsivity is used as the descriptive variable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Figure 1 portrays the mean achievement scores of each sub-group graphically .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">First of all , as we had surmised , the highly compulsive children in the structured setting score significantly better ( * * f ) on achievement than do similar children in the unstructured schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It can be seen too that when we contrast levels of compulsivity within the structured schools , the high compulsive children do better ( * * f ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No significant difference was found in achievement between high and low compulsive children within the unstructured school .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The hypothesis of there being an interaction between compulsivity and teaching method was supported , in this case , at the .05 level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">While we had expected that compulsive children in the unstructured school setting would have difficulty when compared to those in the structured , we were surprised to find that the achievement of the high compulsives within the schools where the whole-word method is used in beginning reading compares favorably with that of the low compulsives .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed their achievement scores were somewhat better on an absolute basis although the difference was not significant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We speculate that compulsives in the unstructured schools are under greater strain because of the lack of systemization in their school setting , but that their need to organize ( for comfort ) is so intense that they struggle to induce the phonic rules and achieve in spite of the lack of direction from the environment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is interesting to note that medium compulsives in the unstructured schools made the lowest achievement scores ( although not significantly lower ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Possibly their compulsivity was not strong enough to cause them to build their own structure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Our conjecture is , then , that regardless of the manner in which school lessons are taught , the compulsive child accentuates those elements of each lesson that aid him in systematizing his work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When helped by a high degree of structure in lesson presentation , then , and only then , does such a child attain unusual success .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The statistical analyses of achievement in relation to anxiety and teaching methods and the interactions of the two are presented in Tables 3 and 4 .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Figure 2 is a graph of the mean achievement scores of each group .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As predicted , the highly anxious children in the unstructured schools score more poorly ( * * f ) than those in the structured schools .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The interaction effect , which is significant at the .01 level , can be seen best in the contrast of mean scores .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">While high anxiety children achieve significantly less well ( * * f ) in the unstructured school than do low anxiety children , they appear to do at least as well as the average in the structured classroom .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The most striking aspect of the interaction demonstrated is the marked decrement in performance suffered by the highly anxious children in unstructured schools .</MPQASENT>
