<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">According to the theory proposed , this is a consequence of the severe condition of perceived threat that persists unabated for the anxious child in an ambiguous sort of school environment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The fact that such threat is potent in the beginning reading lessons is thought to be a vital factor in the continued pattern of failure or under-achievement these children exhibit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The child with high anxiety may first direct his anxiety released energy toward achievement , but because his distress severely reduces the abilities of discrimination and memorization of complex symbols , the child may fail in his initial attempts to master the problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Failure confirms the threat , and the intensity of anxiety is increased as the required learning becomes more difficult , so that by the time the child reaches the third grade the decrement in performance is pronounced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The individual with high anxiety in the structured classroom may approach the learning task with the same increased energy and lowered powers of discrimination .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the symbols he is asked to learn are simple .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As shown earlier , the highly anxious individual may be superior in his memorizing of simple elements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Success reduces the prospect of threat and his powers of discrimination are improved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By the time the child first attacks the actual problem of reading , he is completely familiar and at ease with all of the elements of words .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apparently academic challenge in the structured setting creates an optimum of stress so that the child with high anxiety is able to achieve because he is aroused to an energetic state without becoming confused or panicked .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Sarason et al. present evidence that the anxious child will suffer in the test like situation , and that his performance will be impaired unless he receives supporting and accepting treatment from the teacher .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Although the present study was not a direct replication of their investigations , the results do not confirm their conclusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Observers , in the two school systems studied here , judged the teachers in the structured schools to be more impersonal and demanding , while the atmosphere in the unstructured schools was judged to be more supporting and accepting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Yet the highly anxious child suffered a tremendous disadvantage only in the unstructured school , and performed as well or better than average in the structured setting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Analysis means the evaluation of subparts , the comparative ratings of parts , the comprehension of the meaning of isolated elements .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Analysis in roleplaying is usually done for the purpose of understanding strong and weak points of an individual or as a process to eliminate weak parts and strengthen good parts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Up to this point stress has been placed on roleplaying in terms of individuals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Roleplaying can be done for quite a different purpose : to evaluate procedures , regardless of individuals .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For example : a sales presentation can be analyzed and evaluated through roleplaying .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Let us now put some flesh on the theoretical bones we have assembled by giving illustrations of roleplaying used for evaluation and analysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One should keep in mind that many of the exciting possiblities of roleplaying are largely unexplored and have not been used in industry to the extent that they have been in military and other areas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The president of a small firm selling restaurant products , had considerable difficulty in finding suitable salesmen for his business .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Interviewing , checking references , training the salesmen , having them go with more experienced salesmen was expensive - and the rate of attrition due to resignations or unsatisfactory performance was too high .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was his experience that only one good salesman was found out of every seven hired - and only one was hired out of every seven interviewed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Roleplaying was offered as a solution - and the procedure worked as follows : all candidates were invited to a hotel conference room , where the president explained the difficulty he had , and how unnecessary it seemed to him to hire people who just did not work out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In place of asking salesmen to fill questionnaires , checking their references , interviewing them , asking them to be tried out , he told them he would prefer to test them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each person was to enter the testing room , carrying a suitcase of samples .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each salesman was to read a sheet containing a description of the product .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the testing room he was to make , successively , three presentations to three different people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the testing room , three of the veteran salesmen served as antagonists .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One handled the salesman in a friendly manner , another in a rough manner , and the third in a hesitating manner .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each was told to purchase material if he felt like it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The antagonists came in , one at a time , and did not see or hear the other presentations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">After each presentation , the antagonist wrote his judgment of the salesmen ; and so did the observers consisting of the president , three of his salesmen and a psychologist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Ten salesmen were tested in the morning and ten more in the afternoon .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This procedure was repeated one day a month for four months .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The batting average of one success out of seven increased to one out of three .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The president of the firm , calculating expenses alone , felt his costs had dropped one-half while success in selection had improved over one hundred per cent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The reason for the value of this procedure was simply that the applicants were tested `` at work '' in different situations by the judgment of a number of experts who could see how the salesmen conducted themselves with different , but typical restaurant owners and managers .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They were , in a sense , `` tried out '' in realistic situations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From the point of view of the applicants , less time was wasted in being evaluated - and they got a meal out of it as well as some insights into their performances .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another use of roleplaying for evaluation illustrates how this procedure can be used in real life situations without special equipment or special assistants during the daily course of work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The position of receptionist was opened in a large office and an announcement was made to the other girls already working that they could apply for this job which had higher prestige and slightly higher salary than typing and clerking positions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">All applicants were generally familiar with the work of the receptionist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">At the end of work one day , the personnel man took the applicants one at a time , asked them to sit behind the receptionist 's desk and he then played the role of a number of people who might come to the receptionist with a number of queries and for a number of purposes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each girl was independently `` tested '' by the personnel man , and he served not only as the director , but as the antagonist and the observer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Somewhat to his surprise he found that one girl , whom he would never have considered for the job since she had appeared somewhat mousy and also had been in the office a relatively short time , did the most outstanding job of playing the role of receptionist , showing wit , sparkle , and aplomb .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She was hired and was found to be entirely satisfactory when she played the role eight hours a day .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In considering roleplaying for analysis we enter a more complex area , since we are now no longer dealing with a simple over-all decision but rather with the examination and evaluation of many elements seen in dynamic functioning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Some cases in evidence of the use of roleplaying for analysis may help explain the procedure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An engineer had been made the works manager of a firm , supplanting a retired employee who had been considered outstandingly successful .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The engineer had more than seven years of experience in the firm , was well trained , was considered a hard worker , was respected by his fellow engineers for his technical competence and was regarded as a `` comer '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , he turned out to be a complete failure in his new position .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He seemed to antagonize everyone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Turnover rates of personnel went up , production dropped , and morale was visibly reduced .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Despite the fact that he was regarded as an outstanding engineer , he seemed to be a very poor administrator , although no one quite knew what was wrong with him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At the insistence of his own supervisor - the president of the firm , he enrolled in a course designed to develop leaders .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He played a number of typical situations before observers , other supervisors who kept notes and then explained to him in detail what he did they thought was wrong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Entirely concerned with efficiency , he was merciless in criticizing people who made mistakes , condemning them to too great an extent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He did not really listen to others , had little interest in their ideas , and wanted to have his own way - which was the only right way .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The entire group of managers explained , in great detail , a number of human relations errors that he made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One by one , these errors were discussed and one by one he rejected accepting them as errors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">He admitted his behavior , and defended it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">He refused to change his approach , and instead he attacked high and low - the officials for their not backing him , and subordinates for their laxness , stupidity , and stubbornness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">After the diagnosing , he left the course , convinced that it could do him no good .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We may say that his problem was diagnosed but that he refused treatment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The engineer turned works manager had a particular view of life - and refused to change it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">We may say that his attitude was foolish , since he may have been a success had he learned some human relations skills ; or we may say that his attitude was commendable , showing his independence of mind , in his refusal to adjust to the opinions of others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In any case , he refused to accept the implications of the analysis , that he needed to be made over .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Another case may be given in illustration of a successful use of analysis , and also of the employment of a procedure for intensive analysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In a course for supermarket operators , a district manager who had been recently appointed to his position after being outstandingly successful as a store manager , found that in supervising other managers he was having a difficult time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On playing some typical situations before a jury of his peers he showed some characteristics rated as unsatisfactory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was told he displayed , for example , a sense of superiority - and he answered : `` Well , I am supposed to know all the answers , are n't I '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He was criticized for his curtness and abruptness - and he answered : `` I am not working to become popular '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On being criticized for his arbitrary behavior - he answered : `` I have to make decisions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">That 's my job '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In short , as frequently happens in analyses , the individual feels threatened and defends himself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , in this case the district manager was led to see the errors of his ways .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The necessary step between diagnosis and training is acceptance of the validity of the criticisms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">How this was accomplished may be described , since this sometimes is a crucial problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The director helped tailor-make a check list of the district manager 's errors by asking various observers to write out sentences commenting on the mistakes they felt he made .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These errors were then collected and written on a blackboard , condensing similar ideas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Eighteen errors were located , and then the director asked each individual to vote whether or not they felt that this manager had made the particular errors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They were asked to vote `` true '' if they thought they had seen him make the error , `` false '' if they thought he had not ; and `` cannot say '' if they were not certain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The manager sat behind the group so he could see and count the hands that went up , and the director wrote the numbers on the blackboard .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">No comments were made during the voting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The results looked as follows :
* * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first eight of these eighteen statements , which received at least one-half of the votes , were duplicated to form an analysis checklist for the particular manager , and when this particular manager roleplayed in other situations , the members checked any items that appeared .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To prevent the manager from deliberately controlling himself only during the sessions , they were rather lengthy ( about twenty minutes ) , the situations were imperfectly described to the manager so that he would not know what to expect , new antagonists were brought on the scene unexpectedly , and the antagonists were instructed to deliberately behave in such ways as to upset the manager and get him to operate in a manner for which he had been previously criticized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">After every session , the check marks were totaled up and graphed , and in this way the supervisor 's progress was charted .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">In life we learn to play our roles and we `` freeze '' into patterns which become so habitual that we are not really aware of what we do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">We can see others more clearly than we can see ourselves , and others can see us better than we see ourselves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To learn what we do is the first step for improvement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To accept the validity of the judgments of others is the second step .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To want to change is the third step .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To practice new procedures under guided supervision and with constant feedback is the fourth step .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">To use these new ways in daily life is the last step .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Roleplaying used for analysis follows these general steps leading to training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When an evaluative situation is set up , and no concern is with the details that lead to an over-all estimate , we say that roleplaying is used for evaluation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Observers can see a person engaged in spontaneous behavior , and watch him operating in a totalistic fashion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This behavior is more `` veridical '' - or true than other testing behavior for some types of evaluation , and so can give quick and accurate estimates of complex functioning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While roleplaying for testing is not too well understood at the present time , it represents one of the major uses of this procedure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The objective of this chapter is to clarify the distinctions between spontaneity theory and other training concepts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In addition , the basic approach utilized in applying roleplaying will be reviewed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The goal will be to provide the reader with an integrated rationale to aid him in applying roleplaying techniques in this unique training area .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The reasons for extracting this particular roleplaying application from the previous discussion of training are twofold :
Spontaneity training theory is unique and relatively new .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is not easy for the therapist to discern when , in the patient 's communicating , an introject has appeared and is holding sway .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One learns to become alert to changes in his vocal tone - to his voice 's suddenly shifting to a quality not like his usual one , a quality which sounds somehow artificial or , in some instances , parrotlike .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The content of his words may lapse back into monotonous repetition , as if a phonograph needle were stuck in one groove ; only seldom is it so simple as to be a matter of his obviously parroting some timeworn axiom , common to our culture , which he has evidently heard , over and over , from a parent until he experiences it as part of him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">One hebephrenic woman often became submerged in what felt to me like a somehow phony experience of pseudo emotion , during which , despite her wracking sobs and streaming cheeks , I felt only a cold annoyance with her .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Eventually such incidents became more sporadic , and more sharply demarcated from her day-after-day behavior , and in one particular session , after several minutes of such behavior - which , as usual , went on without any accompanying words from her - she asked , eagerly , `` Did you see Granny '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At first I did not know what she meant ; I thought she must be seeing me as some one who had just come from seeing her grandmother , in their distant home city .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Then I realized that she had been deliberately showing me , this time , what Granny was like ; and when I replied in this spirit , she corroborated my hunch .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">At another phase in the therapy , when a pathogenic mother introject began to emerge more and more upon the investigative scene , she muttered in a low but intense voice , to herself , `` I hate that woman inside me '' !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I could evoke no further elaboration from her about this ; but a few seconds later she was standing directly across the room from me , looking me in the eyes and saying in a scathingly condemnatory tone , `` Your father despises you '' !</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Again , I at first misconstrued this disconcertingly intense communication , and I quickly cast through my mind to account for her being able to speak , with such utter conviction , of an opinion held by my father , now several years deceased .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Then I replied , coldly , `` If you despise me , why do n't you say so , directly '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">She looked confused at this , and I felt sure it had been a wrong response for me to make .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It then occurred to me to ask , `` Is that what that woman told you '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">She clearly agreed that this had been the case .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I realized , now , that she had been showing me , in what impressed me as being a very accurate way , something her mother had once said to her ; it was as if she was showing me one of the reasons why she hated that woman inside her .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">What had been an unmanageably powerful introject was now , despite its continuing charge of energy disconcerting to me , sufficiently within control of her ego that she could use it to show me what this introjected mother was like .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Earlier , this woman had been so filled with a chaotic variety of introjects that at times , when she was in her room alone , it would sound to a passerby as though there were several different persons in the room , as she would vocalize in various kinds of voice .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A somewhat less fragmented hebephrenic patient of mine , who used to often seclude herself in her room , often sounded through the closed door - as I would find on passing by , between our sessions - for all the world like two persons , a scolding mother and a defensive child .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Particularly hard for the therapist to grasp are those instances in which the patient is manifesting an introject traceable to something in the therapist , some aspect of the therapist of which the latter is himself only poorly aware , and the recognition of which , as a part of himself , he finds distinctly unwelcome .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">I have found , time and again , that some bit of particularly annoying and intractable behavior on the part of a patient rests , in the final analysis , on this basis ; and only when I can acknowledge this , to myself , as being indeed an aspect of my personality , does it cease to be a prominently troublesome aspect of the patient 's behavior .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For example , one hebephrenic man used to annoy me , month after month , by saying , whenever I got up to leave and made my fairly steoreotyped comment that I would be seeing him on the following day , or whenever , `` You 're welcome '' , in a notably condescending fashion - as though it were his due for me to thank him for the privilege of spending the hour with him , and he were thus pointing up my failure to utter a humbly grateful , `` thank you '' to him at the end of each session .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Eventually it became clear to me , partly with the aid of another schizophrenic patient who could point out my condescension to me somewhat more directly , that this man , with his condescending , `` You 're welcome '' , was very accurately personifying an element of obnoxious condescension which had been present in my own demeanor , over these months , on each of these occasions when I had bid him good-bye with the consoling note , each time , that the healing Christ would be stooping to dispense this succor to the poor suffered again on the morrow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Another patient , a paranoid woman , for many months infuriated not only me but the ward personnel and her fellow patients by arrogantly behaving as though she owned the whole building , as though she were the only person in it whose needs were to be met .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">This behavior on her part subsided only after I had come to see the uncomfortably close similarity between , on the one hand , her arranging the ventilation of the common living room to her own liking , or turning the television off or on without regard to the wishes of the others , and on the other hand , my own coming stolidly into her room despite her persistent and vociferous objections , bringing my big easy chair with me , usually shutting the windows of her room which she preferred to keep in a very cold state , and plunking myself down in my chair - in short , behaving as if I owned her room .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here a variety of meanings and emotions are concentrated , or reduced , in their communicative expression , to some comparatively simple seeming verbal or nonverbal statement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">One finds , for example , that a terse and stereotyped verbal expression , seeming at first to be a mere hollow convention , reveals itself over the months of therapy as the vehicle for expressing the most varied and intense feelings , and the most unconventional of meanings .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">More than anything , it is the therapist 's intuitive sensing of these latent meanings in the stereotype which helps these meanings to become revealed , something like a spread-out deck of cards , on sporadic occasions over the passage of the patient 's and his months of work together .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">one cannot assume , of course , that all these accumulated meanings were inherent in the stereotype at the beginning of the therapy , or at any one time later on when the stereotype was uttered ; probably it is correct to think of it as a matter of a well grooved , stereotyped mode of expression - and no , or but a few , other communicational grooves , as yet - being there , available for the patient 's use , as newly emerging emotions and ideas well up in him over the course of months .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it is true that the therapist can sense , when he hears this stereotype , that there are at this moment many emotional determinants at work in it , a blurred babel of indistinct voices which have yet to become clearly delineated from one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes it is not a verbal stereotype - a `` How are you now '' ?</MPQASENT> <MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">or an `` I want to go home '' , or whatever - but a nonverbal one which reveals itself , gradually , as the condensed expression of more than one latent meaning .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A hebephrenic man used to give a repetitious wave of his hand a number of times during his largely silent hours with his therapist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the therapist came to feel on sufficiently sure ground with him to ask him , `` What is that , Bill - hello or farewell '' ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">, the patient replied , `` Both , Dearie - two in one '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of all the possible forms of nonverbal expression , that which seems best to give release , and communicational expression , to complex and undifferentiated feelings is laughter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">It is no coincidence that the hebephrenic patient , the most severely dedifferentiated of all schizophrenic patients , shows , as one of his characteristic symptoms , laughter - laughter which now makes one feel scorned or hated , which now makes one feel like weeping , or which now gives one a glimpse of the bleak and empty expanse of man 's despair ; and which , more often than all these , conveys a welter of feelings which could in no way be conveyed by any number of words , words which are so unlike this welter in being formed and discrete from one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To a much less full extent , the hebephrenic person 's belching or flatus has a comparable communicative function ; in working with these patients the therapist eventually gets to do some at least private mulling over of the possible meaning of a belch , or the passage of flatus , not only because he is reduced to this for lack of anything else to analyze , but also because he learns that even these animal like sounds constitute forms of communication in which , from time to time , quite different things are being said , long before the patient can become sufficiently aware of these , as distinct feelings and concepts , to say them in words .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">As I have been intimating , in the schizophrenic - and perhaps also in the dreams of the neurotic ; this is a question which I have no wish to take up - condensation is a phenomenon in which one finds not a condensed expression of various feelings and ideas which are , at an unconscious level , well sorted out , but rather a condensed expression of feelings and ideas which , even in the unconscious , have yet to become well differentiated from one another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Freeman , Cameron and McGhie , in their description of the disturbances of thinking found in chronic schizophrenic patients , say , in regard to condensation , that `` the lack of adequate discrimination between the self and the environment , and the objects contained therein in itself is the prototypical condensation '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In my experience , a great many of the patient 's more puzzling verbal communications are so for the reason that concrete meanings have not become differentiated from figurative meanings in his subjective experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus he may be referring to some concrete thing , or incident , in his immediate environment by some symbolic sounding , hyperbolic reference to transcendental events on the global scene .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Recently , for example , a paranoid woman 's large-scale philosophizing , in the session , about the intrusive curiosity which has become , in her opinion , a deplorable characteristic of mid twentieth century human culture , developed itself , before the end of the session , into a suspicion that I was surreptitiously peeking at her partially exposed breast , as indeed I was .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Or , equally often , a concretistic seeming , particularistic seeming statement may consist , with its mundane exterior , in a form of poetry - may be full of meaning and emotion when interpreted as a figurative expression : a metaphor , a simile , an allegory , or some other symbolic mode of speaking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Of such hidden meanings the patient himself is , more often than not , entirely unaware .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His subjective experience may be a remarkably concretistic one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One hebephrenic women confided to me , `` I live in a world of words '' , as if , to her , words were fully concrete objects ; Burnham , in his excellent article ( 1955 ) concerning schizophrenic communication , includes mention of similar clinical material .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A borderline schizophrenic young man told me that to him the various theoretical concepts about which he had been expounding , in a most articulate fashion , during session after session with me , were like great cubes of almost tangibly solid matter up in the air above him ; as he spoke I was reminded of the great bales of cargo which are swung , high in the air , from a docked steamship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The many linguistic techniques for reducing the amount of dictionary information that have been proposed all organize the dictionary 's contents around prefixes , stems , suffixes , etc. .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A significant reduction in the voume of store information is thus realized , especially for a highly inflected language such as Russian .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For English the reduction in size is less striking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This approach requires that : ( 1 ) each text word be separated into smaller elements to establish a correspondence between the occurrence and dictionary entries , and ( 2 ) the information retrieved from several entries in the dictionary be synthesized into a description of the particular word .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The logical scheme used to accomplish the former influences the placement of information in the dictionary file .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Implementation of the latter requires storage of information needed only for synthesis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We suggest the application of certain data-processing techniques as a solution to the problem .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But first , we must define two terms so that their meaning will be clearly understood :
form - any unique sequence of alphabetic characters that can appear in a language preceded and followed by a space .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">occurrence - an instance of a form in text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We propose a method for selecting only dictionary information required by the text being translated and a means for passing the information directly to the occurrences in text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">We accomplish this by compiling a list of text forms as text is read by the computer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A random storage scheme , based on the spelling of forms , provides an economical way to compile this text form list .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Dictionary forms found to match forms in the text list are marked .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A location in the computer store is also named for each marked form ; dictionary information about the form stored at this location can be retrieved directly by occurrences of the form in text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , information is retrieved from the dictionary as required by stages of the translation process - the grammatic description for sentence-structure determination , equivalent choice information for semantic analysis , and target-language equivalents for output construction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The dictionary is a form dictionary , at least in the sense that complete forms are used as the basis for matching text occurrences with dictionary entries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Also , the dictionary is divided into at least two parts :
the list of dictionary forms and the file of information that pertains to these forms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A more detailed description of dictionary operations - text lookup and dictionary modification - give a clearer picture .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Text lookup , as we will describe it , consists of three steps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first is compiling a list of text forms , assigning an information cell to each , and replacing text occurrences with the information cell assigned to the form of each occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For this step the computer memory is separated into three regions : cells in the W region are used for storage of the forms in the text form list ; cells in the X-region and Y region are reserved as information cells for text forms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When an occurrence * * f is isolated during text reading , a random memory address * * f , the address of a cell in the X-region , is computed from the form of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Let * * f denote the form of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If cell * * f has not previously been assigned as the information cell of a form in the text form list , it is now assigned as the information cell of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The form itself is stored in the next available cells of the W-region , beginning in cell * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The address * * f and the number of cells required to store the form are written in * * f ; the information cell * * f is saved to represent the text occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Text reading continues with the next occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Let us assume that * * f is identical to the form of an occurrence * * f which preceded * * f in the text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When this situation exists , the address * * f will equal * * f which was produced from * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If * * f was assigned as the information cell for * * f , the routine can detect that * * f is identical to * * f by comparing * * f with the form stored at location * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The address * * f is stored in the cell * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When , as in this case , the two forms match , the address * * f is saved to represent the occurrence * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Text reading continues with the next occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A third situation is possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The formula for computing random addresses from the form of each occurrence will not give a distinct address for each distinct form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus , when more than one distinct form leads to a particular cell in the X-region , a chain of information cells must be created to accommodate the forms , one cell in the chain for each form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If * * f leads to an address * * f that is equal to the address computed from * * f , even though * * f does not match * * f , the chain of information cells is extended from * * f by storing the address of the next available cell in the Y-region , * * f , in * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The cell * * f becomes the second information cell in the chain and is assigned as the information cell of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A third cell can be added by storing the address of another Y-cell in * * f ; similarly , as many cells are added as are required .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each information cell in the chain contains the address of the Y-cell where the form to which it is assigned is stored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each cell except the last in the chain also contains the address of the Y-cell that is the next element of the chain ; the absence of such a link in the last cell indicates the end of the chain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hence , when the address * * f is computed from * * f , the cell * * f and all Y-cells in its chain must be inspected to determine whether * * f is already in the form list or whether it should be added to the form list and the chain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the information cell for * * f has been determined , it is saved as a representation of * * f .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Text reading continues with the next occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Text reading is terminated when a pre-determined number of forms have been stored in the text form list .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This initiates the second step of glossary lookup - connecting the information cell of forms in the text form list to dictionary forms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each form represented by the dictionary is looked up in the text form list .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each time a dictionary form matches a text form , the information cell of the matching text form is saved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The number of dictionary forms skipped since the last one matched is also saved .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These two pieces of information for each dictionary form that is matched by a text form constitute the table of dictionary usage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If each text form is marked when matched with a dictionary form , the text forms not contained in the dictionary can be identified when all dictionary forms have been read .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The appropriate action for handling these forms can be taken at that time .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Each dictionary form is looked up in the text form list by the same method used to look up a new text occurrence in the form list during text reading .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A random address * * f that lies within the X-region of memory mentioned earlier is computed from the i-th dictionary form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If cell * * f is an information cell , it and any information cells in the Y-region that have been linked to * * f each contain an address in the W-region where a potentially matching form is stored .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The dictionary form is compared with each of these text forms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When a match is found , an entry is made in the table of dictionary usage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">If cell * * f is not an information cell we conclude that the i-th dictionary form is not in the text list .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">These two steps essentially complete the lookup operation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The final step merely uses the table of dictionary usage to select the dictionary information that pertains to each form matched in the text form list , and uses the list of information cells recorded in text order to attach the appropriate information to each occurrence in text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The list of text forms in the W-region of memory and the contents of the information cells in the X and Y-regions are no longer required .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Only the assignment of the information cells is important .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The first stage of translation after glossary lookup is structural analysis of the input text .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The grammatical description of each occurrence in the text must be retrieved from the dictionary to permit such an analysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A description of this process will serve to illustrate how any type of information can be retrieved from the dictionary and attached to each text occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The grammatic descriptions of all forms in the dictionary are recorded in a separate part of the dictionary file .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The order is identical to the ordering of the forms they describe .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When entries are being retrieved from this file , the table of dictionary usage indicates which entries to skip and which entries to store in the computer .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This selection rejection process takes place as the file is read .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Each entry that is selected for storage is written into the next available cells of the W-region .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The address of the first cell and the number of cells used is written in the information cell for the form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( The address of the information cell is also supplied by the table of dictionary usage . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the complete file has been read , the grammatic descriptions for all text forms found in the dictionary have been stored in the W-region ; the information cell assigned to each text form contains the address of the grammatic description of the form it represents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hence , the description of each text occurrence can be retrieved by reading the list of text ordered information cell addresses and outputting the description indicated by the information cell for each occurrence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The only requirements on dictionary information made by the text lookup operation are that each form represented by the dictionary be available for lookup in the text form list and that information for each form be available in a sequence identical with the sequence of the forms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This leaves the ordering of entries variable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( Here an entry is a form plus the information that pertains to it . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Two very useful ways for modifying a form dictionary are the addition to the dictionary of complete paradigms rather than single forms and the application of a single change to more than one dictionary form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The former is intended to decrease the amount of work necessary to extend dictionary coverage .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The latter is useful for modifying information about some or all forms of a word , hence reducing the work required to improve dictionary contents .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Applying the techniques developed at Harvard for generating a paradigm from a representative form and its classification , we can add all forms of a word to the dictionary at once .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">An extension of the principle would permit entering a grammatic description of each form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Equivalents could be assigned to the paradigm either at the time it is added to the dictionary or after the word has been studied in context .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , one can think of a dictionary entry as a word rather than a form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If all forms of a paradigm are grouped together within the dictionary , a considerable reduction in the amount of information required is possible .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For example , the inflected forms of a word can be represented , insofar as regular inflection allows , by a stem and a set of endings to be attached .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">( Indeed , the set of endings can be replaced by the name of a set of endings . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The full forms can be derived from such information just prior to the lookup of the form in the text form list .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Similarly , if the equivalents for the forms of a word do not vary , the equivalents need be entered only once with an indication that they apply to each form .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The dictionary system is in no way dependent upon such summarization or designed around it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When irregularity and variation prevent summarizing , information is written in complete detail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Entries are summarized only when by doing so the amount of information retained in the dictionary is reduced and the time required for dictionary operations is decreased .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In sentences , patterns of stress are determined by complex combinations of influences that can only be suggested here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The tendency is toward putting dominant stress at the end .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There is a parallel to this tendency in the assignment of time in long known hymn tunes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus the first lines of one of Charles Wesley 's hymns are as follows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` A charge to keep I have , A God to glorify '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the tune to which this hymn is most often sung , `` Boylston '' , the syllables have and fy , ending their lines , have twice the time any other syllables have .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Dominant stress is of course more than extended duration , and normally centers on syllables that would have primary stress or phrase stress if the words or longer units they are parts of were spoken alone : a dominant stress given to glorify would normally center on its first syllable rather than its last .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the parallel is significant .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When the answer to what 's wrong now ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">is Bill 's broken a chair , dominant stress will usually be on the complement a chair .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From the point of view of syntactic analysis the head word in the statement is the predicator has broken , and from the point of view of meaning it would seem that the trouble centers in the breaking ; but dominant stress will be assigned to broken only in rather exceptional versions of the sentence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In I know one thing dominant stress will usually be on the complement one thing ; in one thing I know it will usually be on the predicator know .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In small-town people are very friendly dominant stress will generally be on the complement very friendly ; in the double sentence the smaller the town , the friendlier the people it will generally be on the subjects the town and the people .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In what 's a linguist ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">dominant stress will generally be on the subject a linguist ; in who 's a linguist ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">it will generally be on the complement a linguist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Dominant stress is on her luggage both in that 's her luggage , where her luggage is the complement , and in there 's her luggage , where it is the subject .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Adverbial second complements , however , are likely not to have dominant stress when they terminate sentences .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the answer to what was that noise ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">is George put the cat out , dominant stress will ordinarily be on the first complement , the cat , not the second complement out .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Final adjuncts may or may not have dominant stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">If the answer to what was that noise ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">is George reads the news emotionally , dominant stress may or may not be on the adjunct emotionally .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When prepositional complements are divided as in what are you looking for ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">they are likely to lose dominant stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Context is of extreme importance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">What is new in the context is likely to be made more prominent than what is not .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Thus in a context in which there has been discussion of snow but mention of local conditions is new , dominant stress will probably be on here in it rarely snows here , but in a context in which there has been discussion of local weather but no mention of snow , dominant stress will probably be on snows .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The personal pronouns and substitute one are normally unstressed because they refer to what is prominent in the immediate context .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In I 'll go with George dominant stress is probably on George ; but if George has just been mentioned prominently ( and the trip to be made has been under discussion ) , what is said is probably I 'll go with him , and dominant stress is probably on the preposition with .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When a gesture accompanies who 's he ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">the personal pronoun has dominant stress because `` he '' has not been mentioned previously .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If both George and a piece of information George does not have are prominent in the context , but the idea of telling George is new , then dominant stress will probably be on tell in why not tell George ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But when what is new in a particular context is also fairly obvious , there is normally only light stress or no stress at all .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus the unstressed it of it rarely snows here gets its significance from its use with snows : nothing can snow snow but `` it '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In there are n't many young people in the neighborhood the modifier young takes dominant stress away from its head people : the fact that the young creatures of interest are people seems rather obvious .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If women replaced people , it would normally have dominant stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In I have things to do the word things makes little real contribution to meaning and has weaker stress than do .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If work is substituted for things ( with more exact contribution to meaning ) , it will have dominant stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In I know one thing dominant stress is likely to go to one rather than to semantically pale thing .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In I knew you when you were a child , and you were pretty then dominant stress on then implies that the young woman spoken to is still pretty .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Dominant stress on pretty would be almost insulting here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the written language then can be underlined or italicized to guide the reader here , but much of the time the written language simply depends on the reader 's alertness , and a careless reader will have to back up and reread .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Often dominant stress simply indicates a centering of attention or emotion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus in it 's incredible what that boy can eat dominant stress is likely to be on incredible , and eat will have strong stress also .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In she has it in for George dominant stress will ordinarily be on in , where the notion of stored up antipathy seems to center .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In we 're painting at our garage strong stress on at indicates that the job being done is not real painting but simply an effort at painting .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Where there is comparison or contrast dominant stresses normally operate to center attention .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus in his friends are stranger than his sisters ' strong stresses are normal for his and sisters ' , but in his friends are stranger than his sisters strong stresses are normal for friends and sisters .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">In he 's hurting himself more than he 's hurting you both himself and you have stronger stress than they would ordinarily have if there were no contrast .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In is she Chinese or Japanese ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">the desire to contrast the first parts of words which are alike in their last components produces an exceptional disregard of the normal patterns of stress of Chinese and Japanese .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes strong stress serves to focus an important secondary relationship .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus in Mary wrote an account of the trip first strong stress on Mary marks Mary as the first in a series of people who wrote accounts of the trip , strong stress on wrote marks the writing as the first of a series of actions of Mary 's concerned with an account of her trip ( about which she may later have made speeches , for example ) , and strong stress on trip makes the trip the first of a series of subjects about which Mary wrote accounts .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In hunger stimulates man too the situation is very similar .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Strong stress on hunger treats hunger as an additional stimulus , strong stress on stimulates treats stimulation as an additional effect of hunger , strong stress on man treats man as an additional creature who responds to the stimulation of hunger .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Here again , in the written language it is possible to help the reader get his stresses right by using underlining or italics , but much of the time there is simply reliance on his understanding in the light of context .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When a word represents a larger construction of which it is the only expressed part , it normally has more stress than it would have in fully expressed construction .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Thus when yes , I have is the response to have you finished reading the paper ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">the stress on have , which here represents have finished reading the paper , is quite strong .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In Mack 's the leader at camp , but Jack is here the is of the second main declarative represents is the leader and therefore has stress .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Mack 's the leader at camp , but Jack 's here , with this is deprived of stress , makes here the complement in the clause .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In of all the suggestions that were made , his was the silliest the possessive his represents his suggestion and is stressed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">When go represents itself and a complement ( being equivalent , say , to go to Martinique ) in which boat did Jack go on ?</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">it has strong stress ; when it represents only itself and on which is its complement ( so that go on is semantically equivalent to board ) , on has stronger stress than go does .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Omission of a subordinator pronoun , however , does not result in an increase in stress on a prepositional adverb for which the subordinator pronoun would be object .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus to has light stress both in that was the conclusion that I came to and in that was the conclusion I came to .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">But when to represents to consciousness in that was the moment that I came to , and similarly in that was the moment I came to , there is much stronger stress on to .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In I wanted to tell him , but I was afraid to the final to is lightly stressed because it represents to tell him .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In to tell him , of course , to is normally unstressed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When I have instructions to leave is equivalent in meaning to I have instructions that I am to leave this place , dominant stress is ordinarily on leave .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">When the same sequence is equivalent in meaning to I have instructions which I am to leave , dominant stress is ordinarily on instructions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is clear that patterns of stress sometimes show construction unambiguously in the spoken language where without the help of context it would be ambiguous in the written .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Other examples follow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">`` I 'll come by Tuesday .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I can n't be happy long without drinking water '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the first of these sentences if by is the complement of come and Tuesday is an adjunct of time equivalent to on Tuesday , there will be strong stress on by in the spoken language ; but if a complement for come is implied and by Tuesday is a prepositional unit used as an adjunct , by will be unstressed or lightly stressed at most .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the second sentence if drinking water is a gerundial clause and without drinking water is roughly equivalent in meaning to unless I drink water , there will be stronger stress on water than on drinking ; but if drinking is a gerundial noun modifying water and without drinking water is equivalent to without water for drinking , there will be stronger stress on drinking than on water .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But the use of stress in comparison and contrast , for example , can undermine distinctions such as these .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">And patterns of stress are not always unambiguous by any means .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the Steiners have busy lives without visiting relatives only context can indicate whether visiting relatives is equivalent in meaning to paying visits to relatives or to relatives who are visiting them , and in I looked up the number and I looked up the chimney only the meanings of number and chimney make it clear that up is syntactically a second complement in the first sentence and a preposition followed by its object in the second .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">- Syllables are linguistic units centering in peaks which are usually vocalic but , as has been noted , are consonantal under certain circumstances , and which may or may not be combined with preceding and / or following consonants or combinations of consonants .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Syllables are genuine units , but division of words and sentences into them presents great difficulties .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Sometimes even the number of syllables is not clear .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Doubt on this point is strongest before / l / and / / or / r / .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">From the point of view of word formation real might be expected to have two syllables .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Historically re is the formative that is employed also in republic , and al is the common suffix .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">When ity is added , real clearly has two syllables .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But there is every reason to regard deal as a monosyllable , and because of the fact that / l / commonly has the quality of / / when it follows vowel sounds , deal seems to be a perfectly satisfactory rhyme with real .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is obvious enough that linguists in general have been less successful in coping with tone systems than with consonants or vowels .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">No single explanation is adequate to account for this .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Improvement , however , is urgent , and at least three things will be needed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The first is a wide-ranging sample of successful tonal analyses .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even beginning students in linguistics are made familiar with an appreciable variety of consonant systems , both in their general outlines and in many specific details .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">An advanced student has read a considerable number of descriptions of consonantal systems , including some of the more unusual types .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">By contrast , even experienced linguists commonly know no more of the range of possibilities in tone systems than the over-simple distinction between register and contour languages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This limited familiarity with the possible phenomena has severely hampered work with tone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tone analysis will continue to be difficult and unsatisfactory until a more representative selection of systems is familar to every practicing field linguist .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Papers like these four , if widely read , will contribute importantly to improvement of our analytic work .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The second need is better field techniques .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The great majority of present-day linguists fall into one or more of a number of overlapping types : those who are convinced that tone cannot be analysed , those who are personally scared of tone and tone languages generally , those who are convinced that tone is merely an unnecessary marginal feature in those languages where it occurs , those who have no idea how to proceed with tone analysis , those who take a simplistic view of the whole matter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The result has been neglect , fumbling efforts , or superficial treatment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As these maladies overlap , so must the cure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Analyses such as these four will simultaneously combat the assumptions that tone is impossible and that it is simple .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They will give suggestions that can be worked up into field procedures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Good field techniques will not only equip linguists for better work , but also help them overcome negative attitudes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Actually , none of these papers says much directly about field techniques .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">But it is worth pondering that very little has been published on any phase of field techniques in linguistics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">These things have been disseminated by other means , but always in the wake of extensive publication of analytic results .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The third need is for better theory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We should expect that general phonologic theory should be as adequate for tone as for consonants and vowels , but it has not been .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This can only be for one of two reasons : either the two are quite different and will require totally different theory ( and hence techniques ) , or our existing theories are insufficiently general .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If , as I suspect , the problem is largely of the second sort , then development of a theory better able to handle tone will result automatically in better theory for all phonologic subsystems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">One issue that must be faced is the relative difficulty of analysis of different phonologic subsystems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="subj">Since tone systems typically comprise fewer units than either consonant or vowel systems , we might expect that they would be the easiest part of a phonologic analysis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Actual practice does not often work out this way .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Tone systems are certainly more complex than the number of units would suggest , and often analytically more difficult than much larger consonantal systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Welmers has suggested one explanation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Tone languages use for linguistic contrasts speech parameters which also function heavily in nonlinguistic use .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This may both divert the attention of the uninitiate and cause confusion for the more knowledgeable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The problem is to disentangle the linguistic features of pitch from the co-occurring nonlinguistic features .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Of course , something of the same sort occurs with other sectors of the phonology : consonantal articulations have both a linguistic and an individual component .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">But in general the individual variation is a small thing added onto basic linguistic features of greater magnitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With tone , individual differences may be greater than the linguistic contrasts which are superimposed on them .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Pitch differences from one speaker to another , or from one emotional state to another , may far exceed the small differences between tones .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">However , any such suggestion accounts for only some of the difficulties in hearing tone , or in developing a realistic attitude about tone , but not for the analytic difficulties that occur even when tone is meticulously recorded .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A second explanation is suggested by the material described in Rowlands ' paper .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Tone and intonation often become seriously intermeshed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Neither can be adequately systematized until we are able to separate the two and assign the observed phenomena individually to one or the other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Other pairs of phonologic subsystems also interact or overlap in this way ; for example , duration sometimes figures in both the vowel system and the intonation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Some phonetic features , for example glottal catch or murmur , are sometimes to be assigned to segmental phonemics and sometimes to accentual systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But no other two phonologic systems are as difficult to disentangle as are tone and intonation in some languages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This explanation of tone difficulties , however , does not apply in all languages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In some ( the Ewe type mentioned above ) interaction of tone and intonation is restricted to the ends of intonation spans .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In many of the syllables , intonation can be safely ignored , and much of the tonal analysis can be done without any study of intonation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Still , even in such languages tone analysis has not been as simple as one might expect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A third explanation is suggested by Richardson 's analysis of Sukuma tone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">There we see a basically simple phonemic system enmeshed in a very complex and puzzling morphophonemic system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">While the phonemes can be very easily stated , no one is likely to be satisfied with the statement until phonemic occurrences can be related in some way to morphemic units , i. e. until the morphophonemics is worked out , or at least far enough that it seems reasonable to expect success .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In the `` typical tone language '' , tonal morphophonemics is of the same order of complexity as consonantal morphophonemics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The phonemic systems which must support these morphophonemic systems , however , are very different .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The inventory of tones is much smaller , and commonly the contrasts range along one single dimension , pitch level .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Consonantal systems are not merely larger , they are multidimensional .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Morphophonemic rules may be thought of as joining certain points in the system .</MPQASENT>
