<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The possibilities in the consonantal system are very numerous , and only a small portion of them are actually used .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Phonemes connected by a morphophonemic rule commonly show a good bit of phonetic similarity , possible because of the several dimensions of contrast in the system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tonal morphophonemics , in a common case , can do nothing but either raise or lower the tone .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The possibilities are few , and the total number of rules may be considerably greater .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Often , therefore , there are a number of rules having the same effect , and commonly other sets of rules as well , having the opposite effect .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Tonal morphophonemics is much more confusing to the beginning analyst than consonantal morphophonemics , even when the total number of rules is no greater .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The difficulty of analysis of any subsystem in the phonology is an inverse function of the size - smaller systems are more troublesome - for any given degree of morphophonemic complexity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This hypothesis will account for a large part of the difficulties of tonal analysis , as well as the fact that vowel systems are often more puzzling than consonantal systems .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The statement of the system is a different matter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Smaller systems can of course be stated much more succinctly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A phonemic system can be stated without reference to morphophonemics , but it cannot always be found without morphophonemics .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">And the more complex the morphophonemic system is in relation to the phonemic base , the less easily a phonemic system will be analysed without close attention to the morphophonemics - at least , the less satisfying will a phonemic statement be if it cannot be related through morphophonemic rules to grammatically meaningful structures .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The design of orthographies has received much less attention from linguists than the problem deserves .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There has been a tendency on the part of many American linguists to assume that a phonemic transcription will automatically be the best possible orthography and that the only real problem will then be the social one of securing acceptance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This seems naive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Most others have been content to give only the most general attention to the broadest and most obvious features of the phonology when designing orthographies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Apparently the feeling is that anything more would be involvement in technical abstrusenesses of possible pedantic interest but of no visible significance in practical affairs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The result of this attitude has been the domination of many orthography conferences by such considerations as typographic ' esthetics ' , which usually turns out to be nothing more than certain prejudices carried over from European languages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Many of the suggested systems seem to have only the most tenuous relationship to the language structures that they purport to represent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Linguists have not always been more enlightened than `` practical people '' and sometimes have insisted on incredibly trivial points while neglecting things of much greater significance .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a result , many people have been confirmed in their conviction that orthography design is not an activity to which experts can contribute anything but confusion .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A. E. Sharp , in Vowel-Length and Syllabicity in Kikuyu , examines one set of related orthographic questions and its phonologic background in detail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">His objective is merely to determine `` what distinctions of length and syllabicity it may be desirable to make explicit in a Kikuyu orthography '' ( 59 ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To do so , he finds it necessary to examine the relevant parts of the phonology thoroughly and in detail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In the process , he develops some very significant observations about problems of a sort that are often difficult .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A few of his examples are of very great interest , and the whole discussion of some importance for theory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His orthographic recommendations are no simplistic acceptance of phonemics on the one hand or of superficiality on the other .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Rather he weighs each phonologic fact in the light of its orthographic usefulness .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">He concludes that some changes can made in the current orthography which will appreciably improve its usefulness , but hesitates to suggest precise graphic devices to effect these changes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">I hope his suggestions are given the consideration they deserve in Kikuyu circles .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This , however , will not exhaust their practical usefulness , as they rather clearly indicate what thorough phonologic investigation can contribute to orthography design .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We need many more studies of this sort if the design of written languages is to be put on a sound basis .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One other paper deals with a phonologic problem :
Vowel Harmony in Igbo , by J. Carnochan .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">This restates the already widely known facts in terms of prosodies .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a restatement it makes only a small contribution to knowledge of Igbo .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The paper has a certain value as a comparatively easy introduction to this approach , particularly since it treats a fairly simple and straightforward phenomenon where it is possible to compare it with a more traditional ( though not structural ) statement .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It seems to me that it rather easily can .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the whole they maintain much the same high standard , but they are much more difficult to discuss in detail because of their wider variety of subject matter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">My comments must be briefer than the papers deserve .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">W. H. Whiteley writes on The Verbal Radical in Iraqw .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The practical operational problem of lexicostatistics is the establishment of a basic list of items of meaning against which the particular forms or terms of languages can be matched as the medium of comparison .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The most important quality of the meanings is that they should be as definable as possible .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They isolate out easily , naturally , and unambiguously from the continuum of nature and existence ; and they should be given priority in the basic list as long as they continue to show these qualities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">With the universal list as his weapon , Swadesh has extended his march of conquest farther and farther into the past , eight , ten , twelve millennia back .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The present Federal program of vocational education began in 1917 with the passage of the Smith-Hughes Act , which provided a continuing annual appropriation of $ 7 million to support , on a matching basis , state administered programs of vocational education in agriculture , trades , industrial skills and home economics .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Annual authorizations of $ 15 million were added for area vocational education programs that meet national defense needs for highly skilled technicians .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The Federal program of vocational education merely provides financial aid to encourage the establishment of vocational education programs in public schools .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Throughout the history of the program , state government expenditures in the aggregate have usually matched or exceeded the Federal expenditures , while local districts all together have spent more than either Federal or state governments .</MPQASENT>

<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">State and local agencies in the vocational education field must be encouraged to adopt a wider outlook on future job opportunities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">There is a need for an expanded Federal effort to provide research and information to help guide state education departments and local school boards in existing programs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A related question is whether unemployed workers can be motivated to take the training provided .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">There is little evidence that existing public or private training programs have any great difficulty getting students to enroll in their programs , even though they must pay tuition , receive no subsistence payments , and are not guaranteed a job .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">However , there always is some limit to the numbers who will spend the time and effort to acquire training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Again , one major difficulty is the local focus .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">A training program in a depressed area may have few enrollees unless there is some apparent prospect for better employment opportunities afterwards , and the prospect may be poor if the training is aimed solely at jobs in the local community .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If there is adequate information on job opportunities for skilled jobs elsewhere , many more workers can be expected to respond .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Another problem is who will pay for the training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Local school districts are hard pressed financially and unenthusiastic about vocational training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Programs usually are expanded only when outside funds are available or local business leaders demand it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Even industrial development leaders find it hard to win local support for training unless a new industry is in sight and requests it .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">State governments have been taking the lead in establishing area vocational schools , but their focus is still on area job opportunities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Only the Federal government is likely to be able to take a long-run and nation-wide view and to pay for training to meet national skilled manpower needs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">If only state funds were used to pay for the vocational education , it could be argued that the state should not have to bear the cost of vocational training which would benefit employers in other states .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , if Federal funds are used , it would be entirely appropriate to train workers for jobs which could be obtained elsewhere as well as for jobs in the area of chronic unemployment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such training would increase the tendency of workers to leave the area and find jobs in other localities .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A further possibility is suggested by the example of the G. I. bills and also by some recent trends in attitudes toward improving college education : that is to provide financial assistance to individuals for vocational training when local facilities are inadequate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This probably would require some support for subsistence as well as for tuition , but the total would be no greater than for the proposals of unemployment compensation or a Youth Conservation Corps .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A maximum of $ 600 per year per student would enable many to take training away from home .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A program of financial assistance would permit placing emphasis on the national interest in training highly skilled labor .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Instead of being limited to the poor training facilities in remote areas , the student would be able to move to large institutions of concentrated specialized training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Such specialized training institutions could be located near the most rapidly growing industries , where the equipment and job experience exist and where the future employment opportunities are located .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This would heighten possibilities for part-time cooperative , on-the-job and extension training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Personal financial assistance would enable more emphasis to be placed on the interests of the individual .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">His aptitudes and preferences could be given more weight in selecting the proper training .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wage price policies of industry are the result of a complex of forces - no single explanation has been found which applies to all cases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The purpose of this paper is to analyze one possible force which has not been treated in the literature , but which we believe makes a significant contribution to explaining the wage price behavior of a few very important industries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">While there may be several such industries to which the model of this paper is applicable , the authors make particular claim of relevance to the explanation of the course of wages and prices in the steel industry of the United States since World War 2 , .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , the apparent stiffening of the industry 's attitude in the recent steel strike has a direct explanation in terms of the model here presented .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The model of this paper considers an industry which is not characterized by vigorous price competition , but which is so basic that its wage price policies are held in check by continuous critical public scrutiny .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Where the industry 's product price has been kept below the `` profit maximizing '' and `` entry limiting '' prices due to fears of public reaction , the profit seeking producers have an interest in offering little real resistance to wage demands .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The contribution of this paper is a demonstration of this proposition , and an exploration of some of its implications .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In order to focus clearly upon the operation of this one force , which we may call the effect of `` public limit pricing '' on `` key '' wage bargains , we deliberately simplify the model by abstracting from other forces , such as union power , which may be relevant in an actual situation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For expository purposes , this is best treated as a model which spells out the conditions under which an important industry affected with the public interest would find it profitable to raise wages even in the absence of union pressures for higher wages .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Part 1 , below describes this abstract model by spelling out its assumptions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Part 2 , discusses the operation of the model and derives some significant conclusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Part 3 , discusses the empirical relevance and policy implications of the conclusions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Part 4 , is a brief summary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The Mathematical Appendix presents the rigorous argument , but is best read after Part 1 , in order that the assumptions underlying the equations may be explicit .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The industry with which this model is concerned is a basic industry , producing a substantial share of gross national product .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Price competition is lacking .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the purposes of setting the product price , the industry behaves as a single entity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In wage negotiations , the industry bargains as a unit with a single union .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">We are concerned with aggregate demand for the industry 's product .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The manner in which this is shared among firms is taken as given .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In any given time period , the aggregate demand for the industry 's product is determined by two things : the price charged by the industry , and the level of GNP .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For the purposes of this discussion , the problem of relative prices is encompassed in these two variables , since GNP includes other prices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">( We abstract here from technological progress and assume that prices of all other products change proportionately . )</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The form of the industry demand function is one which makes quantity demanded vary inversely with the product price , and vary directly with the level of GNP .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The industry of this model is so important that its wage and price policies are affected with a public interest .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Because of its importance , and because the lack of price competition is well recognized , the industry is under considerable public pressure not to raise its price any more than could be justified by cost increases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The threat of effective anti-trust action , provoked by `` gouging the public '' through price increases not justified by cost increases , and fears of endangering relations with customers , Congress , the general public and the press , all operate to keep price increases in some relation to cost increases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For the industry of this model , the effect of such public pressures in the past has been to hold the price well below the short-run profit maximizing price ( given the wage rate and the level of GNP ) , and even below the entry limited price ( but not below average cost ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">For such an industry , it is only `` safe '' to raise its price if such an increase is manifestly `` justified '' by rising costs ( due to rising wages , etc . ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , if public pressure sets the effective limit to the price that the industry may charge , this pressure is itself a function of the wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In this model , we abstract from all non wage sources of cost changes , so that the `` public limit price '' only rises as the wage rate rises .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In such circumstances , it may well be to the advantage of the industry to allow an increase in the basic wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Since marginal costs rise when the wage rate rises , the profit maximizing price also rises when the public limit price is elevated , and is likely to remain well above the latter .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The entry limiting price will also be raised for potential domestic competition , but unless general inflation permits profit margins to increase proportionately throughout the economy , we might expect the public limit price to approach the entry limit price .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The foreign entry limit price would be approached more rapidly , since domestic wage rates do not enter foreign costs directly .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Where this approach becomes critical , the industry can be expected to put much emphasis on this as evidence of its sincerity in `` resisting '' the wage pressures of a powerful union , requesting tariff relief after it has `` reluctantly '' acceded to the union pressure .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whether or not it is in the industry 's interest to allow the basic wage rate to rise obviously depends upon the extent to which the public limit price rises in response to a basic wage increase , and the relation of this response to the increase in costs accompanying the wage increase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The extent to which the public limit price is raised by a given increase in the basic wage rate is itself a function of three things : the passage of time , the level of GNP , and the size of the wage increase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We are abstracting from the fact of strikes here , but it should be obvious that the extent to which the public limit price is raised by a given increase in the basic wage rate is also a function of the show of resistance put up by the industry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The industry may deliberately take a strike , not to put pressure on the union , but in order to `` educate '' the government and the customers of the industry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As a strike continues , these parties increase their pressure on the industry to reach an agreement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">They become increasingly willing to accept the price increase that the industry claims the wage bargain would entail .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Public indignation and resistance to wage price increases is obviously much less when the increases are on the order of 3 % per annum than when the increases are on the order of 3 % per month .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The simple passage of an additional eleven months ' time makes the second 3 % boost more acceptable .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus , the public limit price is raised further by a given wage increase the longer it has been since the previous price increase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Notice , however , that the passage of time does not permit the raising of prices per se , without an accompanying wage increase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Similarly , higher levels of GNP do not , in themselves , provide grounds for raising prices , but they do relax some of the pressure on the industry so that it can raise prices higher for a given wage increase .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">This is not extended to anticipated levels of GNP , however - only the current level of GNP affects the public pressure against wage price increases .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Finally , since the public requires some restraint on the part of the companies , larger wage increases call for less than proportionately larger price increases ( e. g. , if a wage increase of 5 % allows a price increase of 7 % , a wage increase of 10 % allows a price increase of something less than 14 % ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We assume that average total unit cost in the relevant region of operation is constant with respect to quantity produced ( the average cost curve is horizontal , and therefore is identical with the marginal cost curve ) , and is the same for every firm ( and therefore for the industry ) .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The level of this average cost is determined by factor prices , technology , and so forth .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">As we have noted , however , we are abstracting from changes in all determinants of this level except for changes in the wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The level of average cost ( equal to marginal cost ) is thus strictly a function of the wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The single union which faces the industry does not restrict its membership , and there is an adequate supply of labor available to the firms of the industry at the going wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The union does not regard unemployment of its own members as a matter of concern when setting its own wage policy - its concern with employment makes itself felt in pressure upon the government to maintain full employment .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">The union vigorously demands wage increases from productivity increases , and wage increases to offset cost-of-living increases , but we abstract from these forces here .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">For our present purposes we assume that the sole subject of bargaining is the basic wage rate ( not including productivity improvement factors or cost-of-living adjustments ) , and it is this basic wage rate which determines the level of costs .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Productivity is something of an amorphous concept and the amount of productivity increase in a given time period is not even well known to the industry , much less to the union or to the public .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Disagreement on the amount of productivity increase exacerbates the problem of agreeing how an increase in profit margins related to a productivity increase should be shared .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The existence of conflict and of vigorous union demand for an increase in money wages does not contradict the assumption that the union is willing to settle for cost-of-living and productivity share increases as distinct from a cost raising increase in the basic wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">We assume further that the union recognizes the possibility that price level increases may offset wage rate increases , and it does not entirely disregard the effect of price increases arising from its own wage increases upon the `` real '' wage rate .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">For internal political reasons , the union asks for ( and accepts ) increases in the basic wage rate , and would vigorously oppose a reduction in this rate , but the adjustment of the basic wage rate upwards is essentially up to the discretion of the companies of the industry .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Changes in the basic wage rate are cost raising , and they constitute an argument for raising prices .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , it is not known to either the union or the public precisely how much of a cost increase is caused by a given change in the basic wage rate , although the companies are presumed to have reliable estimates of this magnitude .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In this model , then , the industry is presumed to realize that they could successfully resist a change in the basic wage rate , but since such a change is the only effective means to raising prices they may , in circumstances to be spelled out in Part 2 , below , find it to their advantage to allow the wage rise .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , for non negative changes in the basic wage rate , the industry becomes the active wage setter , since any increase in the basic wage rate can occur only by reason of industry acquiescence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The presumption in the literature would appear to be that the basic wage rate would be unchanged in this case , on the grounds that it is `` clearly '' not in the interest of the industry to raise wages gratuitously .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">From this presumption it is an easy step to the conclusion that any observed increases in the basic wage rate must be due to union behavior different and more aggressive than assumed in our model .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is this conclusion that we challenge ; we do so by disproving the presumption on which it is based .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is convenient to assume that the union industry contract is of one year 's duration .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the century from 1815 to 1914 the law of nations became international law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Several factors contributed to this change .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The Congress of Vienna is a convenient starting point because it both epitomized and symbolized what was to follow .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Here in 1815 the great nations assembled to legislate not merely for Europe , but for the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Thus the Congress marks a formal recognition of the political system that was central to world politics for a century .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">International law had to fit the conditions of Europe , and nothing that could not fit this system , or the interests of the great European nations collectively , could possibly emerge as law in any meaningful sense .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">Essentially this imposed two conditions : First , international law had to recognize and be compatible with an international political system in which a number of states were competitive , suspicious , and opportunistic in their political alignments with one another ; second , it had to be compatible with the value system that they shared .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In both respects , international law was Europeanized .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was not always easy to develop theory and doctrine which would square the two conditions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">On the one hand , the major European nations had to maintain vis-a-vis each other an emphasis upon sovereignty , independence , formal equality - thus insuring for themselves individually an optimal freedom of action to maintain the `` flexibility of alignment '' that the system required and to avoid anything approaching a repetition of the disastrous Napoleonic experience .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">But there was no pressing need to maintain these same standards with regard to most of the rest of the world .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Thus , theory and doctrine applicable among the great nations and the smaller European states did not really comfortably fit less developed and less powerful societies elsewhere .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Political interference in Africa and Asia and even in Latin America ( though limited in Latin America by the special interest of the United States as expressed in the Monroe Doctrine , itself from the outset related to European politics and long dependent upon the `` balance of power '' system in Europe ) was necessary in order to preserve both common economic values and the European `` balance '' itself .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">A nation such as Switzerland could be neutralized by agreement and could be relied upon to protect its neutrality ; more doubtful , but possible , ( with an assist from the North ) was the neutralization of the Latin American countries ; out of the question was the neutralization of Asia and Africa .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">This Europeanization of the law was made explicit by a number of 19 th century scholars .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">More emphasis was put upon the fact that international law was the law of `` civilized nations '' ; Kent and Story , the great early American scholars , repeatedly made use of this phrase , or of `` Christian nations '' , which is a substantial equivalent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Wheaton stated that the public law was essentially `` limited to the civilized and Christian peoples of Europe or to those of European origin '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Of course it had always been of European origin in fact , but it had maintained a universal outlook under the natural law theory .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Now , with virtually every writer , not only was the European origin of public law acknowledged as a historical phenomenon , but the rules thus established by the advanced civilizations of Europe were to be imposed on others .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The European customs on which international law was based were to become , by force and fiat , the customs that others were to accept as law if they were to join this community as sovereign states .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Hall , for example , was quite explicit on this point when he said `` states outside European civilization must formally enter into the circle of law governed countries .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">They must do something with the acquiescence of the latter , or some of them , which amounts to an acceptance of the law in its entirety beyond all possibility of misconstruction '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">During the nineteenth century these views were protested by virtually all the Latin American writers , though ineffectively , just as the new nations of Africa and Asia protest them , with more effect , today .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">A number of other nineteenth century developments contributed to the transmutation of the law of nations into international law ; that is , from aspects of a universal system of Justice into particular rules governing the relations of sovereign states .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The difference is important , for although the older law of nations did cover relationships among sovereigns , this was by no means its exclusive domain .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The law of nature governed sovereigns in their relationship to their own citizens , to foreigners , and to each other in a conceptually unified system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The theory of international law , which in the nineteenth century became common to virtually all writers in Europe and America , broke this unity and this universality .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It lost sight of the individual almost entirely and confined itself to rules limiting the exercise of state power for reasons essentially unconnected with justice or morality save as these values might affect international relations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">No longer did the sovereign look to the law of nations to determine what he ought to do ; his search was merely for rules that might limit his freedom of action .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To appreciate this development , we must relate it to other aspects of nineteenth century philosophy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">First , and most obvious , was the growing nationalism and the tendency to regard the state , and the individual 's identification with the state , as transcending other ties of social solidarity .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">National identification was not new , but it was accelerating in intensity and scope throughout Europe as new unifications occurred .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It reached its ultimate philosophical statement in notions of `` state will '' put forward by the Germans , especially by Hegel , although political philosophers will recognize its origins in the rejected doctrines of Hobbes .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">National identification was reflected jurisprudentially in law theories which incorporated this Hegelian abstraction and saw law , domestic and international , simply as its formal reflection .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the international community this reduced law to Jellinek 's auto limitation .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">A state , the highest form of human organization in fact and theory , could be subjected to Law only by a manifestation of self-will , or consent .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">According to the new theories , the nineteenth century corporate sovereign was `` sovereign '' in a quite new and different sense from his historical predecessors .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">He no longer sought to find the law ; he made it ; he could be subjected to law only because he agreed to be .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">There was no law , domestic or international , except that willed by , acknowledged by , or consented to by states .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">Hidden behind Hegelian abstractions were more practical reasons for a changing jurisprudence .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Related to , but distinguishable from , nationalism was the growth of democracy in one form or another .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Increased participation in politics and the demands of various groups for status and recognition had dramatic effects upon law institutions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The efforts of various interest groups to control or influence governmental decisions , particularly when taken in conjunction with the impact of industrialization , led to a concentration of attention on the legislative power and the means whereby policy could be formulated and enforced as law through bureaucratic institutions .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Law became a conscious process , something more than simply doing justice and looking to local customs and a common morality for applicable norms .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Particularly was this true when the norms previously applied were no longer satisfactory to many , when customs were rapidly changing as the forces of the new productivity were harnessed .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">The old way of doing things , which depended on a relatively stable community with stable ideas dealing with familiar situations , was no longer adequate to the task .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">First was the period of codification of existing law : the Code Napoleon in France and the peculiar codification that , in fact , resulted from Austin 's restatement and ordering of the Common Law in England .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Codification was followed in all countries by a growing amount of legislation , some changing and adjusting the older law , much dealing with entirely new situations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The legislative mills have been grinding ever since , and when its cumbersome processes were no longer adequate to the task , a limited legislative authority was delegated in one form or another , to the executive .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Whereas the eighteenth century had been a time in which man sought justice , the nineteenth and twentieth have been centuries in which men are satisfied with law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Indeed , with developed positivism , the separation of law from justice , or from morality generally , became quite specific .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">In municipal systems we tend to view what is called positivism as fundamentally a movement to democratize policy by increasing the power of parliament - the elected representatives - at the expense of the more conservative judiciary .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="subj" autoclass2="subj">When the power of the latter was made both limited and explicit - when norms were clarified and made more precise and the creation of new norms was placed exclusively in parliamentary hands - two purposes were served : Government was made subservient to an institutionalized popular will , and law became a rational system for implementing that will , for serving conscious goals , for embodying the `` public policy '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It is true that , initially , the task was to remove restrictions that , it was thought , inhibited the free flow of money , goods , and labor ; but even laissez-faire was a conscious policy .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Law was seen as an emanation of the `` sovereign will '' .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">However , the sovereign was not Hobbes ' absolute monarch but rather the parliamentary sovereign of Austin .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">It was , too , an optimistic philosophy , and , though it separated law from morality , it was by no means an immoral or amoral one .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Man , through democratic institutions of government and economic freedom , was master of his destiny .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The theory did not require , though it unfortunately might acquire , a Hegelian mystique .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It was merely a rationalization and ordering of new institutions of popular government .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">It was not opposed to either justice or morality ; it merely wished to minimize subjective views of officials who wielded public authority .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Particularly was this true as laissez-faire capitalism became the dominant credo of Western society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">To free the factors of production was a major objective of the rising bourgeoisie , and this objective required that governmental authority - administrative officials and judges - be limited as precisely and explicitly as possible ; that old customs which inhibited trade be abrogated ; that business be free from governmental supervision and notions of morality which might clog the automatic adjustments of the free market ; that obligations of status that were inconsistent with the new politics and the new economics be done away with .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Contract - conceived as the free bargain of formal equals - replaced the implied obligations of a more static and status conscious society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Indeed , contract was the dominant legal theme of the century , the touchstone of the free society .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Government itself was based upon contract ; business organization - the corporation - was analyzed in contractual terms ; trade was based on freedom of contract , and money was lent and borrowed on contractual terms ; even marriage and the family was seen as a contractual arrangement .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">It is not surprising that the international obligations of states were also viewed in terms of contract .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">In fact , some - Anzilotti is the principle example - went so far as to say that all international law could be traced to the single legal norm , Pacta sunt Servanda .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">The displacement ( at least to a considerable extent ) of the ethical jurisprudence of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries by positivism reshaped both international law theory and doctrine .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">In the first place the new doctrine brought a formal separation of international from municipal law , rejecting the earlier view that both were parts of a universal legal system .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="obj" autoclass2="obj">One result was to nationalize much that had been regarded as the law of nations .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">Admiralty law , the law merchant , and the host of problems which arise in private litigation because of some contact with a foreign country were all severed from the older Law of Nations and made dependent on the several national laws .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="obj">Private international law ( which Americans call the `` conflict of laws '' ) was thus segregated from international law proper , or , as it is often called , public international law .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">States were free to enact , within broad though ( perhaps ) determinate limits , their own rules as to the application of foreign law by their courts , to vary the law merchant , and to enact legislation with regard to many claims arising on the high seas .</MPQASENT>
<MPQASENT autoclass1="unknown" autoclass2="subj">The change was not quite so dramatic as it sounds because in fact common norms continued to be invoked by municipal courts and were only gradually changed by legislation , and then largely in marginal situations .</MPQASENT>
